HEADLINE: U.S. AND KREMLIN STILL DEADLOCKED ON ARMS TREATIES

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 15

 BODY:
The United States and the Soviet Union, at the end of two days of high-level talks, said today that they remained deadlocked over two important arms control agreements that are delaying the next summit meeting, which Moscow has proposed for the end of May.
Although Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and senior Soviet officials said overall relations remained good, there were rumblings today suggesting that serious strains were developing. 
 One of the treaties is on reducing long-range nuclear missiles, and a year ago both sides said the pact was almost ready for signing.
 
U.S. Accused of Stalling
 Today the official Soviet press agency, Tass, distributed a commentary during the talks quoting a "high-ranking Soviet diplomat" as accusing the Bush Administration of stalling a resolution. It said Washington was refusing to make "a political decision" to complete the treaty and "frankly speaking, does not seem to be willing to meet us halfway."
An American official described the accusation as a Soviet "smokescreen." The official said it was intended to disguise the fact that Soviet and American negotiators in Geneva keep working out technical issues in the strategic arms treaty, only to find them rejected by the Soviet leadership.
American officials say President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who met with Mr. Baker today, appears to be under pressure from members of the Soviet military and its military-industrial base. Many within the Soviet military say the Kremlin has made too many concessions on arms control and should dig in its heels on the strategic arms treaty and on the second treaty, limiting conventional weapons in Europe.
 
'Internal Problems' Cited
 "We've been trying to meet them halfway," an American official said, "but we are not going to pay extra just because of their internal problems."
With Mr. Gorbachev worried about a national referendum on Sunday on the very unity of the Soviet Union -- in a speech tonight, he urged his population to vote "yes" -- Mr. Baker invited leaders of Soviet republics and municipalities, including some who favor separation from the Soviet Union. to a dinner tonight at the home of the American Ambassador.
Boris N. Yeltsin, the President of the Russian Republic and a Gorbachev rival, was invited to the dinner, and to a private meeting with Mr. Baker, but he declined and sent a representative instead. Mr. Baker will meet with leaders of the independent-minded Baltic republics on Saturday.
Asked what signal he was trying to send, Mr. Baker said: "The purpose is to hear from them with respect to their views of the situation within the Soviet Union and the prognosis for reform, to give them the benefit of our views and to have the contacts we said we would be having with republic leaders. We are going to be encouraging them to have contacts at the state and local levels with officials in the United States."
In February 1990, during a visit by Mr. Baker to Moscow, the two sides announced that they had overcome the last major obstacles to a Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty -- known as Start -- and that all that was left were largely "technical details." Yet 13 months later, many of those same details remain unresolved.
 
Differences on Verification
 The main differences are over treaty verification, which is crucial for the Bush Administration if it hopes to get the treaty approved by the Senate.
There are differences over how intrusively the two sides should monitor each other's missile factories to make sure no banned missiles are produced, how they should monitor each other's test flights to make sure that missiles are not improved in certain ways, and how to inspect long-range bombers carrying air-launched cruise missiles.
More problematic, American officials say, is that in November the United States, the Soviet Union and 20 other NATO and Warsaw Pact nations signed a treaty slashing non-nuclear conventional forces in Europe, sometimes called the C.F.E. treaty.
After the signing, the Soviet military insisted on excluding from the treaty three naval infantry divisions and their weapons on the ground that they were involved in shore defenses and were technically not covered by a treaty involving land armies. The action annoyed officials in Washington and raised questions about Soviet sincerity.
 
Insistence by Bush
 Mr. Baker has told Congress that President Bush will not submit that treaty for Senate ratification until the Soviets drop this demand, and Mr. Bush says he wants the treaty on long-range arms finished before another summit meeting.
"Where the summit has been left," Mr. Baker said, "is that we will seek to find a time before the middle of the year. But the leaders themselves have said they would want a Start treaty ready for such a summit, and right now we don't have that situation. We still have unresolved problems with C.F.E., and we have not concluded all of the issues on Start."
Asked when these lingering arms- control differences might be worked out, Mr. Baker said, "I can't answer your question."
While the first meeting between senior Soviet and American officials since the end of the Persian Gulf war did not produce any breakthrough on arms control, both Mr. Baker and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, argued that the good news was that despite many dire predictions, the gulf war did not result in a breach in Soviet-American cooperation.
 
'Constructive Partner' in Gulf
 At a news conference after four hours of talks in the Kremlin between Mr. Baker and Mr. Gorbachev, Mr. Baker said he hoped and expected that the Soviet Union would remain a "constructive partner" with the United States in stabilizing the postwar Persian Gulf.
Mr. Baker, who was accused by Republican conservatives at various stages of the gulf crisis of being naive about Soviet intentions in the Middle East, seemed to take relish in saying: "Many predictions were made, particularly in the latter stages of that crisis, that the Soviet Union would not remain committed to the same goals that other coalition partners were committed to. But it did."
Then, referring to Washington's decision to start the ground war despite an 11th-hour Soviet attempt to find a diplomatic solution, Mr. Baker added with emotion: "The relationship has gone through a test recently, and it has survived. And that is good for the Soviet Union, and that is good for the United States, and that is good for the world. And we should work to keep that relationship on the same track if we possibly can."
Mr. Bessmertnykh said, "What matters most is that the Soviet-U.S. relationship has gone through a very difficult test and passed that test, and this opens reliable prospects for future developments."
 
Baker's Dinner Guests
 The list of those attending the Baker dinner tonight included the Chairman of the Georgian Parliament, Zviad Gamsakhurdia; the Premier of the Republic of Armenia, Vazgen Manukyan; the Premier of the Republic of Kirghizia, Nasirdin Isanov; the Mayor of Moscow, Gavriil K. Popov, and the Mayor of Leningrad, Anatoly A. Sobchak, as well as a former Gorbachev adviser, Aleksandr N. Yakovlev, and a reform economist, Stanislav Shatalin.
Whether Soviet-American cooperation will really persist in the Middle East region could depend how events unfold in Iraq. The Bush Administration appears increasingly interested in fostering the downfall of President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by depriving him of any ability to use chemical weapons, warplanes or helicopters to put down the mounting insurrections against his Government.
Mr. Bessmerthnykh, when asked for his attitude on this, seemed to indicate that Moscow was uncomfortable with anything that smacked of American efforts to use its military position in the gulf to change the regime in Baghdad.
Mr. Bessmertnykh said, "It is my view that military operations which were carried out against Iraq in connection with this aggression against Kuwait were based on Security Council Resolution 678, and there were no other grounds for use of armed forces in Iraq or against Iraq."
 
Baker Praises Gorbachev
 But with the gulf crisis now receding, the quality of American-Soviet relations will again be measured largely by the yardstick of arms control agreements, where the two sides seem increasingly unable to break their deadlocks.
Mr. Baker went out of his way to praise Mr. Gorbachev for his efforts to resolve the Baltic crisis peacefully, after last January's violent crackdown.
He said Mr. Gorbachev had told him that his Government had appointed individuals to negotiate with independence-minded Baltic leaders and was waiting for negotiators to be appointed by the Baltic republics. Mr. Baker said some Soviet troops had also been withdrawn from the area.

International
Western governments have agreed to forgive about half of Poland's debt, with the creditor nations offering "extraordinary terms" to help ease the transition to a market economy. [Page 1.]

The Economy
A sobering report on inflation showed that prices received by American producers rose 0.4 percent in February, excluding energy and food prices. Many analysts said the increase was unsettlingly high for an economy mired in recession. [31.] Industrial production declined 0.8 percent in February to the lowest level in two and a half years. Amid the almost daily reports showing deterioration of the economy, there are beginning to be signs of improvement. [31.]

HEADLINE: New Delays in Hotel Plan for Homeless

BYLINE: By Celia W. DUGGER

 BODY:
New York City has spent two and a half years and $25 million trying to turn a decrepit rooming house on 42d Street into a model residence for 300 homeless people, but no one lives there yet because the city has been unable to pick someone to run the place.
Advocates for the homeless and community leaders say the failure to open the Holland Hotel is a case study of creative social policy stalled, not by lack of money, but by bureaucratic fumbling. 
 The city's latest attempt to select a manager for the former hotel near Ninth Avenue collapsed last month when the chosen candidate withdrew from the project for the second time. Even before the latest snag, the project had been plagued by construction problems.
"This is just incompetence, plain and simple," said Doug Lasdon, executive director of the Legal Action Center for the Homeless. "At a time when we need housing so desperately, we're losing the use of hundreds of rooms for homeless and poor people."
 
Applicant Withdraws, Twice
 Only four groups have applied for the daunting job of managing what will be the city's largest nonprofit single-room-occupancy residence for the homeless, in what was once its most notorious welfare hotel.
Twice, the city's Human Resources Administration has awarded the job to Clinton Community Services, a small, storefront social-service agency in Manhattan that has never run an S.R.O. Twice, that decision has backfired.
The Manhattan Borough President, Ruth Messinger, said the human resources agency could have avoided the latest problem if it had done a basic background check on the application from Clinton. Agency officials insisted that they had followed proper contracting procedures.
In the 1980's, the Holland Hotel, then privately owned, became a symbol of the city's failure to find a humane solution to the plight of the homeless. At times, 275 families were crammed into about 300 single rooms at the hotel.
It was a dangerous, squalid and very expensive place. The city paid up to $1,800 a month for a family to live in one room in the drug-infested, honky-tonk area near Times Square.
Then, in 1988, the city decided it could transform the Holland into a symbol of hope for the homeless. The owner had declared bankruptcy and the city, under the Koch administration, bought the 20-story, tan brick building at 351 West 42d Street for $13 million.
The dream was to make it a model residence for homeless adults, a place where tenants would find under one roof the social services, medical care and moral support they needed to get back on their feet. The realization of that ideal has not been easy.
 
Still Work to Do
 The renovation, which has cost $12 million to date, initially left out such elements as wiring for air conditioners, lounges on each floor, stoves or microwave ovens in each room, intercoms to the front desk and locks on the doors, said Nancy Wackstein, director of the Mayor's office for homelessness and single-room-occupancy housing.
While the city wants to have all those problems fixed, Ms. Wackstein said, it decided to select a nonprofit group to run the hotel before undertaking the final renovations so the group could be involved in the design.
But that choice has itself become a major stumbling-block. In May 1989, the Human Resources Administration issued its first "request for proposals" to operate the Holland. One group applied and was rejected.
The paucity of responses was a harbinger of trouble to come. The prospect of caring for such a large number of formerly homeless people -- some with AIDS, some with drug or alcohol problems, some mentally ill -- concentrated in one building discouraged applicants, officials said. The location near Times Square compounded the difficulty.
In addition, there were concerns over the renovation work, said Ruth Kahn, chairwoman of the human services committee for Community Board 4. "They did the most god-awful job," she said. "It looks like a prison. The rooms look like little cells."
The city again asked for applicants, and again got only one reply, this time from Clinton Community Services, a five-year-old agency that helps homeless people find housing.
 
Contract Awarded
 The agency, which has an operating budget of only $300,000, had never run an S.R.O., but planned to enlist the Central Brooklyn Urban Development Corporation, a private agency, to provide managerial experience.
Clinton got the contract. Then, last July, news reports said that Sylvester Leaks, who headed the Central Brooklyn group, had been ordered to relinquish management of two federally subsidized buildings after an audit found major maintenance problems. Mr. Leaks denied any wrongdoing. Nonetheless, Clinton Community Services withdrew from the Holland project.
In September 1990, the Human Resources Administration sent out yet another request for proposals. This time, three groups replied.
Clinton Community Services sent in a new proposal, this time listing T.U.C. Management Company, headed by Bradford Winston, as its coapplicant. Mr. Winston's company manages S.R.O.'s that house formerly homeless people, and is well known to the city. On the signature page, "Brad" was scrawled on the coapplicant line.
The Doe Fund, another applicant, runs a residence for 70 formerly homeless adults. The third applicant was Selfhelp Community Services, a 55-year-old social-service agency with a $40 million budget. It had never worked with the homeless, but managed 800 units of housing for poor elderly people.
 
Debate Over Tenants
 Selfhelp won the unanimous endorsement of Community Board 4 because of its record and because it proposed that 190 of the Holland's tenants be over 55 years old, with the balance divided between people with AIDS and people with mental illness -- a population the community board found acceptable.
But the city wanted an operator who would "respond to our greatest need," to house young unemployed people, Ms. Wackstein said. Clinton Community Services agreed, and this January was again awarded the contract.
But after the application was approved, Mr. Winston told officials that had never agreed to be the coapplicant. He said he had met once with Mary Clark, Clinton's executive director, but had only agreed to give the group technical assistance. He would never have signed his name as just "Brad" on a legal document, he said.
Ms. Clark said the document that listed Mr. Winston was a working paper submitted accidentally. "It was a boo-boo," she said. On Feb. 28, Clinton Community Services withdrew from the project for a second time.
The Human Resources Administration had never called Mr. Winston to verify his participation before giving Clinton the contract. Jeffrey L. Carples, deputy commissioner of adult services at the agency, said that the selection of contractors is based on the applications they submit, and that the accuracy of the information is checked afterwards.
Ms. Messinger, the Borough President, strongly criticized that process. "Before they announce a winner, the investigation should be thorough," she said. "And in this case, the basis for selecting the group was that they had gotten a strong partner with experience managing S.R.O.'s. It would have taken one call to check that."
Once again, the agency is looking for someone to run the Holland. It may pick Selfhelp or the Doe Fund, Mr. Carples said. Then again, it may issue a fourth request for proposals.
Fred Papert, president of the 42d Street Development Corporation, a private nonprofit group, said he hoped the city would find a manager to turn the Holland's troubled history around. "It would be a great sadness if the Dinkins administration let it slip back into an ugly battle," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Workers installing door frames last year in the renovation of the Holland Hotel, which the city has spent two and a half years trying to rehabilitate. When it reopens, the hotel will become the city's largest nonprofit single-room-occupancy residence for the homeless. HEADLINE: Bolshoi Producers to Declare Bankruptcy

BYLINE: By JENNIFER DUNNING

 BODY:
Entertainment Corporation USA, which is producing tours this year of the Bolshoi Opera and dancers from the Bolshoi Ballet, will declare bankruptcy on Monday, a founder and director of the corporation's British parent company said yesterday.
Peter Brightman, the company's British director, said he did not expect cancellations of the Bolshoi Opera, which is scheduled to open at the Metropolitan Opera House on June 25, and the Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet tour, which is scheduled to open on April 11 in West Palm Beach, Fla. 
 "Fundamentally, we believe these tours are going to take place," Mr. Brightman said yesterday. A spokesman for the Metropolitan Opera House said yesterday that neither the Bolshoi Opera performances nor a summer season by the Royal Ballet, also to have been produced by Entertainment Corporation USA at the Metropolitan, had been canceled. He said that meetings with the company would continue on Monday.
"Basically, the company will go into Chapter 7," Mr. Brightman said. "We have new investors. But there are all sorts of legal problems. What happened is that a new company is being formed on Monday, subject to approval by trustees and the court."
He said that talks with James L. Nederlander, the theatrical producer, had been discontinued. Mr. Nederlander had been named as a possible partner in producing the Bolshoi Opera this summer at the the Metropolitan and at the Wolf Trap Farm Park in Vienna, Va., just outside Washington. "At the moment, he is not involved," Mr. Brightman said. Talks between the Royal Ballet and the Metropolitan will continue next week.
Mr. Brightman said that Entertainment Corporation USA, formed in 1989, had a deficit "in excess of $500,000." He attributed the problems to the "economic recession being faced here and certainly in London," adding that the company had also been hurt by recent cancellations of tours by the Red Army Chorus in England and the Georgian State Dancers in the United States.
Presenters of the Stars of the Bolshoi Ballet said yesterday that they had received no cancellation notices and that ticket sales had been going well. "We heard today that the tour would continue," said Elisa Getto, executive director of Ruteckerd Hall in Clearwater, Fla.

HEADLINE: Secured Credit Cards: Ask Before You Leap

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE

 BODY:
As many as 40 million Americans cannot obtain credit, including the two million people a year whose credit cards are revoked, specialists in the banking field say.
These consumers, as well as others who have difficulty getting bank cards like Visa or Mastercard, are the prime candidates for a category of cards known as secured cards. They are usually willing to pay for the privilege of having a credit card with annual fees, interest rates, late charges and over-limit fees higher than those of regular credit cards. 
 A regular card assures merchants that the bank or savings and loan that issues it will pay for purchases or services if certain conditions are fulfilled. Consumers pledge to repay the issuing bank, with interest, if the monthly bill is not paid in full.
But a secured credit card also requires the holder to keep collateral in the issuing institution against possible default that amounts to at least as much money as can be borrowed on the card.
For those whose applications for regular Visas or Mastercards are rejected, or who lose their cards because of bankruptcy or other serious financial problems, secured cards may be useful, at least temporarily.
But some financial institutions that specialize in secured cards, or the middlemen who market secured cards for those institutions, charge high fees, use deceptive advertising or engage in other practices that consumer advocates deplore.
"The good news about them is that they truly can be a way for a person to establish or re-establish a positive credit history," said Elgie Holstein, director of Bankcard Holders of America, a credit-education organization. "The bad news is that they are frequently marketed by boiler-room purveyors who charge exorbitant fees."
Bankcard Holders sells a list of banks offering secured cards. The fee is $3, sent to 560 Herndon Parkway, Herndon, Va. 22070.
Marvin Kaplan, a spokesman for Associated Credit Bureaus, a trade association, added: "People should not get these cards though a third party, but should go out and shop for themselves. A lot of them are promoted by credit-repair clinics that hold out the lure of promises that probably won't be fulfilled."
 
'Savings' as Collateral
 Secured credit cards became popular in Southern California in the late 1970's; the concept has since spread to other parts of the country. They look like any other bank card and are accepted equally by merchants and service establishments.
Because a credit card is now a virtual necessity to cash a check, guarantee a hotel reservation or rent a car, the secured credit card has attracted a wide segment of the population.
To obtain a card, you open a savings account that serves as collateral for the credit made available (minimum amounts range from $500 to $5,000), generally at a bank specializing in secured credit cards.
The line of credit, the amount available to the holder, is typically equal to half or all the amount in the savings account. When the bank pays interest on the account, it is normally at below-market rates, say, 4 or 5 percent.
"Once you establish or re-establish credit this way, the standard card issuers will usually solicit you after three or four years," said Frank Martinez, vice president of Key Operations Inc., a bank that issues secured cards in Havre de Grace, Md. "It's almost a rehabilitation process."
Budget and Credit Counseling Service, a nonprofit New York organization, has arranged with American National Bank of New York , a Larchmont, N.Y., issuer of secured cards, to offer the cards to people who complete the service's debt-management program.
"If, after a year, you pay your bills regularly, they'll give you the card uncollateralized," said Luther R. Gatling, president of the service.
Because so many consumers are desperate for credit, the secured credit-card business has attracted unscrupulous promoters who use illegal or unethical practices. Many employ heavy television or direct-mail advertising through which they charge "application" or "processing" fees ranging from $15 to $300. Sometimes the fee is just for providing lists of banks in the secured-card field, often without the banks' knowledge. Others merely mail applications for secured cards and the applicant is unaware that there is no assurance of actually receiving credit.
"Some phony outfits promise to get you a card and then close down," said H. Spencer Nilson, publisher of The Nilson Report, a credit-card newsletter in Los Angeles. "Over the years, this has been one of the black marks on the industry."
Kurt T. Peters, editor of Credit Card News, a Chicago publication, said: "Secured credit cards seem to attract a certain kind of marketer. You may be out the money for a secured deposit and also have a dead credit card on your hands."
And so it's important to check out the card's issuer and marketer, determining all costs and qualifications before paying any money. Ask your local Better Business Bureau and the Attorney General of the state where the bank does business if other consumers have complained. Also, be wary of the "900" telephone number used by some institutions to sign up customers; that initial charge could add $9.95 to $80 to your overall expense.

 
 
Knowing What to Expect
If you are applying for a secured credit card, here are some questions to ask:
Is the card a general-purpose card?
Some cards being advertised are really not general-purpose credit cards at all but credit instruments good only for merchandise bought through a particular company's catalogue.
Will I get an actual card?
Some marketers simply send to those who have paid their fee a list of financial institutions that are said to provide cards.
Should I use a 900 telephone number to handle the transaction?
The cost of doing that may be very high. If the price of the call is not disclosed at the start of the call, ask about it.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Elgie Hostein, in Herndon, Va., checking a list of holders of secured credit cards that he prepares for the Bankcard Holders of America. He is the director of the credit-education organization; a secured Visa card. (Bruce Young for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Now, Save Prince William Sound

 BODY:
Exxon's $1 billion settlement of state and Federal claims stemming from the calamitous Exxon Valdez oil spill is clearly preferable to a long and chancy trial that might have yielded a smaller penalty. But the real test will be whether the money is spent wisely.
The six Federal and state agencies controlling the funds will inevitably lodge competing claims. These claims must not be allowed to shortchange the main victim of one of the worst environmental disasters in American history: Price William Sound. 
 Under the settlement, Exxon and a shipping subsidiary will plead guilty to four Federal criminal charges, pay an immediate criminal fine of $100 million and an additional $900 million over 10 years to settle civil claims brought by the Federal Government and the state of Alaska.
The agreement wisely includes a "reopener" clause, obligating Exxon to pay an extra $100 million if damages turn out to be greater than presently anticipated. And while the settlement relieves Exxon of Federal and state liabilities, the company still faces 300 smaller suits brought by fishermen, food processors and other individuals and businesses.
The settlement isn't perfect. The Justice Department might also have pressured Exxon to fork over the entire $1 billion immediately. True, Exxon has already paid a stiff price for its carelessness -- $2 billion so far in cleanup costs. It's also true, as Justice argues, that the additional $1 billion can't be spent right away. But that's disingenuous. A one-time payment would begin earning interest immediately; the same amount spread over 10 years will lose value through inflation.
A further question is why Justice chose not to sue Alyeska, the pipeline consortium composed of Exxon and other companies with drilling interests on the North Slope. Alyeska, which had piously assured the public that it could handle any emergency, thoroughly bungled the Valdez spill. One theory is that the Justice Department feared that Alyeska would countersue the Coast Guard, which also performed miserably. As one Congressman put it: "For Alyeska and the Coast Guard, this agreement may be more shield than sword."
The agreement is unlikely to be changed, so the task now is to make sure it does the most good. Six different agencies -- three Federal, three Alaskan -- will collaborate in administering the funds. The agreement calls vaguely for the "restoration, rehabilitation or replacement of natural resources" or the acquisition of "equivalent resources." Those words could mean almost anything, from cleaning beaches to land acquisition for wildlife refuges to building recreational parks to encourage tourism.
There will be many good ideas and hard choices. But the first beneficiary of the money should be the sound itself. Eleven million gallons of oil did not, as some feared, turn Prince William into a dead sea. The beaches are now much cleaner and there have been predictions, challenged by some environmentalists, that salmon runs will reach record proportions this year.
But coastal wetlands have suffered grievously, as have colonies of sea birds and the bald eagles, shellfish and other species vital to the food chain and the local economy. Despite the sound's hardy resilience, there's no guarantee that the ecosystem will recover on its own. Exxon devastated that ecosystem; Exxon's money ought to be targeted first and foremost at speeding its renewal.

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Winners And Losers

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
Republican leaders, who were on the defensive last summer about taxes, the budget, abortion and other domestic issues, now are gleefully charging Democrats with having been wrong, at best, and unpatriotic, at worst, in opposing the Persian Gulf war.
That war was shorter and U.S. casualties were fewer than I, for one, feared they might be. Iraqi resistance was weaker, Arab allies' reliability greater and the American triumph more overwhelming than I expected. 
 These misjudgments certainly influenced my opposition, and no doubt that of some Democrats, to President Bush's decision -- narrowly approved by Congress -- to go to war with Iraq in January. But they do not prove that that opposition was also "wrong"; nor does the desert victory necessarily mean that Mr. Bush chose the better course.
The world will never know whether the policy he first adopted, and that I and many Americans wholeheartedly supported -- international economic sanctions against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait -- would have worked had it been sustained, as it could have been, for more than a few months. That Mr. Bush decided on war, instead, means that the possible efficacy of the collective economic sanctions never can be determined.
The war was a success. That does not mean that the other strategy might not have succeeded, over a longer period, but at a lower cost -- in dollars and lives, American as well as Iraqi; or that it might not have left the U.S. in a better long-range position in the Middle East, or at the head of a "new world order," than it is as the military victor over what proved to be a weak opponent.
Some argue that Saddam Hussein's erratic but determined leadership shows he never would have knuckled under to sanctions; that leaves out of account what else might have happened in the world during six or eight more months of sanctions. It's also argued that those months would have given the Iraqis more time to build up their defenses; in view of the weak resistance actually offered, and the overwhelming coalition power -- not to mention sanctions still at work -- this argument is not persuasive.
Those who supported the resolution authorizing Mr. Bush to go to war have a right to argue, and they certainly will, that the war's success supported their judgment. Some -- not all -- of them also have the right to say that they judged likely military events more accurately than did others. None of that makes it wrong, and certainly not unpatriotic or cowardly, to have opposed the war.
The most prominent Democratic victim of his opposition vote, and of current Republican taunting, is Senator Sam Nunn of Georgia -- no longer, as he seemed to be last year, a likely Presidential candidate. Perhaps that was as inevitable as his nay vote is irrecoverable. But do the American people really scorn Senator Nunn's reasoning?
"I considered my basic philosophy on war and peace," he told Robin Toner of The New York Times, "and that is that you should fight wars only when it's in your vital interest and there's no other reasonable alternative. And I felt then that there was a reasonable alternative, and I still feel there was a reasonable alternative. . . . I've also had the position, and nothing about this conflict is going to change it, that war is a last resort."
Another Democrat who voted against war in January was Representative Lee Hamilton of Indiana, the chairman of a subcommittee on Mideast affairs. In an article for The Washington Post, Mr. Hamilton made two points that may be of increasing importance as time goes on:
"How do you calculate the cost" not only of Americans killed and wounded, but of an estimated 80,000 to 100,000 Iraqi casualties? "How do you estimate the cost of reconstructing devastated cities? How do you measure the cost of environmental damage to the air and waters of the Persian Gulf and the cost of destroyed oil wells and facilities? Were we wrong to support a policy that might have spared these lives and that damage?"
Mr. Hamilton pointed out, moreover, what Secretary of State Baker may have learned on his Middle East trip -- that "every tough issue on the Middle East agenda remains ahead of us after this war. . . . our military success will be of little lasting value if we do not fare well with postwar political and economic challenges."
There's no doubt who won the war, and who gained the most politically by the victory. But those inclined to deride the political losers might yet have cause to regret their intemperance. As an old Semblan proverb has it, the wise at nightfall praise the day.

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Not Violating Refugee Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Camps Victimize Vietnamese Boat People" (letter, Feb. 23), Arthur C. Helton, director of the refugee project of the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights, accuses the Hong Kong Government of intentionally maintaining "woefully inadequate living conditions" in the detention centers for Vietnamese asylum seekers to deprive them of basic dignity. 
 The Hong Kong Government rejects this distortion. It has scrupulously observed the obligations laid down by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the world community.
Since 1975 about 185,000 Vietnamese have come to Hong Kong in hopes of resettlement in the West, particularly the United States. None have been turned away. All are given refuge, food, clothing, medical care and, where possible, education and training. Hong Kong has spent $450 million caring for the Vietnamese. Scarce land and government resources needed for Hong Kong's own use have been given over, though Hong Kong is one of the most densely populated places on earth, with 5.8 million people crowded into a territory about one-third the size of Long Island.
We are host to nearly 8,000 Vietnamese judged by a screening process approved and monitored by the United Nations refugee agency to be political refugees. While they wait for Western nations to take them, they are housed in open refugee centers and are free to move about and obtain employment. Unfortunately, more than 1,000 have been stuck in camps in Hong Kong more than five years, a sad commentary on the generosity of the international community.
Also, nearly 15,000 Vietnamese found by the screening to be illegal immigrants will not be accepted by Western nations. Under the auspices of the High Commissioner for Refugees, Hong Kong began a program in March 1989 of voluntary repatriation. Almost 7,000 have volunteered to return home. Neither the United Nations refugee agency nor any other has found any indication that they suffered persecution upon return.
We are processing quickly 29,000 more Vietnamese awaiting screening. All have access to legal counsel and the right of appeal.
Most of the problems in the centers are due to overcrowding. The difficulties were exacerbated by more than 52,000 arrivals in 1988 and 1989. The living conditions have improved, as we have dedicated increasing resources to the Vietnamese. A new center opens this month managed by a nongovernmental organization.
Those concerned with the plight of Vietnamese in crowded centers might use their energies to persuade Western governments to change their policies toward Vietnam and help redress the economic difficulties that most of those leaving Vietnam are fleeing. Alternatively, they might accept the terms of the international agreement signed in Geneva in 1989, and endorsed by the United States, which stipulates that these economic migrants be returned to their homeland.
 
KERRY F. MCGLYNN
Director, Hong Kong Economic & Trade Office
New York, March 1, 1991

HEADLINE: Cuomo, Stung by State Budget, Sinks in a Poll

BYLINE: By FRANK LYNN

 BODY:
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's budget woes, which have been around for months, turned up as a poll problem yesterday as his ratings in a nonpartisan survey dropped to their lowest point in his eight years in office.
Fifty-two percent of those questioned in a Marist College Institute of Public Opinion poll rated the Governor's performance as only fair or poor, largely because of dissatisfaction with his fiscal policies, said Lee M. Miringoff, who supervises the Marist survey. 
 The poll was conducted as the Governor confronted the biggest budget deficit in the state's history and as friends and foes continued to speculate about whether he would seek the Democratic Presidential nomination next year.
The Marist poll of 583 registered voters, which had a margin of error of plus or minus 4 percent, also indicated that Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato is still paying the price for questions about his integrity. Fifty-two percent of those polled gave him a poor or fair grade, the same mark as for the Governor. The Senate Ethics Committee has been investigating the Senator's involvement in the awarding of housing contracts.
As for potential Democratic challengers to Senator D'Amato next year, Attorney General Robert Abrams is the strongest at the moment, and Geraldine A. Ferraro, the Democratic Vice Presidential candidate in 1984, is among the weakest, according to the poll.
 
Praise From Rinfret

Mr. Cuomo's decline in the poll, which was conducted on Feb. 28 and March 4, reinforced the impression left by last November's election, when he won a third term with 53 percent of the vote against one of the weakest opponents ever fielded by the New York Republican Party. In 1986, Mr. Cuomo was elected with 64.6 percent against Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Westchester County Executive.
Coincidentally, his opponent last fall, Pierre A. Rinfret, praised the Governor's budget cuts yesterday in a Public Broadcasting System television interview.
Aides to Mr. Cuomo blamed his relatively poor showing in the November election on a low turnout in normally Democratic New York City and a nationwide anti-incumbent sentiment.
A spokesman for the Governor, Tom Conroy, said yesterday, "The Governor is delivering the raw truth on the budget, and he's paying for it politically." He added that "people don't like spending cuts and they don't like taxes."
Customarily, a Presidential candidate's popularity in his home state is important, but Carter Eskew, a Democratic political consultant in Washington, said yesterday that even with the poll decline, Mr. Cuomo "is still remarkably stronger than other Northeastern governors with budget problems." He said that Mr. Cuomo had "tremendous resources" and had articulated Federal responsibility for many of the states' fiscal problems.
 
Abrams's Lead
 Yet, Mr. Miringoff said much of the drop had to do with Mr. Cuomo's specific fiscal policies. The respondents called the budget, taxes and cutbacks the state's biggest problems. Many of those polled also criticized Mr. Cuomo's proposed spending cuts and layoffs of state employees, half of them saying they would prefer taxes on corporations and the affluent to be raised instead.
In the Senate survey, only Mr. Abrams ran ahead of Mr. D'Amato, by 47 to 41 percent. Mr. D'Amato ran slightly ahead of City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman and well ahead of his 1986 opponent, City Consumer Affairs Commissioner Mark Green and Ms. Ferraro. Mr. D'Amato's lead over Ms. Ferraro was 20 percentage points.

HEADLINE: ARCHITECTURE VIEW;
Two Reasons for Dancing in the Streets of New York

BYLINE: By Paul Goldberger

 BODY:
It's been a big week for the good guys, no doubt about it. If you're in the New York City architecture and preservation business, things have suddenly been going so well you could start feeling like Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf. First the United States Supreme Court declines to review the landmarks case involving St. Bartholomew's Church, effectively killing forever the church's plan to erect a skyscraper on a portion of its landmark property on Park Avenue -- and ending the bitterest landmarks dispute of the decade entirely in the favor of the landmarks lobby.
 The ink is barely dry on that story when Donald Trump and a group of do-good civic organizations announce that they are joining forces on a new, revised plan for the 72-acre Penn Yards site on the Upper West Side -- a plan that looks mysteriously like the restrained and sensible design the civic groups have been demanding all along, and not a bit like the huge and overbearing scheme Mr. Trump has been insisting he would build. 
 What's going on here? At this rate it wouldn't be surprising if Mayor Dinkins announced his intention to tear down Madison Square Garden and re-erect the old Pennsylvania Station. And all of this follows by just a couple of days the opening of the new Henri Bendel store at 712 Fifth Avenue, another triumph for the forces of landmark preservation and good planning in New York City. There hasn't been a spate of good news like this since Olmsted and Vaux unveiled their design for Central Park.
 So is it too good to be true? Well, certainly not in the case of St. Bartholomew's. The high court has spoken, and that's that. Period. By deciding to let stand a lower-court decision denying St. Bartholomew's the right to overturn the city landmarks designation and erect a 47-story skyscraper on its landmark property, the Supreme Court has spoken, firmly if implicitly, in favor of the benefits that saving great landmarks can bring to society at large.
 The church had argued that tearing down its community house and putting up a profit-making tower would bring money that would subsidize its other activities, including feeding the poor. Advocates of the St. Bart's skyscraper project thus not only tried to make a case that building the tower would be socially beneficial, but some even went so far as to suggest that not building the tower would be tantamount to denying food to the poor.
 The courts did not buy this highly disingenuous argument, or its corollary that landmark designation for this great church, designed by Bertram Goodhue and built in 1919, was an unreasonable interference of government in the practice of religion. By the same reasoning that permits the government to enforce public-welfare laws, like fire safety, in churches the Supreme Court deemed landmark designation a perfectly reasonable exercise of governmental authority. Its silent ruling -- letting a lower-court decision stand without comment -- implicitly accepts this.
 More important still, it accepts the argument that landmark designation has a positive benefit -- that society at large is helped if the St. Bartholomew's Church complex is allowed to remain on Park Avenue. The joys of this Byzantine church and its community house, set in a garden that is itself the last remaining public open space on Park Avenue, are available to everyone in New York. It is not too flippant to say that in the preservation of St. Bartholomew's as an intact piece of the cityscape there is some benefit to the soul not unlike that which the church aspires to within its doors.
 Emotions ran astonishingly high in the St. Bartholomew's case: the preservation community saw it as a symbolic last stand, while for the church it represented a huge potential windfall. That made this tiny plot of land the subject of tremendously high stakes for both sides.
 Emotions were no less intense, though, regarding what, until a week or so ago, was going to be called Trump City, the site of the huge old railroad yard along the Hudson River from West 59th to 72d Streets. Here, after years of fighting between a developer and a community as bitter as any in New York, suddenly there is peace. Not only peace, but compliments on all sides. Was that really Donald Trump saying on the evening news how wonderful he found the community's proposal for this plot of land?
 When a lion lies down with a lamb, one is always a bit suspicious of what the lion expects to get out of the deal. But Mr. Trump has never been as much of a lion as a tiger -- and a paper one at that. And when his kind of paper -- the junk bonds of the 80's -- evaporated, well, there went his roar.
 The fact of the matter is that Mr. Trump had no real choice but to capitulate before the coalition of community groups opposed to his Trump City project. His version of the design -- which called for more than 14 million square feet of space, a 150-story skyscraper as a centerpiece, and a shopping mall so vast it would have dwarfed most suburban centers -- stood no chance of being approved, and the developer knew it. Such a scheme could not have been approved by the city, and even if it had, it would have had to pass a gantlet of court challenges that could have tied it up for a generation. Even then, it probably could not have been financed -- since Mr. Trump, like all real-estate developers, builds not with his own money but with what banks are willing to lend him.
 And that brings us to what is surely the real reason this remarkable deal, the urban-planning equivalent of Shamir and Hussein sitting down to break bread, became possible: the banks that held Mr. Trump's mortgage wanted to see a plan that had some chance of getting built. Even if Mr. Trump's celebrated financial problems make it impossible for him to build the project himself, the new scheme makes this piece of land a lot more salable to someone else.
 The design of what is now called Riverside South was largely the work of a coalition of community groups, led by the Parks Council, Westpride, the Municipal Art Society and the Regional Plan Association. Paul Willen was the prime architect for the project, along with Daniel Gutman, an engineer, and the firm of Andrews & Clark.
 The basic idea involves relocating the West Side Highway, now an elevated structure along the waterfront, inland to free the river's edge for a public park. (In the Trump City plan, the elevated highway was to remain, cutting most of the project's parkland off from the river.) In the Riverside South design, the highway would curve inland above 59th Street, then back out again to meet the present highway at 72d Street. It would be slightly depressed for much of its length, with a southern extension of Riverside Drive set beside and partly over it. That new Riverside Drive would be lined with tall apartment buildings in the manner of Central Park West; on the eastern portion of the site would be an extension of the existing grid of Manhattan streets.
 It's vastly more sensible than the exercise in gigantism represented by Trump City, designed by Cooper, Robertson & Partners. Indeed, the whole plan is a testament to moderation, political realism and intelligence. Did it happen only because Mr. Trump got desperate, and his bankers got impatient?
 A huge share of the credit must go to the civic groups, who were willing to swallow their pride and negotiate with the man who for six years has embodied all they despise. But the Parks Council, Westpride and the Municipal Art Society did more than just sit down with Mr. Trump: these private groups showed a degree of vision and daring that has seemed altogether absent in the city government. The groups' efforts in the final stages of negotiations were coordinated by Richard Kahan, the former head of the New York State Urban Development Corporation and the Battery Park City Authority and now in charge of the Urban Assembly, a private research and planning group. It was Mr. Kahan's expertise that got the groups and Mr. Trump to agree on a total size for the project, 8.3 million square feet, that represented a density that both met good planning standards and promised to achieve economic viability.
 But in the end, it is hard not to be struck by the curious fact that the last party to join in this agreement was the one that should have come aboard first: the city government. The city had nothing to do with bringing this coalition of private citizens and Mr. Trump together, and the city's planners initially did nothing to support it. Only after the lion had lain down with the lamb and made peace did the city join in and support this remarkable -- indeed, extraordinary -- event in the history of New York.

HEADLINE: SHOPPER'S WORLD;
Mexico's Village Of Guitar Makers

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER; LARRY ROHTER is the West Coast culture correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:
FOR more than 450 years, ever since the Spanish conquistadors arrived in west-central Mexico, guitars have been a way of life in the town of Paracho, high in the Sierra Nevada in the state of Michoacan. It was a priest accompanying the original conquerors, Vasco de Quiroga, who decided that each Indian village should be taught a craft that would enable its residents to support themselves as they were incorporated into the Spanish colonial system. And just as it fell to Santa Clara to become a copper-making site and Uruapan to turn out lacquerware, Paracho soon gained fame as Mexico's principal center for the manufacture of stringed instruments.
As it turned out, the choice made by Tata Vasco, as the cleric is still known affectionately to the people of Michoacan, was a wise one. Paracho, about three hours' drive southeast of Guadalajara, is surrounded by meadows of grazing sheep and goats and a cool, thick forest of pine, augmented in recent years by fragrant stands of eucalyptus. During most of its history, it also lived largely in isolation, thereby allowing guitar-making families to hand down their venerable craft from father to son without worrying that their progeny would be tempted to wander off elsewhere. In other words, both the raw material and the skills needed to produce guitars have always been close at hand. 
 Nowadays, the production of guitars in Paracho is a much more sophisticated process, drawing on materials from around the world. The finest instruments are made of rosewood imported from Brazil or India and of spruce from Canada or the United States. The designs on the elaborate inlays around the guitar sound holes may appear to be indigenous, based perhaps on patterns handed down from the Purepechua people, who were the ancestors of many Paracho residents, or on some Hispano-Moorish archetype. But many of the rosette inlays are actually bought in bulk from Japan and Germany, both of which are increasingly the source of the handtools preferred by the most accomplished of Paracho's guitarreros.
The craftsmanship that brings all these ingredients together, however, is purely home grown and deeply rooted. A stroll down the principal streets of this town of 20,000 makes it seem as if there is a taller, or workshop, attached to every home.

FROM dawn to dusk, the streets of Paracho are filled with old men leading burros loaded with hardwood ready to be worked. Children run down the sidewalks carrying bundles of guitar necks, eager to get out of the house after sanding instruments for hours at a time. Inside workshops open to the street and littered with wood shavings, their fathers can be seen carefully gluing guitar sides, fronts and backs together as their mothers do delicate inlay work on the frets or apply lacquer to the body of the guitar.
"I grew up among people who worked the wood, and if you see that daily, you come to it naturally," Jose Luis Diaz Reyes, one of Paracho's most respected luthiers, said as he fit the neck of a guitar to the body he had made by hand, an apprentice watching closely in his shop at 361 Calle 20 de Noviembre. "My grandfather made violins, and I couldn't have been more than 9 years old when I started with him, picking the wood he would use. I worked on my first guitar in 1953, when I was 13, and I have never stopped since. But I'm still learning and still improving, and every guitar is a new challenge."
The guitar makers of Paracho divide their output into two categories: the handmade, carefully crafted guitarra fina and the cruder guitarra comun. The latter can be purchased for as little as $20, though prices can range up to $150. The fina runs from about $500 to $1,500. But those guitars are truly made to order, allowing the purchaser to choose not only the types of wood (rosewood, ebony, palo santo, spruce, pine, cedar, walnut) and guitar adornment but also one of four timbres: bright, deep, sweet and mellow.
The economic crisis from which Mexico is only now beginning to emerge substantially reduced the domestic market for fine instruments and also resulted in the proliferation of guitar factories, in which cheap and shoddy instruments are turned out on a production line. Nevertheless, certain families in Paracho have a tradition of craftsmanship that they have been able to maintain: the Amezcua, Caro, Diaz, Granados, Reyes and Soto families are perhaps the most prominent. Competition among them is intense, and they do not always speak well of each other when questioned, but their individual pride of craftsmanship is unmistakable.
With communications with the outside world improving, some of Paracho's younger luthiers have branched out and begun to make electric guitars and basses. A few of the more adventuresome have even been lured northward to work in guitar shops on Sunset Boulevard in Los Angeles, a city that has more people from Michoacan as residents than the capital of the state, Morelia. Ruben Vasquez Rubio, 31 years old, was one who made that trip, quickly found work on the basis of Paracho's reputation, discovered that California was not to his liking and is now back in his home town. "It is better to work alone than in bad company," he said.

MANY of the electric instruments produced in Paracho are no more than crude knockoffs of the Fender Telecaster and Gibson Les Paul guitars standard in the pop music world. But in a second-floor workshop above his home at 204 Cuauhtemoc, Mr. Vasquez Rubio displays photographs of an outlandish skull-shaped bass he made while in Los Angeles for Gene Simmons of Kiss and of a no less bizarre guitar he built for George Clinton of Parliament Funkadelic. "I have also made an acoustic guitar to specifications for John Denver and a flamenco guitar for Charo," he said. "But if you want a copy of a Fender Stratocaster, a Gibson, a B. C. Rich or even a Martin, I can do that, too." Prices are roughly half what they would be in a guitar shop in the United States.
In Paracho it is possible to find other stringed instruments of varying quality, at prices comparable to those of the guitarra comun. Many of the guitar makers also produce excellent specimens of the bajo sexto, a traditional Mexican basslike instrument with doubled steel strings, and the rest of the stringed instruments common throughout Latin America. Among these are the tiple, or tenor guitar; the requinto, a small, four-string guitar; and the charango, the tiny, five-stringed Andean guitar made from the bodies of mummified armadillos. Ramon Granados, at 164 Independencia, has tried his hand at lutemaking and found customers as far away as Germany. Violins and mandolins are also for sale in some shops, but the levels of craftsmanship can be erratic.
Since the 1970's, Mexico has held its annual Feria Nacional de la Guitarra in Paracho. The weeklong event, which begins on the second Sunday in August, has become a major attraction for guitar lovers and players from all over the world, and with good reason. Fifty or more of the town's guitar makers, joined by luthiers from other parts of Mexico, compete in several categories for prizes and offer their finest instruments for sale. There are guitar expositions and concerts, ranging from classical and flamenco music to Mexican folk songs and Purepechua tunes that were sung at similar festivals even before the arrival of Tata Vasco.

ONE gauge of the degree of craftsmanship at a workshop is to count the number of certificates that have been awarded as prizes from the national guitar fair; these are displayed on the walls and often used as a bargaining point when it comes time to set a price. Other shops tout their wares by showing off letters and cards from satisfied customers in the United States, Germany, Japan, Sweden, Australia and Britain. "It's a long way to come for a guitar," one visitor from San Jose, Calif., wrote in Mr. Diaz's testimonial registry, "but it's worth it."
For those daunted by distance or the isolation of the town, a wide variety of Paracho guitars can also be purchased at the Casa de la Artesania on the Plaza San Francisco in Morelia. In addition, some guitars from Paracho are available at shops in the Zona Rosa in Mexico City and at the Fonatur chain, which is run by the Ministry of Tourism. (Prices in Morelia and in Mexico City will be roughly a third higher than in Paracho.) Instruments can even be found in trinket stores in Tijuana and other cities on the border, though these tend to be mass-produced, bottom-of-the-line specimens selling for twice or three times the price in the town where they were made. "Yes, it is true that Paracho is known everywhere for its guitars," the luthier David Soto Valencia said. "But the best instruments never leave here. You can only buy them here."
The only hotels and restaurants in Paracho are rather basic. There are good hotels in Uruapan, about 25 miles away, including the Hotel Plaza Uruapan (64 Ocampo; telephone, dialed locally, 30333) and the Meson de Cupatitzio in the Parque Nacional (32060). A room for two will cost about $50 at either place.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property: Office Leasing;
A Big Drop in 1990 In Mid-Manhattan's Level of Activity

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
HAVING kept at a relatively steady level since 1987, the volume of office leasing in mid-Manhattan dropped dramatically last year, to a total of 15.9 million square feet, from 18.3 million the year before.
Downtown, there was a slight increase, to a total of 5.2 million square feet, from 4.6 million the year before, said a new study by the Cushman & Wakefield brokerage. 
 Law firms leased 1.183 million square feet in mid-Manhattan last year, down 33 percent from 1989, another Cushman & Wakefield study found. Securities and financial service concerns leased 356,000 square feet, down 54 percent. Insurance companies leased 162,000 square feet, down 70 percent.
Banks actually leased more space in midtown in 1990 than they had in 1989, but the overall volume, 969,000 square feet, was 31 percent less than two years ago.
Government assumed the No. 1 position in the downtown market last year, with a total of 813,000 square feet, an increase of 180 percent over the year before. Securities and financial services concerns also showed an increase in leasing activity downtown, but the volume, 800,000 square feet, was one-quarter of what it was in 1986.
"If the financial industry is this distressed, what's going to make New York come back?" asked Maurice H. Solomon, vice chairman of the Julien J. Studley concern. "Now you see law firms struggling."
Among the firms that have too much space is Shea & Gould, which is in the former Exxon Building, 1251 Avenue of the Americas, between 49th and 50th Streets.
The building's owner, Mitsui Fudosan (New York), said that "a mutually acceptable restructuring of Shea & Gould's lease is being considered to assist the firm in meeting its short-term needs while satisfying Mitsui's long-term expectations."
"As you look out into the business community, what industry is growing?" asked James S. Vanderslice, managing director of Cushman & Wakefield and the branch manager of its New York offices. "I don't see any that's really growing and adding employees. But every industry is looking to operate more efficiently and at a lower cost, and that's what the market is offering right now."
The spurt of government leasing was occasioned in part by a deliberate decision by the city's General Services Department to take advantage of the lower rents available in the battered downtown market. "I think it would be unrealististic to expect that pace of leasing to be kept up," said David A. Tewksbury, a director of Cushman & Wakefield.
Yet, there may be a lot of activity.
"As we're getting into 1991," Mr. Vanderslice said, "interest rates are coming down and rental rates are coming down. That's helping new activity in the market. We're not anticipating a record year in leasing, but we're anticipating a decent year in 1991, much better than we anticipated coming out of the fourth quarter of last year."
"We have a tremendous amount of potential leasing velocity," said Martin Turchin, vice chairman of the Edward S. Gordon Company, a real estate concern. "You have a whole variety of tenancies that are going to have to move, notwithstanding that many of them might not necessarily be expanding, which, historically, was the typical motivation for relocation.
"In terms of tenants of 200,000 square feet or more, there are probably 7 million to 8 million square feet of those tenancies alone that are in the marketplace right now, at the end of 25- or 15-year leases."
"The expectation is that while there will be a lot of velocity in terms of leases being made," Mr. Turchin said, "there is not going to be any significant change in the amount of space that's occupied, so the vacancy rate overall will probably not diminish."
TO get a clearer sense of what the future holds, Mr. Turchin has been looking all the way back to the late 1960's.
Some 35 million square feet of space came on the market between 1969 and 1972, Mr. Turchin said, and "a lot of leases in those buildings" were taken on a 25-year basis, meaning that they will begin expiring in 1994 -- a date that is on the immediate horizon for any company's long-term planning.
"Most of the lease expirations were primarily dictated by financing," Mr. Turchin said. "Up until 1971, most lenders were giving very long-term mortgages. What they wanted to know was that major tenants would be there for the duration of the mortgage, so they didn't have any risk that the building would be exposed before the mortgage was paid off. The lenders required lease terms coterminous with the mortgages and the mortgages were basically 25 years."
He said there was also a cluster of 15-year leases, entered into during the late 70's and early 80's, whose expirations were near.
"The other problem," Mr. Turchin said, "is that most buildings in the first vintage, from 1969 through 1972, have asbestos. Even if tenants have a desire to renew in those buildings, they find they really can't. They're not going to continue to live with asbestos in the premises, and because of it they can't do any alteration work."
In addition, almost half of the leases at Rockefeller Center will expire in three years. That is a vestige of the fact that much of the property used to be owned by Columbia University, with a lease to the Rockefeller interests that ran until 1994. Until the Rockefeller Group bought the leasehold from Columbia in 1985, it would not extend its tenants' leases past 1994.
Moreover, Mr. Turchin noted, "You have landlords now pursuing tenants saying, 'If you're prepared to move a year earlier, we're prepared to assume your unexpired lease liability.' "
BUT there is still a lot of space available -- some 53.9 million square feet in Manhattan as of last week, the Gordon company calculated. Cushman & Wakefield estimates that the vacancy rate in primary buildings in mid-Manhattan will rise this year as high as 19.3 percent. (They already exceed that level in west midtown.) Downtown, the figure could approach 17.9 percent.
"Sure, there's movement," Mr. Solomon said. "There are firms doing O.K. There are leases expiring. And people will want to make deals. The musical chairs will continue, but who's to say that there will be a net increase in overall absorption? I don't think there'll be too much increase for a while."
"A lot of things make markets," he said. "One of them could be psychological. It's a feeling either of diminishing expectations or fruitful expectations. And I think that we're still in diminishing expectations in New York City. When you couple that with the continual firings from the banks and other institutions, what do you have?
"Plus, you have this incredible communications system that's been built around the world, where computers talk to each other and fax machines don't require messengers anymore. And you wonder whether we're dawning on a new era."
He reflected on the virtual disappearance of the 137-year-old W. R. Grace & Company, once known as the "Old Lady of Hanover Square," whose roots run through New York history. Grace, once a great shipping power and now primarily a chemical company, said in January that it would move most of its staff to Boca Raton, Fla., out of its headquarters on West 42d Street, between the Avenue of the Americas and Fifth Avenue.
"They're leaving because they don't have to be here," Mr. Solomon said. "When you get an old-line firm, a real city firm like Grace going, who I thought had a commitment to New York, then you wonder."

HEADLINE: Campus Life: M.I.T.;
A Class Gift With a Purpose: Creating Teachers

DATELINE: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.

 BODY:
To encourage graduates of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology to become public school teachers, the class of 1991 has made a $60,000 loan-forgiveness program its senior gift to the institute.
"The gift project is a real expression of what a lot of people in our class have as values," said Jason B. Slibeck, a enior in political science from Russell, Ky., and chairman of the senior gift committee. 
 "M.I.T. is one of the best as far as educating professionals in fields such as engineering, architecture, science and economics," Mr. Slibeck said, but the institute "is not educating that vital group of professionals known as educators, at the primary and secondary levels."
 
Pledges of $91

The gift committee hopes to raise the $60,000 this spring, asking seniors to make an initial lump sum donation and to pledge an additional amount over the next four years. As a symbolic gesture, each of the eight committee members has already promised to give $91 to the fund this year.
The money will be used to forgive M.I.T. loans to members of the classes of 1992 to 1996 who become public school teachers. Mr. Slibeck said that details of administering the fund have yet to be worked out, but he said that after the gift committee determines guidelines for eligibility and distribution, it hopes that M.I.T. will administer the fund.
Mr. Slibeck estimated that about 30 students would have loans forgiven through the fund over the next five years, and he expressed the hope that M.I.T. might continue forgiving loans after the fund is exhausted. dry.
In past years, the money for the traditional senior gift has gone toward more material things: classroom renovations, information maps and, last year, a clock for the Student Center.
 
Praise From a Dean
 Although there is no teacher certification program at M.I.T., students can receive certification through an exchange program at Wellesley College. Students pursuing certification can either complete the program during their undergraduate years or stay on for a fifth year, devoting the full year to teaching, and pay only $1,000 in tuition.
M.I.T.'s dean for undergraduate education, Margaret L. A. MacVicar, wrote to the gift committee expressing her enthusiasm for the idea.
"It is critical," she wrote, "that M.I.T. encourage and support its students, staff and faculty to undertake the critical challenge of K-to-12 education facing this nation."
Not everyone, however, thinks that debt forgiveness ought to be used as an incentive for prospective teachers.
Brian M. Katz, a senior in mechanical engineering, from Larchmont, N.Y, voiced concerns that graduates might leave public education after taking advantage of the loan forgiveness. A better idea, Mr. Katz said, might be to finance a fifth-year program to enable students to receive their teaching certification. Mr. Katz participated in the early discussions of the senior gift committee and is completing requirements for teacher certification through the Wellesley program.
The gift committee, which first met early last fall, decided to establish a teaching fund after holding several open meetings and sending out surveys to members of the class.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 7, 1991, Sunday, Late Edition - Final

 CORRECTION:
A report in the Campus Life pages on March 17 about the Massachusetts Institute of Technology misstated the amount of money students must pay to spend a fifth year at the school, devoted solely to teaching. It is the regular tuition, currently $15,600, not $1,000.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Campus Life: William and Mary;
Student Accuses Veteran Professor Of Racist Remarks

DATELINE: WILLIAMSBURG, Va.

 BODY:
Questions of racism and academic freedom have been raised by a departmental inquiry into complaints that a sociology professor makes disparaging remarks about minorities in class and grades minority-group members and women more harshly than white males.
David Lutzer, the dean of the Faculty of Arts and Sciences, said the inquiry into complaints against the professor, Vernon H. Edmonds, did not involve "talking about the theories" he presents in class. 
 "We're not checking for anyone's 'political correctness,' " Dean Lutzer said. "Academic freedom allows him to teach the sociological theories that he believes."
But Mr. Lutzer said he was concerned about the "pedagogical issues" raised in complaints against Mr. Edmonds, a professor of more than 20 years tenure.
Those issues were first raised in a letter sent to college administrators by a sophomore who took Professor Edmonds's "Principles of Sociology" course, a requirement for the major. The student, Mike Halpin, a sophomore English major from Orchard Park, N.Y., wrote that Professor Edmonds used his classroom as a forum for prejudiced ideas about women and minorities, including jokes about blacks and homosexuals, and that he gave lower grades to women and minority students.
Mr. Lutzer said that the letter has been discussed with Professor Edmonds, who denies the charges. He has been asked to respond in writing.
 
'A Snowball Effect'

 If Mr. Lutzer and the department's acting chairman, David Aday, deem it warranted, the complaint could be referred to a faculty committee for further investigation.
Other complaints have surfaced as well. Both the student Minority Affairs Committee and the Student Association Council have passed resolutions calling for an inquiry into Mr. Halpin's charges. The minority committee reported receiving complaints from 13 other students, two of whom turned over their class notebooks to back up their assertions.
"It's basically a snowball effect," said the minority comittee chairman, David Scott, a transfer student who is a computer science and government double major from Elk Grove, Calif. "Edmonds has been teaching for 25 years and for the past 25 years has been complained about."
University officials declined to comment on whether there had been past complaints about Professor Edmonds. But according to the archives of Flat Hat, the student newspaper, he was reprimanded by the Faculty of Arts and Sciences in 1973 after failing four black students in his "Social Problems" course in the fall of 1972. The reprimand charged him with "failing to abide by precise criteria" in grading the students.
The Minority Affairs Committee plans to compare the grades of minority students in Professor Edmonds's classes with those of white men, Mr. Scott said.
In an interview, Professor Edmonds denied the charges, and called Mr. Halpin "a mole" who took the class with "the sole purpose of finding some damaging evidence" against him.
He agreed that minority students tend to avoid his class. "There is some kind of a widespread myth that I lower the grades of black students," he said. "I think they hear it through the grapevine, or through some official or semi-official source."
 
Wants Due Process

 But Professor Edmonds said that in reality, "I have had a number of black students in my classes, and their grades probably average out above the norm."
Professor Edmonds said that if the administration pursued the matter, he would assert his right to due process -- that is, a hearing before the appropriate faculty review committees and, if necessary, further investigation.
Professor Edmonds has been teaching at the college since 1967 and was granted tenure in 1968.
Some students and faculty members have expressed concern that the allegations against Professor Edmonds are aimed at pressuring professors and others to be "politically correct."
 
'He's a Fine Teacher'
 In a letter to Flat Hat, Deborah G. Ventas, an associate professor of psychology, wrote: "Fears about racism, sexism and homophobia in the classrooms are matched by fears among professors that issues of race, class and gender are being forced into the curriculum in the interests of being politically correct."
Professor Edmonds, whose field of expertise is philosophical issues of social science, said that "when you get into the social sciences, facts that don't fit into a certain ideology get passed by the wayside."
Mark Zito, a senior government major from Bedford, N.H., took the "Principles of Sociology" course last fall and wrote to another student publication, The Remant, to criticize Mr. Halpin. "As a student of Dr. Edmonds in Sociology 210 as well as two other classes, I feel qualified to say that he's a fine teacher,", he wrote. "Halpin's alleged factual accounts are grossly misconstrued."
In his letter, Mr. Halpin said Professor Edmonds had gone "so far as to dictate that blacks were happier in slavery."
Mr. Zito said the professor had compared the economic status of black American slaves to that of working-class Europeans and North American industrial workers of the same period. Professor Edmonds, he said, then "revealed the fact" that slaves were economically better off than their white European and North American counterparts, citing a book titled "Time on the Cross," by Robert William Fogel and Stanley L. Engerman (Little Brown, 1974), which he said supports this theory by with comparisons of living space, infant mortality rates and other measures.
 
Dispelling Myths

 Referring to the slavery lecture, Professor Edmonds said, "I was primarily dispelling the myths about slavery, which I think are little better than Sunday school." He said he didn't think that the interpretation he offered was "standard" but noted that "the average sociologist doesn't know a whole lot about slavery."
Mr. Aday said: "You can't rule out all partial presentations as illegal. If the idea is to make students think or question, then it won't be prohibited."
But he said: "It's really a very thorny issue. We don't have very much of a way of resolving challenges to academic freedom."

 Ms. Taylor is an assistant vice president at Manufacturers Hanover in New York. A cum laude graduate of Duke University, she expects to receive an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University in August. HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Yes, That's A Tunnel; Yes, That's Light

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Happy days are almost here again. Consumers, at least if one is to believe what they tell pollsters, are now more confident about the future than at any time since early last year.
The rising tide of consumer confidence is probably good news for owners of stocks and of speculative bonds, but it may not be such great information for owners of Government bonds. For Republicans, basking in the glow of the Persian Gulf victory, it could remove the last apparent obstacle to a landslide victory next year. 
 On one hand, it is hardly surprising to see the consumer sentiment numbers starting to pick up. Investors -- who are all consumers themselves, it may be noted -- stopped getting more worried back in October, just as consumers' views of the future were reaching their lows. And by mid-February, investor sentiment began to approach euphoria.
The report that the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment survey had produced a preliminary March reading of 88.0, almost exactly what it was in July, was greeted by Ed Yardeni, the optimistic chief economist for Prudential Securities, as proof that the gulf crisis was "the main cause of the economic downturn."
Particularly impressive in the survey results -- which will be revised before final figures come out in a couple of weeks -- was that the consumer view of the future, as opposed to the present, is now higher than it was last summer. On the other hand, the view of current conditions remains well below prewar levels. Given the rise in unemployment since then, that is hardly a surprise.
Maybe some of that is simply the elation of victory, and will soon fade. It certainly has not shown up yet in such areas as auto sales, and Fed Chairman Alan Greenspan seems to be a member of the group that is not convinced the recession is ending. Last week, he hinted that more easing was coming, providing a brief lift for the stock market that soon faded as yet another run at 3,000 came up a loser. The Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 6.68 points, to 2,948.52.
If it is the gulf that turned off the economy, and that turned it back on again, perhaps it is wise to look there for possible clues to the future. A negative sign is that the direction of events seems to have passed from the generals to the diplomats, who, it will be recalled, were telling Saddam Hussein in July that this country had no position on his border dispute with Kuwait. It is not hard to imagine a prolonged stalemate in which almost everyone gets mad at America for the lack of progress, and in which Americans begin to wonder if the troops will ever come home.
There were, of course, reasons to worry about the economy long before Iraq invaded Kuwait. Newly poor bears are right to say that the war did nothing to bring down budget deficits, or to relieve the excessive debt burdens on many companies. But it is likely that the Fed's aggressive easing of credit will give the economy at least a temporary shot of adrenaline, and the probability is that the rise in consumer confidence is not near an end.
