HEADLINE: Wall Street;
Currency Traders vs. the Central Banks

BYLINE: By Diana B. Henriques

 BODY:
Traders who have been predicting a rally for the dollar ran up against the concerted force of the leading central banks last week. The score by Friday was Traders 1, Bankers 0.
In a swift turnaround last month, analysts decided the dollar was too cheap, especially against the German mark. Although falling interest rates are usually bearish for a nation's currency, the traders' optimism survived even the rate-cutting noises made to Congress last week by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve. 
 But the dollar's rally apparently smelled of speculation to the tight-lipped central bankers, who sold dollars several times during the week in a bid to rein in the currency. Given the size of the currency market, such gestures are largely ceremonial when an authentic rally arrives, said Robert Gay, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley. What's ahead? Probably more erratic gains, as traders keep one eye on the Fed and the other on the future, he added.

HEADLINE: Business Diary/March 10-15

 BODY:

COMPANIES
 
British Airways Whines About Its New Competition
 
British Airways P.L.C. wants sympathy. Even after winning permission last week to fly between the United States and the Continent and penetrate the American market in a host of other ways -- rights no other foreign airline has had -- the British carrier is sounding defeated and distraught. It seems British Airways will have to accept some competition from United, American and Virgin Atlantic at Heathrow Airport, London's most convenient. The day before creditors were to seize Pan Am's planes, Pan Am and T.W.A. won British approval to sell their Heathrow routes to United and American. "U.S. negotiators have succeeded in weakening British Airways," a spokesman for the airline intoned, as the company's chairman spoke of reduced profitability. Kevin Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, shed few tears. "They're yelping so much it's suspicious," he said. British Airways already plans to invade the Continent by buying a large piece of Sabena World Airlines and forming a new carrier in Germany.
 
The British deal hardly gives America's feeble old international carriers the strength to rise from their wheelchairs. Pan American World Airways, the sickliest case, is earning only enough from its route sale to perhaps survive until someone buys its remaining assets. And Trans World Airlines said the Transportation Department's ban on the sale of three of its six London routes to American, in the interests of competition, imperils its financial health.
 
Maxwell's Plum, or Prune?
 
"Maxwell's Plum," said a Daily News headline Wednesday morning. "Miracle Max!" and "Daily News Lives!" followed that afternoon. Now Robert Maxwell needs to live up to his headlines. The plum he agreed to buy after settling with the unions last Tuesday has shriveled to perhaps half its former circulation of a million-plus, and even less of its former advertising. His purchase of The News -- the Tribune Company is actually paying him $60 million or more to take on the newspaper's liabilities -- is based on agreements by the striking unions to accept sharp staffing cuts. Mr. Maxwell, a British publisher, promised to invest what the News called "mega-money" -- not to mention the mega-time he might need in his trans-Atlantic schedule to lure scores of advertisers, several hundred thousand readers and Jimmy Breslin back to his pages.
 
Exxon, and Taxpayers, Pay Up
 
For a company that earns as much as Exxon, $1.1 billion actually isn't real money. No sooner had the Exxon Corporation agreed to pay such a settlement to Alaska and the Federal Government in the Exxon Valdez oil spill than Lawrence G. Rawl, the company's chairman, said there would be virtually no effect on the company's earnings or image. The company also pleaded guilty to four misdemeanors. Exxon's ability to write off the whole settlement save a $100 million criminal penalty will cost taxpayers an estimated $300 million.
 
A Purge at Chrysler
 
Tough times provided the Chrysler Corporation with the perfect occasion to kick a union leader off its board. Cost-saving, Chrysler called it, adding that four of the other 18 members were leaving as well. In fact, it's the loss of labor's voice, responded Owen F. Bieber, president of the United Automobile Workers, a dissident on the board and the only departing member who is not in at least his late 60's. Labor representation, unusual on American boards, hardly seems to have hurt corporate competitiveness in countries like Germany. But by reversing itself on the issue, Chrysler has carried out Detroit's most celebrated boardroom purge since H. Ross Perot left General Motors.
 
McDonald's New Burger
 
No, McDonald's will not draw in the bean sprouts and oat bran crowd with its new, reduced-fat burger. At best, analysts say, the health-conscious might stop sneering so loudly that they embarrass those for whom dieting means ordering the burger and fries without the shake. Diners who do try the "McLean" are likely to be disappointed, said Caroline Levy of Shearson Lehman. "This doesn't even taste like a burger, based on what I've heard," she said. Like the company's recent abandonment of styrofoam containers to placate environmentalists, Ms. Levy said, "It's good for McDonald's image, but I do not see it as good for the bottom line."
 
In Brief
 
American Airlines, the nation's largest carrier, reduced its lowest fares -- reviving the 30-day advanced-purchase ticket -- to encourage travelers frightened off by the Persian Gulf war or the recession. But some other fares are rising.
 
The Federal Trade Commission is investigating the competitive practices of the Microsoft Corporation, the dominant maker of personal computer software. Microsoft calls the probe minor and limited, its competitors call it broad-ranging, and the F.T.C. is keeping quiet.
 
The House reluctantly poured another $30 billion into the savings and loan bailout last week.
 
 
 
THE ECONOMY

 
Putting a Leash on '900' Calls
 
The Federal Communications Commission proposes that callers to "900" numbers get to hear the price tags before they pay. Under rules announced Thursday, the "900" services would have to describe their prices and offerings, then give callers a chance to hang up before they are billed. No longer would callers applying for construction jobs learn only later that the calls had cost them $18 each, as the Government alleges, nor would callers for nearly useless credit cards end up paying $49.95. Several industry representatives blasted the F.C.C.'s proposal as a threat to legitimate "900" services; many provide weather, sports scores and stock information for willing customers. The F.C.C. is likely to issue its final rules by the end of the year.
 
Harsh Message in Output
 
Factory output fell in February for the fifth straight month, indicating that the recession continued to deepen. An eight-tenths of 1 percent drop last month brought production to the lowest level since June 1988. Lawrence Kudlow, the chief economist at Bear Stearns, said that considering last month's dismal employment report as well, the recession now looks to be as long as average. "The short and mild argument has gone down with the February numbers," he said. But consumer confidence appeared to improve in early March after the war.
 
Inflation Just Simmers Along
 
Wholesale inflation continues to simmer despite a tepid economy. While producer prices overall fell six-tenths of 1 percent last month, the core rate, without volatile food and energy prices, rose four-tenths of 1 percent. Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at Manufacturers Hanover, said that like Goldilock's evaluation of the baby bear's porridge -- "not too hot, not too cold," he sees the inflation report as "not too inflationary, not too recessionary." Some economists say inflation remains too strong for the Federal Reserve to further ease credit.
 
Modest Cutback From OPEC
 
With Iraq no longer around to bluster about the need for much higher prices, the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries last week agreed to cut production by only 5 percent, or about a million barrels a day. The agreement demonstrates the influence of Saudi Arabia, which wants to keep prices moderate enough to guarantee long-term demand for its vast oil supplies. With neither Iraq nor Kuwait exporting, most OPEC members have quotas far higher than their previous levels. News of the OPEC agreement nudged oil prices up by only 69 cents last week to $20.
 
The Great Bankruptcy Shield
 
France had the Theatre du Grand Guignol, presenting murder, rape, torture and suicide. The United States has the bankruptcy courts. The latest example of creative bankruptcy is an Equitable Life Assurance Society production, starring a partly empty 53-story Times Square office tower and grieving investors. The Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company accuses Equitable of deceiving other investors and trying to stick them with tens of millions of dollars in losses by throwing the partnership that owns the tower into bankruptcy. This, after Manville used the bankruptcy courts to confront its asbestos claimants; Texaco, to rebuff a challenge from Pennzoil, and Frank Lorenzo, to fend off his striking airline unions. Equitable and Manufacturers reached a tentative settlement on Friday, but negotiations on the exact terms continued.

 
 
INTERNATIONAL

 
A Bigger Slice of Soviet Pie
 
Soviet officials harass foreign businesses, protesting crowds swarm around the Kremlin walls, but Pizza Hut's first two Moscow restaurants claim profit margins higher than in the United States. Russians line up down the block for the chance to pass an hour or two in a Western setting. But the trials of doing business in the Soviet Union have slowed Pizza Hut's expansion plans. Andrew Rafalat, the Pizza Hut executive who opened the restaurants in September, said he first needs to secure domestic supplies of meat and mozzarella cheese, to save the expense of buying them for hard currency in Western Europe and trucking them all the way in. Soviet meat suppliers are still incredulous when he asks them to meet his specifications. "They say, 'We're giving you a scarce product. We're doing you a favor.' " Mr. Rafalat, visiting the Pepsico parent company's New York headquarters last week, said he hopes to open some stand-alone take-out windows in Moscow by the end of the year. But as David Williams, senior vice president of Pepsico Food Service International, said, "Nothing in the Soviet Union comes easily. Nothing is handed to you on a plate." Except for some American-style pizzas, he hopes.
 
Forgiving Poland
 
Leading industrialized nations have decided that the proto-capitalist Poles should not suffer for the borrowing binge of their deposed Communist rulers. To aid Poland's progress toward a market economy, officials meeting in Paris agreed to forgive about half the $33 billion owed and ease repayment terms on the rest. While micro-entrepreneurs have lined several of Warsaw's broadest boulevards with their booths, the most ambitious economic reforms in Eastern Europe have also caused severe unemployment.
 
The Trade Police in Japan
 
Inspectors and police milling around an American rice exhibit at a Tokyo food show last week became, in the view of American officials, a prime exhibit of Japanese protectionism run amok. Japanese officials insisted that the sealed bags and plastic containers of American rice, if not the "Have a Rice Day" bumper stickers, violated laws against rice imports. Americans insisted the display was solely educational.

HEADLINE: Tech Notes;
Muffling the Thunder in the Sky

BYLINE: By JOEL KURTZMAN

 BODY:
By the year 2000, according to Federal Aviation Administration rules, the nation's noisiest commercial jets must be phased out of the fleet. The trouble is, these aircraft -- built in the 1960's and 1970's -- include almost all of the Boeing 727's, which are among the most economical planes for carrying passengers and freight. To bring these planes into compliance, the engines must be replaced -- which is expensive -- or modified.
Now, Federal Express Aviation Services Inc. in Memphis, Tenn., and Pratt & Whitney of East Hartford, Conn., are developing noise reduction kits -- "hush kits" -- for the JT-8 series of three basic engines. The JT-8 series, built by Pratt & Whitney, is used on the 727's. Certification from the F.A.A. for these kits is expected by fall. 
 Hush kits reduce engine noise by slowing the velocity of exhaust gases and baffling the sounds of the turbines and other moving parts. To reduce exhaust sound, new mixers and farings are added to the engine to blend the core stream of high-velocity gases with lower velocity gases from the fan blades. The kit also modifies the fan blades so more air bypasses the combustion chamber.
Since noise increases with the velocity of the gases, the lower average speed reduces the sound. A new tail pipe reduces the sound further by slowing the exit velocity of the gases. To muffle the turbines, the air inlet of the engine, at the nose cone, is replaced with one with sound-absorbing baffles. Baffles are also added to the support pylon and to the thrust reverse assembly to quiet the plane as it lands.

GRAPHIC: Diagram illustrates a new muffler design for muffling jet engine noise (Source: Federal Express Aviation Services Inc.)

HEADLINE: Mutual Funds;
Playing the Adjustable-Rate Game

BYLINE: By Carole Gould

 BODY:
Looking for a fund that has everything? High yields? And stable principal? And guarantees by the United States Government or one of its agencies?
A new breed of funds -- adjustable-rate mortgage-backed funds -- is one solution, although critics say there are problems. These new funds promise higher yields than money-market funds, less fluctuation than long-term bond funds -- and the credit safety of securities backed by American Government agencies. Investors have poured more than $1 billion into the first fund of this sort and rivals are racing into the market. 
 Mortgage funds, of course, are not new; for years, there have been funds that invest in fixed-rate Government National Mortgage Association securities, and those of Ginnie Mae's cousins, Freddie Mac and Fannie Mae. But adjustable-rate funds investing in offerings from these same agencies were developed to eliminate the volatility that has long characterized the fixed-rate funds. Prices for fixed-rate funds must move around to compensate for any shifts in market interest rates that cannot be reflected in the portfolio's fixed rates.
Adjustable-rate mortgage funds also offer competitive yields as rates rise and a cushion against any sharp rate declines.
 But as fund groups rush into the market, some experts worry that investors don't understand the tradeoff that these funds require. "Trying to do it all in one investment is a loser's game," said Anthony J. Ogorek, an investment adviser in Buffalo, N.Y., who believes investors pay too much in total return for reducing volatility.
For those willing to do so, there are now several options. The biggest -- and oldest -- of these funds is the Franklin Adjustable U.S. Securities Fund, sponsored by Franklin Resources, San Mateo, Calif. Its assets soared to $1.3 billion at the end of February; at yearend 1989, they were $76.2 million.
Although it was set up in October 1987 as the Franklin Adjustable Rate Mortgage Fund, it languished until last year. Its name then was changed and sales shot up, partly because it was perceived as a safe haven during market turbulence and because of its solid record. For the 12 months ended Feb. 28, it yielded an average of 9.5 percent -- or roughly 2 points more than the average money market fund, said CDA Investment Technologies, which tracks mutual funds. Franklin's total return -- yield plus changes in principal value -- was 10 percent, compared with 9.2 percent for all bond funds.
This success has drawn rivals: Pilgrim Group, Los Angeles, launched its fund in late February; Keystone Group, Boston, said it plans to introduce one this month, and others are in the works.
 What is the investor's tradeoff for lowering some of the interest rate risk? For one thing, monthly dividends fluctuate more than they would with a standard Ginnie Mae fund, potentially every month, said Jack Lemein, the Franklin fund manager. That could pose problems for people who rely on regular checks to cover their living expenses.
Another problem is that the funds' yields will drop when interest rates fall. That's because the underlying mortgages will pay less over time as the borrowers' rates are adjusted downward. Even when interest rates rise, the funds will lag because the rates on the underlying mortgages are adjusted periodically, not immediately. And when mortgages are prepaid, the money often is reinvested at a lower rate.
"Franklin's quest to significantly lower the fund's volatility has cost investors too much in total return," said Mr. Ogorek.
Consider this, he said: In 1988 the Shearson Lehman Hutton Mortgage Backed Security Index rose 8.7 percent. The Franklin fund rose 6.4 percent, while the Vanguard Ginnie Mae Fund rose 8.8 percent, according to CDA. In 1989, the index rose 15.4 percent, Franklin gained 10.3 percent and Vanguard, 14.8 percent. Last year, the index increased 10.4 percent while Franklin gained 9.5 percent and Vanguard, 10.3 percent.
Meanwhile, the "standard deviation," a measure of risk, for the Franklin Fund is 0.30 percent compared with 1.45 percent for the Vanguard Ginnie Mae Fund. While it is five times higher, 1.45 percent is hardly a risky rating. Municipal bond funds, for example, carry a 1.29 percent rating.
Then there are sales charges. The Franklin fund has a hefty 4 percent sales load, so if you had invested $50,000 in it three years ago, you'd have $61,684 today, for an annual return of 7.25 percent. But if you had invested the cash in money funds for three years, yielding the Donoghue 12-month average at yearend, you would have earned a combined 7.93 percent return -- or more than a half point more than the Franklin fund. Your $50,000 would be worth $62,865.
Mr. Ogorek's conclusion: You can do better by dividing your portfolio among various investments. But if you do want to invest in mortgage-backed securities, buy shares in a regular Ginnie Mae fund, he said.

HEADLINE: McKesson: No. 1 but a Doze on Wall Street

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO

 BODY:
The 158-year-old McKesson Corporation is old enough to refer to all but a handful of American companies as young whippersnappers. It is big enough to be the only national force in the growing $22 billion business of distributing pharmaceuticals and personal care products to drugstores, hospitals and mass marketers like Wal-Mart Stores Inc. And McKesson is good enough at what it does to have been invited by the Soviet Union to help unravel its infamous distribution logjams.
Yet McKesson is greeted on Wall Street with a yawn -- and in some cases, a wince. 
 The main reason has been the company's failure to generate sustained profit growth. During the mid-1980's, there were costly price wars in the company's core business, drug distribution. Those have subsided, but a variety of problems have cropped up in McKesson's nondrug businesses, which account for less than 20 percent of revenues but a higher proportion of profits. These include companies in "service merchandising" that distribute personal care products, candy and other consumer products to 20,000 grocery and discount stores; the nation's largest bottled water business; Armor All Products Inc., a car-care products concern, and PCS Inc., the nation's largest processor of prescription drug bills.
"McKesson has never fired on all cylinders," said Donald Hultgren, an analyst at Raymond James & Associates in St. Petersburg, Fla. For the first nine months of its current fiscal year, which ends this month, McKesson's earnings fell 2.9 percent, to $78.1 million, even though operating profits from drug distribution rose 8.9 percent and sales were up 9.6 percent, to $6.25 billion.
Analysts say the company's inconsistent performance is the main reason its share price has climbed about 78 percent since the beginning of 1985, compared with almost 125 percent for the Standard & Poor index of 500 stocks. McKesson's shares began the year at $34 and have stayed at that level while the S. &P. 500 jumped more than 13 percent.
"We have had some real disappointments in terms of maintaining earnings momentum," Alan Seelenfreund, McKesson's chairman and chief executive, acknowledged.
Mr. Seelenfreund and Rex R. Malson, president and chief operating officer, assumed the challenge of shedding that legacy in late 1989 when they were appointed to a new "office of the chief executive" after the abrupt resignation of Thomas Field Jr. as chief executive. The company's five units have since undergone consolidation or other changes in top management and focus.
Part of McKesson's problem, analysts say, is that distribution companies get far less attention than their role in the economy warrants. The public is generally unaware that in the drug business, for example, even large manufacturers like Eli Lilly and Company rely largely on intermediaries like McKesson to keep track of what retailers need and make sure they get it on time.
Analysts say McKesson controls about 27 percent of the drug distribution market, far more than the 15 percent held by the second-ranked Bergen Brunswig Corporation of Los Angeles. McKesson's greatest strength is the nearly 3,300 independent drugstores that operate as part of its "voluntary chain" under the Valu-Rite name, which provides purchasing clout, sales promotions and ancillary services from car leasing to insurance. That helps the independents compete with drugstore chains, the largest of which is the Rite Aid Corporation, with about 2,350 outlets.
McKesson is a strong second to Bergen in the fastest-growing segment of the business, sales to hospitals. Analysts say that McKesson is the most bureaucratic of the drug distributors and was slower than Bergen to recognize the potential of the low-margin, high-volume hospital business.
McKesson has also had trouble keeping up with smaller, more entrepreneurial companies like Wall Street's current favorite, the Cardinal Distribution Company. Based in Dublin, Ohio, Cardinal has been assembled by the entrepreneur Robert Walter over the last decade from six older firms and is now the market leader in the Northeast.
"There are very few national customers and very few economies to having a national scale," said Mr. Walter.
Mr. Seelenfreund responds that few regional firms would mind having the Wal-Mart contract, which should produce about $500 million in revenue this year for McKesson, not to mention McKesson's purchasing clout. And while McKesson has no real advantage over regional distributors in buying automation equipment for individual warehouses, it can spread the costs for its communications and order-processing systems over more operations.
Like all major distributors, McKesson invests far more than manufacturers care to risk on such automation. They exploit their investments by buying large volumes of product at discount prices, often snapping up extra supplies in advance of price increases. For about 3 cents on the dollar, they gather and ship the particular mix of products that customers want on any given day.
Typically, the products are delivered to a local drugstore in small bins organized so that a clerk restocking the store finds everything needed for a particular aisle in the same bin. In many cases, distributors actually manage the restocking of the shelves.
McKesson also is a buying agent for druggists in dealing with scores of producers of generic drugs, which can be substituted for more expensive prescription brands. In some cases, retailers even get financial support. McKesson, for example, secured a loan to a Kansas City druggist who wanted to create a separate pharmacy to serve the needs of people with AIDS for various drugs and prompt insurance reimbursement.
McKesson also has a large business delivering bulk supplies to retail chains that supply their own outlets. McKesson charges a markup of just one-quarter of 1 percent on such deliveries, a miniscule margin that produces profits largely because McKesson pays its bills monthly but collects receivables biweekly.
McKesson began distributing drugs in 1833, by supplying the medicine chests of clipper ship captains. The company was nearly bankrupted in the 30's in a celebrated embezzlement case. In 1967, it was acquired by Foremost Dairies Inc. and became part of a mini-conglomerate involved in pasta production, chemicals recycling, home building, industrial real estate management and liquor distribution, as well as drugs and dairies.
Drug distribution re-emerged as the company's focus during the past decade, when it shed the Foremost name and 17 businesses that represented 60 percent of its sales in 1980. Last year, the drug business accounted for 83 percent of the company's revenues and about 60 percent of earnings. Analysts encourage the company to continue narrowing its focus by selling its 83 percent stake in Armor All and perhaps its water business.
McKesson disagrees, although it concedes that Armor All profits have plunged because of mismanagement, price competition from STP and the recession. But the unit still has a 75 percent market share. "Nothing would enhance shareholder value more at the moment than working to get it back on track," said Mr. Seelenfruend.
And the company is enthusiastic about the prospects for bottled water, which it markets door-to-door to 600 homes and offices, principally in the West, under the Alhambra name. Bottled water produces the highest profit margins in the company, and its consumption is growing far faster than other beverages.
A visit to the company's computer and communications center just east of Sacramento underscores why McKesson's core drug distribution business remains the analysts' favorite part of the company.
The six-year-old center handles up to 5,000 orders an hour at peak periods, and an average of 30,000 per day. Orders are entered electronically. Druggists walk their aisles with hand-held computers supplied by McKesson that allow them to compile their orders in a format reflecting the layout of their stores. To place an order, a druggist simply plugs the computer into the phone. The order travels directly to an A.T.&T. substation at the center via McKesson's satellite communications network.
The orders are processed in anywhere from 12 minutes to 55 minutes by the center's I.B.M. mainframe computers. The computers automatically route instructions for completing the order for next-day delivery to whichever of the 45 distribution centers is nearest the druggist. The system costs just 12.2 cents an order, down from 44 cents in the days when McKesson relied on more error-prone human operators.
The system proved its flexiblity by absorbing the addition of some 957 Wal-Mart stores over a single weekend in 1989, when McKesson took over the account from Foxmeyer Drug, a subsidiary of National Intergroup.
To further exploit such state-of-the-art communications, McKesson is investing in warehouse automation. Analysts say Bergen Brunswick is a step ahead in this area, having already installed two giant Austrian devices that automatically pick a high proportion of each order from storage bins at its largest distribution center. McKesson got diverted by an attempt to develop a huge system based on that used for parts handling by the National Aeronautics and Space Administration at Cape Canaveral.
"It turned out to be too expensive to make sense for all but the largest centers," said Eugene Dammel, manager of the West Sacramento, Calif., warehouse. "We want to be near the leading edge but not at the bleeding edge."
That philosophy explains McKesson's cautious drive to become the nation's first multinational drug distributor. McKesson's domestic growth is being hindered by antitrust rules that block it from buying major competitors. So last year, it purchased control of Canada's largest drug distribution firm and a 10 percent stake in a Dutch company. A Soviet invitation was declined; too risky, said one executive.
 
 
WHAT WENT AWRY AT PCS
 The McKesson Corporation and Thomas Field Jr., the company's former chief executive, have refused to explain their abrupt parting in 1989, but analysts believe a major strategic blunder by PCS Inc., the company's drug reimbursement subsidiary, played a major role.
PCS, acquired by McKesson in 1972, rapidly achieved market dominance in the new field of managing payments for prescription drugs covered by major health plans. PCS's clients are insurance companies and large self-insured companies like McDonald's. Anyone covered by such a plan is given a card to present to a participating druggist when filling a prescription. The card tells the druggist how much the insurer will cover; the consumer pays the difference. Typically, the insurance payment reflects a discount from the "average wholesale price," a nationally established benchmark.
Some 51,000 drugstores, more than 90 percent of all retail pharmacies, swallow the discount to get a share of the business of the 22 million PCS card users. They also benefit from prompt payment and instant access to PCS's warnings of potential conflicts in drug therapy or overuse when they process a consumer prescription.
In 1986, McKesson sold 14 percent of PCS to the public to capitalize on its rapid growth. Under Donald Dahlin, a former PCS president and a protege of Mr. Field's, PCS began to pursue new clients by offering plans that sharply cut reimbursement rates to druggists. The druggists angrily blamed their supplier, McKesson, for not halting the aggressive tactics of its subsidiary.
Mr. Dahlin left to join a competitor shortly before Mr. Field's departure. Last spring, McKesson recruited Robert Johnson, who was head of the California pharmacists' trade group, to replace Mr. Dahlin and paid $50 million to buy back the public shares of PCS. Since then, most of PCS's top management has been replaced and PCS has pursued a policy of cutting reimbursement levels only when forced to by competition.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Reaping Innovation From Recession . . . And the Recognition of Visionaries

BYLINE: By KARL D. LOOS; Karl D. Loos is a vice president of Arthur D. Little Inc.

 BODY:
Recently, I asked a random sampling of several dozen of my colleagues and business acquaintances for their thoughts about vision, visioning and what qualities they most identified with visionaries. By vision I mean the ability to correctly foresee the future and navigate successfully through it. I also asked them for their thoughts about putting those visions into action and about which leaders -- in general -- they most regard as visionaries. The results of my informal "poll" were enlightening:
* Although the men and women I polled were all in business, none of them cited a business leader or entrepreneur as a visionary. This, I believe, is quite a commentary on how people in business view their peers. 
 * Only three of the eight most frequently mentioned people on my respondents' lists are alive today: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, Mother Theresa and Lech Walesa. The other people most frequently cited were John F. Kennedy, Martin Luther King, Abraham Lincoln, Thomas Jefferson and Benjamin Franklin.
* Among the people I polled, not one listed a scientist, author or inventor. Their candidates were all in public policy, politics and social reform.
After reviewing these results, I decided to ask my colleagues specifically for visionaries in the business world. Again, the results were significant:
* More than half of the business visionaries mentioned were deceased: Ray Kroc, the founder of McDonald's; Thomas Watson Sr., the chief executive who built the International Business Machines Corporation, and Walt Disney.
* Of the living business visionaries who made it onto my respondents' lists, only one was in office: John Young, president and chairman of Hewlett-Packard. The other one, Reginald Jones, former chief executive of General Electric, is retired.
While those who participated in my survey had trouble naming people who are alive as visionaries, they did agree on the qualities that distinguish visionaries from the rest of us: courage, determination and the willingness to take risks.
I found this listing of qualities particularly interesting since it seems to me that the list of qualities my respondents most admire are those that are closely associated with leadership in business.
For example, in their book "Breakthroughs," P. Ranganath Nayack and John Ketteringham described a number of important innovations and how they were brought about. These innovations included the invention of microwave ovens, the development of the ulcer drug Tagamet, the marketing of 3M's Post-it Notes and the introduction of the Sony Walkman.
The authors concluded that elegance of concept, dogged persistence, serendipity and team management skills were critical success factors. Aside from serendipity and team management, these conclusions closely resembled the qualities my respondents agreed were visionary.
Why don't business people see themselves as visionaries? Partly, it is poor public relations. Business people have not been terribly good at telling the world how much they have contributed to it. They have not explained their story well.
But it is also due to the short-term orientation that today's managers must pursue. Visionaries, my respondents agree, are people who look beyond the next quarter. They take the long view and are willing to take risks and mortgage their careers. These are qualities my respondents admire. They are also qualities that, although in short supply, have changed the world.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Time to Curb the Weapon Makers

BYLINE: By WILLIAM D. HARTUNG; William D. Hartung is a senior research fellow at the World Policy Institute in New York City.

 BODY:
One of Saddam Hussein's most impressive "achievements" in the period leading up to Iraq's invasion of Kuwait was his ability to use financing and advanced technology from the United States and other countries to build up his arsenal. Our policymakers have much to answer for on this front.
In perhaps the most egregious case, Iraq is believed to have milked the American Government and some banks for $3 billion in unauthorized export credits. These credits, it is alleged, were raised by the Atlanta branch of Italy's Banca Nazionale del Lavoro. On Feb. 28, an indictment was issued by the United States Attorneys Office in Atlanta against the bank's manager and several Iraqi officials. More indictments are expected. 
 It is believed that these credits were used to buy chemicals, machine tools, high-speed electronic devices and other components for use in Iraq's nuclear, chemical and ballistic-missile programs. American intelligence agencies were apparently aware of this massive financing of the Iraqi war machine, but the loans were allowed to go on for more than two years before the attorney's office finally began investigating.
 Banks were not the only institutions aiding Iraq. Congressional investigators have revealed that between 1985 and 1990, the Department of Commerce granted licenses for the export to Iraq of $1.5 billion in "dual use" equipment -- items that can fashion metal for use in nuclear weapons, for exmaple -- with significant military applications.
Last but not least, for a good part of the 1980's, President Hussein's alleged front man, Sarkis Soghanalian, an arms dealer, is believed to have run an extensive military export operation to Iraq from his offices in Miami. Mr. Soghanalian has admitted that he supplied Iraq with everything from French howitzers to American transport helicopters. He claims to have done so with the knowledge and support of the State Department and the National Security Council. In 1987, Mr. Soghanalian was indicted for illegal arms dealing when he shipped military helicopters to Iraq without a license. This was after he had provided years of assistance to Iraq's military establishment.
The regulatory agencies that should have prevented these outrageous lapses in military export controls were evidently looking the other way. On the theory that Iran represented the greater danger to American interests in the Persian Gulf, Iraq was removed from the State Department's list of terrorist states, given access to billions of dollars in credits, and allowed unimpeded access to military-related financing and technology.
It remains to be seen whether American policymakers will be more cautious about swapping arms for political and military influence in the future. So far, the signals from the Bush Administration are mixed, with Secretary of State James A. Baker only grudgingly acknowledging that it would be worth looking at future arms sales.
Unfortunately, even the belated recognition of the value of arms-transfer controls has been totally contradicted by the rush to supply tens of billions of dollars worth of American arms exports to Saudi Arabia, Bahrain, Egypt, Israel, Turkey and other states in the gulf region to cement the anti-Iraq coalition and foster postwar "stability." Confidential Bush Administration estimates for the coming year put American arms sales worldwide at a record $33 billion -- $8 billion to $10 billion more than the next-best year.
This new round of military exports is driven by economic as well as strategic motivations. One Congressional aide dubbed last fall's $21 billion American arms offer to the Saudis as "the defense industry relief act of 1990," and for good reason. Three of the systems included in the original prosposal -- General Dynamics' M1 tank, Boeing's Awacs aircraft and McDonnel Douglas's F-15 fighter -- were slated for termination unless foreign customers could be found.
This traditional pork-barrel logic has been given added impetus by the determination among some Bush Administration officials and arms-industry insiders to seize on the success of American weapons in the gulf war as an opportunity to lock up a sizable portion of the Middle East arms market for decades. This would also knock competitors out of the arms business.
It is time to make a clean break from the bankrupt policy of pouring arms into the third world to prop up American allies of the moment against the enemy of the moment. As Saddam Hussein has so painfully demonstrated, continuing on this course could come back to haunt American policymakers down the road.

HEADLINE: A Wrong Technology At a Wrong Site

 BODY:
It is unbelievable to me that our County Administration has spent $1.8 million to study a long-term land-based sludge-management system, required under the terms of a 1989 consent decree, only to come up with a plan that selects the wrong technology at the wrong site at the wrong time ["County to Reasses a Plan to Burn Its Sludge," March 3].
To select incineration over composting is environmentally unsound, expensive and inefficient. The New York State Department of Environmental Conservation's hierarchy of preferred solid-waste management methods, designed to reduce dependency on land burial of wastes, ranks compostings above incineration in the state Solid Waste Management Plan. Incineration with recovery of energy from the solid waste is only to be used on solid waste that cannot be recycled. This sludge, however, can be recycled.
Further, there is no plan to recover any energy from this proposed incineration process and the proposed process will still need a landfill site for the disposal of residue ash. This proposal circumvents the goal, the spirit and the letter of the Solid Waste Management Plan. Westchester's long-term land-based sludge management system should be redesigned as an in-vessel composting process, along the lines of New York City's plan, with a "fair share" given to each community of origin.
The Yonkers Joint Treatment Plant treats 65 percent of the county's waste, which comes from 26 local municipalities, serves a population of over 400,000 people and encompasses hundreds of square miles. This facility has been disposing of its sludge outside of its environs by ocean dumping since its inception.
Why did the county prepare a countywide siting study for this disposal facility rather than one within its catchment basin? Why didn't the administration look to locate disposal sites within the treatment area? How could anyone possibly select a community such as Peekskill, which is less than four square miles and has a population of less than 20,000, that has its own sewage-treatment plan and isn't in the catchment area?
Why weren't actual tests taken to consider the cumulative impact on the air quality in the Peekskill/Cortlandt area of imposing another unwanted and environmentally questionable project? We are host to nuclear power plants, the Resco incinerator, the Sprout Brook Ash Pit, the Croton Point landfill, a hazardous dump at the Harmon Railroad Yard, a low-level radioactive site designated by New York State, pollutants from the Lovett Power Plant across the Hudson and numerous industries. A cumulative health-assessment study must be prepared before this project can be evaluated by the County Board of Legislators.
The environmental-impact statement glosses over the need for 500,000-plus gallons of water a day by the proposed sludge plan and points out that the "Resco Facility at Charles Point is reported to cause a drop in water pressure in the city of Peekskill." It goes on to state that "there are no measures recommended to mitigate the facility's consumption of processed water."
How does the county administration expect Peekskill to fight a fire with low water pressure? Is the bureaucracy aware that Peekskill's water system is trying to develop a plan just to meet the start-up needs of Resco after a boiler shutdown? And, if it is, how does it intend to get processed water?
In 1981 the county canceled a contract with Peekskill to develop sludge-burning at Charles Point. My understanding of this contract is that it allowed the county to make no use of this site unless it is agreed to by both parties. How is the administration planning on using a piece of property over which it has given away control, and for a use which is opposed by the city of Peekskill? The county has selected the only site that the county, by contract, cannot build on.
How is it that New York City, that bureaucratic nightmare of a government, could produce a more environmentally sound, fairer and more efficient plan than Westchester in a shorter period of time? How is it that New York City's plan allowed four months for public comment and ours less than four weeks? How is it that the administration never found the time to give Peekskill's city administration a chance to take part in the selection process? How is it that our consultants could put this enivironmental-impact statement together in only three-and-a-half weeks?
Is it because the administration thinks the March 1 deadline was a gun at the head of every county legislator and that we could be forced to adopt this proposal rather than pay the fines? If it is, they have overestimated their position.
This plan is tragically flawed. It is environmentally unsound and technologically inefficient. It is on a site the county cannot build on, designed outside state guidelines and unfairly placed beyond the catchment area. Finally, and most tellingly, it stinks of the type of social-economic steering that the present administration has been charged with before.
 
TIMOTHY S. CAREY
County Legislator
First District

HEADLINE: Search Is On for Next U.N. Secretary General

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 15

 BODY:
The job pays $183,000 a year and brings a chauffeur-driven Volvo limousine, a mansion on Sutton Place and a role in shaping a new world order.
It has been described by one incumbent as "the most impossible, daunting, challenging, rewarding, fascinating, clearly unique job on earth." 
 There is no shortage of hopefuls to succeed Javier Perez de Cuellar as Secretary General of the United Nations when the 71-year-old former Peruvian diplomat steps down at the end of this year, as he has repeatedly said he would after serving two five-year terms.
The merits of at least a dozen possible candidates are being debated by diplomats here and in national capitals, including the Norwegian Prime Minister, Gro Harlem Brundtland; Prince Sadruddin Aga Khan of Pakistan, recently coordinator for gulf and Afghan refugee relief; Lieut. Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo, a former President of Nigeria, and the Indonesian Foreign Minister, Ali Alatas.
But, for the first time, many countries are pressing for the next Secretary General to be selected in a more open way, saying the 15-member Security Council should search worldwide for the best candidate available.
This would be quite a change. In the past the decision has usually come as aback-room political deal among the United States, Britain, France, the Soviet Union and China, the five permanent members with a veto on the decision.
"A study of how the five Secretaries General since 1949 were appointed," a recent Ford Foundation study of the office said, "creates two main impressions -- its last-minute and unpredictable nature, and the increasingly parochial level at which the matter is considered by member states."The pressure for change reflects a belief that with the cold war over, the United Nations now has a real chance to function better, but that whether it reaches its potential may depend on who is chosen to run the organization for the next five years.
Calling for reform of what it termed the "present haphazard and predominantly political process" of choosing the Secretary General, the Ford Foundation study argued that the United Nations must adapt to changing world circumstances or become irrelevant, saying "effective leadership will be crucial to this transition."
Over the last few months, a somewhat shifting group of diplomats has been reviewing the choice process and trying to agree on the characteristics of the next Secretary General.
The discussions have yielded a broad consensus on several points, participants say. The next Secretary General should have high-level experience in both the political and economic fields, be a proven manager able to organize and motivate a staff of 14,000, speak English and French well, and exhibit personal appeal and an ability to communicate with news organizations.
In addition, many would like to see the Security Council extract a pledge from the successful candidate to reorganize the United Nations' unwieldy bureaucracy.
"Never before has the whole issue of the appointment been discussed so openly in advance," said Olara Otunnu, a former Ugandan representative at the United Nations, who is mentioned as a possible candidate.
African countries are claiming the job, complaining that Africa is the only region of the world that has never filled the post.
The United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France say they are ready to appoint an African, but, as a matter of principle, they oppose rotating the job on a geographic basis. China thinks it is Africa's turn.
Two Africans have declared their candidacy with backing from their Governments -- Kenneth Dadzie, the Ghanaian head of the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development, and the Zimbabwean Finance Minister, Bernard Chidzero. Other possible African candidates are General Obasanjo, Mr. Otunnu, President Abdou Diouf of Senegal, James B. Jonah, a senior Sierra Leone official of the United Nations and Salim A. Salim, the Tanzanian Secretary General of the Organization of African Unity.

HEADLINE: Groups Help Each Other Help the Mentally Ill

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Last year Robert McDonald, a 44-year-old former systems analyst from Kansas, was in a downward spiral. Suffering from severe depression, he lost his job and his house and was living on the streets in Los Angeles.
 Now he has a permanent address and a job driving a van. 
 His descent into homelessness was checked by the housing project where he has lived since August. Camerford, a restored five-bedroom house in West Hollywood, is one of a growing number of grass-roots projects around the nation that provide not only shelter but also psychiatric treatment -- an idea that is now being copied by the Federal Government.
Camerford, which Mr. McDonald shares with four other people, was jointly developed by the Community of Friends, a local nonprofit development organization, and Portals, a mental health agency. There is no estimate of the number of such projects nationwide, but a recent survey of 10 cities found more than 60 organizations providing housing enhanced by social services.
"In New York alone there are at least 20 projects in the pipeline," said Julie Sandorf, president of the organization that conducted the survey, the Corporation for Supportive Housing. The national organization, based in New York, provides financial and technical assistance for such endeavors.
 
Helping the Most Vulnerable
 The Federal Government plans to replicate this model in a new pilot program consisting of six housing projects for homeless people who suffer from severe mental illness. The projects -- two in New York City and one each in Boston, San Diego, Baltimore and Cincinnati -- will be financed by the Department of Health and Human Services and the Department of Housing and Urban Development.
"This collaborative project between the two departments shows that it is possible to be innovative in our approach to helping the most vulnerable of homeless people, those who are mentally ill," said Dr. Frederick K. Goodwin, administrator of the Alcohol, Drug Abuse and Mental Health Administration.
This kind of collaboration is not only for the mentally ill. The Victims Services Agency, an advocacy group in New York, helped develop the first permanent housing for battered women in Brooklyn.
But Liz Rosenbaum, director of Urban Initiatives in Stamford, Conn., a technical consulting firm for developers of housing projects, says that for every successful project there are 10 to 20 that are never completed. "These are not easy deals to pull off," she said.
The main reason is financing. Because many sponsoring organizations are small nonprofit groups, most deals require four or five sources of funds.
 
Promoting Self-Sufficiency
 Under the 1987 Federal law that provides money for housing the homeless, funds are available only for temporary housing. Finally, few private nonprofit organizations have the staff and administrative capacity needed to develop housing enhanced by social services.
One of the challenges of this kind of housing is to foster self-sufficiency. Take the case of Mr. McDonald. He was supplied with his job driving a van for Portals, the mental health agency that helped develop the Camerford project, and he is given daily supervision for tasks like balancing his budget and food shopping. The goal is to help him function successfully on his own.
Developers of low-income housing and social services organizations say they need each other to achieve this goal of self-sufficiency. The service groups say that without housing they can do very little to stabilize the lives of their clients, and developers say that without social services their projects are likely to fail.
"It used to be that the problem was just being able to afford a place," said Jean Butzen, executive director of the Lakeside Single Resident Occupancy housing project in Chicago. "Now, with drug addiction and abuse so widespread, it is much more complicated. The amount of services needed is so large that we cannot fund them all."

HEADLINE: Sideshow to Soviet Votes: Gorbachev vs. Yeltsin

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 16

 BODY:
Soviet voters will take on the cacophonous political disarray of their country Sunday as they cast ballots on President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's referendum on the nation's future.
And, in a significant aside, they will also decide whether to create a powerful new populist vehicle for his chief rival, Boris N. Yeltsin, President of the Russian republic. 
 The basic referendum question is whether to approve Mr. Gorbachev's general approach to protecting a "renewed" national union from the many separatist pressures sweeping the troubled nation, suffering not only from political confusion, but also from a staggering economy.
But in the referendum process, many of the union's separatist republics and localities have defied Mr. Gorbachev by adding ballot questions. In the most important of those, voters in Russia, the largest and most influential part of the nation, face a question they seem likely to approve: whether to inaugurate direct popular election of their republic's President.
 
New Level of Populist Power

To do so would create a fresh and probably secure opportunity for Russia's favorite politician, Mr. Yeltsin, to attain a new level of populist heartland power far beyond that enjoyed by Mr. Gorbachev, who chose last year to avoid the risks of popular election to the larger office of union Presidency. If he were eventually to be directly elected, Mr. Yeltsin's supporters would be able to say that their man was chosen President of Russia by voters in the largest republic in the nation, while Mr. Gorbachev was chosen President of the entire nation only by the national legislature dominated by his loyalists.
Final results are expected to be slow in emerging. But the chief outcome, according to some estimates, are that Mr. Gorbachev might win a somewhat half-hearted approval of his amorphous ballot question defending the simple idea of national unity, while Mr. Yeltsin gets a far more politically attractive mandate with which to maintain his basic criticism that Mr. Gorbachev should now resign because he has failed to uproot the endemic ills of Communism.
Thus, a voting day initially planned by Mr. Gorbachev as a simple means to tap some badly needed popular support for his flagging program of national renewal has grown instead into a juggernaut bristling with separatist ambitions.
Only four of the 15 republics -- Byelorussia, Kirghizia, Tadzhikistan and Turkmenia -- have agreed to hold the referendum precisely as Mr. Gorbachev wants.
 
Boycotts and Partial Boycotts

Six of the rest -- Lithuania, Latvia, Estonia, Moldavia, Georgia and Armenia -- have called for an outright boycott.
The other five -- Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan, Russia, the Ukraine and Uzbekistan -- have qualified Mr. Gorbachev's wording or crafted additional questions to favor greater sovereignty for the republics.
To further blur the political Rorschach, an assortment of sovereignty-minded cities and regions have scheduled their own partial boycotts and non-boycotts, depending on their nationalist proclivities, and also have added a welter of additional local ballot questions.
Those range from the question of beginning popular election of the Mayor here in insurgent-minded Moscow, to the ballot option far to the east in the Kamchatka peninsula of whether that Pacific enclave, until recently a closed, top-secret military region, wants to reclose the area voluntarily because of the already noisome tide of Soviet travelers looking there for opportunities.
 
50% Turnout Needed

To be valid, at least 50 percent of the nation's voters, estimated at 192 million, must take part, with a majority of them, in turn, settling the issue. Mr. Yeltsin has roundly criticized Mr. Gorbachev's referendum for ignoring the practical detail of how greater democracy might be guaranteed in a renewed union.
But the Russian republic leader has declined to explicitly recommend a "No" vote, presumably so no rival can accuse him of trying to bring down the union. At the same time, his Russian ballot question for direct Presidential election is likely to attract extra voters and indirectly help Mr. Gorbachev toward the 50 percent turnout he needs for a valid referendum.
The national referendum question reads: "Do you consider it necessary to preserve the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics as a renewed federation of equal sovereign republics, in which human rights and the freedom of people of all nationalities will be fully guaranteed?"
This nation is so tense with political dispute as its economy and morale continue to sag that such key words as "Soviet" and "Socialist," not to mention "sovereign" set off furious debate. Contrary guidance abounds, with some democratic critics urging that both the main referendum's two options -- Yes and No -- be crossed out as a protest.
 
Nationalist Minorities
 The mathematics of the voting are intricate and confusing, with various spirited nationalist minorities voting as enclaves within some of the boycotting republics. Notably there are the hard-pressed Ossetians in Georgia and Gagauz in Moldavia, as well as the many voters of Russian stock in the Baltics, where nationalist governments already have held plebiscites establishing the majorities' wish for independence from the Kremlin.
Only a few years into being afforded semi-democratic options -- including openly contested local and regional elections -- after seven decades of pure Communist monolith, the voters will be grappling with their most confusing ballot thus far.
"Our 'Yes' guarantees that never again will the flame of war scorch our land that has already gone through trials enough," Mr. Gorbachev said in a TV appeal Friday.
Mr. Yeltsin and other critics, handicapped by being denied equal opportunity on the Kremlin-controlled television networks, say the simple question of merely maintaining a somehow "renewed" union is a distraction from the critical issue of how much power the Kremlin must surrender to the republics to finally make this a nation rooted in the consent of the governed.
 
Struggle of 2 Presidents

As sprawling as the ballot is across the land, the shadow struggle between the two Presidents, Mr. Yeltsin of Russia and Mr. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, remains the underlying attraction. Mr. Yeltsin, caught off base with an emotional call for a political "war" on the Kremlin, has been getting his share of abuse as an alleged political schemer rather than a true reformer.
In one recent telephone call-in interview, he found his usual popular majority of supporters, but also an acid-tongued doubter upbraiding Mr. Yeltsin thusly: "Boris Nikolaivich, when will you die a dog's death?"
"Oh, I still have plenty of things first to be done," he replied amiably, insisting the voters should consider the referendum important but not apocalyptic.

Adding questions to referendum
 
Russians will also be asked: "Do you think it useful to create the post of president to be elected by popular vote?"
 
In Azerbaijan, people will be asked: "Do you think it useful for Azerbaijan to further participate in a Union of Sovereign States as a Sovereign State?"
 
Ukrainians will vote on two ballots: the U.S.S.R. referendum, and "Ukraine is supposed to be in a Union of Soviet Sovereign States on the basis of the Declaration of Sovereignty." Three regions of Western Ukraine have added a third ballot: "Do you want Ukraine to become an independent state?"
 
Uzbekistan will ask its people whether they want "to belong to a new Union."
 
 
Others
 
Kazakhstan will not answer the USSR referendum question. Its citizens will instead answer the following question: "Do you think it necessary to maintain the U.S.S.R. as a Union of sovereign states?"

HEADLINE: Higher Job Loss Forecast in New York Region

BYLINE: By RICHARD LEVINE

 BODY:
Two new economic forecasts predict that the New York metropolitan region, already faltering, will lose tens of thousands of jobs this year, but disagree over the extent of the losses and the timing of a revival.
The Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, in an analysis released last week, said that the region might lose more than 70,000 jobs in 1991, with New York City accounting for 40,000, the New York suburbs 9,000 and northern New Jersey 24,000. 
 But Rosemary Scanlon, the authority's chief economist, said the agency expected the slump that began in 1989 to end toward the end of this year, assuming the national economy strengthens by midyear. Suburban counties would be the first to show signs of revival, she said, since they more closely parallel the national economy.
In a gloomier forecast released last month, Matthew P. Drennan, a professor at the Robert F. Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University, predicted that the region would lose 128,000 jobs this year, 71,000 in the city. Mr. Drennan said that he expected a turnaround in 1992, but that the New York and northern New Jersey region and the city would still end next year with losses of 28,000 and 26,000 jobs, respectively.
Both economists said that job growth, whenever it resumed, would be much slower than in the 1980's. Mr. Drennan projected that by 1995 the region would have 40,000 more jobs than in 1990, but that the city's total would decline by 51,000.
Mr. Drennan said he was surprised by the extent of the job losses in his forecast. He attributed the depth of the slump and the modest growth envisioned after it to a weak national economy, New York's slumping financial services industry, a long real-estate boom that left the city with a surplus of space and little need for new construction, slower growth in the health-care industry and in social services and a decline in local government employment.
Still, he said he expected a continual upgrading of employment opportunities in Manhattan, resulting in a higher percentage of jobs requiring more skills and paying higher salaries. The consolidation of the European economic community in 1992, he said, could help New York's service and financial industries.
"After 1992, the city's economy will be in good shape," Mr. Drennan said.
In the last year, the Port Authority said, the region lost 105,000 jobs, 44,500 in the city and 41,400 in northern New Jersey. Construction starts in the region dropped by 28 percent, compared with an 11 percent decline in the nation. Retail sales rose just 0.9 percent in the region and fell 1.4 percent in the city.
But the authority said increases in travel and international trade in goods and services could provide opportunities for growth in the 1990's.
 
Difficult to Predict
 The two forecasts were based on different analytic methods. Mr. Drennan used a computer model with 250 equations involving 53 industries. The Port Authority analyzed a range of forecasts for the national and international economies, then interpreted the effects locally using its own historical data.
Ms. Scanlon noted another difference: The Port Authority's forecast was completed after the end of the Persian Gulf war, while Mr. Drennan's was compiled earlier.The different conclusions are hardly surprising, given that New York's economy has proven difficult to predict. After the stock market plunge in 1987, for instance, Mr. Drennan projected a drop of 70,000 jobs in the city by end of 1988. The losses materialized, but not for years.
But Mr. Drennan said his model did enable him to predict the city's turnaround in the late 70's, an event missed by many forecasters.
"To some degree, economic science is very helpful," Ms. Scanlon said. But she added, "To get a turnaround is almost as much an art as a science."

HEADLINE: For Foes of Gulf War, Nation's Victory Is Bitter

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
Despite the nation's euphoria over the allied victory in the Persian Gulf, the war's hard-core opponents in the United States -- the small group against military action of any kind -- remain implacable.
They say they worry that the outcome will embolden the United States to resort to further military force to solve other international problems and will also result in increased military spending by Congress at the expense of social programs. 
 The swiftness and completeness of the victory over Iraqi forces, at minimal losses to allied forces, prompted few if any second thoughts among the war's opponents, and they continue to argue that economic sanctions and diplomacy would eventually have accomplished the same goal, with no loss of life and no destruction, particularly the costly Iraqi losses.
"This is one victory I'm not celebrating," said Margaret Hummel, a community organizer from Underhill, Vt., who was so opposed to the war that she journeyed almost 600 miles to Washington to take part in a protest.
 
Different Kind of Defeat Seen
 "This was a severe defeat for the international community," she added. "I was appalled at the death of so many Iraqis. Sanctions and diplomacy could have eventually forced them to leave Kuwait. Now I fear that war will be more and more accepted as a way to solve our problems and that we'll spend more and more money on the military instead of on problems at home that are more pressing."
Ms. Hummel's comments were echoed in postwar interviews with other Americans who earlier had voiced opposition to the war.
"The truth is, I worry more now that the war is over than I did before it started," said Marian Solomon, a public health nurse from Ames, Iowa. "We came off as an impatient bully. We should mind our own business, especially at home. Where will we intervene next? How many more will die?"
Brenda Reed, a writer who was active in the antiwar movement in Oakland, Calif., says the war reinforced the "mistaken notion" by Americans that they can police the world.
 
Hopes for Alternatives
 "I didn't believe that before the war began and I still don't, absolutely," she said. "Now, more than ever, we have to turn to diplomacy and arms control and a sane energy policy to solve the problems in the Middle East."
Some leaders of the antiwar movement, which precipitously lost strength as the gulf conflict progressed, say they will continue to be involved in Middle East and military issues.
"We intend to stay organized so that we can focus attention on this country's neglected social problems," said Bonnie Garvin, a coordinator of the ad hoc National Campaign for Peace in the Middle East, based in New York. "There's outrage that we could find enough money for a war we didn't need to fight but not enough money for peace at home. The puffed-up chests that are now everywhere will deflate in time when people finally realize that we're still not any safer in this world."
The Rev. McKinley Young, an Atlanta pastor who helped black churches in the South form an antiwar movement during the gulf crisis, hopes to redirect their antiwar fervor.
"If this nation can demonstrate so much international war power," he said, "then it can also demonstrate peace power and the ability to solve national problems. A nation willing to depend upon thousands and thousands of black soldiers to help it fight its wars should be able to pass meaningful civil rights laws."
 
Inquiry on U.S. Tactics
 At least one antiwar group, the National Coalition to Stop United States Intervention in the Middle East, based in New York, not only still believes its opposition to the war was correct but is also investigating the military tactics used by the United States.
"We're looking into the possibility of war crimes by the U.S., whether civilians were targeted for bombing," said Brian Becker, a coalition official. "If so, the Iraqi attrocities pale in comparison. We may hold a tribunal, the same way that some antiwar groups did during Vietnam."
Before United States forces went into combat in mid-January, polls indicated that Americans were almost evenly divided over whether to commence the fighting or give sanctions and diplomacy more time to work. After the air attacks began on Jan. 17, support for sanctions and diplomacy dropped to about 15 percent, with most of the holdouts saying they either opposed wars in general or believed United States military involvement in the gulf was not in the national interest.
In interviews, many people who switched and came to approve military action said they had never ruled out that possibility, feeling that Iraq had to be pushed out of Kuwait.
 
Switched to Back Bush
 They explained that they worried about the possibility of another drawn out conflict like Vietnam and generally believed in giving sanctions and diplomacy time to work. But once the war started, they added, they viewed the timing question as moot and sided with President Bush, though some continued to worry about the possibility of becoming bogged down in another foreign conflict with many casualties.
"I was skeptical when it all started, especially because it was not clear to me what the Bush Administration wanted to accomplish, and why," said J. Michael Cassell, a public prosecutor in Charles Town, W.Va. "But I didn't really rule out an eventual military solution. I just knew it had to be quick, not another Vietnam. It was, thank God. Now the job is to preserve and strengthen the peace."
Like Mr. Cassell, Nellie Cutchins of Virginia Beach, also had initial doubts about United States involvement in the gulf.
"But once the war got started, I went along with it," said Ms. Cutchins, a cleaning woman. "I was just hoping right up to the end that there would be some other way to get Saddam Hussein out of there. You do what you have to do and pray for the best."
Like their constituents, many members of Congress initially opposed quick military action, voting in favor of giving sanctions and diplomacy more time to work. But once the war started, most backed the President.
Early polls indicate some lawmakers may suffer politically from their initial opposition. But few, if any, are backing away from their vote.
"I don't regret it," said Senator Paul Wellstone, a Minnesota Democrat who was an outspoken opponent of quick military intervention. "I voted my conscience. The flip side would be not to do what I believe in. Going to war is the last alternative."

HEADLINE: Channelview Journal;
Love, Ambition and the Price for a Child's Success

BYLINE: By ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHANNELVIEW, Tex., March 15

 BODY:
The azaleas and jasmine have bloomed across the Sterling Green subdivision here, and in two nearly identical houses around the corner from each other, two mothers have resumed their routines of car pools and trips to the mall.
They show no signs that they are the suspect and intended victim of a purported murder plot born of big envies and small ambitions. 
 The police say Wanda Webb Holloway, the organist at the Channelview Missionary Baptist Church, tried to arrange the murder of her neighbor, Verna Heath, in an effort to influence a cheerleading contest involving their daughters, Shanna Harper and Amber Heath.
Mrs. Holloway's objective, the police say, was to cause Amber so much emotional grief that she would not be a threat to Shanna in the rigorous competition for slots on next year's freshman cheerleading squad at Channelview High School.
Shanna, 13 years old, has always been an avid participant in cheerleading competitions and in many other contests intended to measure the mettle of Channelview's children. Over the years Amber has not only been her friend but also her chief rival, and Mrs. Holloway was determined, the police say, to bring that rivalry to a decisive conclusion.
A grand jury indicted Mrs. Holloway on Feb. 19 after it heard tape recordings of what the police say are conversations she had with an informer -- Mrs. Holloway's former brother-in-law, who notified the police after she asked him for help in finding a killer -- and an undercover detective posing as the killer for hire. She faces life in prison if convicted.
"She was cold, calculating and persistent about her intentions over an extended period of time," said Lieut. Charles Shaffer of the Harris County Organized Crime Task Force, which handled the investigation.
At first Mrs. Holloway discussed a contract for the killing of both Amber and her mother, Lieutenant Shaffer said, but Mrs. Holloway, who is divorced and unemployed, balked at the asking price of $7,500. The indictment charges that she offered a pair of diamond earrings as a down payment on the $2,500 cost of killing Mrs. Heath.
Mrs. Holloway has pleaded not guilty to the charges. She refuses to comment on the allegations, and her lawyers say they will not address the matter publicly except at her trial, which is scheduled for June in Houston, about 15 miles west of here.
The automotive life style of the suburbs assures that the two mothers, who live just a few dozen yards apart, can go for months without meeting, but Shanna and Amber, so similar in their talents and aspirations, are constantly thrown together. For example, Amber is president and Shanna is vice president of the student council at Alice Johnson Junior High School, where they are both eighth graders.
Just two days after the indictment was issued, both girls were inducted into the school's honor society. As so often before, the alphabet dictated that they stand beside each other and appear on stage one after another, Harper then Heath.
In Sterling Green, like many other subdivisions, tall wooden "privacy fences" seal in the sides and back of each family's little green domain, allowing the family to work out all manner of sins and crises in private, subject to gossip, perhaps, though not exposure. But Mrs. Holloway's notoriety has changed that.
Television trucks have begun invading the neighborhood. Children have gathered behind the journalists doing their on-camera reports, but the adults have mostly remained indoors.
"We are all guilty of standing back and watching what has been happening to her," said James M. Barker, the school principal, "because all of us -- anyone who is a parent -- can identify with her, at least to the extent that we all push our children to compete, that we all want our children to succeed."
Both Mrs. Holloway and Mrs. Heath, who was a high school baton twirling champion, demonstrated considerable zeal in promoting their daughters, Mr. Barker said, but Mrs. Holloway usually seemed ready to go an extra step.
Two years ago she tried unsuccessfully to get Amber disqualified from the cheerleading competition by invoking a technicality in the rules. Last year she showed up at school the day students were voting on cheerleader candidates and handed out pencils and rulers bearing the slogan "Shanna Harper Cheerleader." But as a result of her mother's action, Shanna was disqualified.
This year Mrs. Holloway hired professional coaches to prepare her daughter for the cheerleading competition, but in the end Shanna did not enter it. The deadline was the day after her mother was arrested.
Last week Mrs. Holloway's former husband, Tony Harper, won an agreement in the Houston Family Law Center that granted him an expanded custody of Shanna and her brother, 17-year-old Shane, in which they spend more time with him.
Paula Gavrel Asher, the lawyer who represented Mr. Harper, said, "The mother and daughter had developed a symbiotic relationship, an extreme form of emotional interdependence. It was like the child was in a cult."
Mrs. Holloway has been divorced for 11 years, and in that time virtually her only activities have been raising her children and going to church, which she did several times a week, the police and others familiar with her habits say.
"She was living her life through Shanna," Mrs. Asher said. "Shanna's achievements were all she had, and it had become an obsession."
Almost all murders for hire fall into one of two categories, Lieutenant Shaffer said.
"It's usually either money or love when someone goes out and solicits a murder," he said. "This case has its bizarre twists, but it basically fits the pattern.
"The motive here was love, a mother's love for a daughter."

She received cheerleading training from professional coaches, but in the end did not enter the contest for next year's freshman cheerleading squad at Channelview High School.
