HEADLINE: In Brooklyn, Wontons, Not Lapskaus

BYLINE: By ANDREW L. YARROW

 BODY:
The signs of social change and the transformation of a community are often subtle, sometimes brutal and occasionally bizarre.
Into this last category falls the former Atlantic restaurant, a popular diner that for decades catered to the many Norwegian-Americans of the Sunset Park and Bay Ridge sections of Brooklyn. Today, above the entrance on Eighth Avenue and 54th Street, a bright red-and-yellow sign proclaims "WeeKee's." And in one of New York's strangest ethnically hyphenated amalgams, the menu now describes the cuisine as "Chinese-Norwegian-American." 
 The Chinese and Norwegian waitresses alternate between serving dumplings and wonton soup and fish pudding and stekte middagspolser, or fried sausage. Bjorg Nilsen, who has worked at the restaurant for years, meekly and unconvincingly defended the Atlantic's transformation: "It's good that people can order different things now."
For years, the Atlantic was the hub of a stretch of Eighth Avenue between 45th and 60th Streets that was dotted with dozens of Norwegian bars, bakeries and restaurants. But in the 1980's, as Chinese and Arab immigrants moved in, Chinese restaurants and meat markets supplanted almost all the Norwegian businesses along a street that was popularly known as Lapskaus Boulevard, a reference to a meat-and-potato stew that was a staple of the Norwegian worker's diet.
 
Strangers in Their Own Haunts
 Olsen's, a bakery a few blocks down the avenue, still features apple crumb squares and fyrste kaker, an almond cake, as it has for the last half century. But Edith Reinertsen, a longtime customer, said: "It's sad. We feel out of place, like strangers here. There used to be two or three Norwegian bars and bakeries on each block. Now there are two or three Chinese restaurants on a block."
Another sign of the Norwegian-American community's decline is the flagging fortune of The Norway Times, which is marking its 100th anniversary this winter. There is little to celebrate in the paper's crowded five-room office at 81st Street and Fifth Avenue in Bay Ridge, and among its dwindling readership, there is sadness that the area's Norwegian community is on the verge of extinction.
"The situation of the paper mirrors that of the Norwegian community," said Toralv Ostvang, the paper's editor in chief, who was recruited from Oslo last fall to breathe life into the weekly paper by making it a national publication. "The population is steadily diminishing. I guess it will eventually assimilate and vanish, because many who still live here are older, their children have moved out of Brooklyn and there's no more Norwegian immigration."
A few Bay Ridge churches, like the 59th Street and Trinity Lutheran Churches, still conduct services in Norwegian. The annual Norwegian Constitution Day parade is still held every May 17, making its way along Fifth Avenue to Leif Ericson Park, where Miss Norway is crowned. A Scandinavian food shop is flourishing.
 
From 100 Papers, Only 2
 But The Times is the most prominent vestige of a community settled by tens of thousands of Norwegians and other Scandinavians who emigrated because of crop failures in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. Although many immigrant farmers moved west to Minnesota and the Dakotas, others, especially sailors like those who founded the Norwegian Seamen's Church in 1878 near the docks of Red Hook, stayed in New York, eventually gravitating toward this southwestern Brooklyn neighborhood.
More than 100 Norwegian newspapers were started in America, Mr. Ostvang said, but today his paper and The Western Viking, based in Seattle, are the only survivors. Circulation for The Norway Times has fallen to about 5,000 now, from more than 20,000 in the 1940's, and that slide was only arrested somewhat by the decision of the paper's new Oslo-based owners in 1983 to switch the Norwegian-language publication to one in which 80 percent of its articles are in English. In small letters on the front page and masthead, the paper still identifies itself as Nordisk Tidende.
Mr. Ostvang, a 39-year-old journalist who relished the opportunity to spend a few years in America, has tried to build national circulation by hiring freelance writers, particularly in the Midwest, to cover everything from the re-election of George S. Mickelson, the Norwegian-American who is Governor of South Dakota, to the Uff Da gift shop in Red Wing, Minn. Circulation has increased by 10 percent since September, and half of the paper's readers are now outside New York, he said.
As The Times's only newsroom employee, Mr. Ostvang reports Norwegian political and economic news that he gathers from shortwave-radio broadcasts, facsimile messages from friends in Norway and news summaries from the Norwegian Foreign Ministry. Articles appealing to the Norwegian business community in Manhattan, like one on the prospects for Norwegian companies to capitalize on the growing American demand for environmental-technology products, are increasingly played up, while tidbits of local news like the 80th anniversary celebration of Brooklyn's Sporting Club Gjoa are given shorter shrift.
Perhaps the most upbeat local story is the success of Fredericksen & Johannesen, a Scandinavian food emporium just a few blocks from The Times's office. Pungent smoked hams and legs of lamb hang from the ceiling, wheels of Nokkelost and Norvegia cheese and homemade sausages beckon at the deli counter and shelves are brimming with condiments, candies, caviar and ubiquitous cans of fishballs.
The store, which dates to the 1940's, was bought in 1986 by Stephen Postler, a young Norwegian-American investor and entrepreneur. To attract customers, he got a J. C. Penney catalogue franchise and aggressively developed a national Scandinavian food mail-order business.
In five years, he has increased sales by 150 percent, although he noted, with a mixture of pride and wistfulness, "Everyone who calls to order on our 800 number from around the country says they used to live in Brooklyn."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Baker Ready to Test Plans for Arab-Israeli Peace

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, March 16

 BODY:
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that his talks with Arab and Israeli leaders had encouraged him to begin presenting specific peace proposals next week to see if the leaders are as interested in reconciliation as they say.
In talks in Moscow on the future of Iraq, however, Mr. Baker left a meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Friday with the impression that Moscow and Washington have significant differences, reporters traveling with Mr. Baker were told. 
 American officials said the differences -- on when to lift the economic sanctions against Baghdad and what conditions should be imposed on Iraq for a formal cease-fire -- are likely to become apparent when the cease-fire is debated in the United Nations Security Council as early as next week.
Mr. Baker, speaking to reporters at the end of a 10-day trip to explore the possibilities for an Arab-Israeli settlement, said that he planned to speak by telephone with Middle Eastern leaders next week to elicit answers to specific questions he posed during his trip.
 
Telephone Diplomacy

"We will be following up primarily on the telephone," Mr. Baker said, as he flew from Moscow to Turkey for talks with President Turgut Ozal. "Now you are going to ask me who and when and where, and I can't get into that. In some case we will be asking them: What do you think about . . .? How does the following strike you? Suppose we were willing to get X to do Y. Would you be willing to do Z?"
On his trip, Mr. Baker spoke with foreign ministers or heads of state from Saudi Arabia, Syria, Egypt, Israel, Kuwait, Qatar, the United Arab Emirates, Oman, Bahrain, Lebanon and the Soviet Union. He also met with Palestinian leaders in Jerusalem.
Although he has not disclosed specific proposals he raised or the ideas the countries put to him, he has indicated that the first steps would be simultaneous confidence-building gestures.
For instance, Israel might be asked to reopen closed Palestinian universities in the occupied territories, or to halt the building of new settlements, or to commit itself to one day considering trading land for peace, in return for Palestinian and Arab gestures to end their state of belligerency and their boycott of Israel.
 
Foundation Is Gelling

"From the discussions we have had on this trip I have gotten the distinct impression and sense that the parties to the conflict really want true reconciliation and really want to make an active effort for peace," Mr. Baker said. "While we have to recognize that we have a long way to go, I am pleased that the foundation has gelled as quickly as it has."
But Mr. Baker added: "Now, whether that sense and impression turns out to be correct, we will have to wait and see when we test it. And that is what we are going to do in the weeks ahead -- test it -- by putting specific ideas and proposals to them to see whether or not old, rigid stereotypes can be broken, adjusted and compromised, because without that there won't be peace."
The basis for Mr. Baker's optimism was not clear. Throughout the visit he met alone with each official, with only his policy planning staff director, Dennis Ross, as his notetaker. Clearly, Arab and Israeli leaders have made positive and forthcoming comments in private, but whether they will defend them in public is another matter. Very little has leaked out from Mr. Baker's discussions.
When pressed for details, Mr. Baker said: "We have talked specifics with these countries to bounce our ideas off them and solicit their views and their expressions, their ideas. Now, the surest way for us to sabotage our own efforts is to get into too much of those specifics because what that will do is cause people to have to react, sometimes negatively and prematurely."
When discussing the results of his trip, Mr. Baker made a distinction between the reaction foreign leaders to his ideas for peace and to specific American ideas for a new security structure to stabilize the Persian Gulf. On the security framework, which will be based on an Arab peace-keeping force protecting Kuwait from Iraq, with American naval and air forces on aircraft carriers providing backup, Mr. Baker said he found "broad support."
On the issue of arms control in the Middle East and an Arab-Israeli settlement, Mr. Baker said his talks revealed a "consensus" that there is a "significant opportunity here."
While all the parties apparently agree that there is an "opportunity," it is not at all clear that they agree how to exploit it, and judging from the public declarations made by various leaders along the way, it will be a real challenge for Mr. Baker to find overlapping areas of agreement.
The Palestinians Mr. Baker spoke with from the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, for instance, insisted on a state of their own and representation by the P.L.O.; the Arab states insisted that Israel agree to trade land for peace and Israeli officials said land for peace was a nonstarter.
 
Gulf Changes Create Catalyst
 "Nobody can impose peace, an Arab-Israeli peace, unless the parties themselves really want it," said Mr. Baker. "I think that what makes the situation a little bit different now is that there has been a significant change in the region and that has presented us with an opportunity to act as a catalyst. The Soviets were responsive and I think that there is a basis for us to continue to work together."
Regarding the Persian Gulf, Mr. Baker was asked whether the Bush Administration was playing a dangerous game in trying to unseat President Saddam Hussein -- a process that could inadvertently lead to the collapse of the Iraqi Government and the breakup of Iraq's loosely tied multi-ethnic society of 17 million.
"We want to see the territorial integrity of Iraq," said Mr. Baker. "We don't want to see a Lebanonization of Iraq. I am not prepared right now to give you a prediction with respect to exactly how that situation is going to turn out. But we don't want to see a power a vacuum develop there."
 
Gambling on a Leader

Without putting it in so many words, the Bush Administration is apparently gambling that external pressure on Iraq will stimulate a revolt that will topple President Hussein, without leading to the disintegration of the Iraqi state and the violation of its borders.
This is risky given the fact that Iraq's Shiites, who dominate the southern part of the country, and its Kurds, who dominate the northern mountains, have long chafed under the Sunni Muslims who dominate the ruling Baath Party and run things from Baghdad.
The Saudi leadership has apparently argued to the United States that the Iraqi Baathist regime, which has been in power since 1968, is more than a one-man dictatorship, but rather a substantial state machinery that can hold things together even without Saddam Hussein. Their apparent hope is that someone will emerge from this apparatus who is strong enough and cruel enough to hold Iraq together, but will be more willing to reconcile with its Arab neighbors.
Mr. Baker said he will be discussing with Turkey's President the situation in northwestern Iraq, where the region's predominantly Kurdish population is in open revolt against Mr. Hussein. Most of the people of eastern Turkey are also Kurds.
Six bombs exploded in Turkey shortly before Mr. Baker's arrival, but there were no casualties -- only property damage. The targets included an I.B.M. office and a General Dynamics office in Ankara and a Pepsi-Cola plant in Istanbul.

HEADLINE: $226.5 Million for New York Water Projects

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
The Federal Environmental Protection Agency has awarded $226.5 million for New York State municipalities to upgrade water works.
The grant, announced today, is the largest in the agency's history. The Federal money, coupled with a state grant, will allow New York to use $788 million in bonds to finance cleanup projects, said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York. 
 "These funds are crucial to the efforts to improve rivers, lakes and estuaries in New York State," Mr. D'Amato said.
Mr. D'Amato said the money will subsidize interest rates on loans for at least 69 water and sewage treatment projects across the state. The money can be used for collection sewers, treatment plants, pump stations, sewer overflow work or sludge handling.
"These funds will go for loans to upgrade water and sewage treatment at interest rates as low as 5 percent," said Mr. D'Amato, a member of the Senate appropriations subcommittee for the environmental agency.

HEADLINE: VIEWS OF SPORT/Tournament Money: Root of Good or Evil?;
N.C.A.A. Distribution Plan Makes Rich Get Richer

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. DEALY Jr.; Francis X. Dealy Jr., is the author of "Win at Any Cost: The Sell Out of College Athletics," Birch Lane Press (1990).

 BODY:
For the next three weeks, one of America's most exciting sporting events, the National Collegiate Athletic Association Men's Basketball tournament, will spawn office pools across the land and divert millions of people from their worries about the recession and dwindling job security.
Unfortunately, the tournament will also make people forget the increasingly hapless administration of the N.C.A.A. over the rest of college athletics. If this seems harsh, consider that little of the unprecedented amount of television money coming in will go toward solving the greatest problems. 
 For the genuine reform of college athletics to take place, we must acknowledge that money is the root of all evil in college sports, too, and that the N.C.A.A. exacerbates, rather than deters, this evil.
As part of a $1.1 billion, seven-year package, CBS will pay the N.C.A.A. $143 million to televise this year's tournament, an increase of $88.7 million from last year. But will this huge windfall be used to correct some of the worst offenses in college sports, including steroid use, alcohol abuse, academic fraud, recruiting bribes, campus rape and the exploitation of black athletes?
Sadly, the answer is no.
Shrewdly, the N.C.A.A. leadership precluded college presidents and the N.C.A.A.'s smaller schools from answering this question by diverting them with reform pretexts at its annual convention in Nashville in January.
While the convention at large reduced the number of football scholarships from 95 to 90 by 1996, the N.C.A.A. executive committee met behind closed doors to adopt a formula for distributing the CBS money. Not surprisingly, the formula, which is all but unfathomable, rewards those N.C.A.A. schools with the most tournament victories and the biggest athletic departments.
While big-time athletic departments stand to gain several million dollars annually from the money, needy big-time student athletes will not fare as well. A special fund will be established that will dispense, on average, a trifling $25 per athlete per year for those who qualify.
A mere $25,000 per Division I school will be spent on what the N.C.A.A. refers to as academic enhancement. Division II will receive $1 million to be divided among 209 institutions. Division III schools, 323 institutions, will receive nothing.
With all the new CBS money swamping the N.C.A.A. system, there are still only 18 N.C.A.A. investigators to monitor more than 800 N.C.A.A. schools and 200,000 athletes.
But when questioned, Judith Sweet, the new N.C.A.A. president, said: "With respect to enforcement, we want fair competition throughout the N.C.A.A. system. We feel we have that now. There's always room for improvement, of course, but I don't think more money is necessarily the answer."
To restore its credibility, the N.C.A.A. must divide the opposing functions of promotion and enforcement into two distinct and equal bodies. And the enforcement body must be headed by a commissioner with sweeping powers.
We deserve more from the N.C.A.A., despite the excellent basketball tournament it stages. College athletics reflect the character of our higher education system. When hooliganism tarnishes the World Cup, although regrettable, it reflects only the baseness of a few. But when an athletic scandal taints a university, it corrupts everyone's symbol of integrity.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 3; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1677 words

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The 'New Order' Is a Tall Order for the U.S.

BYLINE: By LEONARD SILK

 BODY:
FOR all of the jubilant comparisons of the triumph in the Persian Gulf to the victory in World War II, Americans have begun to realize that this is not the same world an all-powerful United States faced half a century ago after the defeat of Germany and Japan. Today, threats of civil wars and regional wars survive not only in Iraq and throughout the Middle East, but in Eastern Europe, the Soviet Union and elsewhere; and the United States, less dominant than it was, confronts severe economic, financial and social problems of its own.
The United States is still in a recession which, Government and many private economists say, was triggered by Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. Unemployment, just 5.2 percent last June, has risen to 6.5 percent. Business failures were higher last year than in any year since 1983. The nation's total output, adjusted for inflation, fell 2 percent in the final quarter of 1990 and is likely to fall further in this quarter. But President Bush's economic advisers tell him that the economy will soon rebound, probably by the middle of this year. 
 Yet there are still reasons for concern about the hangover of the nation's underlying economic and financial problems stemming from the debt explosion of the 1980's, when public and private debt soared from $3.4 trillion to $10.6 trillion. Many experts feel that even if the economy turns upward shortly, the recovery will be sluggish. And some, like James J. O'Leary, a consulting economist at the United States Trust Company, insist that "there are powerful forces at play which threaten to make the recession more severe and longer than now expected by most forecasters."
Nevertheless, Mr. Bush, exultant in victory and scoring higher in the polls than any other President, seems unfazed by domestic problems. He remains committed to establishing "a new world order" in which, he has said, "nations recognize the shared responsibility for freedom and justice."
Congressional Democrats, most of whom opposed Mr. Bush on launching the ground war, are looking for an issue on which to contest his popular leadership. "The President seeks a new world order," said George Mitchell, the Senate majority leader. "We ask him to join us in putting our own house in order."
 
Not Strictly Partisan

But the contest between foreign and domestic goals is not a strictly partisan issue. The Republicans, including the President, know that domestic economic and social problems cannot be long buried, with the 1992 election ahead. And the Democrats know that the nation must continue to play a global leadership role in the interests of preserving peace and national security.
President Bush has been criticized by some for his idealistic talk of making the world safe not only for democracy but for justice and freedom and national self-determination. But his actual approach to specific situations has been pragmatic. Indeed, Mr. Bush's willingness to deal with Hafez al-Assad, the Syrian leader whom many believe to be as ruthless as Saddam Hussein, and with Deng Xiaoping after the Chinese leader used tanks to quell protests in Tiananmen Square, seemed to some to signal an unprincipled pragmatism.
But if the President faces a conflict between morality and pragmatism, so do all Americans. It is no simple task to define a new strategy in a world changed so fundamentally since the end of World War II, when the nation's aims were relatively simple: to rebuild the war-shattered countries and to contain Communism.
The success of that strategy helped produce some of the changes now facing the country. America's relative decline -- its share of total world output has fallen from one-third in 1950 to less than one-quarter today -- is due to the soaring economies of reconstructed Germany and Japan. With the end of the cold war, the Soviet Union's economic and political disintegration could revive the threat of violence in Europe.
But the United States is perhaps the first modern world leader to have waged a war with so little money of its own and such big budget deficits -- for 1991, it is likely to be $325 billion. This lack of financial assets makes "shared responsibility" not a catch phrase but a necessity for the United States, and not only in the Persian Gulf, where victory was financed largely with other people's money, but anywhere in the world where the United States assumes a leadership role.
The new American strategy cannot afford ideological purity, if it ever could. The outburst of hope that followed the liberation of Eastern Europe in 1989 and the belief that the Soviet Union was well on the way toward a market economy and liberal democracy has given way to anxiety over Mikhail S. Gorbachev's failure to resist powerful pressures from Kremlin conservatives. At the same time, there are long suppressed nationalist and ethnic conflicts everywhere from Albania and Yugoslavia to the Soviet Union itself.
The United States will have to choose among lesser evils in deciding to whom to give its support. A striking example of this came in Iraq after the war when Saddam Hussein, a Sunni Muslim who had fought Iran, was seen in Washington, at least initially, as a lesser evil than Iraq's Iran-backed Shiite rebels. Without the lodestar of anti-Communism as a strategy guide, American policy-makers may be navigating with a wobbling compass.
In America's relations not only with the Communist world but with the rest of the world as well, this is a new age of uncertainty. The open international trading system that the United States led the way in creating after World War II may have been jeopardized by the recent breakdown in the so-called Uruguay Round of trade negotiations, though efforts are under way to get those talks back on track. Yet the threat to an open world economy has been heightened by the American recession and the possibility that it could spread. If protectionist pressures get out of control, they would inflict serious damage on the United States and the world economy -- as they did during the Great Depression, with frightful consequences culminating in World War II.
 
Continuing Leadership?
 Faced with so complex a range of economic, political and military problems, can the United States continue to play the role of leader of the "free world"? Or has its power to lead been seriously weakened by its relative economic decline or its own lack of fiscal discipline?
One body of literature, headed by Paul Kennedy's "Rise and Fall of the Great Powers," has advanced the thesis that America may indeed be in decline, like other powers before it, as a result of overstretching its resources in an effort to maintain its dominance. The United States has been spending between 5 percent and 6 percent of its G.N.P. on military programs, compared with only 1 percent for Japan.
 
The Right Stuff
 But another body of literature, led by Joseph S. Nye's "Born to Lead," contends that the United States still possesses economic, scientific, technological and even moral qualities that have resulted in its emergence as the only global power that remains crucial to the maintenance of world peace and prosperity.
However, few would deny that the United States now faces serious economic and social problems at home, in such areas as education, poverty, health, drugs, urban decay and crime, and lacks the resources to fulfill both its global and domestic responsibilities.
With the end of the cold war, there was hope that a "peace dividend" resulting from cuts in military spending would free more national resources to reduce the budget deficit and help meet the nation's economic and social needs. But the war with Iraq, among other things, has dimmed those expectations. So the nation still must tailor its global strategy to fit the measure of its purse.
What should its new strategy be? Many would like to inherit the mantle of master strategist that George Kennan once held with his cold war doctrine of the containment of Communism. One contender is Paul H. Nitze, the veteran arms control negotiator and foreign policy expert. Last November, in a speech at West Point, Mr. Nitze spelled out a new strategy that appears similar to the concepts on which President Bush has been acting. The Nitze strategy has these key elements:
* The "the accommodation and protection of diversity within a general framework of required order." This implies an acceptance of very different ideological groupings and a willingness to defend them against outside aggressors. A corollary, which Mr. Bush would doubtless accept, would be to protect the right of each group (the Baltic states? Israel? a Palestinian entity?) to self-determination.
* Significant reliance on supranational institutions, such as the United Nations, to deal with problems that transcend national or ethnic interests, such as drug trafficking, terrorism and environmental concerns.
* The United States, "with first-class military potential, inherent political, economic and cultural strengths, and no territorial or ideological ambitions, can play a unique role" in such a world "in bringing its latent power to the support of order and diversity among diffuse and varied groupings." That could well be what Mr. Bush might say he had done in the Persian Gulf.
But diversity is a more complex concept than containment. If used opportunistically, the doctrine of promoting diversity could mean an utter lack of principle and a tolerance of the intolerable. But this is not what the strategy is intended to imply. Rather, it aims at achieving peace through principles and actions supported by the world community. As Mr. Bush said at the war's end, "Enduring peace must be our mission."
That quest is in jeapardy, however, while the nation's economy, social structure, education system and infrastructure deteriorate. With the thrid world population explosion exacerbating poverty and instability, the achievement of a peaceful world order will depend more on economic development than force of arms.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 4; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
How Do You Tell A Victorious War From a Just One?

BYLINE: By PETER STEINFELS

 BODY:
MILITARY experts are already reviewing the Persian Gulf war, assessing battle plans, appraising the performance of weapons and personnel, drawing lessons for the next war. Somewhat more hesitantly, moralists are beginning to do the same. They are looking back at the debate about the war's morality, evaluating the kinds of arguments they made, wondering whether it all made any difference and, like the military, asking what the implications are for the future.
 There is a lot of "painful retrospecting" going on, said the Rev. Joan B. Campbell, the new general secretary of the National Council of Churches, which was outspoken in its opposition to the American military action. The 32-church umbrella group, which joins the principal liberal Protestant denominations with many Eastern Orthodox and traditionally black churches, is soon to issue a pastoral letter reflecting on the divergence between its own stance and the different direction taken by national policy and public opinion. The council will undoubtedly take some satisfaction in the fact that its objections helped force a moral debate. But it will also have to reconcile its early predictions of a war with no winners and a protracted Middle East disaster with the appearance of a swift American victory. 
 Also under the microscope is the "just war" doctrine, a centuries-old approach to judging the morality of warfare that almost came to dominate the debate about the Persian Gulf. The doctrine was pushed to the forefront last November when America's Roman Catholic bishops outlined the traditional criteria to be met before warfare could be justified, including the sparing of civilian targets from direct attacks. Without issuing any definitive judgment, the bishops strongly suggested that an attack to liberate Kuwait risked violating at least two principles: that war be strictly a last resort, initiated only when means like diplomacy and economic pressure have been exhausted, and that the likely good consequences outweigh the physical and spiritual damage.
 By February, however, President Bush himself was invoking just-war principles to defend his policy. And once the fighting began, the Catholic bishops were divided, with only a few in outright condemnation of the war. Some wondered how useful the just-war categories actually were if they didn't lead to a clear conclusion, while others said that the traditional tenets had proved inapplicable to modern warfare.
 Defenders of the approach were not fazed by the fact that different people used the teaching to reach different conclusions. "If the President makes the case that this meets just-war criteria and you reach a different conclusion, you can at least engage him on the same ground," said the Rev. J. Bryan Hehir, a professor of ethics at Georgetown University.
 Some argue that just-war teaching had an even stronger impact, permeating the military's thinking and its efforts to avoid bombing civilian targets. This was not because of the current debate, said the Rev. John P. Langan, another Georgetown professor of ethics, but because of the bishops' 1983 letter on nuclear arms, which has been closely studied by the military.
 "The early briefings on the air war sounded like the briefers had been reading just-war theory," said Michael Walzer, a political philospher at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. Mr. Walzer is now trying to incorporate the lessons of the Persian Gulf into a preface to the latest edition of his widely used book "Just and Unjust Wars."
 Unlike those who believe that just- war principles actually shaped military policy, Auxiliary Bishop Thomas J. Gumbleton of Detroit, a veteran Catholic antiwar leader, called the military's gesture to the teaching "moral camouflage." By knocking out electrical power and communications and cutting off water supplies, he argued, the air assault ultimately eliminated any immunity for civilians.
Not all the moral debate centered on trying to dispassionately apportion the evils and goods that add up to a just war. Much of what church leaders wrote and said more closely resembled the political commentary appearing on editorial and op-ed pages, with perhaps a strong dash of moral exhortation: Modern war "produces only losers" or unleashes consequences "beyond comprehension" or involves "certain catastrophe." It was not clear whether the statements implied total pacifism or simply argued that war was always tragic.
Also common were what might be called collateral moral arguments about past American responsibility for arming Iraq or the United States' dependence on foreign oil or its failures to solve domestic problems.
Did these arguments mean that the United States was morally disqualified from using force overseas until it had rectified all its domestic and international failures? One critic of these critics wondered how they would have justified fighting Nazism in the 1940's, when even the armed forces were segregated. Many of the admonishments rested on such a profound distrust of American political leadership that a military and diplomatic success in the Persian Gulf would be considered as unwelcome as a failure.
More specific claims about the war's consequences also appeared, and some of them are now being re-examined. In December a group of church leaders organized by the National Council of Churches stated that war "will destroy everything" and "inflame the entire Middle East," a judgment that in hindsight Ms. Campbell acknowledges may have been extreme. At least one goal, the freeing of Kuwait, was achieved, she noted, and some council officials are saying that "maybe this has opened some doors to peace."
Those who looked at the gulf through the lenses of just-war criteria were generally more cautious in their early judgments, whether they concluded the impending war to be justified or not. But they, too, are reviewing both the accuracy of their assessments and the usefulness of their categories.
Comparisons of likely good and bad consequences played a key role in the arguments, but such estimations are notoriously hard to make. "We still don't know the full extent of either civilian or military casualties," Mr. Walzer said, "and there could be a cholera epidemic, plus the deaths to come in the civil war." Some engaged in the moral debate feel strongly that for purposes of future reflection Washington should make every effort to discover and release these figures.
Longer-range consequences for Middle East peace and well-being are even more difficult to assess. But some of the just-war theorists are willing to acknowledge that their forecasts were wrong. "I thought it wouldn't be possible to contain the war to Iraq and Kuwait," Father Hehir said. "And I thought that a major tank battle with large casualties on all sides was inevitable."
The emergence of "smart" weaponry has added another new ingredient to just-war theory. "For most of the 20th century, technology seems to have given us increasingly indiscriminate warfare," Father Hehir said. "We may be seeing a new generation of weapons in which at least some of them have reversed this pattern."
Mr. Walzer said that the war's outcome strongly rebutted the position recently voiced by some officials at both the Vatican and the World Council of Churches that modern weaponry means no war can be just. "Modern technology makes it more possible to exercise discrimination," he said, "and therefore we should be more critical of any non-discrimination." But Mr. Walzer, who believed that the military tried hard to hit only military targets, was still troubled by the definition of those targets to include so much of the infrastructure necessary to civilian life.
 A longstanding objection to just-war thinking is that it seems to promise a clarity that is at odds with the overwhelming uncertainties of international affairs and the terrible ambiguities of balancing human lives, aspirations and predictions about the future. What should be done when the case hangs on difficult questions over which reasonable people easily disagree, like the extent of Iraqi casualties or whether diplomatic efforts had been truly exhausted or whether prolonged sanctions were a realistic alternative to war?
Most Catholic bishops disappointed war opponents by withholding any definitive judgment and disappointed war supporters by continually warning about the need for restraint.
On the eve of the fighting, Mr. Walzer concluded that the war would be "just but dangerous." Father Langan called it "an imperfectly just war." Father Hehir called it "just but unwise."
Are such conclusions properly modest, or do they land policy makers and citizens in a twilight zone of morality that paralyzes conscientious decisions?

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 1619 words

HEADLINE: Victory Lap;
Baker Finds Doors Open, Minds Sealed

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey

 BODY:
RIDING a wave of optimism in the wake of the American victory in the Persian Gulf war, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d took a grand tour of the Middle East and Moscow last week to see whether that victory could be translated into a breakthrough in the Arab-Israeli conflict as well.
What he found, in many ways, was that the connection between events in the gulf and the future of the Arab-Israel dispute is uncertain. Everyone Mr. Baker spoke to was long on optimism, but short on specific promises. It was as if there had been an earthquake in Kuwait and Iraq that turned the world there upside down and prompted nearby governments to act in ways they had never before contemplated. But the Arabs and Israelis down the street got hit with only the aftershocks. It has rattled their diplomatic teacups and unnerved some people, but a survey of the main Arab-Israeli players with whom Mr. Baker spoke last week shows that -- for now -- their world and their attitudes remain mostly intact. Here is a look at what Mr. Baker found.
 
 
ISRAEL
 Israel Radio, describing the political scene at home the other day, referred to the veteran hard-liner Ariel Sharon -- then went to say, "and then to the right of him . . ." When Mr. Sharon no longer defines the right edge of Israeli politics, it means there are some awfully angry Israelis. Moshe Arad, Israel's former Ambassador to Washington who returned home five months ago, said he has found that everyone used the gulf war to prove what they already believed. "Everything is the same only the feelings of people are cruder, sharper, more raw," he said. The No. 1 pop tune on Israel Radio during the war was a Hebrew rap song, "Saddam You're Just an Idiot," with the main refrain being "Saddam, Saddam, these are Americans not Iranians -- boom, boom, boom." 
 The Israeli left argues that the gulf war and the recent wave of stabbings of Israelis by Palestinians only proves definitively that Israel must find a solution both with the surrounding Arab states and the local Palestinians. The Israeli right argues that the same violent incidents only prove that the Palestinians are barbarians and that peace will only come when aggressive, hostile Arab states reconcile their differences with each other and Israel. Although Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir offered Mr. Baker some happy talk about the need to move toward peace, his aides say privately that now is not the time to take any chances, and with once-powerful Iraq out of the way, they don't have to. This is a recurring pattern in Middle East politics: When I am weak, how can I compromise? When I am strong, why should I compromise?
The Israeli silent majority wavers between the extremes, mistrusting the Palestinians more than ever and wanting to find a solution more than ever. Under such conditions, some believe, American diplomacy might succeed with Israel only if it begins with a new vocabulary. Most Israelis today think 242-338 is a telephone number, not the shorthand for two United Nations resolutions that touch their lives and that call on Israel to trade occupied territories for security and recognition from its Arab neighbors.
"There is a hunger here to find a way out," said the Israeli political theorist Yaron Ezrahi. "But when Baker asks the Israelis to consider trading 'land for peace,' most Israelis hear 'land for Utopia' and they instinctively demur. The endemic instability in this region makes the very notion of peace sound naive and not very real. The Americans need a new vocabulary, because the right wing will always shoot them down when they claim that they are going to broker 'peace.' They must approach the Israelis instead by talking about trading land for alternative security arrangements, out of which peace might one day grow."
 
 
SAUDI ARABIA
 When an American diplomat in Saudi Arabia asked a devout Muslim what he thought about predominantly Christian troops from the West defending his country, he answered: "As the Koran teaches, a starving man is allowed to eat pork," which is normally forbidden under Islamic law. The story is a useful reminder that before the gulf war started King Fahd had to seek the approval of his clerics, who told him that under the extreme circumstances, with the nation's survival at stake, it was O.K. to summon non-Muslim troops for protection.
No such extreme circumstances impel the Saudis to recognize Israel. At home, King Fahd is called the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques, references to Mecca and Medina. For the moment his top priorities are insuring that Saddam Hussein is dead and that his own status as Muslim leader is restored. Saudi officials are already talking about an extensive new mosque-building program. Mr. Baker said that he heard the stirrings of "new thinking" from the Saudis about Israel, but for it to flower into anything the Custodian of the Two Holy Mosques will require far-reaching gestures by Israel to trade away land and give the Palestinians something to call their own.
 
 
SYRIA
 When Mr. Baker strolled through the Damascus souk he was greeted with a smattering of cheers and by a throng of schoolchildren chanting "Congratulations to Baker and America." Not the usual reception for an American Secretary of State. But if there is one thing the Syrians respect and understand it is raw power, and in the wake of the gulf war Mr. Baker embodied that. What the Syrians seem to want most out of the gulf war is not a new relationship with Israel, but a new relationship with America. President Hafez al-Assad knows that the Soviet Union can no longer protect him or help Syria flourish economically.
But Israel is another matter. One Western diplomat recalled that on the first day of the American air war against Iraq, the Syrians who worked for him were morose and depressed. Many had relatives in Baghdad, others identified with Mr. Hussein. The next day, when the Iraqis began firing Scud missiles at Israel, the diplomat reported that his Syrian employees were suddenly upbeat and smiling. No wonder that President Assad was so concerned about pro-Iraqi sentiments that he jammed the pro-Baghdad Jordanian Television and barely allowed his own press to even mention Syrian troops fighting alongside the Americans. If Mr. Assad is that sensitive about taking part in a winning war with Americans in the gulf, how far-reaching is he going to be toward Israel?
 
 
PALESTINIANS
 The chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, Yasir Arafat, has had his ups and downs over the years, but his enthusiastic support for Saddam Hussein in the gulf war is a legacy that he will not easily overcome. Put simply, it has severely damaged the legal-moral basis of the Palestinian cause, which is something Palestinians have always been careful to preserve. How could Mr. Arafat be in favor of the Iraqi occupation of Kuwait, and be against the Israeli occupation of the West Bank and Gaza Strip?
Not even the most left of Israeli leftists today is prepared to argue to his fellow citizens that Mr. Arafat can be trusted. Every Arab leader Mr. Baker talked to told him that Mr. Arafat was debased currency and Washington should ignore him. It was ironic to hear President Francois Mitterrand of France urging President Bush to deal with the P.L.O., when Arab commentators were ridiculing Mr. Arafat. "You are a corrupt war criminal, you clown," Moussa Sabry wrote of Mr. Arafat in the Egyptian paper Al-Akhbar. "You betrayed those who fed you and meanly stabbed those who helped you. It's time for the picture of your bewildered-looking, idiotic face to disappear."
But the Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip are not going to dump Mr. Palestine simply because he has become Mr. Unpopular, and they told that to Mr. Baker. They might demand that Mr. Arafat let them take the lead in negotiating the Palestinians' fate -- but they will only do that if the Israelis offer them something worth negotiating over. The Israelis want Mr. Arafat out of the way in the hope that the Palestinians in the occupied territories will accept a lesser deal. But they will only get rid of Mr. Arafat if they prove to Palestinians from the territories that if they represent themselves they will get a better deal.
 
 
 IRAQ
 Iraq is a big Lebanon, a multi-ethnic melting pot of Sunnis, Shiites and Kurds, where nothing ever quite melted. The same iron fist that Saddam Hussein used to smash Kuwait he used to hold his centrifugal republic together. If the United States hopes to withdraw its troops from the gulf, and preserve all of its military gains from the war, it is essential that Mr. Hussein, or, preferably, a different but equally strong figure, is at the helm in Baghdad. Otherwise, the United States and its allies may find themselves with no one to turn over their chunk of Iraq to.
On the day that Mr. Baker left Israel, Benjamin Zeev Begin, a member of the Israeli Parliament and the son of former Prime Minister Menachem Begin, wrote: "Those who call for a 'new order' in the Middle East treat this troubled region very generously, as if it ever had an 'old order.' " Actually, the Middle East did have an old order. It was a fragile, rickety equilibrium built, as it always has been, on the pillars of Egypt and Iraq. This equilibrium was based not on peace and reconciliation between neighbors but on controlled enmity and the balance of power. That ever-precarious equilibrium was sent totally out of kilter by the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait and the Western counterattack.
If Mr. Bush can simply restore this "old order," and still get all the American troops home, it will be no small achievement.

PUB-DATE: March 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 4; Page 2; Column 4; Week In Review Desk

LENGTH: 968 words

HEADLINE: The World;
The View From Inside A Strained Relationship

 BODY:
ON questions like trade, foreign investment, and responsibilities for world security, feelings between the United States and Japan seem to go from bad to worse. Yukio Okamoto, who resigned from the Foreign Ministry recently, spent most of his 23 years as a diplomat massaging the often-troubled Japan-United States relationship. As director of the First North American Division, he was the chief line officer for Japan's fitful response to American requests for aid in the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Okamoto is now president of Okamoto & Associates, a consulting firm that advises Japanese and American businesses on dealings in each other's countries. He was interviewed by Steven R. Weisman, chief of the Tokyo bureau of The New York Times. Following are excerpts from that interview.
Question. Despite Japan's contributions on the gulf, Americans still seem disappointed with its reaction. Are their opinions justified? 
 Answer. Only a portion. Unfortunately, there is a pent-up frustration in the minds of Americans over almost 10 years of economic friction. When we announced the $4 billion package [for the war] in September, the American Congress interpreted this as the result of Japan being pushed into the corner by a Congressional resolution to withdraw American forces from Japan. Obviously, you cannot squeeze out $4 billion within two or three days after the adoption of a resolution in the American Congress. It was in the pipeline for a long time. It's true, the Japanese bureaucracy has been inflexible in interpreting some laws and regulations, and we are not seen to be really accommodating to the changing realities. But under a normal bilateral relationship, these things would not blow into a big criticism.
Q. Didn't American disappointment arise partly because Japan did not participate in a more direct way?
A. Many people thought that Japan should have sent, for instance, a medical corps or transport planes, but these were denied by the people's pacifism.
Q. Was it just pacifism that prevented Japan from moving to this new kind of role?
A. The Japanese Constitution says in its preamble, "We have determined to preserve our security and existence trusting in the justice and faith of the peace-loving peoples in the world. In schools throughout Japan, teachers were saying: "Do you know there's a war going on in the gulf? Who do you think is bad?" "Well, both are bad because both are resorting to force." [They were teaching this] without infusing the fundamental value of freedom or democracy, and how these concepts are important to be fought over. That's one flaw of pacifism.
Secondly, I think that conservatism in Japan failed to get into the minds of people an intellectual and moral framework. So when we were asked to put our life at stake to defend freedom, this was a totally different concept. People did feel that we had to do something. But invariably they were arguing that Japan should contribute by peaceful means.
Q. A lot of people say that Japan's political leadership was weak.
A. I would like to eschew the word "weak." But it was certainly not a strong leadership.
 
Sharing the Blame
 Q. I take it you feel that the United States . . .
A. . . . has to be blamed as well. I was shocked to see the discussions in the Senate. These senators were treating Japan like a malfunctioning cash dispenser. Look at the record of our economic negotiations starting from textile in the late 1960's -- machine tools, color TV, automobiles, steel, farm products, citrus, wood products, satellites, supercomputers, semiconductors. Just name one trade dispute that was not solved. The only weak point of Japan institutionally is how we can cooperate vis-a-vis an international security crisis.
Q. So why have tensions increased?
A. The relationship between any two countries has ups and downs, with frustrating episodes as well as heart-warming episodes. In the present relationship, that latter element is gone. I mean, Japan donates over $10 million to the earthquake in San Francisco. No word is reported. Japan is simply looked at in a monotone color of being a tough, selfish, unyielding, unscrupulous, inscrutable country.
Q. Are Japanese-U.S. relations in a crisis?
A. It's a crisis in perceptions, not a crisis in reality. Trade figures are improving. More Japanese people are awake to the need of Japan contributing more to the common cause of Western democracies. But there's a pent-up frustration on the part of Japanese as well. To people who value honor, to be called tough, selfish, almost liars, this has begun to erode people's warm feeling toward the United States. Japanese people say, hey, wait a minute, Japan is dependent completely on the United States for our security. Why shouldn't Japan be more free to strengthen our military forces, which is the only way to be again assertive to the United States?
Q. Is a shift to the right a serious danger in Japan?
A. Yes, I am concerned. Comic magazines containing rightist stories are sold out the first morning they appear. The Japanese are beginning to realize that perhaps we have to introduce new thinking into the heretofore held pacifism. But if you overdo it, it will be very easy to swing to the other side.
Q. How do you see the future?
A. I thought the relationship was bottoming out last summer, and then this crisis in the gulf hit us. Now it depends on the economic condition in the U.S. and on Japanese political maturity. Basically I am optimistic because of the realities, the complementariness of our economic structures, the geopolitical relationship and the importance of Japan for American security strategy. All these realities can only mean that the U.S. and Japan will have to stick together, whether we like it or not.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.S. and Iraq to Meet on Request by Baghdad to Shift Its Warplanes

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 16

 BODY:
American and Iraqi commanders will meet in the Iraqi desert within two days to discuss an Iraqi request to move warplanes around the country, an action that the Pentagon considers a violation of the cease-fire in the Persian Gulf war.
Iraq flew some airplanes to different locations last week, and Baghdad has sent word to the American military command that it wants to do so again, Administration officials said. In response, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, the senior American commander, warned that under the terms of the cease-fire, Iraq was prohibited from doing so without allied permission, and that the planes risked being shot down.
 
Issue of Cease-Fire
 Iraq's ability to put any of its aircraft in the skies has vexed efforts to reach a permanent cease-fire and clear end to the war. It underscores the delicate problem that the Administration faces in trying to remain firm with Baghdad cease-fire terms while avoiding new combat.
 
 President Bush, meeting in Bermuda today with Prime Minister John Mojor of Britain, said he was determined to insure that Iraq abide by the terms of the cease-fire, reached in a March 3 meeting in a tent in Safwan in southern Iraq.
 Mr. Bush and Mr. Major agreed on conditions that would be proposed for a new Unitied Nations resolution to be presented as early as next week to end the war. The conditions include the destruction of Iraq's chemical weapons and a timetable for resuming Iraq's oil shipments, profits from which would be used to pay reparations to Kuwait.
The request for the desert meeting follows several days in which the United States, which controls 15 percent of Iraqi territory, has warned Baghdad against offensive action.
 
Several U.S. Warnings
 The United States told Iraq this week that its use of helicopters against Iraqi rebels violated the ban on "missile attacks on flights of combat aircraft" spelled out in the United Nations resolution voted after the war. On Friday, the United States said it had moved its forces back to their forward-most positions in occupied Iraq to signal to the Iraqis that they cannot move their forces, including aircraft, as they choose.
Pete Williams, the Pentagon spokesman, said today that the Iraqis were interested in "repositioning" their warplanes. "That may well be true but is nonetheless a violation of the cease-fire," he said. In Saudi Arabia, General Schwarzkopf said today that senior military commanders would meet with Iraqi commanders in a day or two to hear their reasons for wanting to regroup their air force. He did not identify the commanders.
"They will state their reason and we will listen to their request and respond appropriately," Mr. Williamssaid. "We don't wish to be arbitrary about this but we have many forces in the area and the issue of aircraft flying around raises a serious security consideration."
In complaining about Iraq's lack of compliance with the cease-fire terms, Mr. Bush said: "Certain arrangements were made and certain ground rules spelled out. The movement of aircraft, for example, and so they should not violate certain things."
Mr. Bush continued: "Having said that, none of us want to move forces into Baghdad. Frankly, we don't want to have any more fighting. But they know what the ground rules are and they should abide by those rules."
 
'Rhetorical Approach'
 A senior White House official said the Administration was striving to be firm with Baghdad as the best way of avoiding any further military conflict.
"Basically, it's a rhetorical approach at this point," the official said. 'We want to avoid military action if we can and the idea is to keep up the warnings since the Iraqis have been basically going along with what we've been telling them to do and not to do."
The official said that the President was interested in dampening any speculation that the United States is on the verge of resuming military action.
Asked about the possibility of new military action, Mr. Bush said, "We're not ruling anything in or out, but we're making clear, as General Schwarzkopf did I think just yesterday, that they must abide by agreements made."
Mr. Bush also said there were "many provisions in the future that we expect Iraq will comply with." It was in that spirit that Mr. Bush and Mr. Major agreed to propose what they called tough conditions that Iraq must fulfill before the war can be concluded.
In addition to calling for destruction of chemical weapons and allowing for resumption of Iraqi oil shipments, three other conditions are envisioned, officials said: the formal recognition by Baghdad of Kuwait's prewar borders, the setting of a timetable for lifting the economic embargo against Iraq for all but military items and release of all Kuwaiti detainees now held by Iraq.
In addition, the resolution might also deal with what kind of United Nations peacekeeping force should remain in the region. Officials said the resolution would take up the questions of who would make up the force, how long they might be stationed there and on what side of the border or whether there should be a demilitarized zone near the border. Mr. Bush said the force could be international or an Arab force.
Mr. Major emphasized his interest in destroying all of Iraq's chemical arms.
"I certainly would like to see the supervised destruction of their chemical weapons," he said. "I think that is extremely important for future security in the Middle East."
The movement of Iraqi aircraft first became an issue after the allied forces tentatively agreed to allow Baghdad to move helicopters to transport troops in the first few days after the truce.
Administration officials were angered when President Saddam Hussein began using helicopter gunships to attack Kurdish and Shiite rebels. On Wednesday while he was in Ottawa, President Bush sternly warned Hussein that he was violating the cease-fire and that would prevent any permanent end to the war. Earlier the Administration had signalled Iraq it would not tolerate the use of chemical weapons against anti-Government rebels.
 
Bush's Ottowa Warning
 After Mr. Bush's warning from Ottawa, American forces moved some units forward in Iraq, in what was taken as a message to Mr. Hussein not to use helicopter gunships aginst the rebel forces. The sudden decision to send combat troops, including M1-A1 tank units, demonstrated that the United States was prepared to go on the offensive if necessary, officials said.
 Administration officials said that after General Schwarzkopf's response to Iraq about moving planes, Iraqi field commanders ordered their pilots to stay put pending the desert meeting.
Pentagon officials said the issue of whether Iraq may reposition its planes does not involve any of the aircraft flown to Iran during the war.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
Policy Monotheism

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
Americans transform every success and every failure in foreign affairs into a policy doctrine and a political cudgel. We refuse to rest until we possess one lens through which to view the world and one answer for all challenges. We are forever brushing off small but important lessons in the quest for great and single truths.
 Ours is a short and tumultuous history of taking largely unique events -- the fall of Eastern Europe and China to Communism, the Korean War, the Cuban missile crisis and Vietnam -- and elevating their purported lessons into policy dogmas, be they Truman Doctrines, Kennedy Corollaries or Vietnam Syndromes. 
 Once enshrined, high priests wield these theologies like clubs to destroy their political adversaries. But at some point, they are blinded by their own convictions and commit blunders, which, in turn, give rise to new dogmas and new blunders.
 We are the monotheists of world politics. Yet we keep abandoning one god for another with unholy frequency.
 Once again, the nation seems poised to bury what the ascendant high priests call the Vietnam Syndrome in order to establish yet another new world order, or what may come to be known as the Iraq Pandemic.
 The priests of this new order start, appropriately, by settling old historical scores. They charge that the war against Iraq shows that the U.S. could have won in Vietnam if the military had not been handcuffed by timorous civilians. But just as Vietnam did not prove success to be impossible or too costly in Iraq, Iraq does not prove that victory was achievable in Vietnam.
 The U.S. could have obliterated North Vietnamese cities and bombed the dikes and flooded the rice fields. (We did not do such things in Iraq either.) We could have fought the ground war in South Vietnam more relentlessly and spread the fighting into Communist sanctuaries in Cambodia and Laos much sooner.
 Maybe Hanoi would have surrendered then; maybe not. Unlike the conventional victory over Iraq, Vietnam was essentially a guerrilla war, a continuation of a nationalist anti-colonialist struggle and a civil war. Even Hanoi's military defeat would not have ended such a war once and for all.
 The new-order priests also inveigh against liberal Democrats, who, they say, are traumatized by Vietnam, do not fathom the realities of power and have an almost absolute aversion to the use of force. Unfortunately, this is true of a number of Democrats.
 But most Democrats do not fit this caricature and draw quite sensible lessons from Vietnam. They see in that experience the need to make distinctions between countries, to define U.S. vital interests more rigorously, and to understand the imperviousness of most problems to military solutions and the limits of American power.
 There is a healthy skepticism here, not dogma. Democrats with this outlook reluctantly went along with President Bush's invasion of Panama, but are not surprised to find that General Noriega's successors also condone drug-running and money laundering.
 In thinking about the Persian Gulf, many such Democrats took their skepticism too far. They focused far too much on the problems war would not solve and not at all on the one problem -- Saddam Hussein's military power -- it would eradicate. Iraq thus holds a critical lesson for moderate Democrats.
 But the new-order priests shrug off such specific lessons about distinctions. They want Democratic scalps. They also want to squash the healthy skepticism derived from Vietnam and replace it whole cloth.
 Mr. Bush pushes his new world order. With more collective security, billions for economic development, more democracy, more conventional arms for the good guys and no terror weapons for export, it has all the makings of a Bush Doctrine. Charles Krauthammer of The New Republic goes further and calls for a policy of "robust and difficult interventionism."
 Their schemes contain good ideas. But the problem is they lead down the path to new dogma, to the single answer of the U.S. becoming the world's policeman under the umbrella of collective security. Both schemes would result in a vast over-extension of American interests and power. Both seek to make the Iraq experience the rule rather than the exception.
 America's strength lies in its regenerative powers, its pragmatism and its common sense. The nation does not need a new truth; it needs many -- with the wisdom and courage to choose among them.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: New Domestic Supply Of Oil Is Needed

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Conserve Oil -- and Wilderness" (editorial, Feb. 19) is persuasive only because it ignores two critical facts in the energy debate: 
 * Every major oil field in the United States is in decline. Even production at Alaska's Prudhoe Bay, the largest of all, is dropping at a rate of 10 percent a year. Conservation can slow the use of fossil fuels, but not eliminate it. New sources of oil aren't needed so we can burn more; they are needed to maintain our economy while we look for alternatives.
Some would argue we can just buy what we need on the world market, but that's not necessarily true -- which brings us to the second point:
* We already import about half our energy supply, which is responsible for about half our enormous trade deficit. And, while energy use in the United States is declining, third-world use is growing rapidly. In 1973, developing countries accounted for only 17 percent of world commercial energy consumption. Today, they account for 23 percent, and their share is expected to rise to 40 percent by 2020. Because oil is non-renewable, with a universally high value, our needs will conflict with those of other nations.
A rational energy policy will protect our interests in the long term. That means we need stable oil supplies while we find alternatives, and that means new domestic production to help replace our losses. Conservation is crucial, but only part of the answer.
 
FRANK H. MURKOWSKI
U.S. Senator from Alaska
Washington, March 1, 1991

HEADLINE: Learning From the Religions of Others

 BODY:
To the Editor:
You report on the Transfiguration parochial school in New York City's Chinatown, with 95 percent Chinese students, 80 percent of them Buddhists (news article, Feb. 16). 
 What Transfiguration does, despite possible impressions to the contrary, is to combine the cross and the dragon, not Christ and Buddha. The encouragement of Chinese culture is not synonymous with the elevation of the Buddhist faith of these pupils to parity in the school's curriculum with Roman Catholic instruction.
Indeed, the wonderfully tolerant, syncretic and inclusive sentiments of the largely working-class Buddhist parents that you record ("I am a Buddhist," says one, "and when I open my son's religion books, I see the same human values I believe in") puts into embarrassing perspective the school's insistence that "All children, regardless of their faith, attend all Masses and religious ceremonies" -- meaning Catholic ceremonies.
There are other, better models for the spirit of toleration. In St. Xavier's, the splendid Catholic mission school that I attended in Bombay in the 1950's, the Catholics and other Christians had Bible classes; the rest of us were instructed in morals, altogether free from Christianity's theology and rituals. The good deed of providing an excellent education was its own reward, here and in heaven. Perhaps the hope was that the very example of a religion that would evenhandedly dispense benefits to all, while denying itself the advantage of insidious indoctrination, would attract others to its fold.
This is the wiser, and the more appropriate, path for our increasingly multireligious society. Respect for other religions, even while one is wedded to one's own, has to be genuine and strong; it is a sine qua non for harmony and pluralism, values that make our society less fractious.
We should therefore pray for the day when Transfiguration makes the transition from the dragon to the Buddha.
 
JAGDISH BHAGWATI
New York, Feb. 28, 1991
 
The writer is Arthur Lehman Professor of Economics at Columbia University and visiting scholar at the Russell Sage Foundation.
