HEADLINE: Dangerous Thoughts . . . And Machines With Big Ideas

BYLINE: By Sherry Turkle; Sherry Turkle is a professor of sociology at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and the author of "The Second Self: Computers and the Human Spirit" and "Psychoanalytic Politics: Freud's French Revolution."

 BODY:

MODELS OF MY LIFE
By Herbert A. Simon.
Illustrated. 415 pp. New York:
Basic Books. $26.95. 
 As much as any one person, Herbert A. Simon has shaped the intellectual agenda of the human and social sciences in the second half of the 20th century. A brilliant polymath, Mr. Simon is a Nobel laureate in economics, a pioneer in political science, psychology and management and a founding father of artificial intelligence, the enterprise of trying to build machines that think. Now he has turned to autobiography and thus provides a window onto the subjective side of scientific achievement.
"Models of My Life," one of the books in the Alfred P. Sloan Foundation series, offers dramatic examples of science as the product of the whole scientist, of the fit among personality, scientific problems and strategies for their solution. As the work comes out of the life, so the life is shaped by the work. And while readers may come to this book thinking that artificial intelligence is an impersonal product of technological progress, they will come away seeing that it is a deeply personal enterprise -- an expression of the esthetic of the people who work in it and, more than that, a science of self-reflection, a way of thinking about one's own thought.
Herbert Simon was born into a middle-class German immigrant family in Milwaukee in 1916. From his earliest years, and notably from the days of his first algebra course in high school, he had a strong love of order. He was, for instance, "troubled by the fact that some quadratic equations had two solutions, some had one, and some none." Referring to his young self in the third person as "the boy," Mr. Simon comments that the intensity of the boy's feelings "seemed to reveal something of a Platonist within him, a desire to find pattern, and preferably simple pattern, in the world around him." He recalls that during his undergraduate years at the University of Chicago, in the early 1930's, a period of intense intellectual and political ferment, he argued philosophy with friends who were loyal to an unruly "Aristotelian-Thomist-Catholic-Trotskyism." But his own tastes led him to less esoteric intellectual seas. A political scientist by training, Mr. Simon studied decision making within organizations and used his findings to lay the foundation for a critique of neoclassical economic theory.
Mr. Simon developed a vision of rationalism adapted to 20th-century sensibilities. Neoclassical theory, he believed, had turned such abstract goals as what economists call "optimization" and "maximization" into fundamental laws of human behavior, and it had foundered, as he thought any inquiry into ultimate meaning would, on a preoccupation with absolutes. In his view, people who behave rationally are not optimizing anything at all; they are simply making decisions based on what their environment tells them they can and cannot do. People don't strive for the best, he maintained, they look for what is possible within the bounds of their given situation. Instead of satisfying desires, said Mr. Simon, human beings "satisfice," they search "for 'good enough' actions rather than optimal ones."
Mr. Simon tells us that this idea of "bounded rationality" has been his "lodestar for nearly fifty years." As he sees it, people torment themselves when they ask too-big questions about their ultimate desires. He believes the proper procedure is to determine the boundaries in which rationality can most constructively operate and then to keep one's sights within them. Such theoretical beliefs allow Mr. Simon to have a relatively untroubled eye. "Searching for the best can only dissipate scarce cognitive resources," he writes. Borrowing Voltaire's aphorism, he says that in science as in life, "the best is enemy of the good."
In the mid-1950's, Mr. Simon married his vision of human behavior to the possibilities offered by computer technology. The computer gave powerful expression to Mr. Simon's already-formed intellectual esthetic. His idea that humans solve problems under constraint was easily adapted to the task of programming a computer to solve problems using heuristic search -- a procedure that doesn't involve absolute rules but rules of thumb based on the knowledge of specific and bounded environments. And his idea that observation must be the foundation for abstraction led him to create a research strategy for artificial intelligence that he called "thinking aloud."
In "thinking aloud," Mr. Simon and his colleagues asked people to express their thoughts as they solved logical problems, and then they analyzed the transcripts of these sessions. The protocols of human beings playing games and solving puzzles were used to evaluate computer programs made to follow in human footsteps. Whereas some artificial intelligence researchers were content to leave aside the larger question of whether machines that perform intelligent tasks are doing them in the way people might, Mr. Simon took a very different tack. His artificial intelligence was psychology, not engineering. From the first, he says, "we were interested in simulating human problem solving, and not simply in demonstrating how computers could solve hard problems." His school of artificial intelligence was committed to the view that human intelligence is the manipulation of symbols and the implementation of rules. "For my money," he writes, "to show that something whose behavior looks very complex and erratic is really built from the combinatorics of very simple components is beautiful, not demeaning."
What Mr. Simon saw as self-evident, others found controversial. His critics questioned whether he had really demonstrated that people solve problems the way his programs did, and challenged the premise that a rule-based theory could explain the complexity of human behavior. In artificial intelligence, technical and philosophical arguments commingle. So, in addition to contributing to artificial intelligence as a scientific discipline, Mr. Simon became a chief spokesman for a view of the field as a revolutionary and salutary break with past limitations in philosophy and psychology. In Mr. Simon's opinion, the computer offered the 20th century a solution to the mind-body problem -- "how a physical system can have thoughts." He believed that if one put aside the too-literal analogies between the neurological organization of the brain and the wiring of the computer, there was a "more fruitful analogy": people and computers could be shown to process information and manipulate symbols in the same way.
In December 1955, Mr. Simon and his colleague, the artificial intelligence scientist Allen Newell, succeeded in writing a computer program that could prove mathematical theorems. Mr. Simon celebrated the achievement by walking into class in January and announcing to his students, "Over the Christmas holiday, Al Newell and I invented a thinking machine."
To the rest of the world, he was no less enthusiastic or unequivocal. In a letter to Bertrand Russell written the following October, Mr. Simon stressed that when the thinking machine had proved theorems from Russell and Alfred North Whitehead's "Principia Mathematica," the solutions had involved "genuine 'discovery.' " (To this missive Russell replied: "Thank you. . . . I am delighted to know that 'Principia Mathematica' can now be done by machinery. I wish Whitehead and I had known of this possibility before we both wasted ten years doing it by hand.") In a much-cited 1957 paper, Mr. Simon predicted that in 10 years "a digital computer will be the world's chess champion, unless the rules bar it from competition," and that after chess the possibilities were endless. Within the "visible future," Mr. Simon declared, "machines that think, that learn, and that create" will be able to handle the range of problems "coextensive with the range to which the human mind has been applied."
Things have not worked out as straightforwardly as Mr. Simon expected. A digital computer is not yet the world's chess champion, and it has turned out that it is easier to teach computers to solve logical problems than to recognize everyday objects, easier to make them play chess than make mud pies.
These disappointments have led some critics to claim that there are absolute limits on what computers can do and other critics to say that no matter what computers accomplish they will only be simulating thought. The field has sparked an impassioned and continuing debate about the qualities that might make people different from "thinking machines" in fundamental and unbridgeable ways.
In "Models of My Life," however, Mr. Simon barely acknowledges the four decades of controversy in which he and artificial intelligence have been engaged. He interprets and dismisses most of it as romantic resistance. "I think those who object to my characterizing man as simple want somehow to retain a deep mystery at his core," he writes. "In arguing that machines think, we are in the same fix as Darwin when he argued that man shares common ancestors with monkeys, or Galileo when he argued that the Earth spins on its axis."
Mr. Simon does not make his large claims and predictions in a spirit of hyperbole; in his eyes, modeling elements of human logical capacities in machines is the same as creating intelligence. His simplification of the scientific path ahead and his impatience with skeptics have always been in the service of starting and protecting a new discipline. He sees himself as a pioneer, inventor and missionary, whose job is to present artificial intelligence in as sharp and clear a form as possible. The task of recognizing limitations and pronouncing caveats is better left to others. His role was to announce a scientific revolution and declare it ready to set up provisional governments in all the human and social sciences.
One can hardly imagine a better fit between a man and his intellectual enterprise. Artificial intelligence is the expression of Herbert Simon the economist and Herbert Simon the man. He used thinking about his own thinking and strong personal convictions about bounded rationality to create the general shape of his theory. Conversely, when he contemplates his life he uses concepts drawn from his vision of the field. In "Models of My Life," artificial intelligence appears not only as a technical discipline but also, like psychoanalysis, as a structure for self-reflection.
Through its lens, Mr. Simon sees his life in terms of choices, branch points in a maze, searches and decisions. But there are no demons. Mr. Simon describes his life as a "maze without a Minotaur." Indeed, in 1970, he sought out Jorge Luis Borges in Argentina to discuss their shared metaphor of the labyrinth. For Mr. Simon, the search for patterns and rules goes beyond intellectual matters; he looks to it to provide him with a moral metric and a set of values for living. In his autobiography, he explores the meaning of intimate experiences through the formal propositions that might hold them together. Thus, he seems disappointed that Borges denied there was an abstract model underlying his mazes.
In Mr. Simon's hands, even the most emotionally charged events become occasions to discover rules and defend theorems. For instance, he describes an episode during which he contemplated infidelity with an attractive former student he calls Karen. He begins by saying that he "cannot deny" the proposition that one might be "genuinely in love with two women at once" and then shows how he used his experience to add an important new corollary to his theory of love: "You can love two or more women at once . . . but you cannot be loyal to more than one." In his account, Mr. Simon casts his wife in the role of dialogue partner for himself and Karen as they all agree that he was "asking for the moon," attempting the logically impossible. The consistency of Mr. Simon's scientific and personal esthetic, the penchant for the propositional, will surely draw fire from those with Freudian sensibilities who will be alienated by his search for simple rules in complicated situations and his tendency to close down potentially discomforting questions.
When, in 1965, Mr. Simon visited the school in Darmstadt, Germany, where his father had studied engineering, he was faced with questions about his father's real reasons for immigrating to America. Before leaving Germany, in 1903, his father had challenged a fellow student to a duel because of what Mr. Simon believes was an anti-Semitic comment. What, asks Mr. Simon, was his father's relationship to his Jewishness? What, wonders the reader, is Mr. Simon's own relationship to these elements of his past? But such questions are dismissed as irrelevant. They will not yield up facts: "Nothing we could now seek out in Darmstadt would reveal the secret of that student quarrel." And the feelings they would bring up would only be unhelpful: "The mists perform an important social function when they place a statute of limitations on man's memory of ancient wrongs."
The information-processing lens, like all theories of mind, is selective in what it places in the foreground and leaves in the background. It consistently leads Mr. Simon to see facts as more important than feelings and to see logic taking precedence over all. His lodestar principle of bounded rationality makes him comfortable with a situation in which there is little room for considering those things an information-processing model leaves out. He is comfortable with the mists that hide the Minotaur. In focusing on the maze, he falls squarely on one side of a division in the long history of thinking about human nature -- on the side that sees people as rational animals and rationalism as the source of a happy life. If deviation from rationalism is what gets us into trouble, let's be rational. If memory is painful, let's forget.
Of course, there has always been another approach -- to put oneself in touch with memory and Minotaurs. In this view, dreams of rational progress founder on the shoals of fantasy, passion and irrationality. In choosing a life as well as a science of simple propositions, patterns and principles, Mr. Simon is certainly a pre-Freudian, one who does not recognize a seamless web between rational and irrational. But the more important issue raised by this book is that Mr. Simon and his computational esthetic may be the harbingers of a post-Freudian world view. For many readers, Mr. Simon's view of human endeavor, of love and of work, will seem emblematic not of the pre-Freudian rationalism-that- was but of a new, sleeker rationalism-to-be -- a rationalism purged of utopian excess, committed to empirical studies and wedded to the most modern technology.
"Models of My Life" challenges us to think carefully about the costs as well as the benefits of this new rationalism, by suggesting that it may blind us to the Minotaurs in our mazes. And since the parents of scientific revolutions are often more effective if they gaze on their progeny with untroubled eyes, Mr. Simon's book challenges us to do what he has not.

 
 
'I DON'T FEEL LIKE I'M IN A MAZE'
 If there is one thing holding together Herbert A. Simon's work in economics, artificial intelligence and psychology, it is the idea that making decisions is like going through a maze. But even he acknowledged that the maze metaphor can be confining.
After all, "one doesn't spend most of one's time making decisions. One lives. I don't feel like I'm in a maze," he said during a telephone interview from the University of Minnesota in Minneapolis, where he was attending a conference on cognitive psychology. "The choices we make lead up to actual experiences. It is one thing to decide to climb a mountain. It is quite another to be on top of it."
Mr. Simon said that "any model of human behavior that focuses on decision making gives us an overrational idea of humans. Artificial intelligence is only a model of human choice, not of human emotion." So, while a computer program can simulate what human beings are doing when they're making decisions, "no one has ever tried to model, say, two people married to each other."
Why focus on the rational rather than on the emotional? That choice, Mr. Simon said, "may be a commentary on my personality. Being reasonable, if not rational, is very important to me."
His decision to write his autobiography, "Models of My Life," was one of his eminently reasonable decisions. Mr. Simon, a professor of computer science and psychology at Carnegie-Mellon University, said he began to reminisce about his life when Pamela McCorduck interviewed him for her book "Machines Who Think." As he recalled, "she said she wanted to do a biography of me, but then she found something more interesting to do." So Mr. Simon wrote it himself, thinking, as he does about many things in his life, that it was for the best. After all, he said, "I have access to some sources that no one else has."
Mr. Simon said that the experience of writing an autobiography hasn't changed his thinking about thinking and that history hasn't changed his thinking about thinking computers. Though his prediction that a computer would be the world's chess champion by 1967 did not come true, he said, "I still feel good about my prediction. Only the time frame was a bit short." -- SARAH BOXER

PUB-DATE: March 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 7; Column 1; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 3009 words

HEADLINE: He Had Money, Women, an S.&L. Now Don Dixon Has Jail

BYLINE: By N.R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
With a price tag to taxpayers that may reach $500 billion, the savings and loan bailout is destined to become the most expensive financial debacle in the country's history. About 550 failed savings institutions have already been closed, their assets brought under the Government's control to be sold. Deregulation, allowing savings units to invest in everything from raw land to risky "junk bonds," is largely to blame for the failures, but entrepreneurs who rolled into the industry and played fast and loose with the money are also culprits. Federal prosecutors won convictions of 403 of them of fraud. Among the most notorious is Donald Ray Dixon, the head of Vernon Savings and Loan, who could soon get the stiffest sentence of any. His story, culled from court documents and interviews, is emblematic of the torrid living that ransacked the industry. 
 Some people's lives are built on chicanery and deceit; they become snake oil salesmen and confidence men, looters of other people's dreams. Donald Ray Dixon was a savings and loan man, but his life appears to have been built on these same sands, and before his mountain got washed away, it grew very tall indeed.
When the 51-year-old Mr. Dixon was convicted in December of 23 counts of fraud, after a six-week trial speckled with lurid testimony of call girls and hot tubs, yachts and $25,000 shotguns, it brought to a close an extraordinary saga of trickery that may well mark the very depths of the shameful savings and loan debacle. Throughout the country, ruined savings and loans shelter stories aplenty of rapacious greed by owners with long and sticky fingers. There are pirates enough to fill a thousand bedtime story books. But few rival Don Dixon.
"Don Dixon was the highest of the high fliers among the savings and loan crooks," said United States Attorney General Dick Thornburgh after Mr. Dixon's conviction. "His excessive life style and illegal management practices stood as a symbol of the wrongdoing of our national thrift industry."
The craggy-faced Mr. Dixon, who once earned a million dollars a year and wheedled an audience with the Pope (bestowing a $40,000 gift on the Pontiff), now waits in despair for his sentencing on March 26. He faces up to 120 years in prison and a fine of $560,000. He is expected to be dealt the lengthiest jail sentence of any savings defendant.
Mr. Dixon was initially refused bail and remanded to the Mansfield Law Enforcement Center in Dallas. Suspicion persisted among Federal prosecutors that he has squirreled away considerable mad money in Europe and Curacao and, if freed, would flee the country. But he was stricken by a heart attack on Jan. 6 and has since undergone surgery. After his release from the hospital, he was permitted to return home so long as his wife, Dana, surrendered her passport.
 
A Place That Regulators
Call Vermin, Tex.
 The curtain rises on this story of avarice in the same place it falls -- the dusty ranch town of Vernon, Tex., 50 miles west of Wichita Falls and two hours northwest of Dallas. Some 13,000 people call it home, as well as a factory that stitches Boy Scout uniforms. Vernon was named after George Washington's cherished residence, though, in time, Federal regulators would drop their respect and come to call the place Vermin.
Don Dixon's father, W.D. Dixon, was an editor of The Vernon Daily Record and a commentator on the local radio station. Mr. Dixon studied architecture at the Rice Institute, but transferred after two years to University of California at Los Angeles, where he picked up a degree in business in 1960.
Once out of school, Mr. Dixon fell into construction and development, starting with Raldon Homes, one of the biggest homebuilders in Dallas and Houston during the 1970's. The 1974 recession, however, badly ravaged the heavily indebted company and lenders forced Mr. Dixon out as one of the principal managers. He resumed his career with Dondi Construction, a condominium builder. Outwardly, Mr. Dixon appeared reasonably strait-laced during his Raldon days. At Dondi, he took to wearing gold chains and leather vests. He was having his fun.
The Vernon Savings and Loan Association had been founded in 1960 by R.B. Tanner, an erstwhile bank examiner, and it grew in a slumberous way. The only leather around the place was people's wallets. By 1981, Vernon was unmistakably robust, with $82 million in assets and $90,000 in delinquent loans, a mere hiccup.
Mr. Tanner wished to retire. The mood struck Don Dixon to buy the place and he offered $5.8 million. You could see his reasoning. He was building a lot of housing and having his own savings and loan to support his projects was a wonderful prospect to contemplate. As he would later say, "If I were to control my own destiny, I wanted to have a shot at the other end of the business."
By July 1982, Mr. Dixon had himself a savings and loan without much damage to his pocketbook. He put only 20 percent down; Mr. Tanner and other Vernon stockholders agreed to accept a note for the balance and to be paid quarterly.
Quickly, Mr. Dixon became steeped in the joy of his new purchase. He went haring after large deposits by dangling fat interest rates. With those funds, he began some slippery lending to condominium developments and costly commercial real estate projects. A good deal of the money entered the pockets of Mr. Dixon's cronies, and some of it, regulators charged, went to Mr. Dixon himself.
Mr. Dixon was not bashful about the wealth lying at his fingertips. He made a vocation out of exaggerated living. He redecorated a massive $1 million house in the tony San Diego suburb of Del Mar. The money to pay the bills was plucked from Vernon, and why not? He insisted he entertained customers amid its splendor (a multimillion-dollar art collection looked on benignly.)
There were oh so many mirthful parties, and Mr. Dixon loved to show off with special touches. At one Christmas bash, tiny Christmas trees floated in the swimming pool.
When the ski season beckoned, there was a better place to regroup: Mr. Dixon's chalet in Beaver Creek, Colo. Gerald Ford lived down the block.
Too bad Vernon didn't hang on a bit longer. When the money ran out, Mr. Dixon had a $7 million hillside house in Rancho Sante Fe, N.M., under construction. It was destined to have an 11-car garage, a stable for 10 horses, tennis courts with viewing stands, three "Maui" waterfalls and $100,000 worth of hand-picked boulders for landscaping.
And the transportation was always more than adequate. According to court records, Vernon money paid for a $2.6 million yacht named High Spirits, a Rolls-Royce and a Ferarri dealership. Mr. Dixon also bought shotguns priced at $25,000.
When Mr. Dixon relaxed, he relaxed big. In October 1983, he and Mrs. Dixon took a couple along with them on a 10-day tour of Europe. Mrs. Dixon labeled it the trip "a flying house party" and a "gastronomique fantastique." Along the way, the foursome stuffed themselves at seven three-star French restaurants. There was a marvelous lunch in Lyons of truffle soup and champagne. Afterward, the celebrated chef Paul Bocuse lined up his 12 sous-chefs for an inspection by the Dixons.
These cheerful details are well known because Mrs. Dixon had recorded them in a 17-page diary which became part of the court record. Vernon paid for the excursion, and Mr. Dixon justified it as a market study for a fancy French restaurant he intended to open in Dallas. It never opened.
 
Church Business in Rome;
Call Girls in California

In the spring of 1985, Mr. Dixon took along Roman Catholic Bishop Leo T. Maher of San Diego on another European jaunt. They traveled on a company-owned Falcon 50 and rested in the finest hotels. The highlight was when Bishop Maher arranged a visit with Pope John Paul II. Mrs. Dixon didn't know what to say. Mr. Dixon always felt you could never go wrong with a nice present. He handed the Pope a $40,000 oil painting, "Night Sentry" by Olaf Wieghorst, plucked from Vernon's huge collection of Western art.
Representatives of Bishop Maher later said they had planned to go Europe on church business and accepted the Dixon invitation for a ride. The Dixons said the Bishop did not know that Vernon paid for the trip.
Much fun went on at a $2 million beach house in Solana Beach, Calif., that prosecutors said was Mr. Dixon's residence and that the defense argued was a Vernon office and hotel for employees and borrowers. Robert Hauberg, one of the Federal prosecutors, said that Mr. Dixon schemed to hide the house's rent payments -- averaging $15,000 or more a month -- from banking regulators.
Witnesses testified that Mr. Dixon convinced Jack Atkinson, a Vernon borrower and real estate developer, to pay the rent with advances on construction loans. Mr. Atkinson testified that he considered the deal "the cost of doing business" with Mr. Dixon, who he said let him use the house six or seven times in the three years he paid rent.
There was more. For example, the prostitutes. They were hired in 1984 and 1985 to entertain Vernon's directors. There were courtroom descriptions of naked frolicking in the hot tub at the beach house.
Karen Wilkening of San Diego, known as the "Rolodex Madam," testified that some of her high-priced call girls worked several Vernon parties. Their fee was $400 per woman, and they were said to have been paid more than $15,000 all together. At one party, said the Rolodex Madam, $500 was tacked on the bill because one prostitute spent the entire evening with a customer. A Vernon employee fingered Mr. Dixon as the person.
But Mr. Dixon later insisted that there was no truth to that ill-mannered accusation. He said he had occupied the evening in the company of his mistress, Patricia Oberman, a real estate saleswoman. Sure enough, his mistress confirmed the story.
On the stand, Mr. Dixon maintained that he had not intended to hire prostitutes to invigorate his directors. He said he thought the women were simply hostesses, good for some convivial conversation. "I knew they were hired from an escort service," he said, "but I had no idea what services they would perform. I specifically ordered there was to be no sex paid for." He insisted that all the partygoers were "very well-behaved."
Mr. Dixon did acknowledge that, at Vernon's expense, he took L. Linton Bowman 3d, then the Texas savings and loan commissioner, on "goodwill entertainment trips," because he wanted him to see some antique dealerships he felt Vernon ought to own (and that Mr. Bowman did bless). Two employees from the yacht High Spirits told of a 1985 voyage during which one them said she slept with Mr. Dixon and the other said she bunked with Mr. Bowman. One said they were each handed $2,000 for "expenses."
Another time, Mr. Dixon also admitted to hiring topless dancers from the Million Dollar Saloon in Dallas as a special treat for one of Vernon's board meetings.
 
Company Money for
Wright, Kemp and Coelho
 Mr. Dixon was also charged with permitting Vernon officers to make political contributions by reimbursing themselves through company expense accounts. Mr. Dixon said he did not know that it was illegal for companies to donate to Federal election campaigns.
Among those getting contributions, the government said, were Tony Coelho of California, then the House majority whip; Representative Jack Kemp, now the Secretary of the Department of Housing, and Representative Martin Frost of Texas. So was House Speaker Jim Wright, who resigned his Congressional seat in the wake of a probe of his personal and campaign finances. The Government said the politicians were unaware that the payments might have been illegal.
Former Vernon officers testified that Mr. Dixon authorized them to reimburse themselves for political contributions. John Hill, an executive vice president, said he used to scribble down personal items on his expense sheets to recoup the money. Once he charged the institution for a "weed whacker."
During the four years of merrymaking in which Mr. Dixon owned Vernon, the institution saw its loan assets soar by 2,000 percent; it rose to 15th among Texas savings and loans.
But almost from the beginning, Vernon started to groan under the weight of Mr. Dixon's prodigal spending. Bad loans began to rot the place. Federal regulators drove out Mr. Dixon late in 1986. He left in style, saying his goodbyes to employees over hors d'oeuvres and cocktails at the big Vernon hangar at the Addison, Tex., airport.
The Federal Home Loan Bank Board declared Vernon insolvent and closed it in March 1987. Vernon's assets stood at $1.4 billion, but fully 96 percent of them were loans in default. Bailing out Vernon would cost taxpayers at least $1.3 billion.
The indictments were soon to follow.
Mr. Dixon's didn't come until last June 13, but by that time, seven other Vernon officers had been convicted of or had pleaded guilty to criminal charges. The sentences ranged from probation to a 30-year prison term for Woody Lemons, Vernon's former chairman. Mr. Dixon was charged with 38 counts of conspiracy and bank fraud for misapplying Vernon money. Rather than bring charges against Mr. Dixon for the ruinous loans that helped topple Vernon, the prosecutors tackled the sorts of crime that juries find easier to comprehend. Mr. Dixon pleaded innocent.
After he surrendered to the Dallas F.B.I. office and was released on a no-cash bond, Mr. Dixon declared, "All the stories you've heard about the millions of dollars the savings and loans crooks took -- it's totally dead wrong." He said the actual culprits were the politicans and the regulators. Mr. Dixon said he was unemployed and was by no means flush. By this point, he had filed for personal bankruptcy. "There are no hidden bank accounts," he said. "No millions."
To defend him, Mr. Dixon hired William (Billy) Ravkind, a happy-go-lucky lawyer of seductive charms, paying him a retainer of $200,000 in cash and $200,000 in cowboy art. Mr. Ravkind called the charges against his client "bull corn."
 
A Well-Intentioned Maverick
Out for the Industry's Good?
 The trial began in Dallas at the end of October, presided over by United States District Judge A. Joe Fish. Mr. Dixon listened to the parade of testimony of his unorthodox practices. Then he took the stand and sang a song of homiletic tragedy. He blamed Congress and Federal banking regulators for the S.&L. crisis and his own legal woes. He described himself as a well-intentioned maverick who battled for changes he felt would benefit the savings and loan industry.
After nine days of deliberation, the jury of seven women and five men found him guilty of 23 of the 38 charges, including those related to the leasing of the beach house and three charges of using Vernon funds to hire prostitutes. Mr. Dixon was acquitted of allegations that he used Vernon funds to reimburse employees for political contributions and for out-of-state trips with Mr. Bowman.
In his closing arguments, David Jarvis, one of the prosecutors, said Mr. Dixon used Vernon as "his personal piggy bank." He went on, "I think you'll see over and over that Don Dixon was a master manipulator. He manipulated people to get what he wanted."
And that is what is putting Mr. Dixon behind bars -- without the fast cars, the big houses, the loose women and with the fun, long, long gone.

 
 
JAIL TERMS AND FINES
 The conviction of Donald Dixon was viewed by the Justice Department as one of the biggest victories in its pursuit of culprits from the savings and loan crisis and added an important name to the lengthening list of defendants it has put behind bars.
The Justice Department said that in the last two years Federal prosecutors won the convictions of 403 people for savings and loan fraud. More than 315 of them, the department added, have been given jail time.
The trend among judges has been to hand out longer and longer sentences. The lengthiest term meted out so far is 30 years for Woody Lemons, former chairman of the Vernon Savings and Loan Association. He was found guilty by a jury on Dec. 6, 1989, after being indicted on 13 counts of fraud.
The department said that 98 directors or officers of savings and loans were charged with crimes during the two-year period; 78 were convicted and three acquitted. The remaining cases have not yet been settled.
In addition, judges have imposed fines amounting to $4.8 million. Some $231 million in restitution has also been mandated, though the Justice Department has found it difficult to recover much of this money.
 
ONE WHO PLEADED GUILTY
 
 
Don Dixon is perhaps the biggest scalp so far for the Justice Department in its crackdown on savings and loan fraud. But nearly as gratifying for Federal prosecutors was the guilty plea by Edwin T. McBirney 3d, whose four-year romp as chairman of the Sunbelt Savings Association, another failed Texas savings institution, created losses of $3 billion for American taxpayers.
The Justice Department announced the plea by Mr. McBirney the day after a Dallas jury convicted Mr. Dixon of 23 counts of fraud and other crimes. Under the plea bargain with Federal prosecutors, the 38-year-old Mr. McBirney agreed to plead guilty to two counts of a 17-count indictment, one for fraud and one for tax evasion. He faces a maximum prison term of 15 years and $8.5 million in fines and related civil damages.
During his tenure at Sunbelt, Mr. McBirney devoted much of his energies to spending money. It won him the nickname "Fast Eddie" and Sunbelt the name "Gunbelt Savings."
When he ran Sunbelt, Mr. McBirney lived as high as Mr. Dixon. He financed the purchase of 84 Rolls-Royces from the Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh. He took people on gambling trips to Las Vegas in one of Sunbelt's seven private planes. He threw his share of spectacular parties. One Halloween bash featured a live elephant and entertainment by the Spinners. A Christmas party was distinguished by a live bear.

PUB-DATE: March 17, 1991

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2830 words

HEADLINE: Random House's Glitzy New Imprint

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
The weekly editorial meetings of Turtle Bay Books can veer almost anywhere. They are never dour and they are never strictly confined to the peculiarities of manuscripts. Joni Evans, the compulsively talkative editor who runs Turtle Bay, leaned forward and confessed, "What we normally talk about at these meetings is our hair. But today nothing about hair."
Susan Kamil said she badly needed everyone to read a novel she was about to edit. And she said the publicity people were distressed by use of the word "caper" in promotional copy for the book. "Caper is a category that is really, really weak," she said. "It is no category. Get caper out of the copy." 
 Joni Evans said, "It's not really a caper. It's more like picaresque. We can play with picaresque."
Julie Grau mentioned that she had been desperate to get hold of a manuscript and she had finally got it and it was "so mediocre."
"No!" Joni Evans said.
"You're kidding," Susan Kamil said.
"O.K., O.K., where are we?" Joni Evans said. "Where are we?"
Karen Rinaldi mentioned an idea that was a little cryptic.
Joni Evans said, "I don't know who buys this in book form unless you're a brilliant writer."
Julie Grau mentioned that she thought it was the birthday of one of their authors, because she knows it coincides with the birthday of a former boyfriend.
"Send flowers?" Susan Kamil wondered.
Joni Evans scribbled a reminder. "Birthday," she said. "Do something!"
Turtle Bay Books is five women in pursuit of the big time. Whether it is bound for glory is not known yet, but it is bound for attention. For one thing, it is the newest imprint to join the cluster under the vast Random House Inc., the country's largest issuer of general-interest books. And at its nucleus is Joni Evans, long one of the most visible, most prosperous and most voluble people in publishing, a business increasingly punctuated by the clashes of big egos, big dollars and big risks, a business that, even to its practitioners, often seems totally inchoate.
 
Volcanic Gossip
 The gestation of Turtle Bay began in a splashy enough way, resulting in the sort of volcanic publishing gossip that gets told in bars and around water coolers. At the end of October 1990, Ms. Evans abruptly was replaced in her job as the publisher of the Random House imprint by Harold Evans (no relation), who had been editor of Conde Nast Traveler magazine.
Ms. Evans said she had asked to have her own imprint several months before the switch took place, but almost everyone in publishing, including Ms. Evans, was startled at the timing of the change.
When she came to Random House three years ago from archrival Simon & Schuster, where she headed the adult trade department and had run Linden Press, Ms. Evans was to establish Turtle Bay. Six weeks after her arrival, her plans were upset when she was offered the publisher's mantle. After three years in the job, Ms. Evans said she had grown increasingly discontent with the minutiae of overseeing a list of some 100 books and wanted to deal with a smaller grouping of about 25 titles.
When the surprise October announcement came, some people in publishing assumed displeasure with Ms. Evans's performance provoked the change, although Alberto Vitale, Random House's chief executive, denies that, and the lists under her were studded with an unusual number of best sellers.
The wider conjecture was that the timing had to do with rumored rumblings at the Conde Nast magazine empire run by the unpredictable Samuel I. Newhouse Jr., who also presides over Random House. According to this thinking, Tina Brown, the editor of Vanity Fair, one of the most vibrant Conde Nast magazines, was being wooed to accept a job at a Hollywood studio, and if she left, so would her husband, Harry Evans. To keep them both, the conjecture goes, Mr. Evans was swiftly handed the plum Random House job, months before Ms. Evans expected to vacate it.
 
Intimate Feeling
 For the time being, Turtle Bay is installed in boxy temporary quarters on the 12th floor of the Random House offices on East 50th Street near Third Avenue. In mid-April, it will relocate to a quaint nearby brownstone, to afford a snugger, more intimate feeling; the Random House offices give off a vibration of institutional charmlessness.
The five women who comprise Turtle Bay hope to become something of a throwback to a bygone era, when publishers were small and lavished inordinate attention on their authors. They have great fun together. They are emphatically outgoing, decidedly free-spirited, vulnerable to contagious laughter. The effect is festive, college-dormitory-like. What's paying $1 million for a six-page proposal if you can't laugh about it?
Nine sheets of paper summarize Turtle Bay's hopes and dreams: they list the first 45 books under contract -- most years away from publication. It has the scent of a powerful list: commercial fiction from the likes of Mario Puzo and Joan Collins, autobiographies from Michael Caine and Vanessa Redgrave, a biography of Jim Morrison by Albert Goldman, serious fiction from A. S. Byatt and Ann Beattie and nonfiction from Holly Brubach and Suzannah Lessard, a smorgasbord of fiction and nonfiction, the literary and the commercial.
Nevertheless, Turtle Bay Books arrives at a troublous time for book publishing -- still dizzied by several years of slumping sales at many houses. Although the privately held Random House says it had a strong year in 1990, the sagging economy has wrung its effect on book buyers. For years, breathlessly large advances have been doled out and mortifying amounts of returned books have swamped warehouses. The big books sell bigger, the small books sell smaller and everyone complains.
Book publishing is exhausting work, fraught with uncertainty, riddled with paradox. Publishers must have quixotic faith and endure gambler's luck. You hit a few big ones, then pass through long dry spells and then another winner comes roaring home. How well Turtle Bay's books will be parlayed into business success will remain uncertain for several years, though Ms. Evans has demonstrated a knack for spotting books that captivate a wide readership.
"What she's great at is she has very strong authorial relationships and she's a very good commercial book editor," said Mort Janklow, the literary agent. "And she's a very dogmatic and aggressive acquirer."
 
Bubbling and Blunt
 Authors who have worked with her mention her bubbling enthusiasm and fidelity to the books -- and her blunt appraisals. "She says these incredible sentences to you that cause you to walk around the house kicking lamps over and saying, 'What does she mean by that?' and then it dawns on you that that's a brilliant insight," said Julia Phillips, author of the just-published "You'll Never Eat Lunch in This Town Again."
In her new situation, the 48-year-old Ms. Evans will need to shine. Turtle Bay will operate within the sprawling empire of Mr. Newhouse, known to act with seemingly impetuous swiftness with the personnel of his publishing holdings. Editors and publishers seem to be extracted from their offices in the blink of an eye. (For now, Ms. Evans is thought to get on fine with Mr. Newhouse.)
And, then, there is the immutable law that forbids anything from going predictably in book publishing. "With books, you don't control your product," Ms. Evans said. "There are so many variables. Your writer gets sick, he gets writer's block, he gets bad, he gets brilliant, he gets heartburn, his wife divorces him, he says he'll deliver in 1991 and he delivers in 1997. Or his next-door neighbor delivers the same thing and his book becomes obsolete."
Friday morning, and Ms. Evans extinguished brush fires, poured a diet drink, asked Jason Epstein, Random House's editorial director, how he liked her new hairdo (he was rather noncommittal) and revisited the birth of Turtle Bay.
"I turned to the people I knew and liked," she said about the assembling of her staff. Susan Kamil, an executive editor at Random House whom Ms. Evans hired years ago at Simon & Schuster, is one of the editors. Julie Grau, a young assistant editor who worked for Ms. Evans when she was publisher, is another. Fleshing out the staff are Karen Rinaldi, who operates as a junior editor and an editorial assistant, and Christina Gratz, Ms. Evans's assistant.
 
The Name Game
 With the personnel decided on, the maddening, crazed pursuit of a name commenced. Ms. Evans should have known it would be impossible. When offered the job of publisher of Random House, at the age of 45, she was torn over whether to accept it because she was so enthusiastic about having an imprint again. She sought the wisdom of her friend, Robert Gottlieb, the editor of The New Yorker. Mr. Gottlieb said she must take the job and gave her two reasons: "First, you have no right being happy at 45, and, second, you will never think of a name for your imprint."
He was almost right. For six weeks, she and her colleagues sifted through scores of possibilities; mothers and authors and cousins twice-removed called with suggestions. Chicory Books. A Priori Books. Top Drawer Books. Outta Here Books. Monkey Business Books. Multi Ego Press. The names that struck a chord were subjected to a title search by the legal department to make sure no one else had claims to them. Each search seemed to turn up a problem.
One day Norman Mailer phoned and said, "I have your name: Watermark Books."
"I said, 'That's it, that's it, I love it,' " Ms. Evans said. "Then we did a title search and we found out that Princeton University has a small Watermark Books and a place in Arizona has it. And we called them up and we found out we will be sued or go to jail if we even think about using it."
At last, a Random House lawyer, Lesley Oelsner, proposed Turtle Bay Books, since the division would exist in what is known as the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan. Better yet, the lawyer had already taken the trouble to do the title search and found it unencumbered. Ms. Evans disliked it. She would say it to herself and images of Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles would dance through her head.
Then desperation set in and she decided she really adored it. "We started to say it with more authority," she explained. "We'd come in every day and say, 'I hate it, I hate it.' Then we'd say, 'I love it,' 'I love it,' and it started to sound better."
Turtle Bay intends to grow to 25 titles a year within three years, but will publish about 16 next year, starting on Valentine's Day with "How We Met: Recalling Life's Most Romantic Moments" by Nancy Cobb. The book recounts the first meetings of various couples that "resulted in bliss."
Realistically, Ms. Evans doesn't expect to break even until Turtle Bay's third year, since she begins with no backlist books, timeless titles that sell year after year and fortify the bottom line.
Ms. Evans didn't want to discuss revenue and profit projections for Turtle Bay, but publishing executives estimated that a house of that size might expect to amass sales of some $7 million to $10 million in three years, and, if it's successful, might achieve a pretax profit margin approaching 25 percent after five, an impressive amount. Linden Press, she said, attracted revenues of close to $10 million after five years.
Turtle Bay built its beginning list basically by assembling works that the three editors had previously signed up at Random House. A few were let go, because the authors wanted to stay put. For example, Kirk Douglas was being edited by both Ms. Evans and David Rosenthal and Mr. Douglas wished to continue his relationship with Mr. Rosenthal.
 
The Big Bucks
 The books carry advances of anywhere from less than $10,000 to more than $1 million. Turtle Bay's arrangement with the parent Random House is the same as that for the publishing house's other cluster of imprints. Editors can buy any books up to a price of $150,000. Beyond that figure, they need the blessing of Alberto Vitale.
Book publishing in a small house can be frighteningly chancy. The performance of a few titles can vastly affect the house's fortunes. At any publisher, big or small, a sprinkling of titles supplies the profits. Ms. Evans agrees with the suppositions of other editors that as few as 15 to 25 percent of books published by a house in any given year actually earn back their advances and make money -- hopefully enough to more than cancel out losses on all the other titles.
Turtle Bay's employees hope to bring a commonsensical approach to bear. Watching printings and other details will be more obsessively important to them. "When you're small, you must be on guard," Ms. Evans said. "You call authors five times a month to say how are you doing rather than one time a month, because it matters five times a month."
Heavy returns from book stores remain the hoary thorn of publishing. Returns average around 25 to 30 percent, and often exceed 50 percent on many books, higher than was true several years ago. "The fault is optimism," Ms. Evans said. "The optimism of the publisher and the optimism of the bookstores. It's human error overriding the controls. You get a frenzy going when something's happening. You get some good news and you say, 'By god, I better print another 10,000.' "
Ms. Evans said her biggest error at Linden was failing to develop a backlist early. So the other day she was trekking through New Jersey pursuing a book project highly unlikely for her. It would be an authorized corporate history, significant quantities of which would be bought year after year by the company itself.
In picking manuscripts, the Turtle Bay editors have diverging but complementary tastes. While she has wide breath, Ms. Evans is best known for her commercial instincts in fiction. Though she overlaps with Ms. Evans, Susan Kamil leans more toward literary books. Julie Grau has identified herself with literary fiction and serious nonfiction, and has a fond taste for foreign novels. She reads Italian, French, German and Hebrew.
 
The Bug Book
 As a small house, Turtle Bay feels it can often expedite things. "We're hungry and young," Ms. Evans said. "Speed is our best weapon."
Just the other day, an agent brought Susan Kamil a proposal by a first-time author named Kevin Cook. Entitled "Night Crawlers," it was a nonfiction work about exterminators. The proposal related the trials of a Chicago exterminator (he put his wife through law school and then she left him, having wearied of the scornful looks he got when he told people about how he spent his days) and wove in oddities like the spiders that crawl up the Empire State Building. As it happens, Ms. Kamil "loves bugs."
She spoke with the author and suggested that the book encompass the whole world of pest control and this zoo of creatures that exists. She showed the idea to Ms. Evans. She liked a bug book. She showed it to Ms. Grau. She said, "Who would read a book about bugs?" (Following further discussion, she sort of saw how some people would.)
That day, Ms. Kamil made a bid and a few days later had signed up the project. "So we've got a bug book," Ms. Kamil said. "Great!"
 
 
 
THE JONI EVANS STORY -- AND STYLE
 Joni Evans is a spirited woman with short salt-and-pepper hair. Enthusiasm effervesces out of her and seems to encapsulate her, and there is something of the stand-up comic about her manner. If not in book publishing, she would be working the Borscht Belt.
Reading endless pages of unremitting slush for McCall's and The Ladies' Home Journal was her entrance into publishing. She did it for two years, starting in 1964.
"If you found anything good, you couldn't publish it," she said. "I read a wonderful Joyce Carol Oates story and it was too dark. Everything had to be upbeat. You couldn't lose sleep over anything."
After working for a while as a reader for Book of the Month Club, she became a "manuscript girl" at the William Morrow publishing house. This was 1968. "I remember the first day I wore a pants suit to the office," she recalled. "I was shaking because I was afraid I would get fired. Everyone was staring at me. The next day, everyone showed up in pants."
She graduated to junior editor at Morrow, then migrated to Simon & Schuster in 1974 as subsidiary rights director. Five years later, she became the head of Linden Press, where she published a mix of commercial and literary authors like Jeffrey Archer, Anita Brookner and Lois Gould.
In 1978, during a lunch break, Ms. Evans married Richard Snyder, the chairman of Simon & Schuster, and in 1985 she became the head of trade publishing. In early 1987, their vinegary marriage dissolved, to widespread publicity, leading her to leave Simon & Schuster.
The acrimonious divorce case went to trial and still awaits the approval of the presiding judge. "I think it's like the S.& L. crisis," Ms. Evans said. "We'll know the end of it in 1999."

SECTION: Section 6; Part 2; Page 28; Column 2; Men's Fashions of The TimesMagazine

LENGTH: 1388 words

HEADLINE: Bottled Message

BYLINE: BY LAUREL GRAEBER

 BODY:
IN THE OLD DAYS, A MAN'S MAJOR concern with smell was that he'd better not. Legend has it that the cowboys of yore took to lilac water, hoping to cancel out the sour notes with a sweet one. But a lot has changed since then. As we nose into the 1990's, fragrance companies are wooing men with the promise not only of smelling decent, or even sexy, but of acquiring an aura that packs a whole image into a single whiff.
 "I've seen more willingness to be creative in the men's market than the women's," says Michael D. Sweeney, vice president at International Flavors and Fragrances, a New York-based company that formulates scents for much of the industry. 
One reason may be the conviction of perfumers that men are now really interested. Until a few years ago, most fragrance experts believed that as much as 70 percent of the men's products were purchased by women, as gifts or even for themselves. But a recent survey conducted by The Gallup Organization found that three-quarters of the 808 men queried had purchased one or more bottles of aftershave or cologne during the past 12 months, and half had worn a fragrance five or more times within the previous week.
"Men's fragrance has become a more accepted part of an everyday grooming package," says Andrew Shore, an analyst for Prudential-Bache Securities. "Skin care isn't there yet. But cologne is relatively innocuous."
 To lure men by the nose, companies are first appealing to their other senses. In terms of visual draws, faux granite seems to be a trend, appearing in the bottle designs of both Fendi Uomo, introduced in 1989, and Red for Men, a new Giorgio Beverly Hills fragrance, which boasts 551 ingredients and is scheduled to go on the market this spring.
 Name is important, too, preferably short and memorable. Brut, which Michael Sweeney considers an all-time great one, is "a nice little four-letter word," he says, encompassing both the elegance of champagne and all the macho you could wish for. Among the newer men's fragrance names, he gives special points to Boss, introduced by Hugo Boss.
 "It brings to mind Bruce Springsteen," says Sweeney. "Men may not know Hugo Boss, but they certainly know 'the Boss.' " One name men are likely to be tripping over this spring is Egoiste, the new men's fragrance from Chanel. Although the product has already been launched successfully abroad, it has raised a few eyebrows here.
 "I don't know how Egoiste will translate in a supposedly kinder, gentler nation," says Allan Mottus, an industry consultant and publisher of the newsletter "The Informationist." "It sounds smug."
 So, initially, does the campaign. To introduce the product to the press, Chanel had a Manhattan luxury apartment decorated as the Egoiste's abode and dispensed copies of his personal journal, designed to tantalize at least as much as the diary of the late Laura Palmer of "Twin Peaks." Like Laura, the Egoiste seems to have been conceived as a character to be barely glimpsed but discussed incessantly. In television commercials airing in late April, when the fragrance comes to New York as a Bloomingdale's exclusive, viewers will see hordes of beautiful wronged women opening and slamming balcony doors of a Riviera hotel as they hurl epithets in French at the unseen E-man. The high-camp approach begs for parody, and according to Lyle Saunders, Chanel's executive director of creative services, "We'll be very disappointed if 'Saturday Night Live' doesn't do it."
 A macho campaign that doesn't take itself too seriously may be a refreshing change, but it's by no means the only unusual approach. Liz Claiborne Inc., whose one-and-a-half-year-old scent for men, Claiborne, has lagged behind some of the powerhouse brands, has been test marketing new radio spots that highlight the sensitive man of the moment. They include original songs: a baseball-field reverie and a rumination on romance that sound so un-Madison Avenue some listeners have mistaken them for singles. Both end with the Claiborne tag line, "Man is not so simple, after all."
 "This company doesn't do sex," asserts Suzanne Cassano, vice president of marketing. "When we talked to men in focus groups, they all felt they wanted to be viewed as more complex."
 Giorgio Beverly Hills also appears to be going for the whole man. Like Calvin Klein's enormously successful men's versions of Obsession and Eternity, Giorgio's Red for Men is another attempt to cash in on an already strong women's brand. But the company is also putting a hefty budget behind its "life style" commercials, which represent the first time Giorgio has used television to advertise a men's fragrance.
 "We show a man in different settings," says Linda LoRe, senior vice president of marketing. "It's not just in the boardroom, or with the baby, or in bed."
 This multifaceted approach may be extending to the choice of a celebrity symbol. Although Guess Parfum, like most of those launching a fragrance, claims it is going for an 18- to 35-year-old audience, the company is introducing its new Guess Men scent with the same star who has appeared in Guess sportswear advertisements: craggy Tom Skerritt. Skerritt, who is obviously over 35, played one of the training officers in "Top Gun" and seems to fit more into the new 90's mold as described by Allan Mottus.
 "There's a move back to Gary Cooper and the 1950's westerns," Mottus says. "Hunks with some compassion. Look at our military pilots. They're getting-the-job-done types, and some are in their 40's."
 In addition to creating appealing images, fragrance companies are trying to make scent easy both to buy and to try. Prices remain lower than those in the women's market -- many top-of-the-line men's fragrances can be bought in some form for $30 or under -- and more manufacturers are turning to scent strips, free samples and even direct mail. Quintessence, for instance, went so far as to mail a $14 bottle of cologne to virtually every man in Aspen, Colo., when it introduced Aspen for Men in 1989.
 For men who still feel intimidated asking a sales clerk for cologne, the future may include self-service at the corner drugstore. According to market analysts, sales of men's fragrances have accelerated more in mass market outlets than in department stores and specialty retailers. Andrew Shore of Prudential-Bache sees an analogy here.
 "Before the AIDS crisis, men had to go to the counter to ask for condoms," he says. "Once they were moved out, sales started to take off."
 The industry is also keeping up the synergy with the women's market. In addition to spawning men's versions of successful perfumes, at least one company has done the reverse: When customers buy Aspen for Men cologne for this Father's Day, they'll get a free bottle of the newer scent, Aspen for Women.
 But the final, critical factor is the scent itself. No man will go back for more unless it entices him. "Men's fragrances are getting sophisticated, stronger, more floral," says Annette Green, executive director of The Fragrance Foundation, a trade group. "They want the scent to be imaginative and adventuresome -- not just a bay rum."
 It's the job of I.F.F.'s Michael Sweeney to make sure the new products live up to the ideal. He feels that the newest trend is what he calls "a freshness note," which can be a new citrus note -- such as tangerine, in addition to the ever-popular lemon or lime -- or what the industry calls the "ozone note." Now especially hot, the latter is a chemical formulation designed to have the ultimate fresh smell of clothes drying on a line.
 "There are a lot of women's fragrances we call Chypre, which are based on oakmoss, patchouli and coriander," Sweeney says. "We see these scents as appropriate for men." He adds, "Our people are usually good cooks, too."
 Despite the proliferation of new fragrances, some men seem to stay on a scent forever. The classic Old Spice, recently acquired by Procter & Gamble, remains one of the best-selling men's brands, with what Sweeney calls "spicy notes, but a soft, powdery quality." Still, he feels that smell is as much in need of fresh stimulation as the other senses. "Men will always go back to the old standbys, but they also want a new fragrance the way they want a new suit," he says. "It's uplifting."

LENGTH: 1160 words

HEADLINE: CONNECTICUT GUIDE

BYLINE: By Eleanor Charles

 BODY:
 

 
MAGIC IMAGES
 After nine months of restorative work and renovations, the New Haven Colony Historical Society has reopened with a new exhibition, "When Images Were Magic: John Warner Barber, Connecticut's First Popular Historian." It will remain on view through Sept. 15.
 Barber established a successful engraving business in New HAven in 1823 and was one of the founders of the historical society, contributing a substantial portion of its original collection.
 His most ambitious undertaking and the focus of the exhibit is "Connecticut Historical Collections," published in 1836. The book, which sold for $3, then the average weekly wage, contained 560 pages and 180 of Barber's own wood engravings.
 To collect material for the work, he traveled widely, interviewing residents and poring over old documents and newspapers. His sketches and drawings of 19th-century life were among the first histories published in America. Their popularity was based on the appeal of his lively drawings and retelling of local lore, exposing people for the first time to the experiences of other people in other communities.
 Christopher Bickford, director of the Connecticut Historical Society, which organized the exhibit, will give a lecture about Barber on Thursday at 5 P.M.
 The New Haven Colony Historical Society, 114 Whitney Avenue, is open Tuesday through Friday from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. and weekends from 2 to 5 P.M. An opening reception, with no admission charged, will be held today from 2 to 5 P.M. Admission is $2, $1.50 for students and the elderly and $1 for children. Call 562-4183 for more information.
 
FLIGHTS OF FANCY
 "Bradley's Believe It or Not" is an art exhibition that can be seen through April 1 in Terminal A of Bradley International Airport in Windsor Locks. John Cusano, a Norwalk art dealer, selected the artists and organized the airport-related exhibit for the Connecticut Commission on the Arts.
 Mary Bailey's contribution is a collection of enlarged microscopic organisms out of her imagination. They can only survive at altitudes higher than 5,000 feet in pressurized aircraft, and their life span is the time it takes to fly from Hartford to Cleveland.
 Ruby Beers, a woman thought up by Bryan Konefsky, used to be in charge of unclaimed baggage. Now retired, she is depicted in her garden, where she has planted numerous pieces of luggage with only their handles protruding from the earth. The handles bear little stickers identifying each as an attache case, a makeup case or a suitcase.
 Leo Jensen chose an archeological theme in which a dig in 3101 uncovers strange helmets made of wood, twine and generally low-tech materials, assumed to have belonged to pilots and other airport denizens from his fantasy world. And the fourth artist, Suzan Shutan, forces the viewer to peer through little holes to see a variety of objects accompanied by explanatory text.
 
LIVES ON FILM
 The Westport Public Library has begun a film series of film biographies, shown on Thursdays at 7:30 P.M. through May 9. This week's subject is "The World That Robert Moses Built," about the creator of Jones Beach, the West Side Highway and other massive New York City-area projects. Venerated by some and castigated by others, he fueled a debate over public order versus individual liberty when he acquired vast properties by eminent domain, displacing thousands of residents.
 Paul Gaugin's biography, "The Savage Dream" will be shown on March 28, followed by films on Winston Churchill, Andy Warhol, Claude Monet, James Joyce, Frank Lloyd Wright, Isabel Bishop, Albert Einstein and Marc Chagall, among others. Admission is free. For a complete schedule, call 227-8411, extension 24 or 25.
 
WORLD OF YACHTING
 Olin Stephens 2d is to be the featured speaker at 9:15 A.M. on Saturday during Mystic Seaport's Fourth Annual Yachting Symposium, which runs from Friday through Sunday. A founder of Sparkman & Stephens yacht designers of New York City, he designed the schooner Brilliant, berthed at Mystic Seaport, and five successful America's Cup defenders.
 An opening reception on Friday at 7:30 P.M. will feature a talk by the British yacht agent William Collier on restoration work being done on vessels in Europe.
 In addition to Mr. Stephens, Saturday's roster of speakers includes Henry Scheel, a naval architect and designer of the Scheel keel; Jim Brown, designer of cruising multihulls; David Martin, powerboat designer, and John Deknatel, president of Ray Hunt and Associates, yacht designers in Boston.
 A reception will be held from 5 to 7:30 P.M. on Saturday, during which two awards will be presented by Mystic Seaport for contributions to the promotion of yachting and the preservation of yachts. The symposium will end on Sunday with a tour of the Seaport's yachting collection from 10 A.M. to noon.
 The fee is $95 and includes lunch on Saturday. To register or obtain more information, call 572-0711, extension 124 or 125.
 
BLUE JEANS
 Jeans, the pants that cross all barriers of gender, class and economic status, will be explored in a talk, "The Jeaning of America: Stepping Out With Denim, 1850-1990" by Jeanne Atkinson.
 An adjunct professor at the Fashion Institute of Technology in Manhattan, Ms. Atkinson will speak at 10:30 A.M. on Tuesday at the Fairfield Historical Society, 636 Old Post Road. Accompanied by slides and articles of clothing on loan from museums and private collections, she will analyze the popularity of the pants that were once called blue jeans, how and why their use has burgeonedsince the mid-19th century. Admission is $5, and reservations are required. Call 259-1598. FRENCH REVOLUTION
 The Hartford Ballet is sponsoring the presentation of the Ballet du Nord from France in "Marie Antoinette." Devised for the French bicentennial by Alfonso Cata, the company's director, the lavishly staged and costumed work combines court dances of the period with a tale of intrigue and romance, set to the music of Mozart, Haydn and Vivaldi.
 Performances at Bushnell Hall in Hartford are scheduled at 8 P.M. on Friday and Saturday, with a Saturday matinee at 2:30. Tickets priced at $10.50 to $38.50 may be reserved by calling 246-6807.
 
GRAVEYARD HISTORY
 A family graveyard in Griswold, dating from 1740 to 1850 and uncovered by a sand and gravel operation, is the subject of a lecture by Nicholas Bellantoni, state archeologist, and Jeffrey Bendremer, a graduate student at the University of Connecticut.
 From 7:30 to 9 P.M. on Tuesday, the two men will discuss conclusions drawn from the excavation about the medical problems, genetic heritage, life styles and vocations of the family during an entire century. The program will take place in the Connecticut State Museum, Wilbur Cross Building on the Storrs campus of UConn. Admission will be $10. For more information, call 486-4460.

HEADLINE: In Burbank, Revival and Growth Limits

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON

DATELINE: BURBANK, CALIF.

 BODY:
THIS birthplace of Mickey Mouse and Lockheed's Stealth fighter is soon to be home to an unusual 2.5-million-square-foot, $400 million retail and office center. Its presence is already revitalizing a downtown long derided on the Johnny Carson Show as "beautiful downtown Burbank."
But Johnny Carson's studio is more than two miles to the south, in an area known as the Media District, which has blossomed in the last decade with high-rise office towers where vacancies are rare. 
 A prime reason for the near demise of downtown was that three blocks of its San Fernando Road shopping district was closed to traffic in the mid-60's. What was to have stimulated shopping instead vastly diminished it.
In Oct. 19, 1989, the shopping district was once again opened to traffic, the day after construction began on what will be known as Media City Center.More than 240 homes and 83 businesses were displaced from the 41-acre, city-assembled, city-owned site of the largest construction project under way in sprawling San Fernando Valley. It has a tangled history.
One development deal with the Hahn Company of San Diego fell apart when the parent company of a proposed anchor tenant was acquired and quashed expansion plans. Disney and MCA, parent of Universal Studios, dropped their grandiose schemes for entertainment centers.
The 20-year struggle to find a builder for the site ended in March 1989 when the Alexander Haagen Company of Manhattan Beach, Calif., beat out 14 bidders. The 1-million-square-foot, three-level retail mall will include four anchor stores, Bullock's, Mervyn's, Sears and Ikea, the Swedish home-furnishings store, and 100 specialty shops. There is also going to be a four-screen cinema and the first satellite of the Los Angeles Natural History Museum.
Four office towers to be built and owned by the Homart Development Corporation of Chicago are to take up an additional 1 million square feet. A 300-room all-suite hotel is planned by Homart, but so far there is no commitment for it. Office construction was to have coincided with that of the mall, most of which is scheduled to open this summer. But construction of the towers is going more slowly than expected because of tighter lending conditions, said Frederick Bruning, a partner in the Haagen firm.
 Residents of Burbank, a 17-square-mile city of 94,000 residents 14 miles northwest of Los Angeles, have since the mid-80's complained about rampant commercial development in the Media District.
To address this issue, the city imposed broad guidelines last Jan. 8 limiting development there to 16.8 million square feet of new commercial and industrial construction for the foreseeable future and imposing impact fees on both current landlords and future developers for such things as road improvements.
There were no previous limits, and Richard Pruetz, the City Planner, said that developers would have theoretically been able to build an additional 50 million square feet of commercial and industrial projects in the 1.2-square-mile district.
Since 1982, nearly 2.5 million square feet of office space has been built in the district, where the office vacancy rate last month was 1.5 percent, the lowest in Southern California, and space goes for $25 a square foot. Burbank's office vacancy rate as a whole is 6 percent and rents average about $20 a square foot.
" I' M astounded that practically every square foot is taken," said Jef Vander Borght, an architect and City Planning Board member. "It's wildly successful, beyond anyone's imagination."
Within the area are the Disney, Warner Brothers and NBC studios, as well as many of the city's 430 media-related firms,such as post production outlets and recording studios.
The area that straddles the Ventura Freeway and nestles beneath the Hollywood Hills east of Universal City is popular with TV and movie firms because of its proximity to three freeways and relatively affordable housing. Home prices last year averaged $245,000.
The area also includes many quiet neighborhoods, some of them overshadowed by high-rises. Streets are clogged at rush-hour with traffic from office workers.
The engine behind the district's rapid development and distinct skyline is the studios' explosive growth, Hollywood's perceived deterioration and the easy lending practices of the 80's.
Disney in particular has grown enormously. The company already has had to scatter its operations in several locations, including neighboring Glendale. A master building plan that includes six new sound stages, a health club and commissary had been put on hold until after last month's local election, when the most recent development flap was resolved.
After a divisive campaign that led to the largest turnout in a decade, voters on Feb. 26 rejected two growth-control measures -- one that would limit the height of any new construction to 25 feet and 350,000 square feet a year, the other restricting commercial construction near residential neighborhoods -- that the studios contended would have capped their growth.
 Whether the new guidelines that took effect Jan. 8 will ultimately answer concerns about runaway growth remains to be seen.
The proof will be in whether the city is successful in negotiating future development deals that include provisions for ride-sharing, child care and open space.
On March 5, the City Council approved NBC Plaza -- two towers, one 18 stories, the other with a total of 700,000 square feet -- considered the district's future centerpiece. The network, in an equity partnership with John Cushman, will develop the project, which includes a plaza of more than two acres.
The center, which will rise next to NBC's existing 43-acre site where Mr. Carson tapes his shows, is to serve as the network's West Coast headquarters.
To gain the city's approval, NBC agreed to reduce the size of the project by 100,000 square feet, to recycle the water in its plaza fountains and spend 1 percent of the project's cost on art for the plaza. "If either of the Feb. 26 measures had passed, NBC Plaza would have been killed and it would have frozen our operations," said Jack O'Neill, vice president for network real estate, who campaigned against the measures. "You couldn't be for the measures and be for the studios. That was the message."
The message apparently was picked up before the vote, as the recession deepened. Last May, Burbank's largest longtime employer, the Lockheed Corporation, decided to relocate most of its local operations to Marietta, Ga., and Palmdale, Calif., scaling back the famed Skunk Works that made the Stealth fighter and SR-71 Blackbird, and laying off or transferring more than 3,000 of its 6,500 employees.
A decade ago, Lockheed had more than 20,000 employees here.
While Lockheed lost, the entertainment industry gained. In 1976, by all accounts, 10 percent of the labor force was employed by entertainment-related companies. Today, 15 percent of the city's labor force of 84,000 work for the studios and allied entertainment firms employ an additional 14 percent.
 "We surprised ourselves when we looked at the numbers," said Mr. Bruning of the Haagen Company. Studies show that the city's average household income is $52,000, he said. "That's an extremely wealthy population."
The downtown mall is expected to generate $420 million in annual sales and $4.2 million in tax revenue. The mall design, by the Newport Beach, Calif., architect Todd Stoutenborough, will attempt to meet the needs of film-makers to shoot movies on location. Lighting levels can be adjusted to brighter than normal and doors are extra wide to accommodate film crews.
Now that the old downtown has reopened to traffic, it is drawing new businesses, such as children's stores, a jewelry boutique and restaurants.
Larry Kosmont, a former City Development Director and now a commercial real estate consultant, expects the retail office center will ultimately salvage downtown. Part of the reason is growth restrictions and traffic problems in neighboring cities, he said.
"Burbank is the last opportunity for medium- to high-rise development," Mr. Kosmont said. "You need a little density to create some excitement."

HEADLINE: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: Cleveland;
Countering Suburbs' Lure

BYLINE: BY JENNIFER STOFFEL

 BODY:
NEW tax incentives have gone into effect here to encourage the building of housing to keep middle-income buyers in the city.
With the middle class moving to the suburbs, local planners have warned for decades that the city might lose 100,000 people by the year 2000 with a resulting drop in metropolitan Cleveland's tax base. Last year the city's population was 1,412,140. 
 "If someone wanted a bigger, better, newer home, they had to leave," said Terri Hamilton, the city's deputy director of community development.
The city responded last year with initiatives to provide housing for people tempted by the suburbs. The program now exempts buyers of new one-family homes from property taxes for 10 years, rather than the previous seven years. For developers of multifamily homes, the exemption is for 15 years.
There is also a $1 million program of Neighborhood Development Bonds for infrastructure improvements in new subdivisions and a new Housing Trust Fund created by the city with $1.5 million from the Federal Community Development Block Grant program to provide up to 25 percent of the financing for multifamily developments or renovation.
The Housing Construction Office, which was created last year, serves as a developers' clearinghouse, easing the permission and application processes.
The pursuit of foreclosures on vacant or abandoned tax-delinquent parcels in areas where there is residential demand has become a priority. This is to make it easier to assemble parcels in a city where there are few sizable individual lots.
Spurred on by the city's incentives, developers are now targeting small lots close to downtown. In one case, a 16-unit town-house project called Franklin Green has been built by Franklin Green Ltd. Partnership, a local investment group, on a site in the inner city just west of downtown. Nine studio to two-bedroom units have been sold at $98,500 to $124,900. The architect was David Harala of Cleveland.
With an unobstructed view of the city's skyline, each unit will be customized with such add-ons as Jacuzzis and skylights.
The 15-unit project, called Irishtown Bend, is named for a curve in the Cuyahoga River on which it sits. Construction is scheduled to begin in late spring and is expected to be completed this year.
"It's likely now that any lot within two miles of downtown will be developed over the next two years," said Keith Brown, president of Progressive Urban Real Estate, referring to the city's help. "Before, it was highly unlikely.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Franklin Green town houses, being built with tax incentives to keep middle-income buyers in Cleveland. (Barney Taxel for The New York Times)
