HEADLINE: DIALOGUE: The Party's Politics
The Democrats Are Spoiling the Beef;
Don't Argue With Victory

BYLINE: By Stephen J. Solarz; Stephen J. Solarz, Democrat of Brooklyn, is a member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The guns had barely fallen silent in the gulf before the political artillery was rolled out here at home. Republicans, abandoning the bipartisanship that prevailed during the fighting, have begun denouncing the Democrats as the party of appeasement. A number of Democrats, unwilling to accept the clear lessons of the war, have chosen this peculiarly inappropriate moment to resuscitate the argument that we should have given sanctions more of a chance, and that because we didn't, we will never know if they would have worked.
The Republicans are correct in saying that the majority of Democrats voted against the resolution authorizing the use of force. But they fail to add that without Democratic support, the resolution would not have been adopted. In the House, a third of the Democrats, including some of the party's most influential members, such as Dante Fascell, chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee; Les Aspin, chairman of the Armed Services Committee; and David McCurdy, chairman of the Intelligence Committee, voted for it. In the Senate, the resolution could not have passed without the backing of prominent Senators like Joe Lieberman, Charles Robb and Al Gore. 
 Furthermore, in perhaps the most significant statement in the two-day debate, Speaker of the House Tom Foley promised that once the decision was made, both parties would unite around it. In fact, virtually every Democrat supported the war after hostilities began.
To suggest that Democrats who opposed the use of force before Jan. 16 were appeasers is ludicrous. Would the Republicans also argue that two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and six former Defense Secretaries -- all of whom advocated that sanctions be given more time -- were also appeasers?
Moreover, the Republicans have much to answer for. Less than a week before Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, half the Republicans in the House voted against sanctions on Iraq even though Baghdad had already massed 100,000 troops on its border with Kuwait and Saddam Hussein had threatened to "incinerate" half of Israel.
For all the credit that President Bush deserves for his magnificent leadership after the Iraqi invasion, the truth is that his Administration not only resisted imposing sanctions on Iraq before Aug. 2 but, by giving Mr. Hussein the impression he could invade his defenseless neighbor with impunity, made the aggression more likely.
Upon close examination, the claim of some Democrats, even after the war ended, that sanctions might have worked cannot be sustained. Before the debate in Congress, many honorable and knowledgeable Americans believed we could achieve our goals through the continued application of sanctions. Mr. Bush and the majority of Congress felt otherwise, but it was a politically and intellectually respectable position to take.
But that was before the war began. If six weeks of the most intense aerial bombardment in history was not sufficient to bring about an unconditional Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, it is simply not plausible to suggest that six more months of the relatively benign application of sanctions would have done so. Even if sanctions had succeeded in bringing about a withdrawal, who can believe that Mr. Hussein, as a goodwill gesture, would have voluntarily blown up his nuclear reactors? Or dismantled his chemical and biological manufacturing facilities? Or destroyed thousands of tanks and artillery pieces? Sometimes it's best not to argue with success.
The American people can understand that before mid-January honest and legitimate differences existed over whether the sanctions could work. But if Democrats now persist in arguing that we should have stuck with sanctions, they will simply reinforce the view that the party cannot find a set of circumstances, other than a direct attack on the U.S., that would justify the use of force.
Instead of debating the merits of a lost case, the Democrats would be far better off persuading the public that they recognize there may be times when the defense of vital American interests and values requires military action. Such a strategy would be entirely compatible with the party's effort to remind Americans that our victory abroad has not lessened our obligation to address the many pressing problems we still face at home.

HEADLINE: Our Big Appliances Are Made in U.S.A.

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While the basic point of "In U.S. Technology, a Gap Between Arms and VCR's" (front page, March 4) may be valid, Raytheon Corporation's major appliance business was a poor example to choose. 
 The United States major appliances industry is an example of successful international competitiveness. Of the 46 million washers, dryers, refrigerators and other major appliances marketed annually in the United States only 17 percent are imports. Why? Because producers such as Raytheon's appliance group have kept quality up and prices down, while advancing innovation. There has been no niche left for the Japanese and others to exploit.
A recent article in Productions magazine observed that a 14-cubic-foot General Electric refrigerator sold for $525 in 1927. Adjusted for inflation, that refrigerator would cost $8,100 today. Yet, a 16-cubic-foot G.E. refrigerator can be purchased today for $499.
United States defense spending may contribute to a poor competitive posture in some of our industries, but the major appliance industry is not one of them.
 
ROBERT L. HOLDING
President, Association
of Home Appliance Manufacturers
Chicago, March 4, 1991

HEADLINE: Closing the Door on China Won't Help Anyone

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The call by Robert L. Bernstein, chairman of Human Rights Watch, to break up the "Chinese Gulag" by economic reprisals and isolationism (Op-Ed, Feb. 17) is both misguided and myopic. 
 He characterizes the sentencing of two Chinese dissidents, Wang Juntao and Chen Ziming, as "the ultimate demonstration of the failure of so-called quiet diplomacy." While, clearly, the world can and should raise its voice on the imprisonment and sentencing of all the people connected with the protest in Tiananmen Square in June 1989, if the objective is to achieve the release of prisoners and to increase the rights of the people of China, then the means Mr. Bernstein advocates, specifically the removal of most favored nation status for China, would be counterproductive.
I visited China last spring as part of a United States Information Agency-sponsored faculty exchange. Many of my discussions focused on the extension of China's most favored nation status and its importance to all people, both Chinese and Americans. As a registered Democrat, I am often in disagreement with the President's policies but I find myself in support of Mr. Bush's China policy.
It is ironic that the maligned quiet diplomacy is partly responsible for the exit of Fang Lizhi and his wife, as well as the release of a number of prisoners in the last year. While it was not 100 percent successful, that is not a basis to dismiss it.
China is a sovereign nation, and we must respect that. It is expected that governments will disagree over the severity of punishments. Some governments disagree with our country's use of capital punishment. The United States has engaged in acts, for example in Nicaragua, that the World Court condemned, a condemnation whose validity we have never officially acknowledged. We have engaged in a war in the Persian Gulf to protect countries with legal systems based on radically different principles from those we hold dear.
A policy of punishing Beijing on all fronts simply will not be effective. More progress can be made with China through national friendship and mutuality of interest. Clearly, there comes a time to draw a line in the sand, for example as the United States did against appeasement of the Nazis or toward South Africa, a country whose legal system implemented the servitude of a people. But this is not the time for that in China.
Isolationism has a price as well. The incalculable value of academic, cultural and high-level government exchanges will be forever lost. The hope of many Chinese people will be extinguished.
While some feel as Mr. Fang and Mr. Bernstein do, many Chinese repeated over and over to me that it was important that the West not close the door -- that is, the very contact that has opened up China and in a fundamental way changed people's expectations and perceptions.
Attention to human rights issues and maintaining trade relations are not mutually exclusive. There is a reservoir of good feeling between the Chinese and Americans dating back to at least World War II, when they faced a common enemy in the Japanese. This base can lead to economic opportunity for Chinese and Americans. Through an increased standard of living and economic freedom, individual freedom will flourish. As a valued trade partner, the United States will have more leverage to press China on human rights issues.
Moral crusades are often not as effective as pragmatic bargaining, as President Carter's boycott of the Soviet Olympics and the grain embargo showed us.
 
BEVERLEY EARLE
Assistant Professor of Law
Bentley College
Waltham, Mass., March 3, 1991

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Why Must Achievers Pay for Government?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Jeff Faux of the Economic Policy Institute calls for a 38 percent tax bracket supposedly to suport the Persian Gulf war (Op-Ed, Feb. 19). Since the war is being fought by the young and the poor, he asks, why shouldn't the older and richer pay a higher tax? 
 Why do people like Mr. Faux think that the older and richer exist as mere victims to fulfill his tax wishes? Why is labor and effort to be rewarded with increasingly higher tax rates? Why cannot we be allowed to achieve in our jobs and pay the same rate on the last dollar of income we pay on first? Why must only the people who achieve be forced to put more money into the Washington sewer?
We have got to fight people like Mr. Faux and a Government that consumes and wastes too much of our wealth. The Government, and those parasites it serves, have become an all-consuming disease. Let us cut it down and force the parasites to work for a living.
 
J. THOMAS PEARSON
Franklin Lakes, N.J., Feb. 28, 1991

HEADLINE: Germany Sees Sharp Slowdown

BYLINE: By FERDINAND PROTZMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BONN, March 17

 BODY:
The economic boom that unity brought to western Germany is expected to slow significantly this year under the combined weight of eastern Germany's severe economic decline, recession in other industrialized nations and the cost of Germany's contribution to the Persian Gulf war.
But economists say eastern Germans' undiminished appetite for products from the west will keep western German growth well ahead of that in the United States and most European nations. 
 Still, there are signs of at least temporary changes in what is the world's fourth-largest economy. Its inflation, while low by most nations' standards, is inching higher. And rising consumer demand has brought so many imports that in January western Germany posted its first monthly current-account deficit since August 1985.
 
$800 Million Deficit
 In January, the current-account deficit of Germany, which had been the world's leading exporter, was $800 million, in contrast to a surplus of $6.8 billion a year earlier. Current account is a broad measure of trade that includes services, tourism and transportation, as well as merchandise.
Just hours after announcing the deficit, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Government lowered its estimate for 1991 growth in western Germany's gross national product to between 2.5 percent and 3 percent, from more than 3 percent.
Although Germany was unified on Oct. 3, separate statistics are still kept for east and west. Eastern Germany's gross national product is expected to shrink by 20 percent from last year's level.
Gross national product measures a nation's total output of goods and services, and last year western Germany's G.N.P. grew 4.6 percent.
"The economy in united Germany will continue in 1991 to be marked by diametrically opposed development tendencies," the Government said in its spring economic report, released earlier this month. "In western Germany, strong growth and dynamic job creation will continue despite a weakening of the world's economy. In the new states, further adjustment by producers and workers will be necessary."
 
The Effect on Companies
 Western German companies like Siemens A.G., the electrical giant, or Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., which makes BMW autos, have not been hurt. The opening of eastern Germany has helped them avoid the declining sales and profits of their European and American competitors.
Eberhard von Kunheim, BMW's chairman, told reporters in January that domestic sales rose 13.3 percent in 1990, to $6.35 billion. But foreign sales stagnated, edging up three-tenths of 1 percent, to $7.93 billion. He blamed the mark's strength against the dollar and the yen for that development. "Over all, 1990 went pleasingly for BMW," he said.
Germany's sales of new cars are, in fact, propping up the entire European auto industry at the moment. New-car sales in Germany rose 39 percent in January, compared with a decline of 3.8 percent for western Europe as a whole.
Siemens, in an interim report on the first quarter of its fiscal year, credited "a strong contribution from activities in the new German states" for a 19 percent jump in domestic orders in the three-month period ended Dec. 31. Domestic sales were unchanged, however, at $4.5 billion. Siemens said that was not a disturbing development since sales had been unusually high in the year-earlier quarter.
 
Shaky Eastern Germany
 While consumer goods producers are prospering in the eastern German market, the onslaught of western business has undermined the region's already shaky economy, and Bonn has been forced to acknowledge that it underestimated the difficulty of rebuilding the area. The situation has been aggravated by Germany's unexpected expense of contributing $11 billion to the allied effort in the gulf war.
While Mr. Kohl maintains that eastern Germany's economy will be booming within five years, the current crisis has forced his Government to raise personal income taxes and most consumer taxes. Klaus-Werner Schatz, an economist at the Institute for World Economics in Kiel, Germany, predicted that those measures would also slow growth.
"The tax increases will certainly slow growth somewhat, even if it is used for investment in eastern Germany or to fund consumption there," said Mr. Schatz, who is predicting 2.5 percent G.N.P. growth at best. "Exports are running flat, and while there will be stronger demand from eastern Germany, it won't be that much higher than last year."
Peter Pietsch, an economist with Commerzbank A.G. in Frankfurt, acknowledged the boost that eastern Germany had given western Germany's companies, but said they remained export-oriented. For 1991, he is predicting for western Germany a current-account surplus of $9.6 billion, down from $28.7 billion last year. Western Germany's trade surplus is likely to be $32.2 billion, well below 1990's surplus of $67.7 billion.
"They are dramatic declines, but I don't see them as alarming," Mr. Pietsch said. "The Americans and our European trading partners have been pushing Germany to reduce those surpluses. German exporters' strategy has always been to win and hold market share over the long term and that hasn't changed with unity. Exports are likely to begin picking up in the second half of this year, if, as I expect, the U.S. and European economies begin to expand again."

HEADLINE: DUE IN U.S., WALESA STRESSES AID NEED

BYLINE: By STEPHEN ENGELBERG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WARSAW, March 15

 BODY:
President Lech Walesa insists that he is not coming to America with his "paws" out, but warns that Poland's economic reforms will fail if the West does not provide substantial additional assistance.
Mr. Walesa, who is to arrive on Tuesday for a six-day visit and a meeting with President Bush, said in an interview with several journalists here that without both debt relief and new investment, the economies of Eastern Europe would collapse and leave millions of refugees "at the gates of the United States." 
 "We need to escape from the Albanian threat," he declared, referring to the tens of thousands of people who have recently fled that Balkan nation for Italy.
Western governments announced on Friday that they were writing off $33 billion in Polish debts, 50 percent of the total owed to governments. While less than the 80 percent sought by Warsaw, the move gives the Polish economy an essential push forward.
 
'I Complain to Get More'
 Mr. Walesa said Poland needed both investment and technical expertise from the United States and Europe. Asked if he was satisfied with American investments so far in Poland, he replied: "I always ask for more, because I know I will get less than I am asking for. I complain to get more."
In the conversation, Mr. Walesa, the shipyard electrician who founded the independent trade federation Solidarity and rose to become his country's first popularly elected President, seemed comfortable in his new role. He moved easily between the language of high finance and the streets, at one moment speaking of the need to "smash" his political opponents, at another acknowledging with a smile that "I am not fit to be a classical president."
Mr. Walesa also sought to play down the rebuff he suffered this month from Parliament, which rejected his call for immediate elections and instead allowed former Communists to hold their seats at least until October. Parliament is still dominated by former Communists and their allies, who occupy reserved seats under a 1989 political arrangement with Solidarity.
"This can be turned into a success," he said of the Parliament vote. "Now we know who are the causers of undemocratic moves."
The goal of sweeping the former Communist elite from Government has been slowed by the lack of skilled replacements. "We will not bring people from the moon, and America is too far away," he said.
 
Constant Controversy
 Since Mr. Walesa took office Dec. 22, he has had to face constant political trouble. Immediately after he was sworn in, workers began striking and agitating for an end to the restrictions on pay rises at state-run industries. Meanwhile, Mr. Walesa's personal staff underwent several shakeups.
Within weeks, some of his key supporters in the presidential campaign criticized Mr. Walesa for not carrying out promises to accelerate political and economic changes.
Replying today, he said the process of governing had been more difficult than expected.
"I am sorry if I had to find a Prime Minister, and I had to change the government," he said. "Then this Government had to become acquainted with the matters at hand. It needs time, and so I had to accept all this dirty water pouring on me."
In his presidency as throughout his political career, Mr. Walesa has steered a zigzagging course that confounds both friends and foes. One day, he hinted on a radio call-in show that the wage restrictions should be substantially modified. But when his new committeee of advisers endorsed such a step, he immediately issued a statement supporting the current system.
 
Sowing Confusion as a Tactic
 In the interview, Mr. Walesa obliquely acknowledged that some of the political confusion he creates is deliberate, part of a larger plan to obscure his intentions as the country navigates through economically turbulent times.
"I will manage," he said. "Just don't disturb me. We have vision. We have plans."
He illustrated his style of leadership with a story from his years of hiding anti-Communist literature in his car.
"Sometimes, the biggest order can be found in a mess," he said. "Often, before 1980, I drove around with leaflets. I had an old Warszawa car, and I had a lot of spare parts in the trunk because it often broke down. Everything was dirty, greasy.
"Underneath I had my leaflets. Even if they sometimes tried to stop me, they just touched it with their hands and said, 'Yech, who would look deeper?' Therefore, the mess was the biggest security I could have, although not always, and not everywhere."

HEADLINE: Where Phone Lines Stop, Progress May Pass By

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NEW PARIA, Utah, March 16

 BODY:
Despite the challenges posed by rattlesnakes, dirt roads and a fickle water well, Brett Nybo likes the solitude of life in this dusty, remote hollow.
"It would be nice to have a telephone, though," Mr. Nybo, a 32-year-old carpenter, said as he sat in a rocking chair beneath a coyote trap mounted on his living room wall. "In case of emergencies, you know, it would be a handy thing to have." 
 In an age when the four corners of the world are linked by computer modems and fax machines, simple telephone service is unavailable to as many as 200,000 rural American households.
 
Taking Turns on Party Line
 Many more, who still call on the old rotary dial or wait their turn on a party line, cannot use telephone features now taken for granted in most homes and considered essential for businesses.
In isolated regions, the limitations have become especially critical in the last few years, as computers and conference calls have become standard tools of business communication.
"Many places facing these problems could meet the same fate as the ghost towns of the Old West," said Edwin Parker, a communications consultant who has written a book about problems with phone service in rural areas. "Rather than being bypassed by highways and railroads, they will have been bypassed by technology."
For Mr. Nybo and the seven other households in this hollow in southern Utah, telephone service is theoretically available. US West, which controls the regional franchise, said it would install telephones here, but the cost of extending the lines would be $130,000 -- about $16,000 per household.
"That's a little steep for my budget," Mr. Nybo said, adding that he would continue to drive his pickup truck to a pay phone alongside a county road about eight miles away.
 
States Pressing for Improvement
 In states with large rural populations, government regulators have been pressing telephone companies to upgrade old equipment that is slow and often unable to handle new technology, like push-button phones. In Colorado, for example, the state's Public Utility Commission reached an agreement with US West to make $85 million in improvements to rural telephone services, with a sharp reduction in its traditional hookup fees.
A bill pending in the Oregon Legislature would require telephone companies to provide service to households in rural and more densely populated areas at the same rate, or face the prospect of losing part of their franchise to another company.
 
Old Vice: Listening In
 For Stan and Jean Potratz, who run a mail-order business from their farm in Washington, Iowa, the scarcity of telephone lines has meant frustrated customers and lost business.
"Very few people write anymore, so we've got to be able to have enough telephone lines for our customers," said Mr. Potratz, whose business, Premier Sheep Supplies and Fence Systems, has 16 full-time workers. "When customers get a busy signal, they get very angry. The phone company says an upgraded system is on the way, and we sure hope so."
The multiparty line is a nuisance for the owners of the Fernwood Cafe and Laundry in Fernwood, Idaho, which shares service with a local tavern. "You never know how many times people call, can't get through and decide not to come," said Nellie Scheinost, the owner. "And at home, we can't use an answering machine because of the party line."
Since listening in on conversations is a vice as old as the party-line telephone, privacy is difficult to maintain. At the Calder Elementary School in rural northeastern Idaho, where 23 students are enrolled, the breach of confidentiality has caused some thorny problems.
"We'll be having a conversation with a parent about a child's behavior problem, and somebody decides it would be interesting to listen in," said Robert Leonard, the School Superintendent. "In three hours' time, that story has gone up and down the river. There's no way to keep it quiet."
In remote areas, it is often the small momand-pop telephone companies that are best equipped to reach distant customers. Unlike larger companies, these smaller concerns are eligible for subsidies from the Rural Electrification Administration, a Federal agency established in the 1930's to bring power to remote regions.
 
'To Hear That Ring'
 Telephone Utilities of Eastern Oregon, for example, used such a subsidy this year to bring telephone service to the 30 residents of Starkey, Ore.
"Now that we're connected to the outside world, I feel so alive," said Luella Bailey, a Starkey resident. "To hear that ring, and know you can talk to somebody on the other end, it's just wonderful."
But large companies do not receive Federal subsidies, so any extra costs of connecting rural households must be recovered in rates paid by all customers or through huge extension fees. The companies and the state commissions that regulate rates must balance the goal of providing universal service -- the stated goal of the Federal Communications Commission -- with the desire to maintain affordable rates for the vast majority of subscribers.
"If someone lives 25 miles from the nearest telephone pole, it might cost $25,000 to bring telephone service out there," said Ms. Thomas, of US West. "So an inevitable question comes up: Is the impact on society great enough to warrant that kind of expense?"
While poor telephone service can stunt growth for rural areas, a good system can be a boon. People who prefer to live in quiet, picturesque places far from cities can work at home with a comuter modem. In Taos County, N.M., many writers and freelance business professionals communicate with companies in faraway cities without leaving their dens at home.
"Good telephone service," said Representative Lee H. Hamilton, Democrat of Indiana, "could be one of the most effective ways for rural America to lift itself up."
 
Hopes for Satellite Service
 Some rural officials are pinning their hopes on satellite-based communication, which could bring telephone service to some distant regions far more cheaply than traditional wiring methods. Such technology helped bring telephone service to Starkey, Ore.
To examine the role of phone service in rural economic development, the Congressional Joint Economic Committee has ordered a study of the problems and possible ways to remedy them. The study, which is to be released next month, found that better telephone service would help rural areas compete for business with metropolitan regions.
"But it's not going to be a silver bullet," said James W. Curlin, a program director at the Office of Technology Development, an investigative arm of Congress that is conducting the study.
For most people without telephones, however, the hardship runs much deeper than limits on economic development. They would just like to be able to call their friends and relatives, and keep up with the world.
"During the war with Iraq, I'd go a week without having any idea what was going on," said Dale Fausett, who recently testified at a Utah Public Service Commission hearing in Salt Lake City about life without a telephone.
But not everybody sees a telephone as a sign of progress.
Charlie Hochreiter, a 72-year-old former policeman, said he would not want a telephone, "even if you gave it to us for nothing."
"I haven't been on a telephone in 10 years," said Mr. Hochreiter, who lives here with his wife, Lorraine. "There's just no one I care to talk to that badly."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Now that we're connected to the outside world, I feel so alive," said Luella Bailey, a resident of Starkey, Ore., population 30, where telephone service was introduced this year. "To hear that ring, and know you can talk to somebody on the other end, it's just wonderful." (Barbara Reynolds for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: MCI Discounts Expected On Numbers Called Often

BYLINE: By EBEN SHAPIRO

 BODY:
The MCI Communications Corporation is expected to announce a service today that will offer residential long-distance customers discount rates for numbers they frequently call.
William G. McGowan, chairman and chief executive of MCI, is expected to announce the "Friends and Family" plan at a news conference at the Plaza Hotel in Manhattan. 
 Analysts said the service would benefit MCI, which is locked in a battle for market share with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and U S Sprint.
"It is a good customer acquisition tool," said Frank J. Governali, a telecommunications analyst with the First Boston Corporation. People in the industry have speculated that customers who provide MCI with a list of their most frequently called numbers will receive a discount when calling some of those numbers. If the plan works this way, MCI customers will be providing the company with valuable marketing information, since companies often spend considerable sums to acquire the name, telephone number and a bit of information about a potential customer.
Analysts say additional discounts will be offered to MCI customers who persuade family members and friends to sign up for MCI's long-distance service.
While MCI executives would not disclose details of the plan, Mr. Governali said they "view this as a very, very powerful type of marketing." He added that "they think it will have a big impact." MCI officials could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Mr. Governali said MCI executives told him that the service had the potential to rival the success of MCI's Vision, a service package for small businesses that has been quite successful.
 
Important to Growth
 New products have been important to MCI's growth. "Historically, they have done a very good job in introducing new services," Mr. Governali said.
MCI maintains that its new program is designed to take advantage of its sophisticated billing systems by aiming at individual customers. Mr. Governali said that in some areas, MCI's billing system did allow for more flexibility than A.T.& T.'s.
Mark Siegel, an A.T.& T. spokesman, said, "Keep in mind, we have a far greater number of customers to deal with." He added that his company's billing system was excellent.
MCI has been trying to foster interest in the new service with a television commercial featuring Bill Parcells, the New York Giants coach.
A.T.& T. has responded with advertisements for its Select Saver calling plan, which for a small fee allows customers to make discount calls to a designated area code. The program was introduced a year ago. Mr. Siegel said that about half of an individual's long-distance calls are made to a single area code.
He added that A.T.& T.'s discount plan was sensitive to customers concerned about privacy issues. "You don't have to provide any information on your family and friends," he said.

HEADLINE: INSIDE

 BODY:
Safety Measures Delayed
 
The Government has failed to enforce an order issued to airlines last year to take steps to speed the evacuation of planes after accidents. Page B5.

HEADLINE: No Recession for Executive Pay

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
In the midst of a recession, with layoffs rising and corporate profits weak, pay in 1990 for the nation's top executives rose by bigger percentages than the wages of any other group of salaried American workers.
Many chairmen and chief executives receive huge annual salaries, under what corporate America calls a "pay for performance" system. It is intended to make compensation rise and fall with a company's profits and stock price. Neither profits nor stock prices rose last year at hundreds of companies, but surveys show that the pay of top-echelon executives went up anyway -- by an average of 8 percent or more. 
 "If you have people getting millions of dollars in bad times as well as good, then the sensitivity of pay to performance is too low for this sort of compensation system to work properly as an incentive," said Graef S. Crystal, a management consultant and professor at the University of California at Berkeley.
The increases in executive pay came in a year when most American workers received raises of 5 percent or less, not enough to keep them abreast of inflation. Average pay for chief executives of large companies, in fact, is often 70 to 80 times greater than the annual wages of the average worker, according to data from the Labor Department and from Towers Perrin, a New York-based management consulting firm.
This gap between executives and workers has more than doubled in the last 15 years, and so has the spread between America's top executives and those in other industrial nations.
A Towers Perrin survey shows that chief executives in the United States earn almost twice as much as their counterparts in Canada and Germany, which rank second and third, respectively, in chief executive compensation. The higher American compensation reflects stock options and other special long-term incentive payments that add millions to base salaries.
The pay increases for top executives last year are just now being disclosed in the proxy statements that publicly owned corporations mail to shareholders in March and April. Although the data will not be fully available until next month, several surveys by management consulting firms indicate that while cash salaries and bonuses went up by 5.5 to 7 percent in 1990 -- compared with double-digit increases in the late 1980's -- the long-term incentive portion brought the increase in total compensation to 8 percent or more last year.
That was roughly the raise for chief executives at 176 big corporations surveyed by Stephen F. O'Byrne, who tracks executive pay practices at Towers Perrin. The median compensation, which was $1.6 million in 1989, rose to more than $1.7 million in 1990, Mr. O'Byrne estimated.
Such findings, in a recession year, prompted Peter T. Chingos, head of compensation practices at KPMG Peat Marwick, the accounting firm, to tell corporate clients in a recent newsletter, "We are beginning to hear from some circles a growing concern over high compensation without any commensurate risk element for underperformance."
Mr. Chingos said a Peat Marwick survey of large companies showed that executive pay in 1990 rose by more than 15 percent on average from 1989's levels. "The top of the house -- the 15 to 20 highest officers -- clearly got 15 percent more," he said, "and the senior management -- the highest 100 people in a company -- clearly exceeded the inflation rate."
Incentive pay is mostly stock options, which give executives a right to purchase their company's shares over a 10-year period at roughly the price of the stock on the day the options are granted. If an executive is granted the right to buy company stock at an "exercise" price of $10 a share, for example, and it rises to $12, the compensation from the option is $2.
 
Long-Term Compensation
 Some executives clearly did better than others last year. Robert E. Allen, A.T.& T.'s chairman and chief executive, for example, received $2.02 million in salary and bonus, or 15.9 percent more than his 1989 cash pay. But the $536,577 salary and bonus that went to Don V. Fites, chairman and chief executive at Caterpillar Inc., represented only a 3.1 percent rise from 1989. Neither company's net income rose last year, and their stock prices declined.
Both men, however, got big stock-option awards, reflecting a trend that has made long-term compensation, consisting mostly of stock options, an ever larger portion of total pay.
The problem is how to value the options. Mr. Fites, for example, got options last year to buy 20,000 shares of common stock, compared with 12,000 in 1989 and 7,800 in 1988. But the total of 39,800 options carry an average exercise price of nearly $63 a share today, or nearly $10 more than Friday's closing price. That means Mr. Fites is "under water" -- he can make money only if the stock price rises above $63 a share. He will be able to cash in the options for $39,800, for example, for each dollar that Caterpillar's stock exceeds $63 a share.
"Many companies out there have underwater stock options that are really wallpaper today," Mr. Chingos said. But he and other experts in executive compensation do not emphasize the short term; they talk instead of the value of an option over its 10-year life. And over a decade, "if a company is reasonably successful, its stock price is likely to appreciate at what amounts to a 10 percent annual rate," Mr. Chingos said.
For Prof. Kevin J. Murphy, a compensation expert at the University of Rochester, such increases mean that the "recession does not seem to have inhibited stock option awards."
 
A Different Measure
 Mr. Allen of A.T.& T. illustrates the trend. He received 44,898 stock options early in 1990 at an exercise price of $45.94 a share. Those options are temporarily valueless; the stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company closed on Friday at $33.75 a share.
But Mr. Murphy and other compensation experts measure the trend in a different manner. They note that Mr. Allen's 44,898 options, when multiplied by $45.94, represent an "option grant equivalent" of $2.06 million. Enough options were issued, in sum, to more than equal Mr. Allen's $2.02 million salary.
A decade ago, the option grant equivalent was roughly 50 percent of base pay and bonus; now the rule of thumb is to grant enough options each year to exceed the cash portion, according to a Towers Perrin survey of 325 large companies. Other surveys confirm the trend.
The justification for a pay-for-performance system rests largely on the view that the chief executive and a few other top officers are called on to make decisions that risk the future of their company, and their jobs. Mr. Allen, for example, earned his raise because he was successful in advancing a key company strategy, to substantially increase A.T.& T.'s sales abroad, said Richard A. Gray, a company spokesman. Directing such risky strategies requires high pay to attract qualified executives.
"Corporate America operates by the John Wayne school of management," said Alan M. Johnson, managing director of executive pay practices at Handy Associates, a consulting firm. "There are one or two powerful guys at the top who have the power to bet the company on a new project or a huge investment, and that requires John Wayne-type pay. The Germans and Japanese, by contrast, run companies collegially, spreading the responsibility around among top managers."
Still, when a company's stock price falls and stays down, some boards reward the chief executive anyway. They do so by rewriting an executive's options to reduce the exercise price and thus increase the options' value. In a study issued last month, Peat Marwick reported that such revisions had been made at 28 companies, which it did not name.
"In situations where options were granted to management teams over the last five years and they are worthless, some boards say, 'We are going to clean the slate and go forward with a new program,' " Mr. Chingos said.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Quick Kuwaiti Recovery Is Seen, With the Cost Less Than Thought

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, March 17

 BODY:
Kuwait's economy, far and away the strongest among the oil-producing countries before the Iraqi invasion in August put it into a coma, is expected to revive and move back to boom times within two years, say many economic and financial experts on the region.
In scores of interviews here in the last week, Kuwaiti, American and Western financial specialists, including business executives and economic planners, estimated that the cost of reviving the emirate's economy, including the devastated oil industry, would be far less than earlier estimates. 
 With Kuwait holding about $80 billion in financial reserves abroad, it is more than capable of getting back on a sound economic development track, these specialists say.
 
'Catastophic but Not Fatal'
 "There is no economy now," said Wynne Fuller, who heads the emergency operations division of the United States Army Corps of Engineers here. "We are looking to two to five years to re-establish an economy that resembles what the Kuwaitis used to have."
The Corps of Engineers is to evaluate the damage to the Kuwaiti economy and begin a repair program.
"When all is said and done," Mr. Fuller said, "what you have here is catastrophic but not fatal. The only way I can compare this is to Hurricane Hugo in the States, which cost $4 to $5 billion to repair. So you are looking here at $5 to $10 billion outside the oil sector."
Other officials, including the country's Finance Minister, Sheik Ali al-Khalifa al-Sabah, estimated the cost of reviving the oil industry, sabotaged by Iraqi occupation troops, at $10 billion to $20 billion.
 
Fires Halt Oil Industry
 These new and more authoritative estimates are far below others advanced over the last few weeks by a variety of foreign experts living outside Kuwait. Some had suggested that Kuwait's revival might cost as much as $100 billion.
The latest estimates also reflect the growing appreciation here that the damage to Kuwait's roads, power stations, stores, banks and hotels, while substantial, can be repaired through cleaning and patching on a huge scale rather than major reconstruction. Even that work will require skills and coordination that Kuwait cannot muster alone.
The oil industry, source of most of the country's revenue, has been brought to a halt by fires set in most oil wells and refineries. The country's commercial and business centers have been destroyed or looted, immobilizing what was once the Middle East's most active system of private enterprise.
There is no Kuwaiti currency: the Kuwaiti dinar has no fixed value and the Central Bank and other banks have yet to tell people what will happen to their savings or to find records of millions of accounts.
 
Free Food and Gasoline
 For now, people living here are getting free food and gasoline. But no salaries are being paid, and a large-scale review of employment records, with a view to eliminating foreign workers like the Palestinians, has yet to get under way.
A variety of currencies, including United States dollars and Saudi rials, are preferred to the Kuwaiti dinar, which is to be replaced with a new one whose exchange rate has yet to be established by the Central Bank.
Yet with the approximately $80 billion in financial reserves held outside the country and with the help of many foreign construction companies, there seems little doubt that the Kuwaiti economy will start rolling again.
"I am very confident about the fact that we will have a boom here," said Michel Shalhoub, a French businessman of Lebanese origin who operated a franchise business selling luxury items from Western companies like Du Pont, Chanel and Lacoste.
Mr. Shalhoub was directing workers repairing two of his shops in the lobbies of what used to be luxury hotels.
"My personal losses are typical," he said. "We had seven stores in Kuwait which were all looted. We salvaged some of the goods in storage facilities. Altogether, I would say our losses are about $6 million, or about 30 million French francs, which represents one-third of my assets here and the equivalent of five years of profits."
Mr. Shalhoub said Kuwaitis would need, and could afford, to buy millions of consumer goods to replace what they lost, including luxury items.
"Before too long, people will be buying freezers, air-conditioners, furniture, carpeting," he said. "It will be even bigger than before because those people who kept much of their money outside Kuwait for fear of things just like the Iraqi invasion now know for sure that this country is 100 percent secure and that it will be protected by the West's best armies and a reliable defense alliance to preserve its integrity and freedom."
 
Workers' Future Debated
 Before anything that resembles a big economic takeoff can take place, however, the Government must get people back to their jobs, a task that is complicated by some political imperatives dictated by the Persian Gulf crisis.
On the 16th floor of the Industrial Bank here, the chairman, Saleh M. al-Youssef, met over the weekend with his top advisers to determine how they will call their employees back to work, given the Government's edict that expatriates from countries that sided with Iraq must be dismissed.
While the bank's officials have decided to call back their employees this week, other important offices, like the Ministries of Defense, Interior, Information, Oil and Finance, have not yet figured out how to resume operations without many of the foreigners.
"We will decide on a common policy," Mr. Youssef said in an interview. "There are employees we do not wish to keep. They include Palestinians, Yemenites and Sudanese. We will give them their due, of course, but their departure is a political decision. I think the idea is to put pressure on the Palestine Liberation Organization."
There is little doubt that ridding major institutions of thousands of Palestinians will be disruptive to the economic reconstruction of Kuwait. But there is also no doubt of the Government's determination to make sure they go.
 
Change of Attitude Needed
 The magnitude of the problem is evident in the makeup of the Kuwaiti population before the occupation. Of two million or so people living here, only 700,000 were Kuwaitis while the others were expatriates, including about 450,000 Palestinians. These did jobs like running hotels, keeping books, repairing cars and working the night shifts.
The country's Planning Minister, Suleiman al-Mutawa, said it was necessary for Kuwaitis to undergo a transformation in attitude, divorcing themselves of the notion that they work only as managers or state employees collecting large salaries with others doing the work.
In the process, Kuwait will have to do away with the whole structure of a sort of welfare state based on prosperity that it has become used to.
"I think there will be a review of all our policies based on what happened on Aug. 2," Mr. Mutawa said. "The questions that have been flushed to the surface are where we can keep expatriates and where we cannot."
"Many of these expatriates have no genuine interest in Kuwait and have, therefore, collaborated with the Iraqis," he continued. "In vital sectors, we may pick up some of the cost overruns to pay Kuwaitis to do those jobs they will not do for the same low salaries that expatriates accept. This is where Government subsidies should go into the private sector to encourage them to hire Kuwaitis instead of expatriates."
"The bottom line," Mr. Mutawa said, "is that the welfare state was mother and grandmother, and when you have that waiting for you at home, you tend to become very spoiled."
 
Records Need to Be Found
 Then there is the problem of activating the banks and circulating the new Kuwaiti currency. The Government says it has printed notes, but it is far from clear how the money will be distributed and on what basis.
Bankers said they understood that Government policy will be to consider that everything in Kuwait will revert to where it stood on Aug. 1, the day before the Iraqi invasion. That means that people who held bank accounts then will preserve the value of their money. But the problem is how to locate bank records and find enough employees to carry the policy out.
"What about all the Iraqi money we had to deal with?" asked a merchant who asked not to be identified. "I sold much of my stuff to Iraqis because I had no choice. Does this mean that when I go to give them the Iraqi money, they will not give me Kuwaiti money in return? What happens to the values of the goods I sold?"
For the moment, the entrepreneurs of Kuwait have not yet returned from exile and there are still 400,000 Kuwaitis out of the country. Much of the repair work is being done by foreign companies contracted by the United States Army Corps of Engineers.
Mr. Fuller said the corps had already given out seven contracts totaling $46 million. The contracts are for repairs to buildings, roads, electric cables and sanitation.
 
Where Contracts Go
 They have gone to non-Kuwaiti companies, including Shand of Britain, al Harbi of Saudi Arabia and several United States companies, including Blount, American Dredging Company and Brown & Root.
In addition, contracts worth tens of millions of dollars have been given to firefighting companies, largely American, that are preparing to put out fires at an estimated 600 oil wells.
But to get the emirate's economy rolling, Government spending will have to be directed at Kuwaiti companies in the building and rehabilitation business and this cannot begin until the banks are back in business and the Kuwaitis start to return home.
Along with debt, there are fears of inflation. Before the invasion, the inflation rate in Kuwait was kept at low levels -- 1 to 2 percent. With reconstruction, there are fears that political pressure will force the Government to abandon caution and cause inflation to rise to unacceptable levels.
"Economically, we can do it," said Sheik Ali, the Finance Minister. "But how to do it in the most efficient way is the difficulty. There are political considerations that may blow away the spending plans which are cautiously structured."
 
Un Unknown Quantity
 Then there is the matter of political stability, an unknown quantity that could presumably influence economic recovery.
Last week, there was unhappiness here when the Government said it would not be able to restore electricity for three more weeks. Many people asked that the Government abandon its slow reconstruction plans and rush to import thousands of generators to supply homes.
"We need patience, but I can understand that people have suffered too much and do not have much patience to give," the Planning Minister, Mr. Mutawa, said. "The period of crossing from disaster to recovery is going to be a difficult one."

HEADLINE: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS TO REVIVE CREDITS FOR ARMS EXPORTS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The Bush Administration is asking Congress to authorize a Government agency to underwrite sales of military goods for the first time since the 1970's.
After a long and divisive internal debate, the White House came down on the side of American military contractors, whose business has been lagging because of American plans to reduce the size of the armed forces. 
 The proposal comes at a time when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and other members of the Administration have been trying to limit the rearmament of the Middle East in the wake of the Persian Gulf war.
Administration officials insist the two efforts are not at counterpurposes.
 
Could Include Third World
 The legislation would establish a pilot program that would guarantee up to $1 billion in commercial bank loans to overseas buyers of military products. The sales are expected to be made largely to members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and to Japan, Israel and Australia. Should the President determine it is in the national interest, the program would also be available for "any other country," which would include the third world.
Backers say the proposal, which the Administration sent to Capitol Hill last week, would merely level the playing field with America's main industrial competitors, most of which have export credit agencies that finance military sales.
A State Department official, who insisted on anonymity, said the proposal is "a strictly commercial operation and is to be used only to counter subsidized credit packages from competing countries, like France."
But opponents of the proposal say that by diverting resources that should be concentrated on nonmilitary exports, the program will hurt American competitiveness and encourage poorer countries to spend more money on arms. America's competitiveness will suffer, they say, because there is less of a ripple effect through the economy from arms sales than from, say, advances in consumer electronics.
 
'Very Wrongheaded'
 Representative David R. Obey, Democrat of Wisconsin and chairman of the House Appropriations Subcommittee on Foreign Operations, Export Financing and Related Matters, called the proposal "very wrongheaded." Arms sales, he said, are "by their very nature noncommercial and political."
In 1989, the last year for which statistics are available, the United States sold about $10.8 billion worth of major conventional weapons systems abroad. The bulk of these sales went to American allies in NATO.
The Administration's request that the Export-Import Bank, a Government agency, underwrite the arms sales promises to be hotly debated in Congress. A Pentagon-administered military credit guarantee program was suspended in the late 1970's after too many customers went into arrears.
With the President's backing, the proposal is expected to pass the Senate. But it will run into stiffer opposition in the House, and at this stage, its fate there cannot be determined.
Even within the Administration, the proposal produced a debate before the White House decided to proceed. The State Department and the Pentagon supported the change. The principal objections came from some executives of the Export-Import Bank.
The bank was founded 56 years ago to stimulate trade by providing financing to overseas buyers of American goods at below-market rates. Since 1974, it has had policy of financing only nonmilitary exports.
 
Would Rescind Ban
 The Administration's proposal would rescind Section 32 of the Arms Export Control Act of 1968, which was enacted after widespread use of the agency as an instrument of "backdoor financing" of military sales to Southeast Asian nations during the Vietnam buildup. Section 32 bans the use of Export-Import Bank financing of military sales to developing countries. The White House has proposed that the Export-Import Bank guarantee up to $1 billion of commercial bank loans to the overseas customers of American military contractors.
Such a sweeping expansion in the scope of Government credit activities for military exports has been vigorously promoted by large military contractors like the United Technologies Corporation, the Raytheon Company and the Martin Marietta Corporation, and the White House has now decided to go along.
After that decision was made, John D. Macomber, president of the export agency and a friend of President Bush, offered this explanation: "The central point is that we're going through very difficult times in this country for defense industries. The basic motivation behind this is that the Government recognizes there are some real economic adjustment problems for these companies to go through, and this would be a way for the Government to be of some help." He was referring to the budget cutbacks of the last two years.
Representative Jim Moody, another Wisconsin Democrat, is seeking legislators' signatures on a letter to Secretary Baker, warning that the initiative is "likely to cost the taxpayer dearly" and is a "rather transparent attempt to circumvent the budgetary limitations" of the Pentagon's Foreign Military Sales program.
This program is the main military assistance effort under which the Pentagon in the next fiscal year plans to spend nearly $5 billion in grants and low-interest loans to American allies. Although 50 countries are on the list of recipients, half goes to two, Israel and Egypt.
 
Opposition From Industry
 The Administration has also been seeking to limit strategic arms in talks with the Soviet Union, and it has proposed restrictions on the sale of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons technology to the third world. The Administration proposal has divided the export community. Most companies whose earnings are primarily from military sales back the proposal. Others, like the Boeing Company and the General Electric Company, which have some military business but far larger nonmilitary operations, have reservations.
They worry about the crowding out of scarce credit resources, the possibility that separate divisions within companies may have to compete for Export-Import Bank money and an undercutting of political support for the bank if it becomes too strongly identified with military programs.
"Boeing recognizes financing support is required for the export of defense products," said John F. Hayden, the company's corporate vice president. "But we question the appropriateness of involving Ex-Im Bank as the mechanism."
He noted that since "defense products exports are not simply commercial transactions, but involve foreign policy and national security, Boeing feels the Department of State may be the appropriate agency to administer a defense-products export-financing program."
Willard M. Berry, vice president for Congressional affairs at the National Foreign Trade Council, said that before Congress takes up the proposal, "it is in the interest of all concerned to insure that all alternatives are explored and the pros and cons of each are fully debated."
William F. Paul, senior vice president of United Technologies, said that because the United States could not provide competitive credit terms, his company lost a big Brazilian military helicopter contract to France's Aerospatiale in 1988.
"We need a mechanism for financing this kind of defense trade when it's necessary," Mr. Paul said. "Our competitors have access to this sort of facility, and we desperately need it ourselves."
Largely through the efforts of Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, United Technologies, based in Hartford, won legislation last year specifically authorizing the export credit agency, on a one-time basis, to provide loan guarantees for a bid to produce 200 military helicopters jointly with Turkey. United Technologies is competing with French and Italian companies.
 
Some Risks Involved
 But opponents of the proposal say the Export-Import Bank should not be used to assume the risks of financing military exports and taking the risk of political backlash.
Albert H. Hamilton, a former government affairs manager for the bank and now senior associate of First Washington Associates, an Arlington, Va., consulting firm, said export credit agencies of other countries have gotten into serious polticial and financial difficulties by supporting exports of military equipment.
One example is the British agency's backing of military sales to the Kwame Nkrumah Government in Ghana. When that Goverment changed in 1966, its successor sought to repudiate the arms-related debt.
The new legislative proposal may explain why President Bush during his visit to Ottawa on Wednesday was cool to Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney's proposals to curb arms sales.
The President said at a new conference that the destruction of Iraq's military threat gave him hope that there would not be increasing arms sales in the Middle East. But he added: "That doesn't mean we're going to refuse to sell anything to everybody. We're not going to cut off all weapons sales."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
P.R. All-Stars Join Baseball Contest

BYLINE: By RANDALL ROTHENBERG

 BODY:
Every fan knows that pitching is crucial in baseball. But making the right pitch is even more important before a team exists.
With Major League Baseball set to name two new expansion teams for the National League, the six metropolitan areas vying for the franchises are waging a battle of hype and hoopla. In their effort to cajole the sport's current owners, who will decide where the new teams will play, most of the competitors have hired professional image-makers to prove that their grass is greener, their hot dogs tastier and their broadcast markets larger than the competition's. 
 The contest amply demonstrates the influence of public relations firms in the conduct of American business and the contours of contemporary life. The firms involved in baseball's expansion drive have worked on activities typically associated with their craft, like arranging articles in national publications and creating promotional videotapes.
 
Important 'Road Map'
 But their efforts have also included designing logos, writing scripts for local politicians, stage-managing the cities' presentations to baseball officials, recruiting celebrity endorsements and organizing rallies and season ticket drives for nonexistent teams to demonstrate public support.
"Obviously, the parameters set by the National League and its expansion committee are the most important road map anyone has to follow to win a franchise," said Andy Dolich, vice president of business operations for the Oakland Athletics, who also teaches sports marketing at the University of California at Berkeley. "Trying to determine what additional factors go into the decision is what this is all about. It's like the advertisement for Rolling Stone magazine. It's making perception a reality."
Four of the six finalists -- in Washington, Denver, Buffalo and Miami-Fort Lauderdale -- have each hired one of the largest public relations firms. A fifth, Orlando, Fla., has received help from a master of popular imagery, the Walt Disney Company.
Only the sixth finalist, Tampa-St. Petersburg, has relied on local advisers. But the franchise's lead image strategist, Bob Rose, previously served as marketing director for the United States Football League and for the St. Louis (now Phoenix) Cardinals football team.
For the contestants, fielding their dreams does not come cheap. The would-be owners are each spending from $500,000 to $1 million on their campaigns, estimated Robert E. Hope, an executive vice president at Burson-Marsteller, the world's third-largest public relations agency, which represents Miami-Fort Lauderdale. The two winners may spend another $130 million each on stadiums, salaries, promotions and franchise fees before their teams begin to play ball in 1993.
Last June, after several years of planning, the National League announced that it would accept applications from those interested in owning baseball's two newest teams. Eighteen ownership groups in 10 metropolitan areas sent in applications.
Each group gave a half-hour presentation to the league's expansion committee last September. The committee chose the six finalists in December. Since then, the committee has been visiting the areas and weighing their plans. Based on its recommendations, baseball's 26 owners will decide the winning franchises before the end of September.
 
No Specific Criteria
 The National League has remained vague about what it wants.
"We don't have specific criteria," said Katy Feeney, a spokeswoman for the National League. "We wanted strong, financially stable ownership. There was a lot of concern that the lead partner have some commitment to the area and that the community wants a baseball team. We said we'd obviously look at demographics and the media market."
While the competing groups' efforts largely involved the packaging of financial and demographic data about themselves and their areas, the public relations experts say they knew as well as any baseball fan that statistics are only half the story.
"It's a very interesting public relations situation," said Peter Fleischer, a vice president at Hill & Knowlton, which was hired to help lift the Buffalo Bisons from the minor leagues to the majors. "Normally in P.R., you're trying to influence millions of people. Here the audience is much smaller -- you're trying to communicate to the owners of Major League Baseball."
Melinda Rich, the Bisons' executive vice president, said the agency's primary job was convincing journalists, whose stories could affect the owners' perceptions, that Buffalo could support a major league team.
"In 1985, when we first presented our case to baseball, the media laughed at us," she recalled, "Hill & Knowlton helped us break down the misconceptions about Buffalo."
Hill & Knowlton is the second-largest public relations agency, after Shandwick P.L.C. of Britain.
For Denver, which had been trying to lure a big-league team for a decade and was considered an early favorite, the presentation proved crucial. In August, the lead partner in the city's baseball group dropped out because of troubles in his real estate business. Business and government officials scrambled to assemble a new group, which retained Cohn & Wolfe, the 14th-largest public relations agency and an autonomous subsidiary of Burson-Marsteller, to organize a presentation to show that the city's temporary problems paled beside its overall strengths.
The agency helped the new group position the franchise as a team for the entire Rocky Mountain time zone rather than for Denver alone, said Steven E. Ehrhart, the president of the franchise group, Colorado Baseball Partners.
A graphic designer retained by Cohn & Wolfe created the unnamed team's logo, and the agency wrote speeches for the presentation, including those given by Gov. Roy Romer of Colorado and Mayor Federico Pena of Denver. The agency also produced the promotional videotape and the slick information book left with the expansion committee's members.
The six finalists' promotional tapes, which were made to be left with expansion committee members, all followed the same general format, celebrating each area's residents, baseball tradition, love of sports, would-be baseball stadium and hopeful team owner.
 
Disney's Production
 The promotional video for Orlando was produced by Disney, which also donated hotel rooms at Disney World for committee members when they came to inspect the city two weeks ago, said Pat Williams, the president of the Orlando Magic basketball team, who is running the campaign to bring baseball to town. Orlando's franchise group, led by Richard M. DeVos, the president of the Amway Corporation, hopes to turn the city's minor league franchise, the Sunrays, into a major league team.
With the Miami-Fort Lauderdale group, or South Florida, as it is called, Burson-Marsteller hopes to establish the credentials of Mr. Huizenga, the Blockbuster chairman, to own a team. Unlike others chasing franchises, Mr. Huizenga was little known to baseball executives.
Mr. Hope, a former marketing executive for the Atlanta Braves, brought Mr. Huizenga together with Paul Bortz, a sports-broadcast analyst in Denver, and Steve Mat, a consultant with Arthur Andersen & Company in Dallas who does financial analyses for sports franchises.
"From the league's standpoint, they like to see you've got the right people," said Mr. Hope, who previously helped Charlotte, N.C., get a National Basketball Association team and Ottawa a hockey franchise. "It's proof in the process that you're a serious contender."
To demonstrate local support for baseball, Burson's Miami office is also working to fill Joe Robbie Stadium, where the South Florida team would play, on March 30 and 31 when the New York Yankees and the Baltimore Orioles are scheduled to play two exhibition games. The agency's radio advertisements for the games feature Mel Allen, the Yankees' legendary former radio announcer.
Fleishman-Hillard, the seventh-largest public relations firm, has also concentrated on showcasing public support for baseball in Washington, where low attendance forced the Washington Senators to depart the city twice. The agency is arranging a season-ticket drive for the would-be team, whose lead partner is John (Chip) Akridge, a local developer.
Whether any of the public relations efforts will help is unclear. Prof. Gerald W. Scully, a University of Texas economist and the author of "The Business of Major League Baseball," said that while Miami-Fort Lauderdale and Tampa-St. Petersburg were the best expansion markets because of their size and demographics, pure politics could influence the decision.
A team in Washington could be the price for Congressional support if baseball, for instance, wanted to shift some its games to pay-per-view television, Professor Scully said.

(Burson-Marsteller)
