HEADLINE: Seven Minutes In Los Angeles - A special report.;
Videotaped Beating by Officers Puts Full Glare on Brutality Issue

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times; The following article is based on reporting by Seth Mydans, Richard W. Stevenson and Timothy Egan and was written by Mr. Mydans.

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 17

 BODY:
Since it was first broadcast on local television, the videotape of a black man being beaten and kicked for nearly two minutes by a group of white police officers has shamed the city and outraged minority residents who have insisted for years that they are targets of an abusive police force.
Two weeks after it occurred, the beating has pushed the issue of police brutality to the forefront of the criminal justice debate. Local and Federal law-enforcement agencies have opened investigations to determine whether indeed there is a pattern of police brutality, not only in Los Angeles but around the country. 
 Four police officers have been indicted for the beating of Rodney G. King on March 3, and a grand jury is considering indictments against other officers present at the beating.
 
Chief's Views Are Questioned
 A number of points have contributed to the sense among people both in and out of law enforcement circles that the beating was far from the aberration claimed by Chief Daryl F. Gates of the Los Angeles Police Department, including these:
*In the seven-minute videotape, although 11 officers are shown standing by during the beating by three patrolmen under the eye of a sergeant, none makes a serious effort to stop it. And no one moves to care for Mr. King after he is hogtied, dragged to the side of the road and left bleeding until an ambulance arrives five minutes later.
*The beating is carried out with impunity, with no evident concern that, barely 60 feet away, up to 20 local residents are watching, some shouting, "No, don't kill him!," or that the officers are acting in full view of people in cars that drive slowly by.
*Nearly two-thirds of the people questioned in a Los Angeles Times poll published March 10, including a majority of whites, said they believed that police brutality was common here.
*Court records depict a history of similar cases in Los Angeles, some of which seem to differ from the beating of Mr. King primarily in that there was no camera to record them.
"This is going to be the defining incident in police brutality; it's going to be the historical event for police in our time," said Jerome Skolnick, professor of law and sociology at University of California at Berkeley who is an expert on police behavior. "It is highly unlikely that this is unrepresentative of Los Angeles police. Two people can go crazy, but if you have 10 or 12 people watching them and not doing anything, this tells you that this is a normal thing for them."
Although several national organizations, including the National Association of Chiefs of Police and the Police Foundation in Washington, monitor law-enforcement issues and compile statistics on police practices, none keep complete statistics on complaints against the police by citizens. Many large cities rely on their police departments' own internal affairs units to take such complaints and to compile statistics about them.
For all the details captured by the video camera in Los Angeles, several questions remain about what exactly set off the beating. Police and witness accounts of the moments after the chase ended and the beating began are in conflict, with the police accusing the motorist of resisting arrest. And there is no evidence of anything that might have been said to spark the outburst.
No matter what actions Mr. King might have taken before the video camera was switched on, there was a widespread feeling here that nothing he did or said could justify the beating he received from the three patrolmen under the supervision of a sergeant.
Mayor Tom Bradley, who has condemned the beating as reprehensible, said, "The three officers, clearly with the use of their batons and with their feet, left no doubt in anybody's mind about the charges that should be levied against them."
 
The Chase
A Drive Ends In a Nightmare
 Shortly before 12:30 A.M. on Sunday, March 3, Mr. King was driving fast down the Foothill Freeway near San Fernando, at the northern edge of Los Angeles. With him in his white 1988 Hyundai sedan were two friends, Bryant Allen and Freddie Helms.
Mr. King, a 25-year-old unemployed construction worker with two children, had been released last December after serving six months of a two-year sentence for second-degree robbery; brandishing a tire iron, he had taken cash from a grocer. He was still on parole.
In a California Highway Patrol car, a husband-and-wife team, Officers T. J. and Melanie Singer, reported to their headquarters that the Hyundai approached them from behind at 110 or 115 miles an hour, a Highway Patrol spokesman, Sgt. Mike Brey, said later.
Although a number of press reports have asserted that the small car cannot reach such speeds, Sergeant Brey said that at the time it would have been traveling downhill.
When Mr. King was released from jail without charges on March 6, he told reporters: "There was no chase. I may have been speeding just a little bit."
An audio tape of police radio conversations, released last Friday, picks up the chase after the Highway Patrol called in the Los Angeles police when Mr. King's car left the freeway. A police helicopter was also called in.
Then, the tape shows, he led his pursuers in a circle through a darkened neighborhood at about 55 m.p.h. in a 40 m.p.h. zone. "Vehicle stopped at red light but failed to yield to police," a radio transmission from a pursuing car said. Based on the statements of Sergeant Brey and a review of the audio tape, it appears that the pursuing officers did not know that Mr. King had a criminal record.
 
The Beating
Awakening To Commotion
At about 12:45 A.M., Mr. King pulled over and stopped on Foothill Boulevard, a four-lane street running through Lake View Terrace, a middle-class, mixed-race neighborhood that is fairly sparsely settled. At least 15 officers in patrol cars converged on him.
In what other police officers called a chance deployment, all the pursuing officers were white. The force is 14 percent black.
The wailing sirens and the thunderous roar of the helicopter awakened many residents of an apartment complex across the street. Josie Morales, a 26-year-old service representative for the Los Angeles Department of Water and Power, looked out her second-floor bedroom window and saw the Hyundai and police cars pulling up behind it. Mrs. Morales said she and her husband, Heriberto, put on robes and walked onto their balcony before the police or Mr. King got out of their cars.
Mrs. Morales said she heard a muffled command from one police car. Mr. King, she said, got out of his car with his hands up, turned and put his hands on the roof. Then, she and other witnesses said, he knelt, then lay on his stomach, with three or four officers standing in a semicircle around him.
 
Here, Accounts Differ
 There are contradictory accounts of what happened next. Richard Talkington, a Los Angeles police detective, said the report filed by the officers on the scene said Mr. King tried to stand up while being handcuffed, causing one officer to fall.
Detective Talkington, who said he had reviewed the report as part of the routine initial inquiry, said the officers also reported that Mr. King had reached into his pants pocket, presumably raising concern that he might have a weapon.
According to the detective's account, the report said that Mr. King, after standing up, charged at the officers and kicked and swung at them. The full police report has not been released.
Mrs. Morales and other witnesses said they did not see Mr. King reach into his pocket, knock over an officer or charge at the officers. But one other resident of the apartment complex, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said she saw a brief scuffle.
Mr. King said that after lying down he was handcuffed and got an electrical shock from "some kind of device."
"After they shocked me the first time, they paused for a minute and then they struck me across the face real hard with a billy club," Mr. King said. "I was lying face down with my hands tied, and they shocked me again on the other side of my shoulder."
 
The Videotape
Illuminated By Headlights
 A minute or two after Mr. King got out of his car and lay down, another resident of the apartment complex went onto his balcony. George Holliday, a 31-year-old manager of a plumbing-supply business, was carrying his new Sony video camera. He started shooting the scene unfolding across the street, which was illuminated by street lights and police car headlights.
The opening seconds of the videotape show Mr. King leaping up, spinning to his right and taking one or two quick steps. He was not handcuffed or tied, and it cannot be determined whether he had yet been beaten.
A close viewing of the unedited seven-minute videotape -- spanning the time from Mr. King's abrupt motion to a point where he lies handcuffed, hogtied and bleeding at the side of the road -- shows one officer swinging his nightstick at Mr. King like a baseball bat as he rose and turned. Mr. King fell to the ground.
The tape blurs for several seconds. When the focus is restored, one officer is seen striking Mr. King repeatedly around the head and shoulders.
At that point, the tape shows one officer holding a Taser stun gun that has been fired at Mr. King, although it remains unclear whether the gun was fired before or after the videotaping began. A Taser (the name is a loose acronym for "Tom Swift's Electric Rifle") shoots two barbed darts that deliver an electric shock to immobilize a suspect. The darts remain connected to the gun by a wire, which is visible on the tape throughout the beating.
 
Wires Still Attached
 The videotape shows two officers beating Mr. King ferociously for just under two minutes. A third officer joined in from time to time to kick or hit Mr. King. The officer with the Taser paced about 10 feet away, keeping the wire leading to the darts from getting tangled as Mr. King spun and rolled under the force of the blows.
Later, Mr. King showed journalists a bruise on his right side that he said was caused by the Taser darts and the shocks. Los Angeles police regulations say the darts should be removed only after the suspect has been restrained.
The soundtrack is dominated by the roar of the helicopter. But a voice can be heard repeatedly screaming "Stop!" As the beating nears an end, one of the officers seems to be yelling at Mr. King. The sound quality is poor, but it sounds as if he is saying, "Hands behind your back" as Mr. King is struck repeatedly.
At one point Mr. King, lying face down, moves his arms as if to put his hands behind his back. An officer stomps on his head or neck, causing him to jerk his arms up to his head.
The use of the nightsticks and Taser guns are regulated by the department's "use of force" rules, which permit their use only when all other reasonable means of subduing a suspect have been exhausted, or when a suspect poses a danger.
Only once on the videotape did any officer try to intervene. One officer briefly raised his left arm in front of a nightstick-swinging colleague in the opening moments of the videotape. But the gesture had no discernible effect. There appear to have been 15 law-enforcement officers and at least six patrol cars on the scene. Two cars and at least three officers were from the Highway Patrol.
Witnesses said about 20 residents were on their balconies or gathered along the metal fence separating the street from the apartment complex.
"We were yelling, 'No, don't kill him!' " said Elois Camp, a 65-year-old retired teacher who watched from the porch of her first-floor apartment. "They paid us no attention."
 
Dragged Away, to Wait
 The officers made no apparent attempt to conceal or stop the beating, despite the presence of so many witnesses and at least three passing cars, one of which slowed almost to a stop.
The beating ended just under two minutes into the videotape, when one officer grabbed Mr. King's arms and handcuffed his hands behind his back. Half a dozen officers circled around him, and one apparently pulled out the Taser darts. He was then hogtied -- his cuffed hands lashed to his ankles behind his back -- and dragged face down to the side of the street, where he was left alone.
The rest of the videotape shows the officers milling around, moving their cars off the street, searching Mr. King's car and patting down a passenger, either Mr. Helms or Mr. Allen. The tape ends with Mr. King still lying by the road.
Witnesses said about five minutes elapsed after the beating before an ambulance came. They said Mr. King was still hogtied and handcuffed when he was loaded on the stretcher.
After the ambulance left, witnesses said, the police freed Mr. Allen and Mr. Helms, who walked to where many residents were still gathered, asked where they could find a pay phone, then walked down the street. Neither Mr. Allen nor Mr. Helms has been charged; their lawyers would not permit them to be interviewed.
Mr. King was jailed until Wednesday, when he was released without charges. He was then examined by doctors, who said they found nine skull fractures, a shattered eye socket and cheekbone, a broken leg, a concussion, injuries to both knees and nerve damage that left his face partly paralyzed.
On Friday, a sergeant and three patrolmen were indicted.
 
History
Steady Increase In Lawsuits
The beating has raised a central question: Was it an aberration, as Chief Gates said, or part of a pattern?
Complaints of police brutality and racism have continued, and verdicts and settlements against the department have risen over the decades, from $553,000 in 1972 to $6.4 million in 1989 to $8 million in 1990. In one case, a jury found Chief Gates personally liable for $170,000 in damages in 1988 for a beating some of his officers gave a Hispanic family while searching for a murder weapon.
Officer Theodore J. Briseno, one of the four charged in the beating of Mr. King, had been suspended for 66 days in 1987 after he beat a handcuffed man. The others indicted were Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officers Timothy E. Wind and Laurence M. Powell. Sergeant Koon and Officer Powell were also charged with filing false reports.
One former officer used the term "magic pencil" to describe the way the police can make potential allegations of misconduct disappear.
In the first two months of this year, there was a sharp rise in complaints filed against the police -- 127 for two months, against a yearly average over the last five years of about 600. About 25 percent of the complaints involved allegations of assaults by the police. On average, only 2 of the 600 complaints a year result in felony charges.
 
'An Orgy of Violence'
 When people talk about police brutality in Los Angeles, they talk about the Dalton Avenue case in 1988, in which 77 officers invaded the homes of two black families and engaged in what one lawyer called "an orgy of violence," ripping out sinks and toilets and smashing windows and television sets, apparently in retaliation for a telephoned threat to a police station.
Officers scrawled "LAPD Rules" on a wall outside the building, then beat residents as they arrested them. Four officers have been charged in the case. The city settled lawsuits by the residents last year for $3 million.
Also well remembered is the case of Eula Love, a black woman who in 1984 refused to allow a utility man to cut service to her home. When the police were called, she emerged holding a paring knife with a two-inch blade and was immediately shot dead.
Another case that received little publicity but bears similarities to the videotaped beating was the 1987 beating of Stuart Vigil, a 27-year-old white man. As Mr. Vigil, handcuffed and high on drugs, struggled against the police; 14 officers shot him with a Taser gun, kicked him in the head, then jumped on him. He died clutching the darts embedded in his chest.
In a recent case, about 30 youths, most of them Hispanic or black, were rounded up by the police when they entered a park in an affluent, mostly white neighborhood one afternoon. According to a suit filed here, the youths were ordered at gunpoint to lie on the ground, then to walk on their knees while the officers jeered at them and made racial slurs.
Civil rights cases against the Los Angeles police have become routine. Chief Gates recently testified at a trial involving the beating and hogtying of a man by the police.
In numerous interviews this week, minority victims of past police misconduct have said the only difference between their cases and that of Mr. King was the camera.
Louis Frescas, one of dozens of citizens who have been compensated by the City of Los Angeles, was hospitalized after a 1984 arrest. He said he was struck more than 50 times, even though charges were never filed against him. Mr. Frescas, who is Hispanic, said he was dragged from his car, thrown to the ground, and kicked and pummeled with nightsticks by one white officer as six others looked on. His case was settled out of court.
Court documents from several misconduct cases show that nearly all the victims of maulings by Los Angeles police dogs in the last seven years were black or Hispanic -- although whites committed nearly a third of the crimes in which dogs are usually deployed.
In recent years, there have been several incidents in which black celebrities -- people like Marcus Allen, the professional football player, and Jamaal Wilkes, the retired basketball star -- were ordered out of their cars and treated like felons when there was no apparent reason to stop them.
Last January, the California Department of Fair Employment and Housing said the department had systematically denied promotions and advancement to black officers. The accusation came after complaints in December by the same agency that the department discriminated against Hispanic officers. The cases are pending.
 
On the Inside
Personal Code Is Powerful
Whenever force is used -- and police records show it happens in about one out of every 100 arrests in Los Angeles -- the officers are required to file a Use of Force report.
In well-supervised departments, said Dr. Skolnick of Berkeley, officers are encouraged to report any use of excessive force by fellow officers. Department regulations require Los Angeles police officers to report misconduct by their colleagues -- although authorities on police behavior have long recognized that a "code of silence" exists here as in other big-city departments.
Under mounting pressure to resign, Chief Gates has defended his 8,300-member force. The 64-year-old chief, who seems to enjoy wide support among rank-and-file officers, said there was no pattern of violence or racism. So far, he has taken no action to change procedures on the use of force or on investigating complaints of brutality.
"I preach," he said, "and I really mean preach, to every single person who graduates from the police academy about the law and their need for a reverence of the law," Chief Gates said.
 
Bush Supports U.S. Inquiry
HAMILTON, Bermuda, March 17 (AP) -- The White House spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, said Saturday that President Bush fully supports the Justice Department's decision to investigate the "shocking" beating of Rodney G. King in Los Angeles.

Here are main sections of the grand jury's five-count indictment unsealed Friday in the case of four police officers charged in the beating of a motorist, Rodney G. King:
 
1. Assault by force likely to produce great bodily injury and with a deadlyweapon.
 
 Alleges that Sgt. Stacey C. Koon and Officers Laurence M. Powell, Timothy E. Wind and Theodore J. Briseno assaulted Mr. King with nightsticks and kicked him.
 
2. Officer unnecessarily assaulting or beating any person.
 
 Alleges that Officers Powell, Wind and Briseno and Sergeant Koon "didwillfully, unlawfully, under color of authority and without lawful necessity assault and beat a human being." It further alleges that Officers Powell and Wind and Sergeant Koon personally inflicted the injuries.
 
3. Submission of a false police report by peace officer.
 
 Alleges that Officer Powell submitted the report and "knowingly and intentionally made statements in the report which he knew to be false."
 
4. Submission of false report by peace officer.
 
 Alleges that Sergeant Koon intentionally made statements he knew werefalse.
 
5. Accessory after the fact.
 
 Alleges that Sergeant Koon knew a felony had been committed and "did harbor, conceal and aid" Officer Powell "with the intent that he might avoid and escape from arrest, trial, conviction and punishment for said felony."

USE OF FORCE: POLICE GUIDELINES
 
Following is the language on the use of force, from the Los Angeles Police Department's manual:
 
"While the use of reasonable physical force may be necessary in situations which cannot be otherwise controlled, force may not be resorted to unless other reasonable alternatives have been exhausted or would clearly be ineffective under the particular circumstances. Officers are permitted to use whatever force that is reasonable and necessary to protect others or themselves from bodily harm."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Nature of the Economy: Changed and Changing

BYLINE: By CHRISTOPHER LEHMANN-HAUPT

 BODY:

The Work of Nations Preparing Ourselves for 21st-Century Capitalism
By Robert B. Reich
331 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $24.
In his original and important new book, "The Work of Nations," Robert B. Reich offers a fresh analysis of America's present economic and social prospects. Mr. Reich, who is a political economist on the faculty of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, proposes that without many citizens being aware of it, the national economy has undergone a profound transformation that has changed the very idea of what a national economy could be. 
 To simplify: Under the old economic order, which reached high tide between 1950 and 1970, productivity depended on the success of what Mr. Reich calls the core corporation. This was a hierarchical structure, a pyramid with a managerial class at the top and production workers at the bottom. The company's efforts were bent to producing high-volume goods, and the more successfully it did so, the better everyone did, from the rank-and-file worker to the chief executive officer. What was good for the company was good for the nation, to paraphrase the famous remark made Charles E. (Engine Charlie) Wilson of General Motors. The rising tide lifted all boats, and all that.
But as these core corporations went forth around the globe seeking raw materials and new markets, a reaction occurred, Mr. Reich argues. Europe and Japan, unhappy with the subordinate roles that American business hegemony had cast them into, set out to create their own "national corporate champions" to compete and connect with America's. The success of their enterprise created a new economic order, as Mr. Reich sees it.
Under this new order, the pyramid has been replaced by a spider web whose strands reach out all over the world. Productivity has shifted from high-volume to high-value goods, created by people whose skills involve discovering "new linkages between solutions and needs." Mr. Reich classifies these people as "symbolic analysts" for their ability to manipulate symbols like data, words, visual representations and so forth.
Symbolic analysis is one of three types of work of the future, he believes, the other two types being "routine production services" (blue-collar work and lower-level management, for example) and "in-person services" (like physical therapy and security guarding, for instance). But when symbolic analysts do well, the other two categories don't necessarily prosper. It takes a strand of the web to lift a producer to prosperity. And the strand is global not national, so the old metaphors no longer apply.
Unfortunately, the nation's thinking has not caught up with this new order of things, Mr. Reich laments. People continue to think of the economy as national instead of global, with all sorts of adverse results. We worry about our trade imbalance, when in fact much of it "during the 1980's was due not the predations of foreign nations and corporations, insistent on selling more to us than we sold to them, but to American-owned firms making things abroad (or, more precisely, contracting with foreigners to supply them with particular goods and services, which the firm then sold in the United States)."
We confuse skill and ownership, the author writes, so that foreigners get bashed for buying up our assets, when in fact they are really supplying capital for the development of these assets. Bruce Springsteen hasn't become any less American, Mr. Reich points out, now that as a CBS recording artist he is being marketed by the Sony Corporation. He simply has more capital behind him.
What is a problem seriously threatening the country, the author believes, is that while the fifth of the population composed of symbolic analysts is doing better and better, the four-fifths comprising production and in-service workers is doing worse and worse. Moreover, as the gap between the two groups widens, the symbolic analysts are in effect seceding from the nation by withdrawing into their own enclaves, where they build their own schools and protect themselves with their own security guards.
Isolated in golden ghettos like Princeton, N.J.; northern Westchester and and parts of Putnam Counties, N.Y.; Palo Alto, Calif.; Austin, Tex.; Bethesda, Md., and Raleigh-Durham, N.C., the symbolic analysts refuse to invest in the improvement of the country's "infrastructure" that Mr. Reich believes to be necessary if opportunities to join the ranks of the symbolic analysts are to be democratized and the nation's productivity enhanced.
 What is to be done? Mr. Reich is better at defining the problem than proposing a solution. The first half of "The Work of Nations," where he traces the history of economic nationalism, is far more rigorous than the second half, where he limns the future of the global economy. The language sags. He overworks the word "comprise," even using it when he means "compose." And, while I'm quibbling, wouldn't "symbol analyst" express what the new class does a little more clearly than "symbolic analyst"?
 What Mr. Reich calls for as a solution to the nation's growing problem is an exercise in statesmanship. He calls for leaders with both a global economic vision and sufficient residual patriotism to want to aid the nation's have-nots to achieve productivity. What we need is "a positive economic nationalism, in which each nation's citizens take primary responsibility for enhancing the capacities of their countrymen for full and productive lives, but who also work with other nations to ensure that these improvements do not come at others' expense."
It is hard to see, especially in the light the recent global events, how such wise and magnanimous creatures as Mr. Reich envisions are going to spring spontaneously into being. More specifically, it is hard to imagine a prevailing socioeconomic myth, similar to laissez-faire capitalism or New Deal liberalism, that would render Mr. Reich's vision more concretely compelling.
Still, he never promises a program or a myth in "The Work of Nations." He merely wants to push the reader toward seeing things as he believes they really are. To that end, he has succeeded very well. He may not have persuaded the symbolic analysts to pay higher taxes so that the children of the production and in-person workers will get better educations. But surely he has shaken up a few assumptions.
How he does so is best expressed by one of his wittier passages, where he compares this country's present state to one in which the Lone Ranger and Tonto are surrounded by hordes of Indians. "We're surrounded!" exclaims the Lone Ranger. To which Tonto responds, "What do you mean we, kemo sabe?"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert B. Reich (Nancy Wasserman/Knopf)

SECTION: Section A; Page 15; Column 1; Editorial Desk

LENGTH: 778 words

HEADLINE: ABROAD AT HOME;
Bill of Wrongs

BYLINE: By Anthony Lewis

DATELINE: BOSTON

 BODY:
American conservatives have complained for years about constitutional protections for those suspected of crime. Judges enforcing the rules hobble the police, they say. The Bush Administration is pressing Congress right now to limit some rights.
Anyone inclined to that view should think about Britain and the case of the Birmingham Six. We regard the British legal system as similar to ours. It is -- but without a constitution enforced by judges. Thereby hangs the tale. 
 The Birmingham Six, men from Northern Ireland, were charged with bombing two Birmingham pubs in 1974. The Irish Republican Army claimed credit for the bombs, which killed 21 people.
The police produced long, detailed confessions that they said four of the six had volunteered. A forensic expert also testified for the prosecution that there were traces of nitroglycerin on two of the men's hands. The six were convicted and sentenced to life in prison.
At the trial, the defendants said the confessions were false and had been beaten out of them. But the judge, Mr. Justice Bridge, said that to accept their claim one would have to believe in a police conspiracy "unprecedented in the annals of British criminal history." He said the prosecution had presented "the clearest and most overwhelming evidence I have ever heard."
Mr. Justice Bridge is now Lord Bridge, the senior British law lord.
The six appealed, but the Court of Appeal quickly turned them down. The late Lord Widgery, then Lord Chief Justice, said in rejecting the appeal that he could see no evidence to suggest that they had been knocked about by the police "beyond the ordinary."
In 1977 the six brought a civil suit for damages against the police for injuries received after their arrest. Another senior judge, Lord Denning, the Master of the Rolls, threw the case out. Their claim of police malpractice opened up such an appalling vista, he said, that "every sensible person in the land would say 'it cannot be right these actions should go any further.' "
In 1986 a Labor member of Parliament, Chris Mullin, published a book supporting in detail the claim that the police had concocted the confessions. Granada Television did a program examining -- and demolishing -- the expert testimony about nitroglycerin traces. (It turned out that ordinary playing cards would leave the same traces.)
Government officials, now troubled, referred the case to the Court of Appeal again. But in 1988 the court once more dismissed the appeal. The Lord Chief Justice, Lord Lane, said the claim of a police plot to concoct a case against the six was "wholly incredible." He denounced the Granada television program.
Then an unconnected investigation found corruption in the police force that had handled the Birmingham Six case. In another look at the case, officials concluded that the police in charge had indeed faked evidence. The last claim of nitroglycerin traces was also withdrawn. Last week the Court of Appeal ordered the six released -- after 16 years in prison.
The case shook the criminal justice establishment in Britain from bottom to top. It was the third in less than two years in which Irish defendants were found to have been wrongly convicted. The Home Secretary appointed a royal commission to look into the whole system.
"Rarely has the reputation of English justice sunk so low," The Economist said. The Independent newspaper said the scandal "requires not just a royal commission but a resignation. The man who bears responsibility is the Lord Chief Justice, Lord Lane. It is time he threw in his wig."
But there is a broader point in the case of the Birmingham Six. It is not just that British judges were arrogant and insensitive in this case. It is that, in general, they operate without the guiding light of a constitution.
The false confessions could not have been admitted as evidence in the United States, because the six were questioned and "confessed" without a chance to see lawyers. In the Miranda case in 1966, the Supreme Court ruled out such evidence as a violation of the constitutional protection against compelled self-incrimination.
In the absence of a constitution, British judges have come generally to think less of individual interests and more of the state's. They are also hostile to claims of free speech, for example, and freedom of the press.
British politicians, too, have been cold to the idea of constitutional rights -- Labor as much as Conservatives. The result is a far more arbitrary society than ours.
Is that what we want? If Americans who scorn constitutional rights for criminal defendants think about it, I doubt that they really do.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: India Has No History of Anti-Semitism

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The news article describing the shrunken Jewish community of Bombay, India (Feb. 17), states that they constitute "a vulnerable minority scattered throughout predominantly Muslim neighborhoods," and they fear that events in the Persian Gulf "could turn neighbors against them in a country where decades of official support for the Palestine Liberation Organization has contributed to the creation of a climate generally hostile to Israel." 
 This is a wrongheaded and mischievous picture of the situation of Jews in India, seeming to insist on finding tension even where none exists. In 25 years of visits to and travels in India, I have never seen or heard of hostility to Indian Jews. Official friendliness to the P.L.O. and Muslim countries, and hostility to Israel find no reflection in the English-language press or in public opinion or indeed among the high Indian officials who carry out these policies, when one speaks to them privately.
The official stance of India toward Israel is explained by the desire to maintain good relations with Arab countries, with the hope of occasionally getting one or another to abstain in United Nations votes on Kashmir; by the trading relations that bring India its oil; by the large numbers of Indians working in Arab countries.
Jews emigrate from India for the same reasons they emigrate from other countries with small Jewish communities: to live in larger Jewish communities where they can find Jewish spouses for their children, because of the pull of the Jewish ingathering in Israel or because of wider economic opportunity.
To suggest the decline of the Jewish community in India is owing to the official relations of India with Israel, or to Jewish fears of popular hostility or prejudice, is to demonstrate an ignorance of the well-recorded history of Jews in India, a country with no history of anti-Semitism, popular or governmental.
 
NATHAN GLAZER
Cambridge, Mass., Feb. 28, 1991
 
The writer is professor of education and sociology at Harvard University.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Hits 8-Month High Against Mark in Hectic Day

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar strengthened broadly yesterday and briefly hit an eight-month high against the German mark, buoyed by increased demand after the Persian Gulf war, political uncertainty in the Soviet Union and trouble in the reunified German economy.
Currency markets early in the day grew hectic after the dollar hit its highest level against the German mark since before the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait last August. 
 Sustained confidence in the United States economy after the gulf war continued to keep demand for the dollar strong. At the same time, the mark was hurt by reports that Germany's economic boom, invigorated by reunification, was expected to slow significantly.
Before profit taking eroded some of the increase, the dollar was quoted at 1.6380 German marks, matching its level of July 23, 1990. The dollar ended in New York up more than 2 pfennigs, to 1.6282 marks, from 1.6070 late Friday.
Traders said the German currency was further undermined by discord in the Soviet Union, despite referendum results that apparently handed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev a victory in his efforts to preserve the country's political structure.
"With Germany being close to the Russian border, it kind of creates an anxiety in that whole sphere," said Tom Benfer, senior market representative in foreign exchange at the Bank of Montreal in New York.
Rumors circulated throughout the day that central banks were poised to sell dollars in an effort to stem the currency's rise, an action taken several times last week with varying degrees of success. But the reports proved largely untrue. The Bank of Japan did sell dollars against the yen in Asian trading, but traders said the activity was virtually ignored by the European and domestic markets.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.7905, from $1.8340 late Friday. The decline reflected not only the dollar's strength, but also weakness in the pound on expectations of a cut in British interest rates. The dollar also rose against the pound in New York. Sterling ended at $1.7938, less expensive than late Friday's $1.8225.
Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 137.65 yen, up 1.40 yen from last Friday's close. Later, in London, it was quoted at 138.10 yen, and in New York, it settled at 137.97 yen, slightly higher than late Friday's 137.85 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4065 Swiss francs, up from 1.3930; 5.5485 French francs, up from 5.4735; 1,214.75 Italian lire, up from 1,200.00, and 1.1541 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1561.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Loss Is Expected At Boise Cascade

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BOISE, Idaho, March 18

 BODY:
The Boise Cascade Corporation told securities analysts it expects a loss of about $16 million in the first quarter of 1991, largely because of a weak paper market. Net income for the first quarter of 1990 was $33.6 million, while income in the fourth quarter came to $4.8 million.
The company said the decline stemmed from lower paper prices, the weak economy, excess industry capacity and slow construction activity, which reduced demand for wood products. The company said it had reduced budgets and was cutting capital expenditures by about $500 million in 1991. Boise Cascade shares slipped 37.5 cents, to $26.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: FUTURES OPTIONS;
Silver and Platinum Prices Fall as Do Recovery Hopes

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver and platinum futures prices tumbled yesterday as falling commodity prices weakened hopes for a strong economic recovery. Gold futures prices also fell.
Silver futures settled 14.8 to 15.6 cents lower on New York's Commodity Exchange, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.943 an ounce, its first close below $4 since March 7. 
 Platinum ended $9.60 to $9.80 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with April at $396.80 an ounce. Gold was $2.10 to $2.20 lower on the Commodity Exchange, with the active April contract at $363.70 an ounce. Gold for current delivery in March fell $1.90, to $363 an ounce.
 
Vulnerable to Economic Signals
 Silver and platinum have industrial uses that make them more vulnerable than gold to economic signals. Both of the metals rose sharply through late February and early March on hopes that the end of the gulf war would hasten an economic recovery. But the rally faltered last week after Government reports suggested there would be little or no economic growth in the months ahead.
Silver and platinum also responded to a general decline in commodity prices, said Bernard Savaiko, senior metals analyst with PaineWebber Inc. He said declining commodity prices reflected a lack of demand for raw materials.
Analysts said the metals also weakened in reaction to strength in the dollar, which has been gaining against other currencies in recent weeks. A strong dollar makes American-made goods more expensive overseas, which depresses export demand for United States products.
Oil prices moved lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Traders said there was a general lack of interest by oil buyers, which helped to weaken prices. Some players in oil futures contracts were apparently waiting to see whether the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries makes good on a promise to cut daily production by about 1.1 million barrels.
Crude oil finished 25 to 42 cents lower, with April down 25 cents, to $19.76 a barrel; heating oil was 0.06 cent lower to 0.13 higher, with April at 55.79 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.28 to 0.55 cent lower, with April at 69.79 cents a gallon; natural gas was 1 cent lower to 0.3 cent higher, with April at $1.386 per 1,000 cubic feet.

HEADLINE: Chrysler Unit Still on Block After Rebuff by Mitsubishi

BYLINE: By DORON P. LEVIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 18

 BODY:
The Chrysler Corporation said today that it was discussing the sale of a stake in the Chrysler Financial Corporation with a couple of potential suitors but that Japan's Mitsubishi Motor Corporation had said it was not interested.
Chrysler, the No. 3 American auto maker, which has been operating under financial pressure, said it was willing to sell either a controlling interest in Chrysler Financial or a minority interest above 25 percent. 
Jerome B. York, chief financial officer, said Chrysler's finance subsidiary needed higher credit ratings, and the parent company needed more cash in the face of a steep downturn in business. A sale of Chrysler Financial equity could raise $1.25 billion or more.
"The book value of Chrysler Financial is $2.5 billion, and we would anticipate a transaction at book or slightly over book," Mr. York said.
 
Controlling Interest Offers
 He said some potential buyers told Chrysler's investment banks, First Boston and the Blackstone Group, that they would be interested in bidding only for a controlling interest. He declined to identify the remaining potential buyers but said that the list had contained "eight or nine" companies when Chrysler began soliciting interest in the fourth quarter of 1990.
Chrysler had approached Mitsubishi about an equity stake because the Japanese auto maker is expanding its retail automotive business in the United States and is very strong financially. Chrysler owns 11 percent of Mitsubishi and is associated in several joint projects and commercial relationships.
"Our investment bankers said that if this were 1988 or 1989 we would have 15 or 20 interested parties, but because of the crunch in financial markets the list will be shorter," he said. Some potential buyers are not able to secure financing.
In addition to generating fresh cash, selling an equity interest in Chrysler Financial could convince ratings agencies to raise their ratings on the unit's debt securities. Chrysler Financial has been excluded from public debt markets because of its parent's shaky financial condition.
Mr. York declined to say how soon Chrysler might sell Chrysler Financial equity, but if the auto maker is not able to find a buyer, its first priority "is to maintain Chrysler Financial so it can take care of automotive lending requirements," he said, which would mean finding a way to improve credit ratings so Chrysler Financial could regain access to credit markets.
Chrysler Financial, which paid a $300 million dividend to its corporate parent last year, will probably not pay one in 1991.

HEADLINE: First Fidelity In Spanish Sale

 BODY:
The First Fidelity Bancorporation announced plans yesterday to raise $220 million in capital by selling 9.5 million common shares to Banco Santander, a Spanish bank.
The sale will provide First Fidelity, one of the nation's 25 largest banking companies, with the capital it needs to expand and will give the Spanish bank 13 percent of the Newark- based banking company. 
 Banco Santander also acquired warrants giving it the right to buy 9.5 million more shares at $25.50 each, which would provide First Fidelity with another $242.4 million, and leave the Spanish bank with a 24.9 percent stake.
Since the arrival a year ago of Anthony P. Terracciano as chairman, First Fideltiy has moved quickly to cut costs and return to profitable operations, despite the increases in troubled loans caused by the recession. Last month, First Fidelity acquired 48 branches and $2.5 billion in deposits from a failed New Jersey savings bank.
"We looked at some 80 banks in 38 states before deciding ot invet in First Fideltiy," said Emilio Boton, Banco Santander's chairman. "It will be our only direct investment in a major regional U.S. banking company."
Banco Santander paid $23.25 for each new share, or slightly more than yesterday's close of $23.125 on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices Fall in Sluggish Trading

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities fell and interest rates rose in sluggish trading yesterday, deepening the negative tone that emerged late last week.
On Friday, a disappointing inflation report and news from University of Michigan researchers of a sharp rebound in consumer confidence led to a big selloff in the bond market. 
 The reports generated a sense that the Federal Reserve Board was not likely to ease monetary policy again soon if the economy really was on the mend and if inflation was still a problem, and that sense was more broadly visible yesterday.
"The market has relied on the Fed and the recession for so long that any change in thinking is not good," a trader of government bonds said. "And, at least temporarily it seems, we have run out of the stimulus the Fed has given us."
 
Consumer Price Report
 Stung by last week's inflation report, which showed that producer prices excluding food and energy rose by four-tenths of a percentage point in February, some investors yesterday may have decided to lighten up on positions in advance of a report expected today on consumer price trends for February.
Most economists are anticipating that the figures should be fairly good. The consensus is that the overall index rose by about one-tenth of a percentage point, and that the index without food and energy rose by about three-tenths of a percentage point. In January, the so-called core rate shot up by eight-tenths of a percentage pont.
"The market is confused about the economic outlook, and is more willing to assume that the recession will be over sooner and that inflation will not improve very much," said Steven A. Wood, director of financial markets research at the Bank of America.
In addition to worries about inflation, traders said that market participants were beginning to look ahead to a very large volume of new intermediate- to long-term Treasury issues that would be sold over the next six weeks.
 
Sales Start Next Week
 Those sales begin next week, with expected auctions of new two-year and five-year notes. They end in early May, with the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.
"We are looking at a six-week horizon where there is going to be some fairly heavy supply," another bond trader said. "We can absorb it, but we need customers. Right now we aren't seeing any."
At the Treasury's weekly bill auctions, three-month bills were sold at an average discount rate of 5.83 percent, down slightly from an average rate of 5.85 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, bids on the new six-month bills produced an average discount rate of 5.82 percent, compared with 5.91 percent a week ago.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered at a price of 95 1/32 late yesterday, down 14/32, to yield 8.32 percent, compared with 8.28 percent late Friday.
Mr. Wood said the rise in long-term interest rates over the last few weeks could jeopardize a recovery in the housing industry, where activity has been at an exceptionally low ebb for months.
 
No Effect So Far
 "So far, the rise hasn't hurt housing any more than it is already suffering, but it could if the rise in long rates continues, and fixed-rate mortgages go up," he said.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at a price of 97 13/32, down 10/32, to yield 8.13 percent. And the 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 14/32, down 5/32, to yield 7.06 percent.
Elsewhere, participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues slipped by 1/4 point to3/8 point in sluggish trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, prices of most widely quoted issues dipped by about 1/4 point, according to market participants.

HEADLINE: Money and Meters: One Firm, Many Companies - A Special Report;
Winning New York Contracts: Hard Questions for a Supplier

BYLINE: The following article is based on reporting by Martin Gottlieb, Dean Baquet and Eric N. Berg and was written by Mr. Gottlieb.

 BODY:
For the last three years, while New York City awarded contract after contract to the tiny Vanguard Meter Service company of Kentucky, complaints were being lodged inside and outside of city government about the company's performance on what now amounts to more than $50 million of water-meter installation work.
The complaints involved allegations that meters were installed improperly, that homeowners lost workdays waiting for installers who never showed up, and that company workers were paid less than required by law.
 
Financial Troubles
 At the same time, as city officials depicted the company as "the I.B.M. of the water-meter industry," persistent financial difficulties plagued Vanguard's work, caused at least in part by a long history of problems with creditors, of which the city seems to have been largely unaware. 
 City officials say that the meter program has been a huge success and that Vanguard has performed "satisfactory" work, with a small number of problems that are quickly corrected.
But the complaints, which came from union officials, workers, and the city's own supervisors, stand in contrast to this. And they raise broader questions about the city's $5.5 billion-a-year contracting system, which is has many of the same features as the water meter effort. These include heavy reliance on companies that win contracts that hardly anybody else wants to bid on and whose failures can jeopardize entire programs.
In previous articles, The New York Times described how the company, which initially listed $300,000 in assets, hired the politically connected lawyers Sid Davidoff, a friend to Mayor David N. Dinkins, and Armand D'Amato, the brother of United States Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, and won about two-thirds of the contracts let thus far in the city's 10-year, $290 million program to install 630,000 water meters in New York City buildings. Under the water-conservation program, New Yorkers pay for water based on consumption rather than at a flat rate.
Vanguard is now the subject of four government investigations, focusing on possible labor law violations and other improprieties.
The company denies any wrongdoing. And city officials say any program this extensive is likely to lead to complaints. But an analysis of city records and court documents raises questions about the level of problems in three areas:
*The quality of work. At least four times over three years, officials of the city's Bureau of Water Register chastised the company variously for falling far behind schedule, hiring "rude and incompetent employees," and being responsible for an "overworked staff, apathetic response to customers' wishes, ineffectual manpower levels, and poor workmanship."
*Treatment of workers. In a January 1989 letter demanding a city investigation, the union local representing Vanguard employees reported "our office is besieged with complaints" that the company was shortchanging on wages. Workers also complained to the state Labor Department that year, which said it referred them to the city. But the city did not investigate until last year. In the inquiry by the Comptroller's office, which cleared Vanguard, no workers were interviewed and investigators relied solely on company records.
*The company's financial history. Numerous court papers, of which the city was apparently unaware, document how the company's chairman, Robert E. Bates, was warding off creditors well after he began winning city contracts. According to documents, his cash flow became so strained that suppliers threatened to cut him off, a move that could have crippled the metering program.
Yet city officials did relatively little checking on the company's background, particularly in comparison to a check on a competitor that underbid Vanguard on five contracts. After Mr. Bates and water register officials suggested that the company, Volt Energy Systems, had not done enough meter work to qualify, the officials, including Paul Recco, the meter program's director, checked Volt's work history in detail and disqualified it from three large jobs. They were then awarded to Vanguard.
Mr. Recco was later hired as an executive by Vanguard, one month after quitting his city job last September.
In an interview, he said he showed no favoritism to Vanguard and had not spoken to the company about a job until he left the city agency.
In a lengthy interview Mr. Bates said he dominated New York City's metering program because others were unwilling to take the risks. He called his company the "quality contractor in the United States" and said investigators, who have taken three truckloads of his records, "just fired their shotguns hoping they could hit something."
 
Job Performance
 
Overwork And Apathy
The first indication of problems discovered in city files came from Mr. Recco himself. In an October 1988 letter to Mr. Bates, he said the company "has failed to complete the number of installations in the approved progress schedule," creating a "large deficit" of work.
Meanwhile, he said, Vanguard's productivity on older contracts awarded for repair and replacement of old meters had "dropped drastically" as it tackled the new work.
"This," Mr. Recco wrote, "is unacceptable and cannot continue."
The following September, William Reese, Mr. Recco's assistant, wrote Vanguard to complain of a sloppy installation that he said created "a suspicion that a larger number of your work force is not complying with contract specifications."
Three months later Mr. Reese wrote a detailed report to Mr. Recco prompted, he said, by repeated problems on Vanguard jobs, including missed appointments and apathy among employees "obviously overwhelmed with their workload."
He cited 16 cases of missed appointments and poor work that he said were "a sampling of discrepancies encounted over a 90-day period."
 
'Has Proven Disastrous'
 "The sampling presented is a clear signal that Vanguard Meter Service has fallen behind, and continues to fall behind submitted installation schedules," he wrote. "All indicators of overworked staff, apathetic response to customers' wishes, ineffectual manpower levels, poor workmanship, point towards crisis management situations. This type of scenario has proven disastrous in the past. I feel the time has come for B.W.R. to intervene in these contracts." B.W.R. refers to the Bureau of Water Register.
Four months later, in March 1990, Thomas Carchietta, a customer service representative for the bureau, wrote the same sort of exasperated letter, citing five complaints he said were representative of what the bureau received daily. After one, in which he cited broken appointments made with a Queens homeowner, he concluded: "Again B.W.R. has been embarrassed by contractor failure to track customer inquiries accurately and responsibly. This situation is now the rule, not the exception."
The bottom line, he wrote, was that "Customer complaints are surpassing acceptable limits. Our customers are losing work days waiting for installers who don't show."
Steven Ostrega, director of the water register bureau, described these assessments as indications of "tough contract management for which the city should be praised," adding that independent city audits rated Vanguard's work highly. Mr. Ostrega said that the city has also been tough on the other meter installers. Mr. Recco agreed that other contractors were treated as rigorously and described the memos as standard. He added that the company's performance improved after the complaints.
However, present and former D.E.P. officials described the memos as uncommonly blunt and harsh. Mr. Bates, in fact, said he had never come across criticism "of this magnitude" before. He characterized the Reese memos in particular as those of "an overzealous young person with a job to do." He said company policy is to correct problems immediately.
Others also used strong language with the company. In July 1990 Con Edison said Vanguard workers entered one of its plants without permission and tore insulation from pipes without knowing if it was toxic.
"This is not the first time that your personnel have committed violations," Melvin Ross, Con Edison's water program coordinator, wrote Vanguard. "This also is not the first time that I have brought these matters to your attention.
"We pride ourselves in our safety records. We pride ourselves in our reliability of service. And we pride ourselves in good labor-management relations. You have jeopardized all of these."
 
The Workers
 
Was Underpayment The Norm?
The Federal Labor Department's racketeering unit is investigating whether Vanguard illegally paid workers for each meter installed rather than by the prevailing hourly rate required by state law, law-enforcement officials said. A dozen past and present Vanguard workers told The Times that the company assured them they would earn more this way. They said Vanguard contended installations would take an hour and that the company would pay $22 per meter rather than the $16-an-hour prevailing rate in effect at the program's start.
In reality, the workers said, they were often lucky to install two or three meters a day.
The consequences of an underpayment could have been broad. If Vanguard was bidding on the basis of an illegally low wage scale, it would have had an unfair advantage over its competitors.
Mr. Bates contends that nobody earned less than the prevailing rate, but said that as a productivity incentive, he pays the per-meter rate if it is higher.
But in a January 1989 letter to Harvey Schultz, then the city's Environmental Protection Commissioner, Frank LaRocca, business manager of Plumbers Union Local 371, wrote that the meter program "has turned into a fiasco." He said that "over 120 employees have left" Vanguard and that "many are still owed back pay."
Records from the Department of Environmental Protection, which oversees the Bureau of Water Register, indicate that Mr. Schultz wrote a letter asking the City Comptroller's office to investigate.
But Harrison J. Goldin, then comptroller, said he got no such letter. And Louis Haber, a spokesman for Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman, said agency files show no complaints.
Mr. LaRocca later withdrew his complaint, even though Vanguard workers contended in interviews that they had been shortchanged as recently as this year. Mr. LaRocca did not return calls.
Ms. Holtzman audited Vanguard last year, Mr. Haber said, after a competitor's assertion that Vanguard workers were stealing meters. While investigating the theft allegation, Mr. Haber said, investigators examined Vanguard's payroll records in a perfunctory way to see if the company was paying the prevailing wage.
Mr. Haber said the Comptroller has opened another inquiry into whether Vanguard is underpaying.
 
The Finances
 
$12 and a Watch To His Name
As Mr. Bates entered the New York City market, he was trying to ward off creditors in Kentucky, apparently unbeknownst to the city.
Mr. Bates was so pressed that Vanguard's stock, his personal cars and his Kentucky home were placed in the name of his wife, Priscilla. In September 1985, two years before bidding opened on the city's meter contracts, Mr. Bates said in a court deposition that his checking account was empty and his savings account held $12. All he had to his name, he said, was a Timex wristwatch and one-sixteenth of a nonproducing oil well.
Between 1982 and 1988 Kentucky courts ordered him to come up with nearly $300,000 for suppliers, the heirs of a former business partner and an ex-wife.
By 1987, part of Mr. Bates's income from Vanguard was being withheld by court order for back alimony payments.
Mr. Bates said many of his and Vanguard's difficulties were rooted in the national recession of the early 1980's.
 
Trouble Meeting Payroll
 In June 1989, Vanguard's cash flow problems emerged in New York, where the city noted in an internal memo that Mr. Bates was "experiencing difficulty in meeting his weekly payroll and paying his suppliers, who will no longer ship material without payment." If the financial difficulties slowed Vanguard, they would threaten the metering program schedule, the memo said. The agency agreed to expedite paperwork and pick up Vanguard's checks by hand to speed payment by a few days. Mr. Bates maintained said that many of his problems were the result of the city being late in paying him.
Mr. Ostrega acknowledges that the city did not do as extensive a background check on Vanguard as it did on others, because, in his words, the company was regarded as "the I.B.M." of the business.
City officials say ordinarily it would be unfair to disqualify a company because of financial difficulties as long as it could qualify for a bond guaranteeing its performance, as Vanguard has done. But others say the city took a risk in permitting a company in such financial straits to dominate a major program.
"The credit-worthiness of a company and its leader has to be taken into account -- whether it can meet its payments and its responsibilities," Ms. Holtzman said in an interview. "Particularly in a small company, the president's credit-worthiness is key. If the suppliers are worried about it, certainly its customers should be, too."
By Mr. Bates's account, Vanguard's financial problems eased when Armand D'Amato introduced Mr. Bates to Alvin Benjamin, a Long Island developer who became a 32 percent partner. Mr. Bates said he hired Mr. Davidoff, the city's largest registeredlobbyist, to help free up payment checks. Mr. Davidoff has been successful in arranging meetings with Mr. Schultz and others, Mr. Bates said.
Last year, Vanguard was purchased by Asplundh Tree Expert Company, of Willow Grove, Pa., a large privately held company with many government contracts. Mr. Bates remains as its chairman.

HEADLINE: New York State and City Run in Place on Budgets

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 18

 BODY:
Although New York State and New York City are facing combined fiscal troubles of crisis proportions, budget negotiations here have become mired in what even the participants concede are Albany's usual parochial and political concerns.
Unwilling to approve many of the proposed cuts offered by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, but lacking a politically palatable alternative, the state's legislative leaders seem to have adopted a wait-and-see approach. 
 Even as the Legislature searches for ways to fend off the Governor's budget, many fiscal analysts are questioning whether the proposal presented by Mr. Cuomo is adequate to solve the state's and the city's problems. What is lacking, these analysts say, is a comprehensive plan to deal with both governments' financial ills.
Instead, they say, the state and local governments, led by the City of New York, appear to be entering a fiscal tug-of-war in which the solution to one government's budget problems only compounds the problems of the other.
 
'The Numbers Are Bigger'
 "What we are seeing is more of the same, clearly, except that the numbers are bigger," said Raymond Horton, president of the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group financed by businesses. "Unfortunately, there's no overarching plan that's designed to create some stability."
In contrast to the fiscal crisis of the mid-1970's, when the state and the city worked furiously to fashion a sweeping solution, this year there is little sense of urgency to budget negotiations.
"What was created last time during the fiscal crisis was an atmosphere that allowed people to do things that had never been done before," said one former state official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. "Now, nobody's doing anything that they have never done before. There's no real atmosphere of crisis."
For the fiscal year starting in April, the state and the city are facing combined budget gaps of $8 billion, and together are considering laying off thousands of workers.
The current problems are very different from the fiscal crisis of 15 years ago, when New York City was shut out from the credit markets. The city's inability to borrow money precipitated an emergency that prompted state and city leaders to draft a plan to restore the city's finances.
In part because of the controls imposed during the last crisis, neither the city nor the state is faced today with being shut out of credit markets.
But many fiscal analysts say the magnitude of the problems facing the two governments is even greater now than it was 15 years ago, when the city was insolvent, but the state remained on firm footing. They wonder, they say, whether a tangible crisis, like being closed out of the credit markets, is needed before the state and the city will take the kind of bold action that they took in the 1970's.
"The good news compared to the 1970's is the money won't stop tomorrow," said Felix G. Rohatyn, chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation. "But the bad news is also that money won't stop tomorrow. There is no clear and visible pressure here."
Six weeks after Governor Cuomo presented his $51.9 billion budget to the Legislature, the Assembly Speaker, Mel Miller, and the Senate majority leader, Ralph J. Marino, have yet to take a firm position on the proposal. So far, the only comments the legislative leaders have made on the budget have been noncommital.
Mr. Miller, a Brooklyn Democrat, has suggested that the Governor's budget, which calls for deep cuts in state aid, raises too many policy questions to be resolved during the normal course of budget negotiations, but he has failed to offer a clear alternative. He has skirted the politically perilous issue of new taxes, and has declined even to say how large he thinks the budget should be.
Mr. Marino, an Oyster Bay, L.I., Republican, has stated that he does not want to spend more than the Governor has proposed, but has also failed to take a clear stand on taxes. Neither man has offered a counterproposal to the Governor's plan.
In the meantime, the news only grows worse, and the lobbying in Albany more frenetic. Today the State Comptroller warned that the state was facing an additional $275 million gap for the fiscal year that starts April 1. And on Tuesday, more than 20,000 demonstrators are expected to arrive at the State Capitol to pressure lawmakers into restoring many of the cuts in the Governor's budget.
Two weeks before the state's budget deadline, the only issues that have emerged definitively from the desultory budget talks are the same ones that emerge virtually every year with the first tentative signs of Albany spring.
State Senate Republicans are insisting, according to their custom, that school aid to their principal supporters on Long Island be increased. Assembly Democrats, living up to their tradition, are pressing for more aid for their primary constituency: New York City. Both the Assembly and the Senate are expressing their usual opposition to raising the state's gasoline tax, as the Governor has proposed. And Mr. Cuomo is pledging, once again, to oppose to any efforts to raise the state's income or corporate-tax rates.
"We represent our constituents," Mr. Marino said, explaining the recurrent themes. "Our constituents have certain interests, and we are guided in large measure by those interests."
Cuomo administration officials offer a less flattering explanation. "The facts have changed," one adviser to the Governor said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. "It can't be business as usual. But it's very, very difficult to get these guys to change their political stripes."
Governor Cuomo has roundly chastised lawmakers for the slow pace of budget negotiations, saying that he made tough choices in preparing his budget, now it is time for the Legislature to do the same.
"If you're late on April 1, I will not be in the room with you," he said recently in remarks aimed at the Legislature. "I will sit back and wait for you to deliver a budget to me."
Many analysts, however, say that the Governor, too, deserves some of the blame for the business-as-usual atmosphere in Albany. Mr. Cuomo's budget, they say, while certainly containing many tough cuts, contains few proposals aimed at actually changing the way state government operates and solving the long-term budget problems confronting the city and the state.
"Solving the Governor's budget problem with aid cuts is simply passing the problem onto the the city and other localities," said Charles Brecher, research director of the Citizens Budget Commission.
 
Higher Taxes?
 The Governor's budget, Mr. Brecher continued, is likely to prompt another round of local tax increases across a state that already relies heavily on local revenues. Such increases, he said, could be even more harmful to the state's economy than the state tax increases the Governor is resisting. "We should be shifting more of the tax burden onto a statewide base," he said.
Mr. Cuomo has rejected this argument, saying that local governments can cut their budgets just as he cut the state's. But the Governor's efforts to solve the state's budget problems without a broader plan to deal with local governments' problems as well have created chronic problems, which are evident in the nagging tensions between Mr. Cuomo and his ostensible ally, Mayor David N. Dinkins.
Recently, hardly a day has passed without some new sign of the increasing strains between the two men. On Wednesday, for example, reports that the Mayor would speak at a rally against the Governor's budget raised hackles in the Cuomo administration; the Mayor eventually decided to skip the demonstration. Then on Friday, the Mayor released an angry letter to the Governor, denouncing his proposed cuts in criminal justice.
"I have given the State Legislature and you an unprecedented commitment to increase police officers and related criminal justice spending," Mr. Dinkins said, referring to his recently approved crime plan. "I had assumed and understood there to be a state commitment to at least the current level of funding for our criminal justice programs."
Without a plan to deal with the state and city troubles in concert, many analysts say that the state will solve its budget problems only to find itself a few months later forced to grapple with New York City's, as the city begins its fiscal year in July.
Mr. Marino, the Senate majority leader, acknowledged that "the ideal would be to deal with both of them together."
"But it's hard to deal with both subjects at once," he said. "It's so utterly difficult to get past the state's problems; there are so many crosscurrents at work."

HEADLINE: To Albany Lobbyists, It's Only Good Times

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 18

 BODY:
There were more lobbyists than ever walking the halls of the State Capitol last year, and they earned a record amount of money for their attempts to influence state government.
A report issued today by the State Commission on Lobbying showed that 1,993 lobbyists were registered with the state in 1990, a 17 percent increase over 1989. They were paid a total of $29.3 million in fees and expense reimbursements, a 12 percent rise over the previous year. 
 Last year's growth contributed to a five-fold increase in state lobbying fees since 1978, according to the report. The largest increases have been seen in the last three years, when spending on lobbyists rose by 63 percent.
 
Four Firms Over $1 Million
 "This is probably one of the few recession-proof industries left," said Celia Viggo Wexler, legislative director of New York State Common Cause. "In good times and bad, people are willing to pay good money for lobbyists."
Four lobbying firms collected more than $1 million in 1990, twice as many as exceeded that mark in 1989. Leading the pack was the law firm of Bower & Gardner of Manhattan, which merged at the beginning of last year with one of Albany's most successful lobbying groups, Condello, Ryan & Piscitelli.
The firm's chief lobbyist is Kenneth Shapiro, a former chief counsel to both Assembly Speaker Mel Miller and Mr. Miller's predecessor, Stanley Fink. Mr. Fink is a partner in the law firm, but does not lobby in Albany, said Peter A. Piscitelli, one of the firm's most active lobbyists.
Bower & Gardner collected $1.6 million in lobbying fees and reimbursements last year. The other firms that passed the $1 million mark were Shea & Gold; Hinman, Straub, Pigors & Manning; and Davidoff & Malito, each with about $1.1 million.
A report issued last week by the New York City Clerk showed that Davidoff & Malito was paid an additional $1.6 million last year to lobby city officials, more than any other firm. One of the law firm's partners is Sid Davidoff, a friend, occasional adviser and regular tennis partner of Mayor David N. Dinkins. The report last week by the New York City Clerk showed that one of every three dollars in new lobbying money last year went to Mr. Davidoff's firm.
Among the largest state lobbying clients were members of the tobacco industry, which fended off legislation proposed last year by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to restrict the sale of cigarettes from vending machines and to prohibit the free distribution of cigarettes in promotional schemes. Philip Morris U.S.A. spent $566,223 on state lobbying last year, more than any other corporation or association. The Tobacco Institute spent an additional $250,258.The second-largest spender was the New York State Soft Drink Association, which paid $430,224 to lobbyists. That group was the loudest voice against another Cuomo initiative, which would have given the state the unclaimed nickel deposits on beer and soft-drink containers. The group also lobbied unsuccessfully against the enactment of a two-cent container tax on soda bottles and cans.
Several Albany lobbyists said the growth of their industry has resulted from a combination of factors, including the Federal Government's ceding of responsibilities to the states during the 1980's and the increasing sophistication of corporations and interest groups.
Morris H. Klein, the chairman of the commission, speculated that the state's budget woes also contributed to the increase in lobbying. With fewer state dollars available, more agencies and interest groups are seeking every advantage in maintaining their share, he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
U.S. Chain Is Said to Plan Tokyo Store

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 18

 BODY:
Japanese who love to emulate fashionable New Yorkers may get a chance to spend their yen just like Manhattan's shoppers: Bloomingdale's is coming to the Tokyo area, according to reports here today.
A Japanese Bloomingdale's is being planned for the Makuhari area in neighboring Chiba Prefecture, said a leading financial newspaper, Nihon Keizai Shimbun, whose report was confirmed today by a local official. The report added that the department store, the first in what could be a chain here, might open in 1994 or 1995. 
 The Governor of Chiba Prefecture announced that the Tokyu Department Store Company had won a competition to develop the site, which is next to a large convention center in the Tokyo suburb. Tokyu apparently hopes to complete a deal with Bloomingdale's, but those talks have yet to be concluded.
Tokyu officials refused to comment on the article. And in New York, Bloomingdale's chairman and chief executive, Marvin S. Traub, denied the report.
Tokyu "is one of a number of Japanese companies which, over the past several years, have expressed interest in developing some sort of relationship with Bloomingdale's," Mr. Traub said. "At present, we are not involved in any formal negotiations toward such an arrangement, nor do we expect to be involved in such negotiations in 1991."
 
Seeks Affluent Customers
 Tokyu, a second-tier retailer that has been struggling to upgrade its image among affluent Japanese consumers, is part of the Tokyu Group, a large railroad and real estate company, which sets up its department stores near its stations.
Tokyu and Bloomingdale's became acquainted when the financially troubled New York retailer, whose parent is in bankruptcy reorganization, was put on the auction block two years ago. A number of Japanese companies, including Tokyu, looked over Bloomingdale's, but all backed away, reportedly over concerns that the retailer looked like damaged merchandise because of the ills of the parent, Federated Department Stores.
Federated had been acquired by the Campeau Corporation in a transaction involving billions of dollars of "junk bond" debt. But as the economy slowed down and the junk bond market began to unravel, Bloomingdale's was put up for sale to try and alleviate the debt burden.
 
Japanese Investments
 Japanese retailers have been on something of a shopping spree themselves in recent years, snapping up foreign specialty stores and opening outlets in Japan in an effort to lure consumers enchanted by the international panache these stores carry here.
Mitsukoshi bought a share in Tiffany, the jewelry retailer, and has placed Tiffany's boutiques in most of its Japanese stores. Jusco acquired Talbot's and a share in Laura Ashley and has been putting up boutiques for the two here. Isetan has a venture with Barneys New York and has opened a Barneys outlet here. Last year, Tobu came in second in the bidding for Saks Fifth Avenue.
