HEADLINE: How Milwaukee Has Thrived While Leaving Blacks Behind

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, March 16

 BODY:
This proud workhorse of a city, with its well-swept streets and chic new office towers, has become a striking antithesis to the recession on the coasts. It has an unemployment rate well below the national average, a booming downtown, a generous budget surplus and more jobs than skilled people to fill them.
Milwaukee pulled itself out of a serious slump in the early 1980's and staved off the current recession by making its old manufacturing plants more efficient and expanding services like hotels and retailing.
 
A Secondary Effect
 But that strategy has had an unintended but equally profound secondary effect. It has devastated the city's poor black neighborhoods, whose residents thrived in the high-wage union jobs of the city's manufacturing heyday and are now adrift on a rising tide of unemployment, crime and despair. 
 With black joblessness five tmes the rate among whites, "Milwaukee is a classic case of how a restructured economy has diminished the employment opportunities for blacks and for black males in particular," said Dr. James H. Johnson Jr., director of the Center for the Study of Urban Poverty at the University of California at Los Angeles, who has studied poverty in Milwaukee. "The indicators of poverty and joblessness fall solidly in the black community."
The retooling of factories also hurt unskilled whites, of course. But the effect was less severe for several reasons. At factories that laid off only some workers, whites often had seniority and were retained. And even for whites who were laid off, the prosperity of the white parts of the city insured that new businesses would spring up there, offering jobs suitable for former assembly line workers. Such jobs have generally not appeared in black sections.
The result is a city of 628,000 people where black men stand idle on street corners just blocks from the breweries and factories that used to employ them, while well-dressed white-collar workers sell insurance or computers out of some of those same factories, now converted into office parks.
 
Murder Rate Soars, Too
 More than half of all black Milwaukeeans are on some form of public assistance. The city has one of the highest black unemployment rates in the country, 20.1 percent. And its homicide rate, fueled by a new and thriving drug trade, doubled in three years to a record 165 in 1990, from 78 in 1988.
Business leaders argue that Milwaukee's social problems are far from the nation's worst, but many acknowledge that the city's overall health makes the pockets of sickness more vivid.
"I dare say that our black community is not in any worse shape than blacks in Detroit or Cleveland or other cities," said Robert H. Milbourne, executive director of the Greater Milwaukee Committee, a group of business leaders. "But here the rest of the economy is doing so well, that it sticks out."
With its social problems thus amplified, Milwaukee offers a striking glimpse of how a shifting economy can create winners and losers along racial lines. "Historically, our cities have been the machines of mobility for low-income people," said Dr. Mark Hughes, an assistant professor of public affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton University. "Now those machines seem to be broken."
A University of Chicago study has listed Milwaukee, where blacks are nearly a third of the population, as one of five cities whose patterns of segregation were so clear that they were deemed "hypersegregated." Most white residents live on the south side of the city with its neat bungalows and frame houses, or along the lakefront with its mansions and luxury condominiums. Most blacks live on the north side in neighborhoods dominated by worn "two-flats," or duplexes. Chicago, Detroit, Cleveland and Newark were other cities cited as hypersegregated.
The prosperity of Milwaukee has done little for Anthony Hoskins, a 28-year-old black resident who had a hard time remembering his last full-time job. It was as an Army sergeant, he finally said, nearly two years ago.
 
Dozens of Job Rejections
 Since then, Mr. Hoskins has had part-time and temporary jobs as a security guard, a janitor, a factory worker and a construction worker. He has applied at businesses around the city -- Wendy's, Pick 'n' Save, K Mart, McDonald's, Wisconsin Bell, Harley-Davidson and dozens of others. Usually, he said, he does not hear from them again. And if he does, he is told that he does not have the skills they are looking for.
"I'm in an endless cycle," Mr. Hoskins said. "How am I going to get qualifications if I never get a chance? You got 16-, 17-year-old white kids working and here I am a grown man, an Army veteran, and I can't get a damn job. I've even said, 'Give me a probationary period. I'll work for half the pay. Just give me a chance.' "
White residents see the city, whose Gothic towers and church spires could as easily be in Munich, through a different prism. "It's a clean and beautiful city," said Mary McGrath, who is white, lives on the lakefront and teaches at a private school. "I know there are a lot of racial problems. It's very entrenched. People tend to stay in their own enclaves. It's more fear than anything else. It makes me sick to think about it."
The economic changes have left a widening gulf between disgruntled blacks and perplexed whites, some officials say, and have even touched off a revival of the Black Panthers, with members threatening violence if the situation does not improve.
"Black people see one thing, whites see another," said Annette Polly Williams, a Democratic state representative, who is black. "We are not included in this new prosperity. The struggle is, how do we fit into the new order?"
 
Steps to Fight Poverty
 The question confounds city and state officials who have put into motion a variety of initiatives to fight poverty and welfare dependency.
Last year the state permitted some poor parents to enroll their children in private schools at state expense. Last month Gov. Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, proposed that welfare checks for teen-age mothers be cut unless the women got married. And next September, two new schools, known as African American Immersion Schools, will begin focusing on the needs of black boys.
"The economic problems are severe, and we're trying to deal with them," said Mayor John O. Norquist. "We do have problems, but it is not like walking into the South Bronx."
Mr. Norquist has tried to lend racial balance to city government by hiring more minority members as department heads than any previous administration. But his critics say that such moves have little effect on the average out-of-work black resident and that a resentment appears to be welling up.
That anger has found a voice in Michael McGee, a black alderman who started the Black Panther Militia last year and vowed to take violent action if his demands were not met by 1995.
He says that his group has a membership of 600 and that its activities so far have been limited to unarmed neighborhood patrols. But Mr. McGee has not backed away from his threats of violence.
"There's something brewing in Milwaukee and it ain't beer," Mr. McGee said. "Things are not booming in the black community. The only new construction is churches, and the No. 1 employer is drugs."
 
Opportunity Used to Abound
 The diagnosis was not always so bleak in the black neighborhoods. They were once vibrant communities that attracted thousands of immigrants from the South from the 1940's to the 1970's to work in factories and foundries. One in three jobs was in manufacturing; people with high school diplomas could buy a house and live well.
"I remember when you could quit one job one day and go out the next day and get a better job making more money," said Lawrence Hunter, a 48-year-old machinery operator who is black and unemployed. "You could go to a foundry and get a job any day. It was hard-bull work, but if push came to shove there was a job for you."
Then came the recession of the early 1980's. Debt-laden factories laid off workers or closed. Even Schlitz, "the beer that made Milwaukee famous," shut its brewery. From 1979 to 1983, Milwaukee lost 60,000, or more than a fourth, of its manufacturing jobs.
"We fell farther and faster than a lot of other cities," said Timothy Sheehy, executive vice president of the Metropolitan Milwaukee Association of Commerce. "We took a tremendous kick in the teeth."
In the decade since that recession, Milwaukee has reinvented its economy. It has recast an outdated manufacturing sector and bolstered it with tens of thousands of service jobs.
Moreover, the nature of the current recession may have actually helped the city. The slump 10 years ago was marked by high interest rates, which were perilous for debt-dependent manufacturing concerns, and a strong dollar, which effectively shut off export markets. Now the reverse is true, making it easier for manufacturers to borrow money and sell overseas.
 
City Rarity: A Fiscal Cushion
 Milwaukee is in its 88th straight month of job growth, state figures say, and in the last five years has had job growth second only to San Diego's, another study found. It ended the last fiscal year with a surplus of $58 million, or 15 percent of its expenditures.
But the city has been able to restore only 9,000 of the 60,000 lost manufacturing jobs, and manufacturing now accounts for less than one in four jobs. About 100 manufacturing jobs will be created in the coming months when Steeltech Manufacturing, a new minority-owned steel fabrication concern backed by several Milwaukee businesses, gets off the ground.
"The rain barrel gets full with drops like that," Mr. Sheehy said.
But people like Mr. McGee say it will take a lot more raindrops to bring blacks to a par with whites. On a recent drive downtown, he surveyed the restaurants that look like castles, and the skyscrapers with glass and marble atriums, then paused just as Old World Third Street, a major downtown avenue, turned into Martin Luther King Jr. Drive, with its boarded storefronts and abandoned lots.
"Look out there," he said, pointing to the condominiums on the Milwaukee River and the skyline beyond. "Don't it look beautiful? The other world is living good. Go a few blocks and it changes before your eyes."

HEADLINE: BUSH SEEKS TO TAP FEDERAL RESERVE TO AID BANK FUND

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
Seeking to keep the Federal deposit insurance program afloat, the Bush Administration will propose that bank regulators be able to increase the amount they can borrow by $25 billion, Administration officials said today.
Under the proposal, which will be sent to Congress this week, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation would be given the authority to borrow $25 billion from the Federal Reserve, on top of the $5 billion it can now borrow from the Treasury. Any money borrowed, along with interest, would be repaid through increased bank contributions to the bank insurance fund. 
 Administration officials said they decided to take this approach instead of relying on the Treasury for further lending to avoid even the appearance of using taxpayer funds.
 
Help for Solvent Institutions
 The increased borrowing authority would be used to rescue the depositors at insolvent banks as well as to give additional help to ailing but solvent institutions under a current program known as "open assistance."
In recent weeks, regulators and the Administration have been considering ways to enlarge the program, particularly in New England, which has been hit hard by the recession. But critics have said that providing cash to solvent banks props up unhealthy institutions and that increasing the program provides opportunities for political manipulation.
The Administration's proposal is largely an endorsement of a similiar one made three weeks ago by L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and head of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout of the savings and loan industry.
The precarious financial condition of the bank insurance fund and the growing crisis in the nation's banking industry have raised concerns about a replay of the bailout of the savings and loan fund, which is expected to cost taxpayers hundreds of billions of dollars. The rising rate of large bank failures has left the bank fund at its lowest level since it was created in 1934 during the Great Depression.
The fund currently has $8.4 billion, or about 43 cents per $100 in deposits, and it is estimated that it will decline to 19 cents by the end of the year. Federal law has set $1.25 per $100 as the goal that should be sought by regulators.
It is too early to determine whether Congress will ultimately support the Treasury's plan, although the Congressional Budget Office has already recommended increasing the borrowing authority of the F.D.I.C. by another $5 billion, to $10 billion.
 
Optimism on Prospects
 But Mr. Seidman appeared optimistic today about the Administration plan's prospects. "My guess is that the reception on Capitol Hill will be pretty good, because it meets our needs and their needs," Mr. Seidman said in an interview. "Their No. 1 interest is that the taxpayer not get stuck with the bill. This meets that interest."
The Treasury Department's endorsement of Mr. Seidman's plan came in a letter today to him from Treasury Under Secretary Robert R. Glauber.
The original proposal by Mr. Seidman, who has enjoyed an alternately warm and cold relationship with the White House, did not detail where the borrowed money should come from.
When Mr. Seidman announced his plan, Treasury officials declined to comment. In early January, the Treasury disclosed a plan to overhaul the banking industry that included a measure to take away much of the F.D.I.C.'s authority, and that was seen by lawmakers and many in the industry as a slap at Mr. Seidman.
But the Administration has denied that it was aimed specifically at him, and more recently Treasury officials have backpedaled and said the attempt to entirely strip the F.D.I.C. of much of its authority had been "a mistake."
Unlike the bailout of the savings and loan industry, in which Congress set up a corporation that raises money by selling bonds in the marketplace and uses taxpayer funds to pay the interest, the replenishing of the bank insurance fund through Federal Reserve borrowings should be considerably less expensive because it will enable regulators to obtain lower interest rates.
The rates of interest charged for the loans and any other conditions, such as the type of collateral that would need to be posted by banks requesting open assistance, would be set by the Federal Reserve.
 
Equal to Treasury Rate
 Administration officials said the interest rate would be equal to the Treasury rate paid for borrowings of comparable maturity, which is lower than what the Government would be able to obtain from investors.
The Administration also said the premiums banks pay to the deposit insurance fund would be increased for every $1 billion drawn by the F.D.I.C. from the Federal Reserve.
As part of the proposal, the Administration will recommend that Congress cap the premiums paid by banks to the insurance fund at 30 cents per $100 in deposits. Last fall, Congress, at the urging of Treasury officials, had lifted all restrictions on premium increases.
After raising premiums from 12 cents to 19.5 cents in January, the F.D.I.C. has said it will increase premiums this summer to 23 cents per $100 in deposits, a 92 percent jump from last year. The increase will help to finance $10 billion in loans to keep the bank insurance fund from becoming insolvent by the end of this year, as some economists have predicted.
Mr. Seidman, whose term as chairman of the F.D.I.C. and of the Resolution Trust Corporation expires in the fall, estimated today that the F.D.I.C. would need to borrow only that $10 billion this year.
 
Premium Rise Would Be Needed
 Mr. Seidman has said previously that borrowing an $15 billion beyond that would require a premium increase of 5.25 cents per $100 in deposits.
In addition to its existing line of credit with the Treasury, the F.D.I.C. has the authority to borrow based on a formula pegged to its net worth. Its present net worth enables it to borrow about $65 billion, but that amount will dwindle as the insurance fund continues to pay out more than the contributions it receives from the industry.
The F.D.I.C. already has the authority to provide open assistance to banks by lending them funds, but in the last two years it has only exercised that authority twice, with two small institutions. Last September it provided $2.5 million to the Pawnee National Bank of Pawnee, Okla.; in 1989 it lent $2.3 million to the Metropolitan National Bank of San Antonio.
 
Viewed as Taxpayer Bailout
 On the outlook for Congressional passage of the Treasury's plan, the chairman of the House Banking Committee, Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, Democrat of Texas, has expressed concerns about borrowing from any source. Any borrowing would be ultimately guaranteed by the Government and he views these guarantees as a form of a taxpayer bailout.
The chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., a Michigan Democrat, has not commented on Mr. Seidman's plan, saying only that he awaits the Administration's legislation.
"Congress is going to be extremely wary about doing anything that resembles a taxpayer bailout," a Congressional aide said. The strongest sign of the reluctance of Congress in the area came last week when the House voted by only a narrow margin to continue financing the savings and loan bailout.

HEADLINE: First-Time Buyers Aid Home Sales

BYLINE: By RICHARD D. HYLTON

 BODY:
Lower interest rates and a backlog of unsold low-priced homes are pushing first-time buyers back into the housing market again after many years.
Their buying is adding to the small spurt in real estate activity that was detected first in the sluggish Northeast late in January and that has now spread across the country. The influx of first-time buyers is also making it possible for some homeowners to sell and move up to bigger homes. 
 "We are seeing a resurgence of the first-time buyers in the market," said Pall Spera, head of Pall Spera Realtors in Stowe, Vt., whose comments were echoed by brokers from Los Angeles to Miami.
 
A Deal After a Year and a Half
 Typical of the first-time buyers are Ketty and Jean Felix Day, who recently bought a three-bedroom, two-bath house in north Miami for $75,000. The couple, who got a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage at 9 percent, had been looking for about a year and a half.
The Days, who together earn about $43,000, said the key to their purchase was monthly mortgage payments of no more than $800. Six months ago, they said, the house would have cost at least $80,000, and interest rates were higher. As both came down, so did the mortgage cost; their monthly payment is $728.
"We were just looking last year, but the interest rates were very high, and I knew that the interest rates would go lower," said Mrs. Day, a 32-year-old editorial assistant for an airline magazine.
 
Word of Real Estate Agents
 While there are no specific measures of activity by first-time home buyers like the Days, real estate agents say such buyers have been out in force. Moreover, home sales have been strongest at the lower end of the market, typically the province of the new buyers.
First-time buyers have been among those most hurt by high housing prices because they have been unable to save enough money for a down payment.
High interest rates compounded their problems, because even if they could raise the down payment, they often were unable to make the monthly mortgage payments.
This picture has changed sharply in recent months. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation this month pronounced the current housing market the most affordable since 1977. The agency looks at affordability in terms of average family income, housing prices and mortgage rates.
 
Single-Digit Rates Help
 Fixed-rate mortgages are now being offered at about 9 3/8 percent, while adjustable-rate mortgages are available at about 7 3/8 percent. Adjustable-rate mortgages are reset -- usually annually -- depending on other interest rates.
"I think the psychology of single-digit rates has very, very positive connotations," said Dick Ritchey, regional director and owner of Century 21's south Florida office in Miami.
The Mortgage Guaranty Insurance Corporation, one of the nation's leading private mortgage insurance companies, is also reporting that houses are now more affordable for first-time buyers than they have been in several years. And by paying a premium of several thousand dollars for mortgage insurance, buyers can often secure a home with a small down payment.
The apparent uptick in activity is too recent to have shown up in national figures on home sales, which still appeared to be falling in January. According to preliminary figures from the National Association of Realtors, owners sold 2.91 million houses in January, down from 3.13 million in December and the 3.47 million sold in January 1990.
Statistics on newly built houses, which usually trail the sale of older homes especially when the economy is coming out of a slump, also showed a decline. In January 408,000 new homes were sold, down 12 percent from 465,000 in December, and down 35 percent from 627,000 in January 1990.
 
Signs of Recovery
 But Leland C. Brendsel, the chairman of the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, said last week that he thought the recession in the housing market had bottomed out and that it should show clear signs of recovery by midyear.
Another encouraging sign for the housing industry is the increased traffic at new subdivision sites. Many subdivisions consist of lower-priced homes aimed at new buyers. According to a monthly survey by the National Association of Homebuilders, 42 percent of the 300 builders surveyed reported that traffic was in the high to average range in February, up from 24 percent in January. Both months are generally the worst time of the year for home sales.
PHH Homequity Inc., a Wilton, Conn., firm that handles relocation of employees for corporate clients, is also seeing improvement in some housing markets, including Fairfield County, Conn.; northern New Jersey; Washington, D.C., and in San Francisco, Los Angeles and San Jose, Calif. It said its offers for homes are now being outbid by other potential buyers.
The relocation firm, which deals with homes in the upper-middle-income segment of the residential market, said it saw a 7 percent increase, seasonally adjusted, in its housing market indicator, which tracks the rate of sold and unsold inventory and the rate at which sellers accept first bids. It maintains a data base of 10,000 houses across the country.
 
'A Significant Improvement'
 "Although a month does not a trend make, in January we saw a significant improvement after seeing a decline for the previous six months," said Stephen Fragapane, president of PHH.
While Mr. Fragapane and others are encouraged, they caution that the revival is a far cry from a fully recovered market. The January figures underlined how weak the market has been, with existing homes selling at their lowest rate in seven years and sales of new homes at their lowest in nearly nine years.
Nevertheless, the real estate industry is optimistic that the recent surge signals the start of a turnaround.
The median sales prices of existing homes in most regions of the nation are down significantly from their 1989 highs. In the Northeast, for example, which still has the highest median sales prices of any section of the country, the median is now $141,200, down from $148,800 in 1989, according to the National Association of Realtors.
People shopping for houses are also finding themselves in heated competitive bidding situations.
 
Midwest a Different Story
 "A couple of our managers are talking about multiple offers again, and our inventory is decreasing," said Gail Carriero, a marketing representative in the San Francisco office of the Coldwell Banker Residential Group.
Similar reports are coming from brokers in the Los Angeles area, Dallas, Phoenix and in southern Florida, as well as in Boston, Vermont and elsewhere in upper New England.
The Midwest is a different story. The drop in prices and consumer demand did not hit that region as hard last year as it did other sections of the country, and now brokers say they have not seen a sharp increase in sales since January. In Ohio, Michigan, Wisconsin, Illinois and Indiana, brokers did not see the precipitous fall in sales and consumer demand last year that buffeted their colleagues in other regions. They have been experiencing a slow decline in sales and demand but that has not been interrupted by a sharp rise in the last few weeks.
"I don't think there's been an increase," said Steven Pew, head of Max Brooch Realtors in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., and regional vice president of the National Association of Realtors. "There has been a slight downturn over the past few months, but it has been in the single digits," said Mr. Pew, who said the situation might worsen quickly if car sales did not improve soon.
 
Improvement in California
 In California, where the weakening of the housing market was not as severe as on the East Coast, brokers from San Diego to San Francisco are reporting improved activity at the lower end of the market.
Brad and Kifa Nantz, a young professional couple in the San Francisco Bay area, are among those who did not think they would soon see the confluence of low prices and low rates again. Although they had been looking for more than a year, the couple stepped up their search in January and put their condominium on the market. A few weeks ago they sold their one-bedroom condo for $193,500 (they bought it in 1989 for $157,000) and bought a three-bedroom, three-bath house on a golf course in San Ramone, Calif., for $310,000. In San Ramone, such prices put the young couple at the lower-middle end of the market.
The Nantzes got a 30-year mortgage that is fixed at 8 7/8 percent for the first three years and then becomes adjustable.
"We had our open house the day the war started," said the 29-year-old Mr. Nantz, who said that at first he and his wife thought the timing was a disaster. But their condo sold within weeks. The Nantzes got a mortgage for $191,000 on their new house.
"We felt that this was a good time and the rates had a lot to do with it," Mrs. Nantz said.

HEADLINE: In Messages, Officers Banter After Beating in Los Angeles

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 18

 BODY:
Police officers who had just beaten a black motorist were relaxed and even jocular in their communications with each other and with a desk officer, according to transcripts released by the police today.
In addition to lighthearted banter in the transcripts of computer communications among squad cars, an audio tape of police communications at the scene ends with a call for an ambulance followed by the sound of laughter. 
 Comdr. Rick Dinse, who is heading the investigation of the incident for the Police Department, said the tape indicated that the officers at the scene knew the motorist's injuries were serious and that "there was some levity over it."
In the transcripts of communications among the squad cars moments after the beating of Rodney G. King on March 3, a supervising officer at the scene, identified by a police spokesman as Sgt. Stacey C. Koon, typed out, "You just had a big-time use of force."
The reply from the police communications desk was: "Oh well. I'm sure the lizard didn't deserve it. Ha, ha. I'll let them know, O.K."
Then Sergeant Koon sent a message asking for a fresh supply of darts for the Taser stun gun that was fired at Mr. King at the time of the beating.
The comments from the sergeant and other officers seem to show them treating the beating as an ordinary incident, lending support to critics who say it is not unusual for Los Angeles police officers to use force with little provocation.
At 1:12 A.M., about 15 minutes after the beating ended, the transcripts show that a patrol officer sent the message, "Oops." The Police Department spokesman, Fred Nixon, said the two officers in the car sending this transmission were Laurence M. Powell and Timothy E. Wind.
In another squad car, an officer who was apparently not at the scene responded, "Oops what?" The dialogue went on:
FIRST CAR. I haven't beaten anyone this bad in a long time.
SECOND CAR. Oh not again. Why for you do that? Thought you agreed to chill out for a while. What did he do?
FIRST CAR. I think he was dusted. Many broken bones later. After the pursuit.
The use of the word "dusted" appears to refer to the officer's suspicion that Mr. King had been taking the drug phencyclidine, commonly known as PCP or angel dust. Tests later found no trace of drugs in his system.
Sergeant Koon and Officers Powell and Wind, along with Officer Theodore J. Briseno, were indicted last week on charges of assault with a deadly weapon and are scheduled to enter their pleas this Friday.
The officers were using miniature computers fitted into their squad cars to communicate among themselves and a supervisor at the station. A police spokesman said the computers were used to supplement the heavily used voice communications system.
All police radio communications are routinely tape-recorded and preserved for some time.
The Police Department released the transcripts today at the request of Mayor Tom Bradley, through his appointed Police Commission, which oversees the department.
Earlier today, Chief Daryl F. Gates expressed his own thoughts about the victim, Mr. King, saying he hoped he would make use of the experience to embark on a better life.
Surrounded by yellow ribbons hung on his behalf at police headquarters, Chief Gates told a hundreds of cheering police officers and department employees that he would not heed widespread calls for his resignation.
 
'We Regret What Took Place'
 In response to a question, he said Mr. King and his family deserved an apology for the beating. "We regret what took place," the Chief went on. "I hope he gets his life straightened out. Perhaps this will be the vehicle to move him down the road to a good life instead of the life he's been involved in for such a long time."
Mr. King, 25 years old, was unemployed and on parole at the time of the beating. He had just completed six months in prison on a sentence for an armed robbery conviction. He had previously been convicted of trying to hire a prostitute,
Mr. King was not charged in the incident, in which the police said he was stopped for speeding.
He is in a hospital recovering from surgery to repair a shattered eye socket. His doctors say he suffered multiple skull fractures, a broken leg, injuries to both knees, a concussion, nerve damage and possible brain damage.
 
Emotional Support
 In recent days calls for the Chief's resignation have come from community leaders here and from the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., Democrat of Delaware.
The Chief has many supporters in the police force and the community, and the reception for him this morning was loud and emotional.
"I will be here," he told reporters at his office this morning. "I will stay here and I will fight any attempt to get rid of me. I will fight it with all the effort I have."
Chief Gates, 64, has headed the Los Angeles Police Department for 13 years. As a civil service appointee, he can be removed only for cause after a proceeding of the five-member Police Commission.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Chief Daryl F. Gates of the Los Angeles police yesterday as he was greeted at work by supporters asking him to stay on the job. (Associated Press) (pg. A18)

The Economy
Seeking to keep Federal deposit insurance afloat, the Administration will propose that bank regulators be able to increase the amount they can borrow by $25 billion. Under the proposal, which will be sent to Congress this week, the F.D.I.C. would be given the authority to borrow $25 billion from the Fed, on top of the $5 billion it can now borrow from the Treasury. [Page A1.]
Many first-time buyers are able to enter the housing market, thanks to lower interest rates and a backlog of unsold low-priced homes. Their buying is adding to the small spurt in real estate activity that was detected first in the sluggish Northeast. [D1.]

HEADLINE: French TV Seeks a Slice of the Hollywood Pie

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, March 17

 BODY:
The idea is quite simple: If American movies are invariably the biggest box-office hits in France, if 40 percent of movies shown on French television are American, why not invest directly in Hollywood productions? Two new production companies with ties to French television channels have decided to do just that.
"It's a bit like renting lots of apartments in a building," explained Rene Bonnell, who runs Studio Canal-Plus, a new production company with $220 million in capital and ambitions to match. "You pay so much rent that you might as well become a co-proprietor." 
 Certainly for the pay-television channel, Canal-Plus , which controls Studio Canal-Plus, the logic of owning a piece of the movie industry is apparent. Last year, it paid some $130 million for the right to show about 160 American films to its 2.8 million subscribers in France.
A similar logic appears to be behind the other new production company, Ciby 2000. It is owned by the construction magnate Francis Bouygues, who is also the largest shareholder of TF-1, France's most widely viewed television channel.
"The great problem of television is to have images," Mr. Bouygues told the French magazine Le Moniteur, last year. "Yet the basis for interesting images is not television films but cinema. Production is an activity that will grow. That's why I have created Ciby 2000."
 
The First Projects
 The two companies, though, are not limiting themselves to infiltrating Hollywood with their money. Both plan to finance French films, to seek out new European directors and to participate in the growing number of multinational productions, which accounted for 65 of the 146 films made here last year.
They have also completed their first projects. Studio Canal-Plus has co-financed Maurice Pialat's "Van Gogh," which will be released here this spring, while Ciby 2000 was the main investor in Jean-Loup Hubert's "Reine Blanche" ("The White Queen"), starring Catherine Denueve, which will be released this summer.
Unsurprisingly, their arrival has already made a big impact on the French movie industry, which has long depended on the Government to provide seed money. After only a few months, Studio Canal-Plus and Ciby 2000 have emerged as major players, at least in France.
But in many ways, the two companies are very different. Canal-Plus, which is principally a movie channel, has been so successful that it has now invested in similar pay-television channels in Belgium, Spain and Germany. Showing 400 different films in France alone last year, its revenues exceeded $1.1 billion.
Bolstered by these revenues, it has held onto 60 percent of Studio Canal-Plus, with 25 percent owned by the powerful Havas communications group, 10 percent by Societe Generale and 5 percent by the Banque Nationale de Paris. There are plans to increase its capital to $300 million this year.
 
The American Contacts
 Studio Canal-Plus has also benefited from Mr. Bonnell's long experience as Canal-Plus's main purchaser of foreign movies, and it has moved quickly to sign co-production accords with major American studios.
It has agreed with Mel Brooks Productions to co-produce two films a year for the next three years. It has signed with Warner Brothers to make 20 films in the next five years with Arnon Milchan as producer, including Oliver Stone's "J. F. K." Last year it bought 5 percent of Carolco Productions and it will soon co-finance Robert Redford's "Dark Wind."
In France, too, Studio Canal-Plus is active, participating in six new movies, including one by Roman Polanski that is to begin shooting in June this year. Mr. Bonnell soon hopes to co-produce films directed by Jean-Luc Godard, Bertrand Tavernier and Jacques Doillon.
"It's true that making films in English facilitates their export," Mr. Bonnell said, "but you can do well with smaller budget films in other languages if they have quality, such as Jean-Paul Rappeneau's 'Cyrano de Bergerac." It's also important to make films not spoken in English because that's how you find new directors."
For Studio Canal-Plus, there is another good reason to finance French films. Unable to force Americans to watch French movies, the Government requires that French films account for 50 percent of all cinema shown on television here. Ten percent may be other European films, and American movies are limited to 40 percent.
 
A Different Style
 In contrast, Mr. Bouygues's relationship with cinema appears to be more personal. According to those who know the 68-year-old multimillionaire, he set up Ciby 2000 as a way to keep busy during his retirement after he handed over the reins of his vast construction group to his son, Martin, last year.
So far, Mr. Bouygues, who owns 100 percent of Ciby 2000, and his manager, the French film director Jean-Claude Fleury, have refused to speak publicly about their activities, reportedly because they plan to unveil the new company with much fanfare at the Cannes International Film festival in May.
But Mr. Bouygues's approach is said to involve agreements with big-name directors and film stars rather than with American studios. According to people in the industry, he has already signed multi-movie deals with the director David Lynch and the French actress Isabelle Adjani. He is also reportedly negotiating with the directors Bernardo Bertolucci, Francis Ford Coppola and Pedro Almodovar.
How much Mr. Bouygues is willing to spend remains a mystery, but what one French film expert described as Mr. Bouygues's checkbook strategy is causing concern inside France's Culture Ministry, where officials fear it could cause an inflationary competition for talent that might hurt the entire industry.
One Culture Ministry official said the Government welcomed new participation in an industry "where money is never enough." But echoing the ministry's constant battle to limit the influence of American movies here, he added: "We want them to put good money into the French and European cinema and not just into Hollywood."

HEADLINE: Gains Seen in Study of African Sleeping Sickness Parasite

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
A MONG the many parasites that infect and kill human beings, perhaps none is so bizarre as the wormlike creature that causes African sleeping sickness.
The organism, Trypanosoma brucei, is able to change its outer coat into as many as a thousand different shapes, thereby constantly eluding the immune system. And several features of its genetic makeup are unlike anything else yet observed. 
 In fact, so peculiar is the parasite that until the last year or so, researchers barely knew how it reproduced, let alone how any part of that life cycle might be blocked.
Now scientists have at last learned how to manipulate and replace the genes of the protozoan, raising hopes that they will soon identify the switching mechanism that controls its ability to change from one slippery cloak to another. The new genetic machinations may also allow researchers to grow a harmless strain of the parasite that could be used in a vaccine.
"It's enormously valuable to be able to go for the genes," said Dr. Larry Simpson, a molecular biologist at the University of California at Los Angeles, who has long studied the trypanosome. "It blows the field wide open."
In a report in the current issue of The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, scientists from the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine in Baltimore announced that they had prodded trypanosomes in the laboratory to exchange their native copy of an important gene for a mutant copy of the gene that had been designed through genetic engineering techniques. The work demonstrated that 100 percent of the time scientists can replace the parasite's own gene with a doctored version that destroys at least part of the trypanosome's ability to thrive.
In the new work, the scientists interfered with the gene that allows parasites to absorb calcium, a critical biochemical step in maturation.
Other researchers have recently reported similar advances in Nature and other journals. "These things have outsmarted people for years," said Dr. Josiane Eid, an author of the new report. "But with the ability to manipulate the genes at our discretion, we now we have a chance to find the enzyme that's important for the whole process of varying the surface coat."
Sleeping sickness, which is transmitted through the bite of the tse-tse fly, causes significant medical and economic misery in central Africa. It infects about 10,000 people a year, and nearly all of them die within months. It also kills tens of thousands of cattle as the animals are driven from one grazing area to another.
Trypanosome lives and reproduces in the bloodstream and central nervous system, eventually using up most of the body's glucose. It seems nearly invincible. Each time the immune system manages to make antibodies to attack one type of outer protein coat on the protozoan, it adopts another coat style from its enormous repertoire.
"If you look at a smear of blood from an infected person, it's a horrifying thing," said Dr. Barbara Sollner-Webb, another author of the report. "You can see the normal red blood cells, which look like Cheerios, and then you see at least as many of these wiggly trypanosomes, which are pointed at one end and have flagella on the other."
Scientists have recently discovered some real genetic oddities about the trypanosome. In most creatures, different proteins of the body are made from neighboring building blocks on the DNA molecule. But in trypanosome, a single protein can be stitched together from pieces of biochemical material found on widely dispersed parts of the DNA. That talent seems to give the creature extraordinary genetic flexibility.

HEADLINE: Treated Mosquito Nets May Offer Best Hope Against Malaria

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "Outwitted by Malaria, Desperate Doctors Seek New Remedies" (Science Times, Feb. 12): The world public health community is greatly concerned with the spread of this deadly disease and with the difficulty in providing effective treatment in endemic areas at a cost that can be borne locally. The new drugs you mention cost far more than chloroquine and cannot be distributed through the primary health care network. Thus they cannot be considered part of the armamentarium to attack this disease in most endemic areas.
An important approach that you do not mention is being tested by research workers from the United States and other countries. This is to develop a community-based intervention to attack the anopheline mosquito, the main source of infection. The method is based on new, safe pyrethroid insecticides, which can be used to treat nylon mosquito nets. The nets then become effective in killing and repelling mosquitoes. 
 Research in Africa and other parts of the world over the last eight years suggests the method will be effective and inexpensive. The nets, obtainable for $3 to $4 each, provide protection as well as killing the mosquitoes. The cost of insecticide is about 50 cents for a treatment that will last about six months.
The research involved is arduous and expensive. However, the Africa Bureau of the Agency for International Development recently provided support for a project developed by workers at the Johns Hopkins University and the Muhimbili Medical Center in Dar es Salaam to conduct a large, community-based intervention using these nets in Tanzania. The project involves social science studies to see how the local people view the problem of malaria and to educate them in the use of the mosquito nets. Approximately 20,000 nets will be distributed at subsidized cost, and the effect on the local mosquitoes and the incidence of malaria in those who use the nets will be evaluated.
There is a need to encourage entomologists and field malariologists in this low-tech approach. Where the laboratory-based sciences have run into serious problems, the field malaria worker may once more come to the forefront.
 
CLIVE J. SHIFF
Baltimore, Feb. 26, 1991
 
The writer is an assistant professor of immunology and infectious diseases at the Johns Hopkins School of Public Health.

HEADLINE: Fax Displacing Manhattan Bike Couriers

BYLINE: By ROBERT E. TOMASSON

 BODY:
They whooshed through the streets of Manhattan, members of a mobile cottage industry born of the incompatibility of big-city gridlock and the need to get important papers from one office to another right away. They were bicycle messengers, fearless and feared as they raced through red lights, around vehicles and sometimes into pedestrians.
But now the messengers have largely disappeared, victims of a speedier service they cannot match -- the facsimile machine -- and a business requirement they cannot meet -- insurance. 
 The consensus of authorities and some of the surviving services is that the ranks have thinned significantly from the mid-80's, when there were thousands of messengers working for about 200 services with whiz-bang names like Atomic, Fireball, Bullet and Zoom.
"We still get them in for flat tires, but their numbers have fallen sharply in recent years," said David Vandervere, sales manager for Bicycle Renaissance on Amsterdam Avenue near 84th Street, which has been in business for 20 years.
The nature of the messengers' work has never lent itself to a precise census. Most of the services, which came and went almost as fast as the bikers rode, did not even bother to list themselves in the telephone book.
Official documentation is even scarcer. For years, the services existed without licenses or monitoring by city agencies; most paid their workers in cash, operating outside the paper trails of tax laws, unemployment benefits and Social Security. When the state and the Federal Government did begin to focus on the services and their insurance problems, it was the beginning of the end.
What records do exist come from the police and traffic officers.
"It's hard to document, but there's no doubt that the public doesn't perceive them as the physical menace that they did years ago," said Police Capt. Richard P. Morrison, commander of the Manhattan Traffic Division.
 
Statistics Tell a Story
 From 1981 to 1985, accidents involving bicycles rose 77 percent in the city and then began to decrease steadily, said Gerard Soffian, assistant commissioner of traffic planning in the city's Department of Transportation.
In 1987, 25,982 traffic tickets were issued to cyclists, most of them messengers; 4,246 accidents were reported between bicycles and cars, and 510 pedestrians were hit by bicycles.
By 1989, traffic tickets had declined to 19,533, bicycle-car accidents to 3,544 and pedestrians hit by bicycles to 327.
The cyclists paid a price for their daring: from 1981 through 1986, an average of two a year died in accidents, and countless others were injured.
One of those statistics is Robert T. Dolan, then a freshman at New York University, who described himself as a very experienced cyclist, well able to operate in Manhattan traffic. He lasted three weeks as a messenger in the summer of 1988. Riding on Lexington Avenue at 38th Street, he swerved to avoid another cyclist, was brushed by a car and fell, breaking his left wrist.
"That was enough for me," he said.
 
Mayoral Intervention Blocked
 To calm public concerns, Mayor Edward I. Koch's administration proposed banning cyclists on weekdays from three of their favorite north-south speedways: Fifth, Park and Madison Avenues. That created an outcry by, among others, environmentalists who supported bicyling as a way to reduce air pollution.
Then a State Supreme Court justice ruled that the city was all wrong in the way it planned to impose the ban, so in April 1988 the measure died quietly, as did a proposal to create a special administrative court to deal with two-wheeled violators.
But what the city could not do, technology did. The standard "I'll send it over right away by messenger" rapidly changed to "What's your fax number?"
Sales of facsimile machines have risen sharply, from 145,000 nationwide in 1985 to an estimated total of 1.6 million last year, according to a study by Datapro Research Group, a research concern.
Still, not everyone has a fax number, and some messages are too bulky to be transmitted through telephone cables.
James Boyle, a senior vice president for administration for Ogilvy & Mather Public Relations, said, "We still do quite a business with the messenger services." But in sending something from here to there, Mr. Boyle said he was not sure how it actually made the trip.
 
Adapting to Change
 Most messengers go by subway, others by foot or by car and some still by bicycle, said Michael D. Jabick, president of the Barjac Courier Service, which counts Ogilvy & Mather among its clients. "It depends on who's available," he said. "Sometimes a customer thinks a bike messenger is faster. Others think they're more irresponsible."
Mr. Jabick is a new messenger entrepreneur, in the business three years -- "I came in when the fax was already here." He has, he said, doubled his business in each of those years as, in tempo with other parts of corporate America, he and his partner, Barrett Wolf, absorb smaller companies. His new company name will soon be the Barjac/ Royal Courier Service with 53 messengers, 10 of whom use bicycles.
Life in the big city became intolerable for many of the small courier services about four years ago when New York State and the Federal Government decided that the services and the bikers had the traditional employee-employer relationship. The courier services had maintained that the messengers were independent contractors.
The distinction meant that the employers were subject, many of them retroactively, to all the expense and regulation of laws on workers' compensation, Social Security and unemployment benefits.
"It killed a lot of the smaller companies," said Mr. Jabick. As his company's gross income rose to $500,000 a year, he was able to absorb the more than $50,000 in yearly costs for insurance and the other programs, he said.
Carlos, who shrugged off a request for his last name, is one who is living the harrowing life of a cyclist, earning about $300 for a 40-hour week.
He has been in three accidents in the year he has been a messenger, he said, landing once in the hospital with a crushed shoulder. He has no insurance, he said as he locked his bike to scaffolding in front of the Grace Building on the Avenue of the Americas at 43d Street.
"I know of three who have been killed doing this," he said. "It's a tough life."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 22, 1991, Friday

 CORRECTION:
An article on Tuesday about bicycle messengers misstated the number of bicyclists who died in accidents in New York City in 1981 through 1986. The annual average was 16.
The article also misstated the origin of Barjac Couriers/Royal Delivery Systems Inc. It was formed by a merger of two companies.
The article also referred erroneously to Bullet Services. Neither the company nor its subsidiaries has used bicycle messengers.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Senator Blurs the Party Line

BYLINE: By WAYNE KING, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 18

 BODY:
In a city where political brand names are important identification, Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut might be labeled Brand X.
He votes Democratic, sounds Republican and puts a plague on both political houses. 
 "Democrats have continued to have this idea that what we have to do is throw money at problems and any help to the private sector is a giveaway to the rich," Mr. Lieberman observed during a chat in his office the other day. "Republicans, on the other hand, have given a message that they don't care much about meeting social needs."
And where does that leave Joe Lieberman?
He reflects only a moment. "I am an amalgam of various opinions," he said. "I'm conservative on foreign policy and the crime thing. If you insist, I reject all labels and say I'm independent." But he will, he says, accept "eclectic."
 
Ribicoff Is His Hero
 Politics is a continuing exercise in research and development for Mr. Lieberman, who is now in the middle of his first term as a Democratic senator, after serving for 10 years in the Connecticut Senate and later as the state's attorney general. His professed political hero is Abraham Ribicoff, the unabashed liberal governor and senator. Mr. Lieberman once wrote an admiring biography of John Bailey, the quintessential Connecticut Democrat who was state chairman for nearly three decades, from 1946 to 1975.
But when Mr. Lieberman defeated Lowell P. Weicker Jr., the incumbent Republican senator, by a hair-thin margin in 1988, he ran as a conservative. Since then, on the most visible issues, he has lined up with the Bush Administration, although a look at his overall record suggests that the tilt to the right is something of an optical illusion. Analyses by several groups have judged his voting record on the floor scarcely distinguishable from that of his Connecticut colleague, Christopher J. Dodd, who is nothing if not a loyal Democrat.
But on several high-profile issues, Mr. Lieberman seems at odds with his party.
He was, for example, one of only 10 Democrats in the Senate who voted to authorize military action in the Persian Gulf, the others being seven Southerners and the two Nevada senators.
He also favors the death penalty and a moment of silence for those who want to pray in public schools. He supported the invasion of Grenada and the bombing of Libya and he voted for a cut in the capital-gains tax. He is willing to experiment with a voucher system to allow parents to choose what school their children will attend -- even if it is a parochial school.
And he sometimes sounds as if he had stumbled on a cache of Ronald Reagan's old speeches, sprinkling an interview with comments like these:
*"Basically, our message, the Democrats' message, has been, 'We are going to take your money you worked so damn hard to earn and we are going to give it to a lot of people who don't work.' "
*"Work should be rewarded. We understand that middle-class people are breaking their backs so they and their kids can live better and it is our responsibility to make that happen, and not just to keep taking from them."
*"I supported the war in the gulf because I have a whole set of feelings about being strong in foreign policy -- that, like it or not, we live in an imperfect world, so, like it or not, you've got to stand up and fight. If I can be simplistic about it: If good people stand by while bad things are being done, evil will triumph."
*"The Democratic Party, the national party, in the last couple of decades has come to be seen as a party that cares only about social policy and not about economic policy, that only cares about meeting social needs and not making the economy go. It has focused on how to divide the pie and not on the fact the pie is shrinking."
 
Changing Liberalism
 Mr. Lieberman stresses that when he says things like this, he is deliberately oversimplifying. But he is firm in his belief that the liberal orthodoxy that has been central to the Democratic agenda since the days of Franklin D. Roosevelt no longer applies.
"It's been almost 60 years since the New Deal began and a lot of it has run its course," he said. "It's not working, and that's natural. Very few ideas can remain vibrant and effective for a long time."
Then why be a Democrat?
That's easy, says Mr. Lieberman. It's the only humane thing to do.
"What has always distinguished the Democrats, and I hope will continue to distinguish them," he said, "is that they care about people's problems, and believe that government has an obligation to solve those problems. But what we have got to do is to redefine how that happens."
What all that means in practical terms is that Mr. Lieberman is not predictable. But he is less a maverick than some of his positions might indicate. The liberal Americans for Democratic Action, for example gives him a 75 percent rating in the current session, 10 points better than his colleague Mr. Dodd. The American Conservative Union, on the other hand, gave him a 32, a shade higher than Mr. Dodd's 22.
The Congressional Quarterly, moreover, found that Mr. Lieberman voted with the Democrats 87 percent of the time in 1990, only a bit under Mr. Dodd's 92 percent. A Dodd staff member notes that except for some high-profile issues like the gulf war, their voting records are similar. Thus Senator Lieberman said his working relationships within the party are good, although he admitted he "felt a bit lonely" on the gulf vote. "I was never put under any pressure," he said.
 
'A Real Up-and-Comer'
 "We're not talking about a conservative Republican in Democrats' clothing," said Norman J. Ornstein, a congressional analyst at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative policy study group. Mr. Ornstein rates Mr. Lieberman a standout among the Senate class of 1988, which also includes Charles Robb of Virginia and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska.
"The first time I met him, I said, 'This guy is a real up-and-comer,' and the more time I spent with him, the more I became convinced of it," Mr. Ornstein said.
Mr. Lieberman has been particularly active on environmental matters and wrote or helped write eight bills or substantial amendments that became law in the current Congress. He was a principal author of the Clean Air Act of 1990, and helped write the Pollution Prosecution Act of 1990 that quadrupled the number of Environmental Protection Agency investigators. He was also active in developing legislation promoting international trade, affordable housing and measures to increase and improve tax collections by the Internal Revenue Service.
Although they share a penchant for independent thinking, Mr. Lieberman is in many way the antithesis of the man he replaced in the Senate, Mr. Weicker, who is now governor of Connecticut.
Mr. Weicker is a towering, aggressive figure who was given to stentorian outbursts on the Senate floor and passionate, sometimes self-righteous, attacks on others, including fellow Republicans.
Mr. Lieberman, on the other hand, is a smallish, thoughtful-seeming sort who turns the issues over and over and seldom raises his voice, which is deep and resonant and seems at times to be coming from somewhere behind him as he speaks.
But once convinced of the rightness of his position, he is seldom swayed. Indeed, back home in Connecticut, where he is seen as measured and moderate, some were surprised at the intensity of his stand on the war in the Persian Gulf.
But he is a man of strong commitments. For example, as an Orthodox Jew, he declined to appear at the Democratic convention to accept his own nomination because it was held on the Sabbath.
One of the men Mr. Lieberman says he admires most, Mr. Ribicoff, calls the Senator "a man of very great ability who I would consider a good senator."
 
Appeal to Republicans
 Mr. Ribicoff skirted the question of whether he agreed with Mr. Lieberman's positions, but conceded that his own record in office was "generally liberal," while "on the cutting edge of liberal and conservative issues, you'd have to say he's conservative."
But Mr. Lieberman's positions "come from his philosphy and he is sincere," said Mr. Ribicoff, who is in private law practice in New York and lives in Connecticut. "I don't think there is any hypocrisy at all."
Is Mr. Lieberman the wave of the future for the Democratic Party in Connecticut?
"No," said Mr. Ribicoff. "He is the wave of the future of the Republican Party."
What he means by that, Mr. Ribicoff said, is that in a fundamentally middle-of-the-road state like Connecticut, a Democrat is very close to a sure winner if he appeals to conservative Republicans -- many of whom regard Mr. Weicker, the former Republican, with something akin to loathing.
"It's very difficult," Mr. Ribicoff said of such a balancing act. "But I think he is comfortable with it."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "I am an amalgam of various opinions," said Joseph I. Lieberman, a first-term Senator from Connecticut. (Paul Conklin)

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
New President At General Tire

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: AKRON, Ohio, March 19

 BODY:
General Tire Inc. said Monday that it had appointed a new president and chief executive.
It said Alan L. Ockene would replace Wilhelm Borgmann, who will return to Germany to work for General Tire's parent company, Continental A.G., 
 Mr. Ockene, who is 60 years old, joins the company from the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, where he served for the last six years as vice president of Goodyear's Latin American operations.
The change in top management at General Tire, which employs 1,100 people in Akron, comes at a time of retrenchment in the tire industry, which is suffering from overcapacity because of lagging auto sales and the recession.

HEADLINE: Lessons About Business And Hard Times as Well

BYLINE: By WILLIAM CELIS 3d

 BODY:
Britt Eastland frets about the recession like any other businessman.
Sales have declined. The budget to develop new business lines has been trimmed. And monthly company-wide lunches have been eliminated to conserve cash.
"It worries me," Mr. Eastland said quietly. "But we're trying hard."
Mr. Eastland sounds as if he is burdened by the weight of a Fortune 500 company, but he is all of 12 years old. He is the current president of the Hunt School Fifth and Sixth Grade Classes Inc. at Hunt Elementary School in south central Texas. The company was formed in 1973 and legally incorporated 10 years later. Since it started, education in Hunt's working-class community of about 600 people has not been quite the same. 
 The company's founder, Tracy Gilbreth, a teacher of the combined fifth and sixth grades at Hunt, has been making the most of this teaching tool for 18 years. The 31 youngsters in his class this year have been schooled in the ways of business, marketing and a host of other lessons unusual for 11-and 12-year-old students.
 
Learning by Doing
 "We all learn more by doing than by hearing," said Phil Neighbors, executive vice president of the Kerrville Area Chamber of Commerce and a big supporter of the Hunt students, who are members of the countywide chamber. "These kids would have been written off a long time ago if they were not serious, dedicated and effective."
The students produce and sell novelty items, run a snack stand, organize pancake suppers and other such fund-raising events. They visit business people in the community to ask questions as well.
In good times, the company has earned more than $40,000 in a single school year, allowing members to outfit the school's four classrooms with televisions and videocassette recorders one year, and remodel the principal's office another.
Some proceeds have been put into certificates of deposit and money market funds, and some money has treated class members -- those with passing grades -- to year-end trips, chaperoned by teachers or school board members, to the Caribbean, Los Angeles and New York.
 
Flip Side of Prosperity
 But as the recession takes root, Hunt School Fifth and Sixth Grade Classes Inc. has learned about the flip side of prosperity.
For example, at the company's after-school concession stand -- in past years a cash cow -- receipts have declined to $18 to $20 a day from $35 to $40 a day a year ago.
"Last year, our concession stand had a lot more customers," said 12-year-old Amy Hatcher, the company's treasurer. "This year, we don't have as many. I guess they don't have enough money."
As a result, marketing efforts have become more aggressive. For example, students this school year sent letters to every school district in the state, pitching the company's "Texas Weather Rock," a novelty item with an accompanying leaflet explaining that when the rock is wet, it is raining outside, and when it is dry, the weather is fair.
The letters asked prospective customers at other schools to buy the rocks, and pointed out that they in turn could sell them to their students.
 
Grades Still Count
 Despite the headaches of managing a recession-battered company, leadership positions are prized. Good grades and good behavior are necessary to get and keep one of eight officer positions. Homework must be turned in when due; three misses and officers get the boot. In the past, several officers have been turned out, some of them for their roles in schoolyard fights.
Mr. Gilbreth, who acts as a benevolent chairman, predicts the class will finish this school year with $18,000 in the bank, up from last year's $14,000, but still below previous records.
"Whatever we have, it's not enough," said Amy Laughlin, 12, the company's secretary and publicity manager. But, she added sagely, "You have your ups and downs in your business life."

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Cheap Oil, Expensive Cartel

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
SAUDI ARABIA, the muscle behind the international oil cartel, made no secret of its aims at the meeting of OPEC ministers in Geneva last week: keeping the price of a barrel high enough to replenish its war-depleted treasury -- but not high enough to weaken the magic kingdom's grip on the market.
America, the muscle behind Saudi Arabia, is of two minds about the price of oil. On the one hand, policy makers worry that low prices would discommode their friends from Abu Dhabi to Houston. On the other, they fret that high prices would slow recovery from the recession and anger voters who believe deep down that Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf was fighting to make the world safe for unleaded regular at $1.06 a gallon. 
 None of this surprises M. A. Adelman, professor emeritus of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and perennial gadfly to the energy establishment, who argues that Washington's views on oil have been muddled by a mix of "high policy and low politics." To Mr. Adelman, the right price to pay for oil is the lowest price that would assure an adequate supply for the foreseeable future. And that, he estimates, is a startlingly low $6 to $10 a barrel.
If oil were sold in competitive markets, like cameras or computers, no single producer could hope to influence the price by raising or lowering output. Over the long term, the price would equal the cost to the highest-cost producer able to find a market for its crude.
But plainly, the oil market is not competitive. Roughly one-quarter of the world's production -- and more than half the known, low-cost reserves -- comes from a handful of Persian Gulf states. Production decisions by Saudi Arabia (and, in the future, perhaps Iraq and Kuwait as well) affect the price of oil. That has not, however, stopped Mr. Adelman from calculating the "efficiency price" of oil, the price that would emerge from a competitive market.
Over a period of weeks or months, he notes, it would pay producers to deliver oil as long as they could cover their operating costs. The competitive price floor, then, would be the price below which the world's high-cost producers -- notably Americans -- would be better off leaving the oil in the ground. And that price, Mr. Adelman reckons, may be as low as $5 a barrel and is certainly no more than $10.
In the long run, of course, output from high-cost regions would be bound to decline unless producers believed prices would be sufficient to cover both operating costs and the cost of developing new reserves. But in a competitive market the loss could easily be filled by production from low-cost regions, notably the Persian Gulf. The OPEC nations alone, Mr. Adelman estimates, could profitably produce more than 60 million barrels a day through the 1990's (and perhaps beyond) at just $6 a barrel -- three times the quantity they currently deliver at one-third the current price.
George Bush's new world order is not likely to include a blueprint for a competitive oil market. Mr. Bush, a former oilman, has never shown much enthusiasm for cheap fuel. Indeed, as Vice President, he pressed the Saudis to curb their inclination to prove their power over the cartel by driving the price toward the competitive floor. And in any case, nothing short of carving Saudi Arabia, Iraq and Iran into a dozen small oil-producing states and then applying America's antitrust laws to OPEC would do the trick. Nonetheless, the Adelman calculations do cast a different light on some current policy questions.
His cost estimates for OPEC make clear that most of the cash going to oil exporters is pure windfall. Squeezing the cartel would thus not be likely to reduce the supply. And it is hard to think of such a policy as unfair, unless one happens to believe that Saudi Arabia, Norway and Alaska deserve to be rich at the expense of Brazil, Poland and Oregon.
By the same token, the calculations suggest the magnitude of economic waste created by OPEC's continuing financial grab. High prices have created perverse incentives to drain America first: If Mr. Adelman's numbers are in the ball park, little or none of the billions of dollars spent annually on oil development in North America could be justified in purely economic terms.
There are environmental implications here, too. Environmentalists correctly argue that the ecological damage from burning carbon fuels -- local air pollution, global warming -- ought to be factored into the price at the pump. What they rarely acknowledge, though, is that OPEC already assesses a "carbon tax" that triples the price of crude.
Washington does have an oil policy. The only catch, it seems, is that the policy is made in Houston and Riyadh.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Detroit Is Getting New Help From Plastics

BYLINE: By PAUL C. JUDGE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 19

 BODY:
Automotive engineers have puzzled for years over how to use weight-saving plastics in car and truck engines without losing the strength or heat resistance of metal.
Now, new economical ways of reinforcing and molding plastics are providing a solution, and auto makers are using large plastic parts for the first time under the hoods of some cars made in the United States. 
 The Ford Motor Company uses a plastic valve cover -- which sits atop the engine and keeps the oil circulating -- for one of its large 8-cylinder engines. The engine powers Ford's Lincoln Town Car, Grand Marquis and Crown Victoria models. The General Motors Corporation and the Chrysler Corporation are also producing plastic engine parts in limited quantities.
The engine parts are made from a type of plastic called thermoset, a heat-resistant compound reinforced with glass fibers. They weigh about 30 percent less than the metal ones they replace. Using them in the engine, the heaviest part of the car, could reduce a car's weight.
The breakthrough goes beyond saving weight. Plastic parts cost less than many metal parts, mainly because plastic has a smooth finish that requires little, if any, machining after molding. That means less work goes into each part, which makes them cheaper to produce.
 
A Joint Venture
 Ford recently announced a joint venture with BTR P.L.C., a British company, to make plastic intake manifolds for some of Ford's 6-cylinder engines. Intake manifolds act as chambers where the air needed to burn fuel is drawn into an engine. Like valve covers, most intake manifolds are made mainly from aluminum alloys. Years ago, most manufacturers switched to aluminum from iron to save weight.
The joint venture, called Dunlop Automotive Composites Inc., is building a plant in Benton Harbor, Mich., and has orders to supply plastic intake manifolds for the 3-liter engines in Ford's 1993 Ranger pickup trucks. Ford is completing plans to use plastic manifolds on two other engines, as well, according to industry reports.
Robert M. Tamburrino, director of business operations at Dunlop, said the company hoped to get contracts with Ford that would lift its annual sales to $50 million in a few years.
So far, plastics have received serious consideration only for nonmoving engine parts. Plastic has still not proved strong enough to use for rotating components, like cam shafts and connecting rods, where engineers would dearly love to pare ounces.
"One reason Japanese engines run so smoothly, aside from the tight tolerances, is the light weight of the components they use," said David E. Cole, director of the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation. He said the lighter weight reduced the vibration and noise from an engine.
But Dr. Cole said he thought that auto makers would continue to use metal alloys for the moving engine parts for the foreseeable future.
"None of the auto makers are willing to do trial and error with customers," he said. "The plastics technology we see today has been very carefully validated before it is introduced."
The main obstacle to using plastics in engines has been the heat, which can reach as high as 350 degrees Fahrenheit in engine compartments. The most common type of plastic resin used for engine parts, known as phenolic, undergoes a molecular change in the molding process. When the plastic is melted for the first time to mold the part, the molecules that link up to form the plastic originally become joined differently and irreversibly. Once the plastic sets, it cannot melt again. Indeed, some parts made from phenolic can withstand higher temperatures than aluminum and other metals.
 
How It's Done
 To make an intake manifold, plastic resin reinforced with tiny glass fibers is injected into a mold that contains a metal core. As the molten plastic cools, it undergoes the molecular change and sets in the shape of the mold. The metal core is then melted out -- usually by submerging the entire part in hot oil -- leaving behind a one-piece plastic shape with very precise dimensions.
Before parts could be mass-produced using this technique, engineers had to perfect their recipes for alloy cores that were strong enough to handle the molding process but could still be melted out quickly without hurting the surrounding plastic. Depending on the part, manufacturers use cores made from metal alloys with melting temperatures ranging from 150 degrees to more than 450 degrees Fahrenheit.
The aluminum used to make most intake manifolds in cars today is melted down and cast in dies around sand cores. The sand is then flushed out after the aluminum hardens.
But sand cores limit the shapes that can be achieved. Large metal parts normally require two or more pieces that are cast and then joined together, adding to the manufacturing cost.
Furthermore, the precise shape and finish of intake manifolds is critical to engine performance. Sand cores leave a rough finish on the inside of aluminum manifolds. By contrast, a plastic manifold formed around a metal core has a much smoother interior finish. That eliminates some of the turbulence and eddies caused by friction as air streams through the manifold, and results in better performance.
"It translates into mileage increases, and in some cases, horsepower increases," said Mr. Tamburrino of Dunlop. Although the gains in mileage and horsepower are small, only 1 or 2 percent, auto makers are eager for any improvements.
 
Experiments in the 30's
 Henry Ford experimented in the 1930's with a type of plastic derived from the fibrous structure of soya beans. It was used to make insulated casings and interior knobs and buttons on some Ford models. General Motors used petroleum-based plastics for engine valve covers that appeared on some Cadillac models in the early 1970's. But a spate of engine failures was attributed to oil leaks from the plastic covers and the auto industry rejected plastic until improvements were made.
The car companies reacted quickly when the plastics industry learned how to mold parts around a metal core. "The auto makers recognized that this presented a way to mold very complicated structures, and they pounced on it," said Elio Eusedi, head of G.M.'s polymers department.
Oil pans and valve covers made from plastic first turned up on diesel engines about five years ago. The jarring vibrations and critical oil seals of diesel engines provided a grueling testing ground for the new material. Many trucking companies expect their diesel engines to run for 500,000 miles before replacing oil pans or valve covers.
"A loss of oil in a heavy truck diesel engine means disaster," said Eldon Trueman, vice president of sales and marketing for the plastics division of the Budd Company in Troy, Mich. The division supplies plastic oil pans for diesels. "Fleets are interested in keeping those trucks on the road and moving," he said.
