HEADLINE: Starts in Housing Show February Jump of 16.4%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Construction of new homes and apartments shot up 16.4 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today. It was the biggest monthly gain for the depressed housing industry in more than a year.
Building permits, an indicator of future construction plans, also jumped last month. 
 Analysts said a rebound in consumer confidence now that the Persian Gulf war has ended should help housing make a modest but solid comeback in 1991 from a severe slump in the last year. A number of realtors have reported a recent rise in housing demand, particularly from first-time home buyers attracted by lower interest rates and a backlog of unsold low-priced homes.
 
First in Eight Months
 The rise in building activity last month followed a revised 12.5 percent drop in starts in January. The rise in building permit applications in February was the first in eight months.
"This report makes a pretty convincing case that we saw the bottom of the market in January and we're seeing a recovery in the housing sector," said Tom Holloway, an economist with the Mortgage Bankers' Association in Washington.
Preliminary survey results from the University of Michigan showed consumer confidence was nearly as high in early March as it was before the Persian Gulf crisis began last August with Iraq's invasion of Kuwait. The fall in confidence after that event was blamed by many economists for pushing the United States into recession late last year.
There were solid signs in the housing report that builders reacted quickly to evidence of a more aggressive consumer.
The February rise was concentrated in single-family homes, where starts jumped 18.3 percent in February. Apartment construction rose 10.1 percent from January levels.
In all, housing starts rose to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 989,000 units last month from an 850,000-unit rate in January. But that was still 32.2 percent lower than the rate of starts recorded in February 1990.
"We're not looking at a boom here," Mr. Holloway said. "We're looking at a snapback from January and the likelihood of steady but modest growth for the full year."
Mr. Holloway forecast that starts will increase to an annual rate of 1.15 million units by the final three months of this year.
 
Biggest Since January 1990
 February's 16.4 percent rise in starts was the biggest since a 21.8 percent gain in January 1990. That was just before the industry began a long slide that was interrupted only once, by a small increase in November, before last month.
On a regional basis, starts rose 77.2 percent in the Midwest, 7.9 percent in the South and 5.7 percent in the Northeast. The only region where starts fell was in the West, where they were down 9.6 percent to the lowest levels since August 1982, during the 1981-82 recession.
Builders, realtors and lenders say more potential buyers are showing up at housing developments and are inquiring about loan rates now that mortgage rates have fallen below 10 percent.
"Although the construction industry is not yet out of the doghouse, it clearly is on its way back," said John Tuccillo, chief economist for the National Association of Realtors. "We expect housing starts to total 1.06 million units in 1991, down 12 percent from 1990," he added.
Housing starts peaked in 1986 at an annual rate of 1.8 million units.

HEADLINE: Wyoming Journal;
The Iron Horse Makes A Comeback Out West

BYLINE: By DIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHEYENNE, Wyo., March 15

 BODY:
In the past decade, even those with a fierce pride in Wyoming's elbow room had begun to worry about the declining number of elbows.
With agriculture and the oil-drilling business hard hit, the state's population declined by 3 percent, or 14,000 people, in the 1980's. And when Amtrak pulled up stakes in Wyoming eight years ago, the state's future seemed especially lonely and bleak. 
 But soon Wyoming will have an influx of people by the trainload, even if they are only passing through. Amtrak is returning to Wyoming.
Earlier this month the passenger train service announced that its Pioneer line, between Seattle and Chicago, would be re-routed through Wyoming, starting in June, with stops in Cheyenne, Laramie, Rawlins, Rock Springs, Green River and Evanston.
Until now, Wyoming was one of only four states in the contiguous United States without Amtrak service. The others are Maine, Oklahoma and South Dakota.
"It's real good news," said Gunther Krix, a grocery worker in Cheyenne. He did not quite exult over the Amtrak announcement, but rather, in the manner of most Westerners, nodded approvingly.
But if the people here hope that Amtrak's decision symbolizes a vote of confidence in their state, they may be disappointed.
"It really doesn't have very much to do with Wyoming," said R. Clifford Black, a spokesman for Amtrak. "It has more to do with Seattle."
The current Pioneer route, which crosses the Rocky Mountains, is known for its breathtaking scenery. But the rugged landscape, which must be navigated at lower speeds, has often meant delays for the train.
As a result, passengers leaving Seattle had to board at 5 A.M. so that the train would have enough time to make its connection in Denver. Amtrak believes it can attract more passengers in Seattle, a booming market, if the train leaves at a more civilized hour. By crossing southern Wyoming's gentler terrain, the Pioneer can leave Seattle a few hours later.
Under the new route system, no community will lose Amtrak service. Passengers can still choose to ride across the Rockies, on a line that meets in Boise, Idaho, with the Zephyr, the San Francisco-Chicago line.
No matter what the reasons are for the route change, Wyoming residents say they will be happy to hear the rumblings of passenger trains again.
"I can remember years ago taking the sleeper car to Salt Lake City," Charles Hanscum, an 84-year-old retired game warden, said with a pleasant sigh. "It sure beats going on these highways."
Sister Marie Raymond, a Dominican nun who teaches music in Cheyenne, said Amtrak had been missing the boat by bypassing Wyoming.
"We don't have all that many people, but we've got an adventuresome spirit out here," she said.
Sister Marie said she hoped the new train service would make it easier for her to visit friends in the Midwest. "As it is now, if you die and go to hell you've got to go through Denver first," she said. "Now don't say I said that."
Cheyenne was settled in the 1860's by railway workers laying the Union Pacific line, and Wyoming politicians expressed hope that the new rail service will mean another economic boom.
"Most of the passengers will be passing through Wyoming," said Dennis Curran, an aide to Gov. Mike Sullivan. "It will be our job to get them off the train to take advantage of our tourist attractions."
Some people are already making plans to take advanage of the new train route. For Keith Kershisnik, the train could provide one leg of a long commute he makes regularly.
"I live in Rock Springs and work in the oil fields in Alaska," said Mr. Kershisnik, 31, a burly man in a Bart Simpson T-shirt. He was browsing through the Wyoming State Museum in Cheyenne, where the gift shop sells a book about Wyoming entitled, "Courage in a Lonesome Land."
"With all the economic problems we've had, the lack of jobs and all, it's a good sign to get the train back," he said. "In the last several years, even the people with blood going all the way back in Wyoming were starting to wonder if maybe we should all leave. But the real, true Wyoming people know that if we're strong, we won't fail."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
I.B.M. Sees Sharp Drop In Earnings

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
I.B.M. said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings would be about half of its profit a year ago and far short of most analysts' projections. The prediction jolted Wall Street, which took it as a sign that there were new grounds for concern about a stumbling national economic recovery.
The bad news, which was delivered in an early-morning conference call to financial analysts, stunned the stock market. On the New York Stock Exchange, trading in shares of the International Business Machines Corporation was delayed for an hour and a half because of an order imbalance. When trading finally began, the stock was off $9.125 from Monday's close. It ended the day at $115.125, down $12.75, or nearly 10 percent, helping to send the whole market to a sharp fall. 
 I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., attributed the earnings decline to an international economic slowdown and to rising uncertainty surrounding the Persian Gulf war. It added that improvement would not come until there was an economic turnaround.
 
Some Analysts Skeptical
 But several analysts expressed skepticism about whether the company's difficulties could be pinned solely on broader economic events.
"They've done this thing before," said Ulric Weil, a financial analyst at Weil & Associates in Washington. "They've come out of left field and hit everyone with a wet cloth.'
Some analysts suggested that I.B.M.'s weak performance showed it might be having a slow product transition to its new family of mainframe computers introduced last year. But I.B.M. made a special point of rejecting those suggestions. The company said all of its product lines, with the exception of its new RS/6000 work station line and software and services, were hurt equally. The RS/ 6000 came closer to meeting the company's expectations.
The newest sign of a global economic slowdown that is buffeting the world's largest computer maker is particularly troubling, analysts said yesterday, because I.B.M. officials had been saying that the company was skirting broader economic declines.
"There was a lot of spending in the fourth quarter that has distorted earnings for I.B.M. and others," said Daniel Mandresh, a computer industry analyst at Merrill Lynch. "The moment-of-truth time is going to the March quarter."
Economists said economic deterioration had been most pronounced in Western Europe, a market that has been good for many United States computer makers in recent years. "They can certainly blame the world economy and expect more of the same in the first half of this year," said David Hale, chief economist at the Kemper Financial Companies.
The poor I.B.M. performance also suggested that the corporate restructuring engineered by the chairman, John F. Akers, in the last three years might still be incomplete. Last fall the company introduced its first new family of mainframe computers in almost six years and it has maintained that the product transition is proceeding smoothly.
Yesterday an I.B.M. spokesman said the company would continue to cut expenses that would reduce its work force.
In a brief statement, Mr. Akers said the company remained confident of its product line and its relationships with customers, but added, "The ability to take advantage of these strengths in 1991 is contingent on how rapidly the worldwide economic environment improves."
I.B.M. told analysts that sales had slowed in all of its major geographical markets and that the United States market, which has seen slow growth for several years, was hardest hit.
The company said it expected first-quarter earnings to be close to 90 cents a share, far lower than the $1.81 in the first quarter of 1990. Peter Thonis, an I.B.M. spokesman, said that analysts' predictions for the current quarter had been $1.65 to $1.95.
I.B.M.'s warning of a poor first quarter also effected the stocks of a number of other computer makers. The Digital Equipment Corporation's stock also had a delayed start in trading, and ended down $5.25, to $71.375, in what analysts called a reaction to the I.B.M. statement.
Mr. Weil, the analyst, said I.B.M.'s problems could not all be attributed to economic factors. "Akers still hasn't done the right things to get the information flowing from the bottom to the top so that he doesn't get blindsided," he said. "This doesn't speak well for the transformation of I.B.M."
Several analysts also warned that foreign currency factors, which have helped I.B.M. recently, could begin to hurt later this year if the dollar continued to strengthen.
At the Compaq Computer Corporation, Eckhart Pfeiffer, the chief executive, said that his company's outlook had not changed but that the United States outlook was particularly difficult. He said the gulf war had also hurt Compaq's business in Europe.
Several of I.B.M.'s competitors said yesterday that they also saw the possibility of further earnings declines in the quarter.
The Amdahl Corporation, a maker of mainframe computers based in Sunnyvale, Calif., said it expected earnings for the first quarter to fall well below last year's results.

HEADLINE: U.S. AGENDA URGED BY ASTRONOMERS

BYLINE: By JOHN NOBLE WILFORD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Setting research priorities for the next decade, astronomers today recommended a $3 billion national program to build and operate new telescopes for investigating the presence of planets around other stars, the life cycles of stars, the existence of black holes and the evolution of the universe.
The astronomers, in a report issued by the National Research Council, gave their highest endorsement to proposals for two telescopes for viewing the heavens in infrared wavelengths. 
 One is the $1.3 billion Space Infrared Telescope Facility, which would be a thousand times as sensitive as Earth-based infrared telescopes. The other is an $80 million ground-based telescope that would be the first designed specifically for infrared observations.
"New instruments will reveal previously unimagined aspects of the universe and will lead to new questions about objects that we do not yet know exist," said Dr. John N. Bahcall, an astrophysicist at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., who headed the study of priorities in astronomy for the 1990's. More than 300 astronomers participated in the study.
 
Peering at Galaxies' Cores
 Dr. Alex Filippenko, an astronomer at the University of California at Berkeley, said, for example, that more powerful infrared telescopes should be able to penetrate the cores of galaxies and establish if many of them are, as suspected, inhabited by black holes, regions of matter so compressed that gravitational force does not permit light to escape.
"Infrared telescopes would be able to see whether stars are concentrated at the centers of galaxies," Dr. Filippenko said. "That will be the smoking gun that black holes really do exist."
These telescopes should also be able to detect emissions from possible planetary systems, observe the birth of stars in dust clouds and their death in tremendous explosions and detect the weak light of infant galaxies and galactic clusters formed later across vast regions of the universe.
Dr. Bahcall said at a news briefing that emphasis was placed on infrared astronomy because the technology had reached a high state of maturity and these facilities were not duplicated by telescopes in other countries.
Dr. Carl Sagan, the astronomer from Cornell University, said that the orbiting infrared telescope "has a potential to revolutionize many areas of astronomy."
 
Emphasizing Small Programs
 The astronomers assigned an equally high priority to the more mundane work, mainly financed by the National Science Foundation, of refurbishing present ground-based facilities, establishing computer networks and data archives for astronomy and increasing support for students and theoretical studies. Equipment at many observatories, the report said, has seriously deteriorated and "now poses a threat to the continued success of U.S. astronomy."
In a recommendation aimed primarily at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, the astronomers called for an "increased emphasis in the astronomy budget on small and moderate programs," especially in space astronomy. Simpler missions, they said, could be launched more quickly in response to changing technology and new scientific ideas and to train future generations of scientists.
Even so, the study group concluded that some large telescopes were required to answer many of the most fundamental questions in astronomy. The recommended space-based infrared telescope would complete NASA's great observatory program to examine the sky across the electromagnetic spectrum. The orbiting Hubble telescope is designed for optical and ultraviolet observations. The Gamma Ray Observatory is scheduled to be launched next month. And the Advanced X-Ray Astrophysics Facility is to be launched in 1998.
Other projects endorsed by the study, in descending order of priority after the orbiting and ground-based infrared telescopes, include the Millimeter Array, a group of radiotelescopes that will observe emissions from the centers of galaxies and from regions of young, hot stars, and a 310-inch optical telescope to be built in the Southern Hemisphere.
The study also endorsed the development of "adaptive optics" to compensate for atmospheric interference and thus improve ground-based observations; a spacecraft called the Far Ultraviolet Spectroscopy Explorer; a far-infrared telescope to be flown on a Boeing 747; an increase in the number of small spacecraft for astrophysics, and expansion and refurbishing of the Very Large Array, a cluster of radio antennas in New Mexico.
 
Telescopes on the Moon
 At the request of NASA officials, the astronomers assessed the suitability of the Moon as a base for telescopes. They concluded that "a cost-effective and scientifically productive program would require early technology development."
Both Dr. Bahcall and Dr. Sagan emphasized that a return of astronauts to the Moon could open the way for erecting and operating telescopes there, but that such missions would have to be justified in terms other than their usefulness to astronomy.
For every project the astronomers included in their wish list, Dr. Bahcall said, at least 10 others were rejected for one reason or another in order to keep the recommendations in line with current spending plus an amount to account for inflation.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Advances Broadly; Gold Up in Europe and U.S.

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar climbed yesterday in a powerful rally inspired by Germany's top monetary official, who said his nation's hasty currency union last year was an economic disaster.
Gold fell in Asia but rose in Europe and the United States. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold bullion for current delivery edged up 80 cents a troy ounce to settle at $363.80. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $363.00 a troy ounce, up 90 cents from late Monday. 
 The dollar gained against all major currencies but the Japanese yen. The rally came despite a concerted attempt by many of the world's major central banks to satisfy some of the market's voracious demand for dollars by selling them in the foreign exchange markets.
Remarks by Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, suggested the European Community move slowly toward a single currency, or the union could have the same "disastrous" results as Germany's monetary union on July 1, 1990. After the remarks were made, the Bundesbank said Mr. Pohl's comments were "taken out of context."
However, "the damage had already been done," said Mike Faust, foreign exchange analyst at MMS International in Chicago. "It set the stage for a dollar rally."
Mr. Pohl's apparent reference to broad unemployment in the former East Germany and Germany's rising interest rates briefly pushed the dollar to 1.6740 marks, a nine-month high against that currency.
 
Steady Advance of Dollar
 The central banks intervened after Mr. Pohl's remarks, but the move seemed to only marginally dampen enthusiasm for the dollar, which has been gaining steadily since the end of the Persian Gulf war gave rise to optimism about the United States economy.
"There are still people out there who want to buy dollars," said Robert Hatcher, corporate dealer for Barclays Bank P.L.C.
In Europe, the dollar ended at 1.6540 German marks, up from 1.6330 late Monday, while in New York it rose to 1.6423 German marks, from 1.6282. The economic optimism was helped by a Commerce Department report that construction of new homes and apartments shot up 16.4 percent last month.
In addition, traders said they were heartened by a Government report that the nation's underlying inflation rate, absent food and energy, was surprisingly high.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing 137.98 yen, from 137.65 yen at Monday's close. Later, in London, it rose to 138.15 yen, and in New York, the dollar settled at 137.55 yen, down slightly from late Monday's 137.97 yen. In London, the British pound fell to $1.7655, from $1.7905 late Monday. The pound also weakened in New York, where it fetched $1.7800, less than late Monday's $1.7938.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Monday, included: 1.4175 Swiss francs, up from 1.4065; 5.5945 French francs, up from 5.5485; 1,225.00 Italian lire, up from 1,214.75, and 1.1549 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1541.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Kurds Alone Viewed as Unlikely to Oust Hussein

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
The unrest in Iraqi Kurdistan is the most serious anti-Government revolt in that region in almost two decades, but it alone is unlikely to topple President Saddam Hussein of Iraq, Middle East experts say.
Military and political analysts inside and outside the Bush Administration agree that the rebellion by the Kurds, non-Arabs who make up about 20 percent of Iraq's population, could be an important factor in weakening the Hussein Government. But no Kurdish revolt has ever brought down an Iraqi government since the nation gained independence from Britain in 1932, although an inability to quash rebellions contributed to the overthrow of a number of governments before the Baath Party came to power in 1968. 
 This Kurdish rebellion is different from others in that the Baghdad Government has been further weakened by Iraq's humiliating military defeat in Kuwait, the nation's desperate economic situation, the continuing unrest in southern Iraq and the allies' refusal to let Iraq use what remains of its air power against rebels.
"We have seen Kurdish rebellions over and over and over again, but never in the context of such a weak central Government," said Graham Fuller, senior political scientist at the Rand Corporation. "It's not the fact of the uprising but the context in which it is taking place that gives it half a chance."
 
Iran Said to Send Arms
 The situation in Kurdistan could become more serious if foreign governments send significant amounts of arms and money to the Kurds, as they did in the 1970's.
Bush Administration officials said today that Iran was sending arms across the border, both to Kurdish guerrillas in the north and Shiite Muslim rebels in the south. "There is some support, some arms from Iran," one Administration official said. "Is it a major supply operation? The answer is no."
The Kurds were also heartened last week when President Turgut Ozal of Turkey, reversing a policy of half a century, announced that his Government had opened contacts with Iraqi Kurdish leaders opposed to the Hussein Government. Senior Turkish officials said after the announcement that Turkey would send humanitarian aid to the Kurds and was considering a Kurdish request to serve as a conduit for arms.
"The Kurds are being manipulated one way or the other," Mr. Ozal said. "Everyone else is talking to them. Why not us?"
But any concrete support for Iraq's Kurds could stimulate unrest among Turkey's 12 million Kurds, who are officially referred to as "mountain Turks," and many Turkish military and political leaders oppose Mr. Ozal's approach.
 
Arab Pledges Reported
 Jalal Talabani, leader of the Patriotic Union of Kurdistan and one of the Kurdish leaders who met with Turkish officials, has said that Arab nations promised to give his group substantial amounts of arms to fight Baghdad. He did not say which Arab nations had offered arms, although both Syria and Saudi Arabia have actively supported various Iraqi opposition leaders. Mr. Talabani keeps a home in Damascus and is part of the Syrian-backed coalition of opposition leaders.
Bush Administration officials said that they saw no evidence of arms shipments over the Turkish or Syrian borders and that for the most part the arms used in the uprisings in both the north and south were captured from or handed over by Iraqi troops.
Administration officials said today that the Kurds appeared to be expanding their control over large areas of Kurdistan, but had not taken control of the strategic oil-producing city of Kirkuk, despite their assertions that they had.
Until the last several days, Mr. Hussein largely focused on suppressing opposition in Shiite areas in the south of the country, which he traditionally has considered more of a threat to his country's stability. As the unrest in Kurdistan worsens, Mr. Hussein has begun to rush army units back to Kurdistan.
In the first part of the 1970's the Iraqi Government faced a serious rebellion in Kurdistan, which makes up about one-seventh of Iraqi territory. Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran, with substantial help from Israel and the Central Intelligence Agency, supplied Iraqi Kurdish rebels with financial and military aid in an attempt to weaken the Baath Party Government. By 1974, the Kurds controlled substantial parts of Kurdistan.
The rebellion was so threatening that Mr. Hussein signed a humiliating accord with the Shah in 1975 under which the Shah agreed to end his activities in Iraq and Mr. Hussein agreed to give up his claim to the entire Shatt al-Arab, the waterway that divides the two countries. After that agreement, tens of thousands of Kurds were arrested and sent to detention camps in southern Iraq.
During the Iran-Iraq war, the Iraqi Government moved ruthlessly against Kurdish rebels while making conciliatory moves toward those it could coopt and quiet. Mr. Hussein contained unrest in Kurdistan using a combination of repression and rewards. The repression included the relocation of Kurdish civilians and attacks like the chemical-weapons strike at the town of Halabja in 1988 that killed about 5,000 Kurds; the rewards included jobs and the construction of new towns with roads, electricity and running water.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Cheney Wants No Limit On Arms for Gulf Allies

BYLINE: By PATRICK E. TYLER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that the United States would not limit the sales of sophisticated conventional weapons to America's allies in the Middle East when their security might be at stake.
Addressing questions from the House Foreign Affairs Committee, Mr. Cheney said in testimony that he expected foreign military sales to continue and in some cases increase to allies such as Egypt, Israel and Saudi Arabia so that those countries would be able to defend themselves from aggression long enough for United States forces to come to their aid. 
 The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to pay $15 billion for the Persian Gulf war, but attached language to the spending bill that bars Government funds for military sales to any nation that fails to fulfill its pledge of financial assistance for the war effort. The House has taken a less punitive stance about countries that have yet to complete promised payments for the war. They include Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, the United Arab Emirates, Japan, nd Germany and Korea. The Senate action is viewed primarily as a warning.
In his House testimony, Mr. Cheney said that his principal arms control interest is in preventing the spread of "sophisticated technologies" like ballistic missiles and chemical, nuclear and biological weapons capabilities.
 
Future Arms Sales Questioned
 A number of legislators questioned any policy that would not restrain future sales of conventional weapons -- tanks, warplanes and air defense missiles -- in an unstable region whose history has been marked by a recurring arms race among Arab countries, Iran and Israel.
Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat, voiced one complaint, saying: "Israel is being crushed under the burden of the massive amount of weaponry it needs to deal with the weaponry that we and our allies and the Soviets have been sending to others of our quote 'friends' in the Middle East. This is the same old cycle."
Mr. Cheney said he was willing to consider some restraint in conventional arms sales, "but I think our first concern ought to be to work with our friends and allies to see to it that they're secure."
"The policy we're pursuing now," Mr. Cheney said, "is one in which we want to minimize the U.S. military presence on the ground in the region. It's probably easier to do if we help out friends like the Saudis and the gulf states to have sufficient capability to be able to defend themselves long enough for us to be able to get back."
 
'Pretty Severe Scare'
 Using the Persian Gulf crisis to bolster his argument, Mr. Cheney said: "I don't think there's any question but that there are legitimate security threats to Saudi Arabia. They've just been through a pretty severe scare."
Mr. Cheney's remarks appeared to signal a determination within the Bush Administration to go forward at some point with weapons sales to United States allies in the Middle East. These sales are likely to include top-of-the-line tanks and warplanes to Egypt and Saudi Arabia, and Patriot missiles to Israel and perhaps to Saudi Arabia.
The debate over future arms sales in the region may have plenty of time to develop while the Kuwaitis and Saudis take six months to a year to sort out the heavy commitments they have made to finance their share of the military operations, put their domestic economies back in order and rebuild war-damaged facilities.
The Saudis have put their arms purchase requests to Washington on hold, an official said, to give Riyadh time to deal with its cash-flow problems, to determine how much pre-positioned military equipment the Pentagon is willing to leave behind and to avoid a bruising fight with Israel's supporters in Congress just as President Bush is undertaking a peace initiative in the region.
"There is no immediate specific request," from the Saudis, said one official.
 
Availability of Funds Conditional
 In the Senate today, the $15 billion appropriation bill was approved by a vote of 98 to 1. The Senate version said the funds could only be spent if foreign contributions fell short of the amounts pledged by coalition partners.
Senator Robert C. Byrd, the West Virginia Democrat who is chairman of the Appropriations Committee, said foreign nations had paid only $25.6 billion on pledges totaling $54.5 billion. "The pace at which we are receiving contributions from our allies is of real concern to me, particularly with regard to the cash-rich gulf states," the Senator said.
"It is more than just a little disconcerting to see this delay, especially by those countries the defense of which we took up," he added.
Mr. Byrd said Saudi Arabia had paid only $6.1 billion on pledges of $16.8 billion, Kuwait had paid only $5.5 billion on pledges of $16 billion, and the United Arab Emirates had paid only about half of the $4 billion it had pledged.
 
Others Also Lagged
 Other nations that lagged behind in their payments were Germany, which paid $4.6 billion on a pledge of $6.5 billion; Japan, which paid $7.3 billion on a pledge of $10.7 billion, and South Korea, which paid $71 million on a pledge of $385 million.
The House of Representatives approved the appropriation bill on March 7, but merely warned recalcitrant nations that Congress "may consider appropriate action" if their financial commitments were not met.
The White House opposed the Senate prohibition, but did not threaten a veto if the ban survived a House-Senate conference. The Office of Management and Budget said that the prohibition "places unnecessary and inappropriate constraints" on sales, credits and guarantees for military equipment and services to America's allies, whose payment delays were sometimes justified.

HEADLINE: Dow Plunges 62.13 Points, Or Over 2%

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Stocks were slammed yesterday by the report on consumer prices for February and by I.B.M.'s prediction of sharply lower earnings.
The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 62.13 points, or more than 2 percent, to 2,867.82, its first close below 2,900 since Feb. 26. It was the largest drop in the Dow since the 3.1 percent decline on Oct. 9. 
 Volume was a modest 177.1 million shares, up slightly from 163.1 million the previous day. Declining issues outstripped those advancing by a ratio of about 2.5 to 1. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks fell 5.52 points, to 366.59, while the Nasdaq composite dropped 3.46 points, to 462.81.
The Labor Department reported that the Consumer Price Index rose by two-tenths of 1 percent in February, but when price gyrations in energy and food are eliminated, it spurted seven-tenths of 1 percent. That sign of surprisingly high inflation seemed to dash hopes that the Federal Reserve would ease short-term rates soon, and stock prices tumbled.
And trading in I.B.M., the bluest of the blue chips, quickly fell 9 1/8 after its opening was delayed an hour and a half by an order imbalance. The corporation said its first-quarter earnings would probably be about half the current estimates, citing the worldwide economic slowdown and disruption caused by the Persian Gulf war.
Since the stock weighs heavily on the Dow, many investors regard it as a bellwether issue. "It not only supports the market psychologically, it supports the other technology stocks," one trader said. I.B.M. ended the day off 12 3/4, or nearly 10 percent, at 115 1/8, accounting for 25 points of the Dow's plunge.
Edward P. Nicoski, chief market strategist at Piper, Jaffray & Hopwood in Minneapolis, said "I.B.M. disappointed most observers, and took technology stocks down hard, while the disappointing core rate of inflation did technological damage to bond market." By late in the day the price of the Treasury's 30-year bond was off about 3/4 point.
"We've got a market that was extremely extended on the upside," Mr. Nicoski said. "And in recent weeks we've begun to see the beginning of investor movement toward the historically defensive stocks, like utilities and health care, in a down market."
In early trading stocks came under heavy pressure and by 11 A.M, with the Dow down 50, a New York Stock Exchange rule kicked in that bars computerized program trading when the last trade is below the previous one. After dropping about 51 points, the Dow backed off to 43 down.
By noon the Dow was down about 48 points, to 2,881.44 on about 85 million shares traded. Stocks had recouped some of their earlier losses, but were still down sharply. A weak bond market, declines in technology and drug stocks continued to tug at the market.
Fifteen minutes later the market was back down 50, it rebounded briefly, then fell below 50 for nearly the rest of the day, tumbling lower minutes before the bell sounded the end of trading.
Unnerved investors sold about 3.6 million I.B.M. shares, taking other tehnology stocks down along the way. Intel fell 1 3/4, to 45 1/4; Compaq Computer was down 3 5/8, to 61 1/4; Digital Equipment dropped 5 1/4, to 71 3/8, and Texas Instruments fell 1 1/4, to 39 7/8.

HEADLINE: Exports Help Japan in 4th Quarter

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 19

 BODY:
Japan's economy was sustained by solid export growth in the fourth quarter of last year, the Government said today, a trend that is likely to contribute to a rebound in the politically sensitive trade surplus.
Over all, as economists had forecast, Japan's economy slowed to a crawl under the strain of high interest rates and the Persian Gulf crisis, the Government figures showed. 
 Still, experts found a far from gloomy message in the much-anticipated figures: the export surge could carry Japan into what would be its longest postwar economic boom.
According to the Economic Planning Agency, the economy grew at a 2.1 percent annual rate in the October through December period. Although strong compared with the recessionary lull in the United States, that looked anemic compared with Japan's 4.1 percent annual growth rate in the third quarter and the overall expansion of 5.6 percent in 1990.
Few economists were as sanguine as Shinyasu Hoshino, vice minister of the Economic Planning Agency, who said the economy was hitting "cruising speed." But several said the figures suggested somewhat greater flexibility in the economy than is expected in tough times. Officially, the Government is forecasting 3.8 percent growth this year, while most private economists are predicting 3 percent or less.
In the patchwork of figures released today, two stood out: while domestic demand declined one-tenth of 1 percent from the previous quarter, as Japanese consumers pulled back in the face of uncertainty, external demand, mainly exports, jumped a healthy six-tenths of 1 percent from the third quarter.
 
Unexpected Stimulus
 "We were not expecting that strong a stimulus from exports," said Paul A. Summerville, economist at Jardine Fleming Securities here, who noted that domestic demand had been the engine of growth in recent years as Japan sought to ease trade tensions with the United States.
"This is good for the economy all-in-all, but it means the trade tensions could get worse," he added. Mr. Summerville said that Japan's trade surplus could swell to $66 billion in the fiscal year that begins April 1, from $51 billion in the just-ending fiscal year.
Mr. Summerville said that much of the expansion in exports was to other Asian nations, not to the United States, where consumer buying has also been sluggish. Over the last several years, Japanese companies have been increasing their trade and investment in Asia, particularly with Thailand, Indonesia and Malaysia.
Japan's domestic economy showed pronounced weakness in contrast to the external sector. Personal consumption tumbled three-tenths of 1 percent from the third quarter, according to the figures. Housing posted a particularly big decline, largely a product of high interest rates.
"In times of uncertainty, the Japanese consumer cuts back on BMW's and American washing machines," said Jesper Koll, an economist here for S. G. Warburg Securities. "But that meant imports declined, too."
One facet of the domestic sector, capital spending by corporations, was robust. Investment in plants and equipment continued to expand at a double-digit annual rate during the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Israeli Army Chief, Stirring Furor, Suggests the Golan Is Expendable

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 19

 BODY:
The army Chief of Staff, who retires in a month, said in remarks reported today that Israel might safely give up some occupied territories if the nation made satisfactory peace agreements with its Arab neighbors.
The remarks by the officer, Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron, came after a series of public statements by Israeli Government officials apparently intending to reaffirm how intractably wedded Israel is to the Golan Heights, which were seized from Syria. General Shomron's remarks helped turned a hot debate into a public brawl. 
 Several Cabinet members quickly told the general to keep his views to himself. Some said he should immediately resign, even though he is so close to retirement. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon urged leaders of Jewish settlements in the occupied territories to redouble their efforts to build new housing there to affirm resistance to giving up the territories.
The political storm began Sunday, when Health Minister Ehud Olmert gave a speech in Washington. He offered a view that is heretic for a Likud party official by saying that Israel might be willing to discuss territorial issues with Syria. Israel captured the Golan Heights from Syria in the 1967 war, and Damascus demands its return as a condition for peace.
"We are ready to negotiate all of the issues," Mr. Olmert told the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, "all of the claims, all of the demands, including the territorial demands of the Syrians and our demands, and conclude peace between our two countries."
As the United States tries to move the nations of the Middle East to make peace, this country's position is that it wants to open talks with Arab countries without any conditions. To many in Washington, Mr. Olmert seemed to be offering only a logical extension of that position. But to Mr. Shamir and others in his Cabinet, Mr. Olmert's remarks smacked of betrayal.
"I am not happy with Olmert," said Mr. Shamir, who counts the Health Minister among his closest advisers. Other members of the governing coalition threatened to bring down the Cabinet unless Mr. Shamir repudiated Mr. Olmert's words.
He did, but then General Shomron offered his view in a briefing for Israeli military correspondents.
"A political arrangement, when it exists, is far more than just territory," he said. "It is linked to limiting weapons, supervision of one country over another. Thus if you are talking about nations at war, without a doubt territory has very great significance. But when you talk about these other arrangements, it is clear that these include various elements that diminish the threat of giving up territory and offer the possibility, for example, of long-range warning."
The statement was oblique, but more than enough to set off this Government.
The issue of the Golan remains a highly emotional one in Israel, where many still remember how, before 1967, Syrians shelled Israeli settlements from the highlands. But with the development and acuuisition of long-range missiles and Awacs reconnaissance planes, some military analysts have contended that a truly demilitarized Golan would have little strategic value.
 
Request, Then Refusal
 Mr. Shamir said on Monday that Israel was ready to talk to Syria without conditions.
"Syria has the right to ask us to withdraw from the Golan Heights," he continued. "If Syria does ask, we shall say we do not agree to withdraw."
Asked what would then be left to discuss, Mr. Shamir said: "We can talk about peace, about the ways of peace, about economic cooperation. There are many things. We say we are ready to negotiate unconditionally with all the Arab states -- nothing more than that."
Mr. Sharon then announced that his ministry had a major building program for new settlers on the Golan Heights.
"At the moment," he said, "we are in different states that range from preparations of infrastructure to actual construction of 1,200 housing units in the Golan Heights, and I intend to add the same number next year.
"There are 11,000 Jews on the Golan today," he added, "and we hope that next year the Jewish population there will be increased up to 20,000."
The statements made by Mr. Shamir and the others ended the weeklong hiatus on rightist public statements, a halt ordered by Mr. Shamir when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Jerusalem.
The statements reported today dealt also with topics other than the Golan Heights. Pressed by political rivals during a committee meeting in Parliament to say what he thought of Mr. Baker's meetings with Palestinian leaders in Jerusalem a week ago, the Prime Minister said he considered these people unfit for negotiations with Israel.
"They met him in the name of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to express the stand of the P.L.O.," the Prime Minister said. "We shall not talk to people from the P.L.O."

HEADLINE: The Cost of 'Really' Living vs. Just Living

BYLINE: By N. R. KLEINFIELD

 BODY:
It's always fabulous to be rich, and now it's gotten even more fabulous.
Last year, for only the second time in eight years, the inflation rate for a sampling of luxury goods was essentially identical to the inflation rate for the more basic consumer goods that Americans buy. In other words, big spenders could have the same indulgent life and not pay much more. 
 That, at least, is the conclusion of the latest version of the Moet Luxury Index, which Moet & Chandon, the Champagne people, released yesterday. Moet has used the index since 1982 to monitor price changes of luxury goods and services in New York City -- or, as Moet likes to phrase it, the cost of "really" living. Although the index ranks as one of the lesser-watched economic indicators and is not known to have a profound effect on Government economic policy, Moet thinks it is an interesting bit of calculation.
Moet's basket of a dozen luxury items rose 6.2 percent last year, virtually identical to the 6.1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index. In prior years, the luxury index was sometimes two or three times higher than the consumer index. The one other exception came in 1983, when the consumer index rose 3.8 percent and the luxury index went up just 3.7 percent. Then it was unbelievably fabulous being rich.
 
Rich Also More Cautious
 According to the Moet people, last year's results indicate that the economy was so perilous that businesses needed to keep a tighter lid on high-priced items because the rich were being more cautious, too.
In 1990, Moet pointed out, some luxury items were outright bargains (at least for the people accustomed to buying them without wincing). For instance, the cost of a wash, cut and blow dry at the Bumble and Bumble hair salon didn't change at all. It was still $65. Maid service for a day, according to Maids Unlimited, was also the same $100 it had been in 1989.
What happened to a full-length mink coat at Alixandre Furs was stunning. It fell 11.8 percent in cost, to $15,000, the sole product in the index to decline in price.
A Rolls-Royce Corniche III convertible was only 5 percent more at $226,700. Cuvee Dom Perignon Champagne was up 4 percent, to $79. Hennessy X.O cognac was 4 percent higher at $90.65.
Not everything was tremendous last year for the heavy spenders. A 1.05-ounce portion of Russian beluga caviar was up a nasty 15.8 percent, to $69.50. A pound of Teuscher imported chocolate truffles rose 11 percent, to $40. A round trip from New York to Paris on the Concorde was up 10 percent, to $5,840. And a men's Rolex Oyster perpetual day-date watch with a President bracelet climbed 17.5 percent, to $13,750. Makes you think twice.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
A Reverie: Unity on Domestic Problems

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
Senator Tom Daschle has this dream: Now that the war is over, the Government and the news media begin to focus on domestic problems with the same intensity they gave the Persian Gulf.
President Bush says money is no object when the future of the nation is at stake, and his budget director, Richard G. Darman, holds daily briefings on the progress of the war against poverty and the battle for supremacy in education. Congressional leaders agree to bury partisan differences. 
 The network anchors fly off to Detroit and Boston and Pine Bluff, Ark., to report from the site of the recession. And in no time at all, the problems are conquered, the American economy is proved to be the strongest on earth and those who worked night and day to turn the country around are given heroes' welcomes when they return to their everyday lives.
Senator Daschle, a South Dakota Democrat, laughs at the fantasy. But he said, "Without unity of purpose with a clear objective, without George Bush on television late at night calling the problems to the attention of the American people, without a full-scale debate in Congress and without the full attention of the media, the changes that are needed will not be made."
Whatever their ideology or political perspective, almost all the two dozen Administration officials, lawmakers, economists and political strategists interviewed in the last week agreed with Mr. Daschle's assessment. But they also agreed that such unity was not in the offing, certainly not this year.
"The rest of this year will all be an anticlimax," said Senator Warren B. Rudman, a conservative Republican from New Hampshire.
In the aftermath of the war, the focus here is expected to turn to the same issues the White House and Congress, Republicans and Democrats, have been bickering over for years: civil rights and racial quotas, banks and savings and loans, capital punishment and gun control, highways and mass transit, abortion and parental leave, trade and energy, capital gains, individual retirement accounts and Social Security taxes.
But the fundamental problems, those interviewed agreed, lie elsewhere: an education system inadequate for the 21st century, 20 percent of all children in poverty, homelessness and serious crime in nearly every community, soaring medical costs, and savings and productivity rates so low that they threaten Americans' standard of living.
 
Big Hurdle: New Budget Rules
 Those problems are not being addressed, said Robert D. Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office and Congress's chief economist, in part because "it's just not clear what the solutions are, even if we could afford them."
But in part it is also because the budget law enacted last year basically proscribes dramatic initiatives.
Under the new rules, the budget is broken down into five categories: military spending, discretionary domestic spending like highways and space exploration, foreign aid, benefit programs like Medicare and Social Security in which payments are made automatically to those who meet the qualifications, and taxes.
In the first three categories, any additional spending must be offset dollar for dollar by a budget cut in the same category. For example, more money for an education program must be balanced by a cut somewhere in other discretionary domestic spending. Money cannot be taken from the military to pay for domestic programs or vice versa.
 
A Case in Point
 In the last two categories, benefit programs and taxes, any extra spending or cut in taxes must be offset by higher taxes or benefit cuts. For instance, increasing welfare benefits could be paid for only by cutting another benefit program, like Medicare, or by raising taxes.
Here is an example of what all this means in practice:
A recently published study of prisoners 10 years after their discharge showed that more than three-quarters of those required to undergo anti-drug therapy while in prison committed no crimes after they left prison.
Representative Charles E. Schumer, a Brooklyn Democrat who sits on the Judiciary and Budget Committees, was impressed, and he has proposed a $150 million program to provide such treatment to all addicted Federal prisoners.
No one has expressed opposition to the proposal, and under traditional budget rules, it would probably become law. But Mr. Schumer says he will have trouble getting it enacted because it will be difficult to find $150 million to cut elsewhere.
 
Calling an 'Emergency'
 "The budget blocks you and boxes you in," said Mr. Schumer, who was a strong advocate of last year's budget deal and, despite his frustration, says it should not be breached.
The budget does provide for additional spending if the President and Congress declare an "emergency." Two such cases have already arisen this year: more generous veterans' benefits in the afterglow of the war and more money to staff unemployment offices during the recession.
Representative Leon E. Panetta, the California Democrat who heads the Budget Committee, said that if the "emergency" language "becomes boilerplate for every appropriation," the budget deal would quickly unravel. But he said he did not expect that to happen.
One consequence of the budget restrictions is that many of the battles this year will be fought over issues that cost the Government no money, like capital punishment, gun control, civil rights, trade limits, changes in the banking laws and requirements that businesses grant leaves of absence to new parents.
 
What About the Economy?
 The other fights will be over how to divide the existing pie -- whether, for example, to spend transportation money on highways or mass transit; whether to concentrate student aid on the poor or give smaller amounts to many more college students, including those from middle-income families; whether to withhold Medicare benefits from affluent elderly people so as to avoid cutbacks elsewhere.
Thus, the Government will continue to spend resources on the basis of priorities that were set years ago. Few policy makers starting from scratch now, for instance, would devote such a large share of the budget to the elderly and such a small share to children. Changes in the rules are unlikely unless the economy performs much worse than expected.
"The biggest imponderable is the timing and nature of the economic turnaround," said Michael J. Boskin, chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers. Like most other economists, he is predicting an end to the recession by this summer.
But economic forecasts are often wrong. If the economy does considerably worse than expected, pressure will develop for tax cuts and spending increases to counter the recession, what Mr. Boskin called "a frontal assault on the budget."
 
What Bush Wants
 For his part, Mr. Bush has a limited domestic agenda. A middle-level White House assistant said he perceived a deliberate political strategy to "lower expectations."
"If we promise too much or ask for too much and fail, people will hold it against us," said the aide, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified. "But if people expect little and we accomplish something, it will be very much to our advantage."
In his victory speech to Congress on March 6, the President mentioned only two domestic proposals, legislation on crime control and highways, and called on Congress to enact them in 100 days. Few people in the capital think that will happen.
The President's crime bill is essentially the same one Congress rejected last year. It would expand the number of Federal crimes punishable by death, limit appeals by inmates on death row and permit the use in court of illegally obtained evidence if the police acted in good faith. Republicans like the way it allows them to portray the Democratic opponents as soft on crime.
The transportation bill would provide $105 billion over the next five years, holding spending slightly below what would be needed to keep pace with inflation. It would increase state governments' share of highway construction costs, limit direct Federal spending on mass transit and give state officials more leeway to transfer highway funds into mass transit. Democrats plan to rewrite the measure to restore transit money and spread the pork barrel.
 
The Democratic Agenda
 The Democratic agenda is no less driven by politics and hardly bolder than the Administration's. In some cases, they are counterpunching. Mr. Bush proposes capital punishment; the Democrats counter with gun control. The President proposes to cut the capital gains tax; the Democrats fire back with a surtax on incomes over $1 million.
And in a step opposed by nearly every economist outside of organized labor, from the most liberal to the most conservative, the Democrats plan to press this year for further trade restrictions, perhaps blocking a free trade agreement with Mexico or requiring the President to retaliate against Japanese trade practices. They hope, no doubt, with the 1992 election approaching, to position themselves on the side of American workers and to make President Bush appear to be soft on Japan.

HEADLINE: Some Veterans Fear Reopening Psychic Wounds

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MENLO PARK, Calif., March 15

 BODY:
Bill Soares returned unheralded from Vietnam 22 years ago and began a tortured slide into cocaine addiction, marital discord and chronic unemployment.
Now, Mr. Soares and his fellow patients at a psychiatric hospital here for the victims of combat stress have been invited to a celebration, in the nearby community of Millbrae, to honor those who served in the Persian Gulf. 
 They will not be going.
The invitation was turned down by Fred D. Gusman, the founder and director of the National Center for Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder, the model for 20 such in-patient programs at Veterans Affairs medical centers across the country, most of them full to overflowing with the psychiatric casualties of the Vietnam conflict, America's most unpopular war.
"Everyone will be too preoccupied with the Desert Storm people, and it will raise sad memories," said Mr. Gusman, a social worker. "The fact that we've had a military success doesn't mean everyone is healed."
 
Some Lessons Learned
 Mr. Gusman's task these days is a complicated one: preparing to treat the new victims of post-traumatic stress disorder now that the Persian Gulf war has ended, and continuing to nurture the 100 men in his care whose old hurts have been revisited.
A national study found that 15 percent of Vietnam veterans suffer serious combat stress, and experts expect a smaller percentage among the Persian Gulf troops, in large measure because of military and political lessons learned in the Vietnam War and psychiatric lessons learned afterward.
The gulf war was far briefer and less bloody than Vietnam, and ended with a clear victory and an exuberant welcome home. In addition, in the intervening years between Vietnam and the gulf war post-traumatic stress disorder has been recognized as a psychiatric illness, thus making it likely the latest victims will be diagnosed early and will get the best care available.
"Because of what happened to the Vietnam veteran, something different is happening today," said Joan Furey, an Army nurse in Vietnam and the associate director at the Menlo Park program, which was the first of its kind when it opened in 1978.
 
Unflattering Comparisons
 The patients in Menlo Park, on the penisula south of San Francisco, share the nation's postwar euphoria and are proud that their experience has improved the odds for the soldiers that followed them. But they are also racked by the unflattering comparisons being made to the Vietnam War, a long and losing effort that for many veterans brought nightmares and failed marriages rather than yellow ribbons and parades.
Like others here, Mr. Soares is awash in those contradictory emotions. "It brings a pride to see these soldiers treated the way we wanted to be treated and not dropped off on the street corner by the bus," he said. "But it's hard to get rid of 20 years of pain, misdirection and agony. The wounds heal but the scars remain."
In some ways, during the Persian Gulf war life went on as usual at the hospital here, where the walls are hung with combat photographs and maps of Southeast Asia and the book shelves bulge with medical dictionaries, Alcoholics Anonymous manuals and Vietnam retrospectives. Therapy groups continued from morning to night, new patients arrived and others graduated, and men pushed their wheelchairs into the courtyard for cigarette breaks.
But television privleges were expanded from weekends-only to several times a day, Dan Rather came to visit and report, and the patients watched current events unfold through the lense of personal history.
Like Americans elsewhere, some were for the war and others against it; some were angry and others sad. Many were disheartened that the nation would choose to fight yet another foreign war. Others longed to relive the adrenaline surge that combat brings, and had to resist the urge to enlist.
 
Studies on Stress Disorder
 When the ground war was delayed from mid-January until the end of February, the men here were jumpy with anticipation, as if the wait was their own. And when victory came, with a rush of praise for an all-volunteer force that was sober, chaste and efficient, some were insulted at the implication that the Vietnam-era soldiers did not have the right stuff.
Their war produced the research and literature on post-traumatic stress disorder that will shape treatment for years to come. A national study in 1988, done by the Research Triangle Institute in North Carolina, found that of the 3.1 million Americans who served in combat zones in Vietnam from 1964 to 1973, 15 percent, or 479,000, suffer from the disorder. Another 11 percent, or 350,000 more, suffer a partial form of post-traumatic stress disorder, less intense but warranting professional attention.
Other studies have painted a grim picture of how the Vietnam era combat veterans have fared. One-fourth of them were arrested within two years of discharge, and 200,000 are thought to be addicted to drugs or alchohal. Their divorce rate is twice that of the general population and their suicide rate 23 percent higher. Among the nation's homeless, one-third are said to be veterans of the Vietnam War.
 
Some Hesitant Predictions
 Mr. Gusman and Ms. Furey offered a few hesitant predictions about who among the Persian Gulf veterans is most likely to suffer post-traumatic stress disorder. They were careful to note that war zone stress is most common but not limited to those with the longest and most intense exposure to the sights and sounds of combat.
At special risk, they said, were the prisoners of war, the seriously wounded and the people who saw the most bloodshed. They also mentioned members of the National Guard and the Reserves, whose lives were most disrupted by the hostilities and who do not return to a military community, but rather to ordinary jobs and more indifferent neighbors.
Mr. Gusman, Ms. Furey and other experts noted that quick diagnosis of war-related stress lessens the severity of the illness because dysfunction is not heaped upon dysfunction. By the time Mr. Soares entered the hospital last December, for example, he was addicted to cocaine, had been married and divorced four times and was so disruptive that he could no longer find work as a furniture-maker.
With patients like these, "we're not really treating the person who came home from Vietnam," said Mr. Gusman. "We're treating a 40-year-old who has had a lifetime of experiences since then. The longer they wait to get help the more ingrained they are in coping styles that are destructive."
As Mr. Soares prepared for discharge from the hospital later this month, he said he had one bit of advice to offer the soldiers returning from the Persian Gulf so they can save all the time that he has lost. "If you feel anything change within yourself," he said, "go ask for help -- fast."

"The wounds heal but the scars remain," said Bill Soares. (Terrence McCarthy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER PRICES INCREASE, RAISING FEAR OF INFLATION

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
In the second recent dose of surprisingly high inflation figures, the Labor Department reported today that the Consumer Price Index rose two-tenths of 1 percent in February but that when price gyrations in energy and food are eliminated there was a jump of seven-tenths of 1 percent.
This surge in so-called core inflation at the retail level, which followed Friday's report of a substantial increase in prices paid to producers, dismayed economists and drove interest rates up again. It also contributed to a big drop in the stock market, where the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 62.13 points, the biggest loss in five months. [Pages D1 and D16.] 
 Many analysts and market participants have concluded that the Federal Reserve is now likely to be worried enough about inflation to defer for perhaps weeks further steps to fight the recession through an easier monetary policy. They generally disregarded the favorable overall consumer index figure today since it included a 4 percent drop in energy that resulted mainly from allied successes in the Persian Gulf war after a sharp price runup.
 
Same 5.4 Percent Pace
 Business downturns are generally expected to curb inflation, but analysts find little evidence of this so far, with overall consumer prices rising at the same 5.4 percent pace during the six months ended in February and the six months ended last August.
"There seems to be very little progress" against inflation in this recession, said Brian M. Jones, an economist at Salomon Brothers. He added that the Federal Reserve would almost certainly not act further to spur the economy until March job data are published on April 5 and might not move until it sees whether inflation subsides in reports due a week after that.
Perhaps further encouraging the Fed to wait and see was a Commerce Department report today showing that housing starts jumped 16.4 percent last month above the severely depressed January level. Permits for future construction rose 9 percent.
These were taken as additional early signs that the recession may be approaching its nadir.
Last Friday the Government reported that while prices paid to American producers fell six-tenths of 1 percent last month, the rate excluding food and energy rose an unsettling four-tenths of 1 percent.
"The Fed cannot ease again until the inflation news gets better, and by then the economy should be showing signs of improvement," said Robert T. McGee, chief economist for the Tokai Bank in New York.
The Consumer Price Index's overall advance of two-tenths of 1 percent was only half as much as in January but the index was held in check by a huge decline, 4 percent, in the price of energy. The price of oil had risen sharply after Iraq invaded Kuwait in early August, reaching $40 a barrel in October, but it has retreated to just above $20, near the prewar level, after the allied successes in the war.
Food, which is also subject to wide monthly swings, also contributed to the moderation by falling after a substantial January increase.
"You have got to be concerned" about the core rate, which has run at a 7.7 percent annual pace during the latest three months, said Kathryn L. Kobe, an analyst at Joel Popkin & Company, a consultant specializing in price and wage data. That compares with a 3.9 percent pace for consumer prices overall from December through February.
While some price gains last month, like a 16.1 percent rise in postal rates, will have only a temporary effect on the index, analysts said that increases were relatively widespread and that upward pressure on prices seemed likely to continue. For example, services, which account for nearly 55 percent of the index and whose prices tend to be less restrained by recession or official anti-inflation measures, rose five-tenths of 1 percent last month.
Fresh increases in the cost of apparel, out-of-town lodging and alcoholic beverages combined with the postal increases to account for about 40 percent of the overall February rise, the Labor Department said.
Among the seven major subindexes, food and beverages rose two-tenths of 1 percent, with a two-tenths of 1 percent drop in food more than offset by a second straight increase in alcoholic beverages. The latter's 3.1 percent jump resulted in part from higher Federal excise taxes that took effect Jan. 1 but that, because of bimonthly surveying in all but the five biggest metropolitan areas, were not entirely captured in January.
 
1.1 Percent Poultry Increase
 Grocery-store food prices fell five-tenths of 1 percent, with lower prices for beef, pork, fish, seafood and eggs only partly offset by a 1.1 percent rise for poultry. Fruits and vegetables, which were mainly responsible for a hefty January increase in food prices, fell 2.3 percent last month.
Housing rose five-tenths of 1 percent, a moderation that reflected a sharp decline for household fuels and other utilities coupled with a smaller increase in the cost of shelter itself. But household furnishings and operations posted a 1.3 percent increase, its biggest since January 1976, with nearly half this rise reflecting postal rates. An eight-tenths of 1 percent increase in renters' costs largely reflected another greater than seasonal rise in prices at vacation resorts that baffled Labor Department officials.
Apparel jumped 1.6 percent, a second straight hefty increase accounted for mainly by an earlier than usual introduction of spring lines.
The Consumer Price Index for all urban consumers now stands at 134.8 -- 34 percent above its 1982-84 average and 5.3 percent above its level of February 1990. Before rounding, the increase last month was 0.2225519 percent, or 2.7 percent at a compounded annual rate. The index covering urban wage earners and clerical workers rose one-tenth of 1 percent overall and seven-tenths of 1 percent without food and energy.

HEADLINE: TAPE FOREVER TIES VICTIM TO BEATING

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 19

 BODY:
Rodney G. King, whose beating at the hands of Los Angeles police officers on March 3 may long be linked in the public's minds to police brutality, is being described by friends and relatives as quiet and gentle.
Yet Mr. King, a 25-year-old high school dropout, pleaded guilty 13 months ago to robbing a grocer of $200. Mr. King, who wielded a tire iron during the robbery, was sentenced to two years in jail and was released on parole in December. 
 Two years ago he was convicted on a misdemeanor charge of disorderly conduct for soliciting a prostitute. He paid a $352 fine and was placed on probation for one year.
 
$1 Million for Each Blow
 Today a lawyer for Mr. King said Mr. King would seek a $56 million legal award for the beating, videotaped by a witness who was nearby. The lawyer, Steven Lerman, said the figure represented $1 million for each blow struck by the police officers. Mr. Lerman said at a news conference that Mr. King, who remains hospitalized with extensive injuries suffered in the beating, is still afraid that police officers might come after him again.
"I fear the police," Mr. Lerman quoted Mr. King as saying. Mr. King's lawyers have declined all requests to interview him since March 6, when Mr. King held a brief news conference.
In the aftermath of the beating of Mr. King, who is black, by a group of white police officers, a police sergeant and three officers have been indicted, and a Federal investigation of police brutality around the nation has begun.
Mr. King had initially said he did not consider the incident racially motivated. But asked today if Mr. King now believed race was a factor in the incident, Mr. Lerman quoted Mr. King as saying: "I'm scared to say that. I don't want to start a riot."
Mr. Lerman said he planned to file lawsuits on Mr. King's behalf in county and Federal courts.
 
A Model Worker
 Mr. King was unemployed at the time of the beating, but said he had a construction job lined up, and a former employer described him as a model worker.
Mr. King is married. He and his wife, Crystal, live with their two young children and some of Mrs. King's relatives in a neatly tended house on a palm-lined street in Altadena, 10 miles northeast of downtown Los Angeles.
Mr. King's friends and family say he is not violent or menacing, despite his criminal record. After pleading guilty in the robbery case last year, he wrote to the judge in June seeking to have his sentence reduced.
"Give me another chance, your honor," Mr. King's letter said. "I have a good job and I have two fine kid who wish me home. I have so much at stake to lose if I don't get that chance. My job and my family awaits me so please reconsider your judgment, your honor. The sky my witness and God knows."
A relative who answered the door at Mr. King's home today said he is kind.
"All I can say is that he is a very nice guy," said the relative, who declined to identify herself. "He's always willing to help around the house."
 
Mr. King's Injuries
 Mr. King remains hospitalized, recovering from what his doctors said were nine skull fractures, a shattered eye socket and cheekbone, a broken leg, a concussion, injuries to both knees and nerve damage that left his face partly paralyzed.
Mr. King has spoken publicly only once since the beating. At the brief news conference three days after the incident, Mr. King -- his face bruised, an eye swollen half closed and a leg in a cast -- said he had done nothing to provoke the beating.
"I was scared," he said. "I was scared for my life. So I laid down real calmly and took it like a man."
The opening seconds of the videotape of the incident show Mr. King jumping up and trying to spin away from the police officers, but it is unclear whether he had been beaten before then. The videotape does not show any evidence that Mr. King resisted attempts by the police to handcuff and arrest him.
Mr. King denied the contention of the police that he was stopped after a high-speed chase, although he acknowledged that he might have been speeding "a little bit." The police said they do not plan to file any charges against Mr. King in the case.
 
No Other Trouble
 Parole officers said Mr. King had not been in any trouble since being released from jail in December.
Mr. King has not given a public account of where he and his two passengers, Bryant Allen and Freddie Helms, were going the night of the beating. John C. Burton, a lawyer for Mr. Allen, said the three men were longtime friends and that they had gone for a drive, perhaps to a park where Mr. King used to go with his father. Mr. Burton said he did not know where the park was.
Mr. Allen and Mr. Helms have declined to be interviewed.
The robbery committed by Mr. King occurred in November 1989 in Monterey Park, a predominantly Asian community east of downtown Los Angeles. According to testimony at a court hearing and an interview with Tae Suck Baik, the victim, Mr. King walked into the store and asked if it accepted food stamps.
When told that it did, Mr. King bought gum, then pulled a tire iron from under his jacket, told Mr. Baik to open the cash register and reached in to take the cash. When Mr. King reached for some checks in the register, Mr. Baik grabbed his arm, and the two men began fighting. Mr. Baik picked up a small metal rod and hit Mr. King several times. Mr. King hit Mr. Baik with a small bread rack, but did not swing the tire iron.
Mr. King ran out of the store, jumped into his white Hyundai -- the same one he was driving the night of the beating -- and sped away. Mr. Baik wrote down the license plate number.
A week later the police searched Mr. King's car and found a check from Mr. Baik's store. Mr. King was arrested, and he pleaded guilty three months later.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH
