HEADLINE: Movie Producers and New York Unions Reach an Accord

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS

 BODY:
Negotiators for a consortium of Hollywood producers and two New York unions reached a tentative settlement yesterday that would end a 19-week stalemate that had virtually shut down moviemaking in New York City, a vital part of the city's economy.
The unions, representing production crafts workers and cinematographers, agreed to the studios' demands for money-saving work-rule changes that would reduce overtime and weekend pay. 
 In return, the unions won substantial increases in health and pension benefits. While ratification is likely, some rank-and-file members said the loss of the overtime made approval less than certain. The unions will vote on the agreement by mail ballot within the next month.
Mayor David N. Dinkins said he was thrilled to learn of the tentative settlement with the unions, Local 52 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators and Local 644 of the International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries. Together, the two unions have nearly 3,500 members. The agreement was reached in Sherman Oaks, Calif., where the international alliance has its headquarters.
The producers are Columbia Pictures, the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Paramount Pictures, Warner Brothers and <biMGM-United Artists. Orion Pictures also participated as a distributor.
Jaynne C. Keyes, the director of the city's Office of Film, Theatre and Broadcasting, said the city had been pressing for a settlement. But while the Mayor had talked with producers who visited New York and had offered to mediate, City Hall did not in the end appear to play a large role in the accord.
If the unions' memberships ratify the agreement, production could resume by May, Ms. Keyes said. City officials were worried that a prolonged boycott would hurt the city's economy. Moviemaking is estimated to generate between $500 million and $3 billion in fees to the city and in jobs for everyone from actors and camera operators to caterers who feed them between scenes. Some caterers say they have had to lay off workers since the boycott began, and some crafts-services workers like prop makers and electricians have left for cities where there are more opportunities.
But it is hard to quantify the total cost of the filmmaking boycott. Winter is normally a slow time for moviemaking in New York, and this winter has been even slower. The city has granted 25 feature film permits this year, compared with 33 at this time last year, Ms. Keyes said.
To city officials, the larger concern was that movie production has to be scheduled months before the cameras roll. So the city stood to lose a large chunk of business for 1991 unless the two sides came to terms before the warm weather, the prime time for outdoor shooting.
Local 52, which has 1,950 members, provides the sound people, electricians, shop craftsmen, prop people, camera grips and set dressers for the city's film productions. Local 644 has 1,500 members, all cinematographers.
The obstacles in the talks had been about parity between the New York locals and those on the West Coast.
The producers had said they would steer films away from New York City until an agreement was reached. The unions offered to continue working without a contract during the negotiations, but most major producers chose to go elsewhere. One exception was Woody Allen's newest movie project, which went into production in New York under a deal with the unions.
 
Concessions on Night Work
 The new agreement permits the producers to schedule workers for any five consecutive days without having to pay overtime if shooting happens to take place on a Saturday or Sunday, as was the case before. Producers would also be permitted to change the days of an employee's work week once during a shooting without penalty. This follows the pattern of an agreement with the Directors Guild of America.
The agreement also allows for a later daily shooting schedule. Filming would now start as late as 6 P.M. from May 1 to Sept. 31 and at 3 P.M. the rest of the year. Overtime pay, at time and a half, could be collected after eight hours on the job. Overtime pay would go up to double time after 14 hours on the job. Previously, all overtime was at double the hourly wage.
The new terms would mean considerable savings for producers who shoot at night, as most of them do.
Louis D'Agostino, business representative for Local 644, said that the agreement with the cinematographers was "very similar" to the settlement with Local 52. He said that his union had achieved a 65 percent increase in the producers' contributions for health benefits, and that the producers' increased contributions to the pension fund "would allow us to raise the benefit to the membership by 50 percent."
Neither side characterized the settlement as a victory. But some union members suggested that by giving up large amounts of overtime, they would ultimately gain by working more days each year, assuming that production increases in the city.
 
No Share in Residuals
 But the workers would not share residual earnings of films from supplemental markets, like videocassette rentals, a benefit that Local 52's sister locals on the West Coast have won.
Workers would receive a 4 percent pay increase in each of the three years of the contract. For Local 52, the producers would more than double their hourly contribution for health benefits -- from $2.39 to $5 -- and "significantly" increase pension contributions, a participant in the talks said.

GRAPHIC: Chart: 'The Agreement at a Glance'
 
The Unions:
 Local 52, International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees and Moving Picture Machine Operators of the United States and Canada; 1,950 members, including sound technicians, electricians, shop craftspeople, prop people, camera grips and set dressers; jurisdiction is New York City and Long Island.
 Local 644, International Photographers of the Motion Picture and Television Industries; 1,500 members; jurisdiction is the East Coast.
 
The Filmmakers:
 Columbia Pictures, the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation, Paramount Pictures, Warner Brothers, MGM-United Artists and Orion Pictures.
 
The Agreements:
 Local 52 -- Tentative agreement permits producers to use workers on any five consecutive days out of seven days, without overtime that was previously incurred for shooting on Saturday and Sunday. Producers permitted to change days of employees' work week once during the shoot.
 Agreement also allows for a later daily shooting schedule year round. Filming can start as late as 6 P.M. from May 1 to September 31, and at 3 P.M. the rest of the year, without overtime for the first eight hours. After eight hours, workers receive time and a half, instead of double time.
 Workers receive a 4-percent pay increase in each of the three years of the contract. Producers more than double hourly contribution for health benefits -- from $2.39 to $5 -- and "significantly" increase pension contributions.
 Local 644 -- Similar cost-cutting work rules to those agreed to by Local 52. The union achieves 65 percent increase in producer contributions for health benefits, and a 50 percent increase in contributions to the pension fund.
 The changes, to be voted on by unions in the next few weeks, apply only to productions requiring more than five days of shooting.
 
Chronology: "The Story of the Stalemate"
 Sept. 30, 1990 -- The contract between Hollywood producers and the 1,500 cinematographers of Local 644 expires.
 Oct. 31 -- The contract between Hollywood producers and the 1,950 production crafts workers of Local 52 expires.
 Nov. 1 -- Beginning on this day, no new contracts are signed to bring new feature films from five major Hollywood studios to New York City. The producers begin steering New York City-bound productions to other locations.
 Nov. 9 -- Production of the last major feature film made entirely in New York under the old contract, "The Super," begins. The film, about a grasping slumlord, stars Joe Pesce, Vincent Gardenia and Reuben Blades.
 Dec. 4 -- The producers make an offer to Local 644 that is rejected by 96 percent of its membership.
 Jan. 10, 1991 -- Members of Local 644 begin leafleting Manhattan theatergoers to inform them of the labor stalemate and to try to pressure the producers to continue negotiations.
 Jan. 23, 1991 -- The producers' head negotiator with Local 52, Joel Grossman, reports "progress" in negotiations, but says that negotiations are "at an impasse" with Local 644.
 Feb. 14 -- Three independent feature film productions sign contracts to film in New York City under a low-budget provisions designed by Local 644 to bring more filmmaking to the city.
 March 19 -- Tentative agreement between the negotiators for the two unions and the Hollywood producers is announced. Ratification by mail ballot by the union members is exected to be completed in one month. (pg. B5)

HEADLINE: Miramax Films Goes Up Against the Big Guns

BYLINE: By RICHARD BERNSTEIN

 BODY:
Late last year, when the big Hollywood studios were coming out with such blockbuster movies as "Bonfire of the Vanities" and "The Godfather Part III," Miramax Films released "The Long Walk Home, " a small, intimate story set against the Montgomery bus boycott of 1955, starring Cissy Spacek and Whoopi Goldberg. Then Miramax watched, chagrined, as one of its favorite films got lost amid the heavy competition.
"There was a meeting of the staff to talk about the films we had going," said Harvey Weinstein, one of two brothers from Queens who started Miramax 11 years ago. "When somebody suggested that maybe the economics of 'Long Walk Home' were so bad we should drop it, 12 people, including my brother and me, threatened to resign if we did." 
 "I think that tells you how we feel about our movies," Mr. Weinstein said.
The story of a small, serious, commercially unspectacular, not-very-successful film dovetails at this point with the story of an ever more prominent film distribution company. "The Long Walk Home," uninteresting to the big studios and not destined for a mass market, is the sort of production Miramax tends to acquire and to promote, often with remarkable critical and commercial success. Among its more striking successes have been "Sex, Lies and Videotape," "My Left Foot," "Cinema Paradiso" and, most recently, "The Grifters," a list that has made Miramax a star distributor, the darling of the world of unusual, sometimes experimental films, a company with a reputation for boldness, creative marketing and a willingness to take risks.
 
For the Underdog
 "Miramax are real street fighters," Richard Pearce, the director of "Long Walk Home," said in a telephone interview from Los Angeles. "They love to take on the underdog, fight the big guys."
The company is also known forunusual gestures, and it is making one with "The Long Walk Home." The film portrays two families, one black and one white, during the Montgomery, Ala., anti-segregation campaign that was led by the young Martin Luther King Jr. and that is widely considered the start of the civil rights movement in the South.
Despite the film's poor commercial performance, everyone at Miramax loves it, the Weinsteins say, and they reject accusations of historical innacuracy. They insist that it deals with an important topic and that audiences should have the chance to see movies that are not high-tech spectaculars or fantasy-fulfilling romances. And so, in a move that goes contrary to all conventional wisdom in the movie business, Miramax decided to pull "Long Walk Home" temporarily from the theaters, launch a new publicity campaign, and finally to open it a second time, which they are doing in some 15 to 20 cities on Friday.
"It's a real classic Weinstein move," Mr. Pearce said. "You never know what they are going to do next."
 
Important Intermediaries
 Though generally unnoticed by the moviegoing population, film distributors are the intermediaries between the viewers and the movie theaters. But as one Miramax client, Shirley Sun, the producer and director of "Iron and Silk," puts it, distributors are becoming ever more the key figures for independent film makers and foreign producers.
"It's actually more difficult these days to get a film distributed than it is to get a film made," she said.
In a world where there are fewer and fewer theaters devoted to what used to be called "art" films, distribution has become increasingly difficult in recent years. That is where Miramax and a few other small companies come in, most commonly acquiring the rights to a movie by paying its producer a guarantee against future receipts from ticket sales. Miramax's revenues were estimated by Forbes last year to be $55 million, making it probably the biggest of the independent distributors. New Line Cinema , which made big profits from "Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles" last year, and Orion Classics , which specializes in foreign films, are its two biggest competitors.
 
Several Big Winners
 In addition to such sensational finds as "Sex, Lies and Videotape" and "My Left Foot," which the company spotted at film festivals, Miramax has distributed several other big winners, including, characteristically, a few that other distributors were unwilling to take on. Among them were Errol Morris's documentary "The Thin Blue Line," Pedro Almodovar's "Tie Me Up, Tie Me Down" and Peter Greenaway's "The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover," the last two the sort of sexually daring foreign films viewed as high-risk products in the movie business. Among the company's current releases are "Iron and Silk," "Mr. and Mrs. Bridge," "The Nasty Girl" and "Ay, Carmela."
"Bob saw 'The Cook, the Thief,' at the Toronto Film Festival," Harvey Weinstein said, "and he noticed that maybe some 60 or 70 people at a certain point just got up and walked out of the theater." "Then he calls me and says that he loved it and I said: 'Are you crazy? Why would you buy a film that people are walking out of?' But then Bob described it and it was clear that the artistry was there and the uniqueness was there."
How do two guys who are not rich, not connected and not experienced get started in one of the world's most difficult and tightly controlled businesses? This part of the story begins with Harvey and Bob Weinstein, both lovers of Truffaut, Bunuel, Fellini and other cinematic giants, producing rock concerts during their student days at the University of Buffalo and finding themselves in control of a movie house, where they started putting on second- and third-run features costing $50 or $100, which they could afford.
"Then we decided to expand and we went to Cannes," Harvey Weinstein, the elder brother, said. They financed the trip from the proceeds of their college music-producing business.
 
Creative Cutting
 Mr. Weinstein says that he and his brother, who knew only each other in Cannes, quickly discovered that all the commercially interesting films were taken. But they found "The Secret Policeman's Ball," the film of a benefit concert for Amnesty International. It had no takers, so the Weinsteins bought it, cut it in half and joined it with a sequel called "The Secret Policeman's Other Ball," with performances by Monty Python, Sting, Phil Collins and Bob Geldof.
"The two films together became a big art-house hit," Harvey Weinstein said. The brothers and Miramax were, financially speaking, on their way, and now, ll years later, they are movers and shakers. They stay at the Beverly Hills Hotel when they are on the West Coast, and when they go to Cannes for the festival, they have a suite at the Hotel Majestic. But, they say, their basic philosophy has remained the same, and they illustrate that claim with their recent efforts on behalf of "The Long Walk Home."
"I love this movie," the elder Mr. Weinstein said. "It doesn't have sex and violence or any cutting-edge ingredients. It's a picture with a good director, good actors, and it makes you feel good about this country."
"This effort," he said, speaking of the company's plans to give "Long Walk Home" another shot at attracting an audience, "is for everybody who strikes out one time and needs another chance. And if Miramax means anything, its epitaph would be that this was the place that wasn't afraid to break the rules."

HEADLINE: Books of The Times;
Recounting the Lowlights of the Reagan Years

BYLINE: By HERBERT MITGANG

 BODY:

Sleepwalking Through History
America in the Reagan Years
By Haynes Johnson
Illustrated. 524 pages. W. W. Norton . $24.95.
The half-remembered personalities who ruled the airwaves during the Reagan Presidency, some of whom managed to stay out of jail, now appear in a stinging indictment that resembles a cartoon history of the United States in the 1980's as drawn by Herblock in The Washington Post: 
 Jim and Tammy Faye Bakker. Ivan F. Boesky. Michael K. Deaver. Jerry Falwell. Jessica Hahn and Fawn Hall (one posed topless, the other shredded government documents, but which was which?). Arthur B. Laffer. Dennis B. Levine. Edwin Meese 3d. Michael R. Milken. Lyn Nofziger. Oliver L. North. John M. Poindexter. Oral Roberts. Richard V. Secord. Jimmy Swaggart. Donald J. Trump. E. Bob Wallach. Not to forget Nancy and Ronald Reagan, who dominated the scene.
All these real-life characters turn up as leading or featured players in "Sleepwalking Through History" by Haynes Johnson, a national affairs columnist for The Washington Post and a regular panelist on the television show "Washington Week in Review." What distinguishes this ambitious book as social history is that it uses the Reagan Presidency (Mr. Johnson throws in President Bush's succession to round out the decade) to describe what was happening while the Chief Executive and his spear carriers were, in Mr. Johnson's view, setting the highest standards of greed, immorality and deception.
From all this, Mr. Johnson draws a conclusion for today: that the country is now paying for the Reagan legacy with lowered ideals and a debtor economy. He writes: "Two types of problems typified the ethical misconduct cases of the Reagan years, and both had heavy consequences to citizens everywhere. One stemmed from ideology and deregulatory impulses run amok; the other from classic corruption on a grand scale."
Mr. Johnson draws up a long bill of particulars against the Reagan Administration. He discusses some of the major scandals that stained the popular President's record. All involved what he calls the age-old corruption "formed by the connection between money and politics." One of the cases concerned defense contractors in 12 states, initiating what the author says became "the biggest government procurement scandal in American history."
Some of President Reagan's closest California cronies, in positions of power in Washington, found themselves dodging subpoenas and copping pleas. Was their greed inspired by the President's own hunger for money? Mr. Johnson suggests that there is linkage between the public scandals and the President's private financial desires and his wife's extravagances. Mr. Johnson makes sure to mention that Mr. Reagan's mansion in Bel Air was bought and leased to him by his wealthy friends; that both he and his wife obtained multi-million-dollar book deals; that Mr. Reagan received $2 million for giving two speeches in Japan at the invitation of a Japanese conglomerate whose founder he had once favored with a photo opportunity in the Oval Office, and that it costs the Government $10 million annually for his security, more than double that of any other living former President.
A centerpiece of "Sleepwalking Through History" is, of course, the Iran-contra deception of Congress and the public. It is still fascinating and frightening to read about how a cabal of military and civilian officials ran a government sub rosa with the President's knowledge and winking approval.
Although Mr. Johnson's book was completed before the war in the Persian Gulf, it is doubly interesting to follow the Iran-contra money now. We read about President Reagan's national security advisers secretly soliciting a million dollars a month from the Saudis as a "humanitarian gesture" when Congressional money for the contras was about to run out.
The author notes that President Reagan, Vice President Bush, Secretary of State George P. Shultz and Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger were all told of the illegal Saudi arrangement. He writes:
"None of this was communicated, as solemnly pledged, to Congressional intelligence oversight committees. The omission was deliberate and made with full recognition by these highest U.S. officials, including the President, that such a deception could have the most grievous political consequences. Reagan himself and his top aides were well aware that public disclosure could result in impeachment proceedings against the President. They chose to proceed anyway."
Was President Reagan responsible for the growing power of the televangelists, the leveraged-buyout manipulators, the excesses of the new Gilded Age? All typified "a self-indulgent and imitative age when entertainers became public leaders and when celebrities, not pioneers, scientists or artists, became cultural heroes." Mr. Johnson does not say so specifically, but the reader cannot help thinking that by emphasizing the national sleepwalking during the Reagan Presidency, he attributes the inspiration for the worst of times to the Reagan White House.
"Sleepwalking Through History" is an important addition to the growing shelf of works about the Reagan years because of its rich background information. It deserves a place just below Ronnie Dugger's "On Reagan: The Man and His Presidency" and Garry Wills's "Reagan's America: Innocents at Home," both of which are even harsher in their judgments of the President who brought Hollywood to the Potomac.

HEADLINE: Topics of The Times;
Saving on Paving

 BODY:
New York City's Planning Commission, the local community board and Claire Shulman, the Queens Borough President, have approved a Transportation Department plan to build a new asphalt plant in Long Island City, to be owned and operated by the city. So should the City Council Land Use Committee, when it takes up the issue today.
The city's private asphalt vendors have been lobbying hard to maintain their profitable hegemony over the city's asphalt supply. The proposed plant would supply city paving crews in Queens and upper Manhattan, reducing reliance on private vendors by up to 350,000 tons a year. A similar plant in Brooklyn produces asphalt for about $23 per ton, compared with the average $30 per ton charged by private vendors. When recycled asphalt and glass are mixed in, the savings are even greater. Lucius Riccio, the city's Transportation Commissioner, presents persuasive numbers showing that the new plant would also be a sound investment -- even with relatively high building costs.
The proposal and the economic slump have recently driven private asphalt prices to a more reasonable $25 a ton. A vote to approve the Queens site wouldn't commit the city to spend scarce capital to build the new plant if competitive long-term agreements with the private vendors can be reached. But it would, one way or another, assure more asphalt savings for New Yorkers.

HEADLINE: Abstract Arguments, Real Births

 BODY:
In the four months since the Food and Drug Administration approved the Norplant System, a five-year, reversible, low-dose contraceptive, there's been a lot of talk about how to coerce the young and poor into using it. The talk is abstract, way off target. The practical question for public debate is how to make Norplant available to every woman who chooses to use it.
Most poor women are as eager as the more affluent to avoid unintended pregnancies. But they frequently lack access to or are suspicious of the most effective contraceptives. One consequence is that the abortion rate for women who are covered by Medicaid is three times that of women who are not. 
 The new Norplant System appears to be remarkably effective and relatively free of side effects. Six tiny tubes of progestin are implanted under the skin of a woman's upper arm, and the hormone is then slowly released into the body over five years. But lack of information and money may keep poor women from taking advantage of it.
A Norplant implant costs $350 and involves several visits to a doctor's office. That's a lot less than it costs to take the pill for five years. Even so, it's an unattainable fortune for a woman who lives in poverty. That's why it's imperative that Norplant be covered by Medicaid.
Wyeth-Ayerst Laboratories, which markets Norplant and is training 8,000 physicians in its use, has filed applications with all the state Medicaid organizations. Twelve, among them New York's, have agreed to coverage, and several others are expected to. The remainder, some of which are balking at the cost, would be wise to do so.
The long-run savings for the Medicaid program -- in expenses for unintended pregnancies and state-funded abortions -- are obvious. But it is humanity, not economy, that should compel the states to help poor women obtain Norplant. Just as this country is trying to insure that all America's babies are born equal, so it should insure that all America's women have an equal chance to make reproductive choices.

HEADLINE: FOREIGN AFFAIRS;
A Unified, Weak Iraq

BYLINE: By Leslie H. Gelb

 BODY:
President Bush's central postwar strategic objective has been to keep Iraq whole and relatively insulated from regional vultures, even if it required a delay in Saddam Hussein's departure.
 But Mr. Bush is now getting caught up in Iraq's civil war, in protecting the rebels from Baghdad, and he is losing his strategic focus. He thus runs the risk of the rebels -- who are backed by secret deliveries of arms and money by Iran, Turkey, Syria and Saudi Arabia -- transforming Iraq into a second Lebanon. 
 The happiest outcome, of course, would be for the Iraqi opposition (the Kurds, Shiites, Sunnis, Assyrian Christians and exiled democrats) to patch up their historical hatreds and form a harmonious democratic government in Baghdad. But this is a pipe dream whose pursuit will guarantee Iraq's fragmentation, not its democratization.
 The real choice is between Lebanonization and this: a united Iraq with a weakened central government run by some of Saddam's cohorts. The second is the lesser evil for Iraqis and Americans.
 Mr. Bush does not have much power to bring about the lesser-evil solution, but he can make a difference. He can stress to Iraqi military leaders that he favors a united Iraq and the restoration of order as long as they avoid their traditional brutality. He also can tell our coalition partners and Iran to butt out of the civil war. Once they taste blood and oil, there will be no containing their ambitions.
 Mr. Bush was firmly on the right course until the fighting ended two weeks ago. Then, with the Iraqi Army killing rebels in the streets, he sent out confusing signals.
 He warned Baghdad against using chemical weapons on the insurgents, and stopped Iraqi forces from using helicopters and moving fixed-wing aircraft. The impulse here was a good one -- to give Iraqi forces second thoughts about mass killings.
 But the warnings also sent the wrong signal to Iraq's neighbors about U.S. intentions. They thought Mr. Bush was altering course and favoring Iraq's breakup.
 Iran rushed into the opening and supplied small arms to its brothers, the Shiite fundamentalists, in southern Iraq. Turkey dispatched arms to the Kurds in the north, a surprise move given Ankara's usual opposition to Kurdish separatism. Saudi Arabia offered cash to a diverse and untenable new group based in Beirut and Damascus. Syria reached out secretly to its few hidden contacts in Iraq's ruling Baath Party.
 Secretary of State Baker only made matters worse on Sunday. Though he said the U.S. was not secretly providing arms to rebels, he hinted at other covert aid (which Administration officials later denied).
 Washington has to say a clear no to any effort by Iraq's neighbors to pour in arms and exploit the civil war. According to U.S. intelligence experts, more arms for the rebels will not produce their victory. At the most, the rebels can be expected to hold off the Iraqi Army -- and turn their country into fiefs rivaling their tragic brother Arabs in Lebanon.
 Separatism surely sounds sweet to peoples long terrorized by Baghdad and Saddam. But replaying the Lebanese experience would be a nightmare of at least equal proportions. Outside powers would prey on the chaos. The next war and the next eruption of Islamic fundamentalism would be waiting around the corner, with Iraq, Saudi Arabia and the whole Persian Gulf at high risk.
 There is hope for another way if Mr. Bush will focus again, and hard, on preserving one Iraq. That means not destroying the only centralizing forces in the country -- Saddam's Baath Party and the military. It means that holding Iraq together should take priority over Saddam's fast ouster. He can, must and will be removed by economic pressure, later.
 His likely successors, Baath Party and military leaders, will be enervated and beleaguered. Mr. Bush can use that vulnerability to wrest concessions on constitutional reforms and greater local autonomy for the Kurds. Deserved Kurdish autonomy will be more secure if granted by a debilitated Baghdad than if the Kurds have to fight for it every day. Full independence for Kurds would mean independence for the Shiites, and that is not a healthy trade-off.
 Few want to see Saddam remain in power a minute longer than necessary, or see bad guys succeed him in Baghdad. But a unified Iraq with a weak central government may represent the only chance for its people to be at peace with each other and with their neighbors.

HEADLINE: On Not Going Into Engineering Today

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Trying to Fill the Shortage of Engineers" (Careers, Feb. 26) amused me because it was the same sad tale I heard when I was an undergraduate engineering student in the mid-1960's. After 25 years in the engineering profession, I still don't believe it. 
 I suspect that the shortage tale is perpetuated by people like James A. Sawyer, president of the American Society of Civil Engineers (of which I am a member), but also chief operating officer of a large engineering company. It is in the best interest of employers of large numbers of engineers to have a big supply available. Supply and demand, simple economics: the more engineers available, the lower the average salary.
I believe that the real reason there may be a shortage of engineers, if there is one, has to do with what the profession lacks: high salary, compared with other professions, and high prestige. For the many long and extremely difficult years of rigorous education and training required to become a professional engineer, the average salary pales compared with that of a lawyer, investment banker and many other professionals.
And as for the prestige of the profession, you quote the head of a university civil engineering department saying, "There is a lot of civil engineering activity now in two areas, transportation . . . and the environment." On all levels of government how many heads of departments of transportation or environment are engineers, and how many are lawyers, business people or politicians?
If I were starting out today and wanted to make a significant contribution in either transportation, the environment or the infrastructure, in general, I think I'd go to law school, business school or into politics -- not engineering!
 
DAVID W. JACOBS
Niantic, Conn., March 6, 1991

HEADLINE: South Miami Schools Don't Want to Return to Earlier System;
Causes or Results?

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Injustice Taints the 'Just War' " (Op-Ed, March 2), which has the subheading "Blacks see a double standard," Richard Joseph refers among other complaints to "disgraceful public schools." 
 For the last 16 years I have been teaching in the same New York City high school. I recall that just 10 years ago, one of my students asked my advice about whether he should go to Yale or Harvard. He had been accepted by both.
This semester, I have a senior economics class again, in which one student explained her recent absence because her son was sick. Another young female pupil was absent for several days because both of her children were ill. A third sent me a note to let me know that she went in to early labor and would not return for several weeks.
Just two days ago I reprimanded a student in the same class because she wandered into the classroom five minutes after the late bell had rung. Her reply was: "This is not a job. I can come in when I please."
Are these situations the causes or are these the results of "disgraceful schools"?
 
SIDNEY G. ADLER
Lawrence, L.I., March 3, 1991

HEADLINE: Israeli Army Chief, Stirring Furor, Suggests the Golan Is Expendable

BYLINE: By JOEL BRINKLEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, March 19

 BODY:
The army Chief of Staff, who retires in a month, said in remarks reported today that Israel might safely give up some occupied territories if the nation made satisfactory peace agreements with its Arab neighbors.
The remarks by the officer, Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron, came after a series of public statements by Israeli Government officials apparently intending to reaffirm how intractably wedded Israel is to the Golan Heights, which were seized from Syria. General Shomron's remarks helped turned a hot debate into a public brawl. 
 Several Cabinet members quickly told the general to keep his views to himself. Some said he should immediately resign, even though he is so close to retirement. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon urged leaders of Jewish settlements in the occupied territories to redouble their efforts to build new housing there to affirm resistance to giving up the territories.
The political storm began Sunday, when Health Minister Ehud Olmert gave a speech in Washington. He offered a view that is heretic for a Likud party official by saying that Israel might be willing to discuss territorial issues with Syria. Israel captured the Golan Heights from Syria in the 1967 war, and Damascus demands its return as a condition for peace.
"We are ready to negotiate all of the issues," Mr. Olmert told the American Israel Public Affairs Committee, "all of the claims, all of the demands, including the territorial demands of the Syrians and our demands, and conclude peace between our two countries."
As the United States tries to move the nations of the Middle East to make peace, this country's position is that it wants to open talks with Arab countries without any conditions. To many in Washington, Mr. Olmert seemed to be offering only a logical extension of that position. But to Mr. Shamir and others in his Cabinet, Mr. Olmert's remarks smacked of betrayal.
"I am not happy with Olmert," said Mr. Shamir, who counts the Health Minister among his closest advisers. Other members of the governing coalition threatened to bring down the Cabinet unless Mr. Shamir repudiated Mr. Olmert's words.
He did, but then General Shomron offered his view in a briefing for Israeli military correspondents.
"A political arrangement, when it exists, is far more than just territory," he said. "It is linked to limiting weapons, supervision of one country over another. Thus if you are talking about nations at war, without a doubt territory has very great significance. But when you talk about these other arrangements, it is clear that these include various elements that diminish the threat of giving up territory and offer the possibility, for example, of long-range warning."
The statement was oblique, but more than enough to set off this Government.
The issue of the Golan remains a highly emotional one in Israel, where many still remember how, before 1967, Syrians shelled Israeli settlements from the highlands. But with the development and acuuisition of long-range missiles and Awacs reconnaissance planes, some military analysts have contended that a truly demilitarized Golan would have little strategic value.
 
Request, Then Refusal
 Mr. Shamir said on Monday that Israel was ready to talk to Syria without conditions.
"Syria has the right to ask us to withdraw from the Golan Heights," he continued. "If Syria does ask, we shall say we do not agree to withdraw."
Asked what would then be left to discuss, Mr. Shamir said: "We can talk about peace, about the ways of peace, about economic cooperation. There are many things. We say we are ready to negotiate unconditionally with all the Arab states -- nothing more than that."
Mr. Sharon then announced that his ministry had a major building program for new settlers on the Golan Heights.
"At the moment," he said, "we are in different states that range from preparations of infrastructure to actual construction of 1,200 housing units in the Golan Heights, and I intend to add the same number next year.
"There are 11,000 Jews on the Golan today," he added, "and we hope that next year the Jewish population there will be increased up to 20,000."
The statements made by Mr. Shamir and the others ended the weeklong hiatus on rightist public statements, a halt ordered by Mr. Shamir when Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d arrived in Jerusalem.
The statements reported today dealt also with topics other than the Golan Heights. Pressed by political rivals during a committee meeting in Parliament to say what he thought of Mr. Baker's meetings with Palestinian leaders in Jerusalem a week ago, the Prime Minister said he considered these people unfit for negotiations with Israel.
"They met him in the name of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to express the stand of the P.L.O.," the Prime Minister said. "We shall not talk to people from the P.L.O."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 21, 1991, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
A headline yesterday with the continuation of a front-page article about Israeli opinions on territories seized in the 1967 war referred imprecisely to remarks by the Israeli Army Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Dan Shomron. He spoke in general terms; he did not refer specifically to the Golan Heights.

HEADLINE: First Fidelity Recast for Future

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
When Anthony P. Terracciano was named chairman of First Fidelity Bancorporation a year ago, his goal was to recast the Newark-based bank much the way many experts predict the entire banking industry will have to change in coming years.
He has weeded out unnecessary operations, pared costs and payrolls, and focused the bank to serve a potentially lucrative niche in small-business and consumer lending. That kind of housecleaning is needed in almost every corner of the banking industry, experts say, and Mr. Terracciano's formula at First Fidelity is likely to be repeated in hundreds of regional banks around the nation. 
 For First Fidelity, New Jersey's biggest bank and the nation's 23d largest, Mr. Terracciano's cost-cutting program is a warm-up for the widely anticipated round of bank mergers that lies ahead.
"If we do this right," Mr. Terracciano said, First Fidelity, with $29.1 billion of assets, has a chance "to be a player when the consolidation of the industry accelerates."
 
Dramatic Turnaround
 So far, Mr. Terracciano seems to have led a dramatic turnaround at Fidelity, which was for sale shortly before he arrived in February 1990. On Monday, he got both a vote of confidence and capital from Banco Santander, a Spanish bank that agreed to invest $220 million for 9.5 million shares of First Fidelity common stock, or 13 percent of the company.
Banco Santander also agreed to acquire warrants to buy 9.5 million more shares, which would give First Fidelity another $242.4 million and a total stake for Banco Santander of 24.9 percent.
"We looked at some 80 banks in 38 states before deciding to invest in First Fidelity," said Emilio Boton, Santander's chairman.
The confidence shown by Banco Santander would have been unlikely three years ago, when First Fidelity merged with Fidelcor, Philadelphia's largest bank, only to discover that it had bought into a portfolio of troubled loans. Top executives from Fidelcor, who were expected to run the newly merged institution, departed, leaving the bank adrift with interim management.
But Mr. Terracciano arrived last year with a fast-track agenda and a track record that suggested he could bring it off. He had come from the Mellon Bank Corporation of Pittsburgh, where he guided a cost-cutting program that reduced expenses by more than 20 percent from 1987 to 1989. Earlier, he had spent 23 years at the Chase Manhattan Corporation, rising to head of global banking.
Mr. Terracciano describes himself as a "genetically programmed worrier" who is a hard-bitten executive not given to bonhomie. Poorly performing staffs are summoned to Mr. Terracciano's office, where meetings can be painful enough that "people don't really want to talk with me," he acknowledged.
To put First Fidelity among acquirers rather than the acquired, Mr. Terracciano has used the savings from cutting costs to build reserves to cover losses from bad loans. He has also bolstered the capital the company will need if it tries to make acquisitions.
The payroll has been cut by 22 percent through layoffs and attrition, to 10,500 employees, from 13,500 at the end of 1989. The bank hired the Electronic Data Systems Corporation to manage its expensive and inefficient computer center, a move that is one of the major parts of a program to save $115 million a year by the end of 1991.
In 1990, non-interest expenses, like rent, payroll and equipment, were reduced by $86 million, despite the one-time expenses of severance payments and the extraordinary cost of managing a growing number of foreclosed real estate properties.
 
Growth in Small Loans
 Eventually, growth is expected to come from consumer and small-business loans through a network of 550 branches in New Jersey and Eastern Pennsylvania. That, according to plan, will provide the capital for acquisitions.
"The new group at First Fidelity has done about as much as they can in terms of improving lending practices and controlling expenses," said Thomas Hanley, a Salomon Brothers banking analyst who expects the bank's profits to grow quickly when the economy improves. "Within another year or 18 months," he said, "there will probably be a major merger in which Terracciano comes out the winner."
In the last seven months, First Fidelity bought 57 branches with $3 billion of deposits from the failed City Federal Savings Bank of Bedminster, N.J., for less than $30 million. The customers at the savings bank branches do not include as many businesses as other branches, but they add to the base of low-cost deposits that has allowed First Fidility to sharply reduce the amount it borrows from large corporations, other banks and the Eurodollar market, all of which are more expensive sources of funds.
 
Return to Profitability
 So far, the plan has worked despite a weak economy. Although bad loans, particularly for commercial real estate, remain a serious drain on profits, First Fidelity returned to profitability in mid-1990 and earned $123.2 million in the second half of that year.
One reason for the rapid success in cutting expenses is that before Mr. Terraciano's arrival, First Fidelity was known as a company with a lot of fat. In the last half of the 1980's, for example, First Fidelity's non-interest expenses averaged about 65 percent of its income, compared with only 54.8 percent at rival Midlantic Banks Inc. of Edison, N.J.
One source of cost savings was eliminating separate computer systems at each of the company's eight banking subsidiaries. That system is being replaced by a centralized system, which will be based in Philadelphia and operated by Electronic Data Systems, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation.
 
Largest Outside Contract
 The bank's $450 million cost for the the 10-year agreement with Electronic Data is less than First Fidelity would have spent if it had handled the work itself. The Electronic Data pact makes First Fidelity the largest banking company to have hired an outside company to manage day-to-day data processing like preparation of monthly account statements.
A centralized computer system also helps the bank develop and introduce new services. With a more streamlined computer operation, in which 250 programs were reduced to 60, simple services like deducting interest payments on small business loans from the owner's personal checking account are easier to offer.
Allan R. DeCotiis, president of Payment Systems Inc., a bank advisory concern in Tampa, Fla., noted that most banks "are better off concentrating on developing their skills in marketing and building relationships with their customers, and leave the actual processing of transactions to specialists in that business."
 
Reorganized Lending Practices
 Lending activities have also been reorganized so that all parts of the company are now following the same standards in evaluating new loans. Real estate appraisals are done through a department separate from the loan officers, providing more objective measurement of risk.
"Before, we had situations where two of our banks were competing with each other for the same business and offering different terms," said Michael L. LaRusso, First Fidelity's executive vice president and head of the internal audit group.
Mr. LaRusso, previously a senior Federal examiner who has seen dozens of banks from the inside, spent much of his first year at First Fidelity sorting through the company's loans to identify the trouble spots. That resulted in a $150.4 million second-quarter loss as the company added $300 million to its reserve for loan losses. But when Government examiners arrived later in the year, they found little to criticize.
First Fidelity could have been in worse shape had it not been preoccupied with the Fidelcor merger during the late 1980's. In 1988 and 1989, when other banks were making real estate loans that are now in deep trouble, First Fidelity was not as aggressive.
At the end of 1990, commercial real estate accounted for about 14.8 percent of First Fidelity's loans, or well below the 32.2 percent at rival Midlantic or 25.6 percent at the UJB Financial Corporation of Princeton, its two large rivals in New Jersey.
"I think they were too distracted by internal problems to be aggressive real estate lenders," said William McCrystal, an analyst at Thompson Bankwatch, a bank rating concern.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
2 Buildings To Be Opened In Cleveland

BYLINE: By Jennifer Stoffel

DATELINE: CLEVELAND

 BODY:
TWO new office buildings set to open in downtown Cleveland this year will enhance Cleveland's ability to provide major tenants with first-class space. They have also raised the city's office vacancy rate to 22 percent, a record.
The previous vacancy peak was 16 percent in 1986. With office employment having slowed and the city still trying to absorb the space completed last year, Cleveland is now ranked eighth on the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation's list of the 10 riskiest cities for new commercial investment. Hartford tops the list. 
 The new buildings themselves are expected to fare well, however. They will draw most of their tenants from older buildings downtown. One is the 1.2-million-square-foot Society Center, already 60 percent leased. The other is Bank One Center, with 485,000 square feet of space, 32 percent of it leased.
"What we have is a flight to quality," said Chandler B. Converse, vice president of office leasing for Cragin Lang Inc., a real estate brokerage firm. "Over the past five years, there has not been enough new product and there is a pent-up demand among large tenants."
For decades, Cleveland lagged behind other urban centers in the development of downtown commercial space. In the early 1980's, new development stalled while buildings erected during the city's booming years in the 1920's fell into disrepair. The first sign of a turnaround came in 1985 with the completion of the 1.5-million-square-foot BPAmerica building on Public Square.
While an additional two million square feet of space was added in 1987 and 1988, following a burst in service jobs and demand for downtown office space, the vacancy rate in commercial space fell below 6 percent in 1989 after peaking at 16 percent in 1986.
All that changed in 1990 with the opening of five major commercial projects totaling two million square feet.
While the overall market for space is not expected to grow, absorption of new space has tended to result from tenants in class B buildings taking advantage of the soft market to move. In 1990, tenants took 549,200 square feet of class A space -- generally defined as buildings under 30 years old -- but vacancies in class B space grew by 277,000 square feet that year, according to Cragin Lang's survey. Older buildings are expected to continue to be hard hit by such moves.
In fact, the current market has created bargains for commercial tenants, especially those willing to take 60,000 square feet or more. Typical landlord concessions or discounts include periods of free rent, moving allowances, lease assumptions and decorating allowances. The cost of office space is expected to drop as much as 30 percent.
Class A space in the central business district is currently renting from $18 to $35 a square foot a year. "We have a slight oversupply right now, but not the G word," said Robert F. Redmond, senior vice president at the Ostendorf-Morris Company, a real estate firm, dismissing suggestions of a glut.
The 57-story Society Center occupies a full city block across from Public Square. Thirty percent of the space has been leased by the Society Corporation, a regional financial services concern and owner of the Society Bank. Also committed are the Squire, Sanders & Dempsey law firm and Deloitte & Touche accounting firm.
Set for a November opening, the project also includes a 402-room, 25-story Marriott Hotel; a two-level, 960-space underground parking lot built for the city, and a private fitness club.
As part of the project, the century-old Society for Savings Building was preserved. Both the original facade and the first floor banking lobby have been renovated. The upper 10 floors were gutted to align the old building with the new.
The other new building, Bank One Center, has been developed by The Galbreath Company of Columbus, Ohio, with Bank One leasing about 100,000 square feet for its headquarters. Bank One currently occupies the Sterling Building on Euclid Avenue, which it will vacate to occupy the new building, at 600 Superior Avenue. The law firm of McDonald, Hopkins, Burke & Haber has signed a lease for 40,000 square feet.
In light of the current market, Richard E. Jacobs and David H. Jacobs, the local developers, announced late last year the indefinite delay of construction of the 60-story, one-million-square-foot Ameritrust Center, also planned for Public Square. It was originally set to open in 1994, with construction to begin in 1991, and to include a 484-room Hyatt Regency Hotel. "The economy has changed tremendously since we signed with Ameritrust," said Martin J. Cleary, president of Jacobs, Visconsi, Jacobs. "At a time like this, a prudent developer is going to move carefully."
When it is built, Ameritrust Center is likely to be Ohio's tallest building, at 900 feet. At this point that honor belongs to Society Center, which topped out a few months ago at 788 feet.

HEADLINE: MEXICO CITY JOURNAL;
A Daring Magazine and Its Awkward Questions

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 20

 BODY:
If the editors of Mexico's newest monthly magazine had merely wanted to print their own views about Mexican politics and society, no one might have cared. What has stirred critics of the new magazine, Este Pais, is a much more delicate editorial goal: to publish what the Mexican people think about themselves.
Started by a group of intellectuals and public servants that spans the spectrum of Mexican politics, the new publication has been designed to include extensive monthly opinion polls and analysis of national attitudes, exploring public feelings on everything from politics to corruption to religious behavior. 
 But in a society where such surveys are carefully managed and seldom published, that proposition has surrounded the magazine with controversy, even before the publication of its first issue, which is scheduled to come out next month.
Government officials portray the magazine as an opposition tool, opposition parties are wary of its electoral implications, and, in general, the idea of putting cherished political myths to a statistical test appears to have challenged the comfortable ambiguity that pervades much of Mexican scholarship and political life.
 
A Tradition Is Lacking
 "If you think about political science in the United States, you think about polls, statistics, that kind of thing," said Federico Reyes Heroles, a 36-year-old political scientist and novelist who is to edit the new publication. "But in Mexico, political science means philosophy. We don't have a tradition of fact in Mexico, even in economics."
Although scientific soundings of national opinion are routinely commissioned by Mexican political parties and the Government itself, they have seldom formed an important part of public debate. Moreover, rarely if ever have they presented a full-scale portrait of values and social attitudes in a country where national stereotypes have long substituted for direct investigations of public thinking.
Among other findings presented in its first few issues, editors say, the new magazine will scrutinize traditional conceptions about Mexican nationalism, citing recent polling data that show just 56 percent of Mexicans to be "very proud" of their nationality, down nearly 10 percent from survey results a decade ago, and fully 20 percent below the corresponding figure for the United States.
Similarly, according to figures compiled by the magazine, the number of Mexicans who are ready to fight for their country in case of war has fallen from 90 percent in 1981 to less than 75 percent last year.
Other issues will deal with delicate social and political questions, ranging from confidence in public institutions to family relations to moral issues. For example, Mexican respondents in recent polls expressed a lower level of trust in their family members than did American or Canadian respondents. And the number of Mexicans who described themselves as "very religious" was just over 40 percent -- less than the corresponding figure for American respondents.
 
Some Are Uneasy
 The striking unpredictability of those figures -- and the prospect of having such data published and analyzed systematically in the pages of Este Pais -- has prompted conspicuous unease from many politicians and business people with a stake in the traditional order of Mexican society.
Citing the opposition ties of Mr. Reyes, who gave up his membership in the governing Institutional Revolutionary Party to form the magazine late last year, many party and Government officials have hurried to denounce the journal as an anti-Government project.
"It seems clear at this point that this is going to be strictly an opposition magazine," a Government official said.
But ownership of the magazine has been structured around a diverse group of 200 principal shareholders, each of whom is permitted only one vote in decisions on magazine policy, regardless of financial investment. And Mr. Reyes and his colleagues have taken care to insure that the group spans the broadest range of Mexican politicians and intellectuals, ranging from opposition economists to sitting Governors from the ruling party.
The magazine's founders' list also includes an eclectic, nonvoting group of foreign associates that includes many of the most distinguished American academic experts on Mexican government and society.
"This is something that could help reduce cynicism about Mexican politics," said Susan Kaufman Purcell, a foreign associate of the magazine who is vice president of the Americas Society, a prominent New York-based group dedicated to the study of Latin American affairs.
"The problem at this point is that the Mexican people don't trust declarations and statements and rhetoric. So to the extent that you can start basing things on more scientific kinds of studies, the people may have more confidence."
As now envisioned, the magazine will conduct many of its own polls, overseen by Miguel Basanez, a well-known Mexican political scientist who is president of the magazine's board of directors. But its editors say they also plan to use polls conducted by academic institutions, foreign experts, multilateral institutions and other investigators, making full disclosure of the samples and methods used in each to provide the clearest possible portrait of Mexican thinking.
Dr. Purcell and others caution that the test of Este Pais's success will lie in the magazine's ability to maintain a political balance in the kinds of questions it seeks to explore, as well as the scientific accuracy of the results. But that concern is viewed more as a challenge than a limitation by the editors of the magazine, who say they have planned from the start to let the political chips fall where they may.
"Everyone is very anxious about what we are going to find," Mr. Reyes said. "But that is exactly the point -- nobody really knows."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "In Mexico, political science means philosophy," said Federico Reyes Heroles, foreground, political scientist, novelist and editor of Mexico's lively new monthly magazine, Este Pais. "We don't have a tradition of fact, even in economics." With him in the magazine's office, was an unidentified colleague. (Sergio Dorantes for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money Market Fund Yields Are Mixed for Third Week

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report for the week that ended yesterday were mixed for the third consecutive week.
Walter S. Frank, Donoghue's chief economist, said the week's results reflected the relative stability in short-term markets. He predicted that short-term markets would continue without dramatic direction for the next few months. 
 "They'll be resting on their oars," Mr. Frank said.
 
Tax-Exempt Funds
 Tax-exempt money funds showed the average number of days that securities are held in portfolios at 50 days, down one day from the previous week. Assets declined $324 million, to $91.1 billion, a moderate decline, Mr. Frank said.
Yields on the tax-exempt funds were largely up for the week. The average seven-day simple yield was at 4.24 percent, up from 4.06 percent the week before. The seven-day compound yield for the week, also known as the effective yield, was at 4.33 percent, up from 4.14 percent. The 30-day simple yield was 4.10 percent, up from 4.07 percent, and the compound, or effective, yield, was 4.18 percent, up from 4.15 percent.
The taxable equivalent of the effective seven-day tax-exempt yield was 6.01 percent in the 28 percent tax bracket and 6.46 percent in the 33 percent bracket.
Of the tax-exempt funds with assets of more than $100 million that are monitored by IBC/Donoghue's, the Calvert Tax-Free Reserves Money Market Fund in Washington produced the best return on investment with a seven-day compound yield of 5.34 percent.
 
Top Yielding Tax-Exempt Funds
 In New York City, the top-yielding tax-exempt fund was Salomon Brothers New York Municipal Money Market Fund, at 4.89 percent. New Jersey's top fund was the New Jersey Daily Municipal Income Fund, with a yield of 4.79 percent. In Connecticut, the top yielding fund was the Dreyfus Connecticut Municipal Money Market Fund, with a yield of 4.67 percent.
Assets on taxable funds rose by $6.2 billion, to $464.5 billion. The figure, however, includes the assets of seven new funds added to IBC/Donoghue's list. Without those seven, assets rose $3.4 billion, which was termed a significant increase by Mr. Frank.
The average number of days that taxable securities are held in portfolios remained 54, the same as in the previous week.
The average seven-day simple taxable yield fell to 6.06 percent, from 6.15 percent in the previous week, while the seven-day compound, or effective, yield, was 6.24 percent, down from 6.34 percent. The 30-day simple yield was 6.18 percent, while the 30-day compound, or effective, yield was 6.37 percent, down from 6.46 percent.
The taxable fund with the best return on investments last week was the Dreyfus Worldwide Dollar Money Market Fund, based in New York. It had a seven-day compound yield of 7.19 percent.
By comparison, bank money market accounts, which compete with the money funds and are included in The Bank Rate Monitor national index, showed the average rate of return at 5.59 percent, unchanged from the previous week.

HEADLINE: Congress Gets Bush Bank Plan

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The Bush Administration sent to Congress today its sweeping proposal to overhaul the banking system.
The 317-page bill is a detailed version of a plan outlined last month by the Treasury Department to repeal laws written as far back as the Depression. The Administration's proposal, a response to the growing crisis in the banking system, would permit the merger of investment and commercial banks and would allow industrial companies to own banks. It would also eliminate barriers to interstate banking. 
 Many elements of the plan have been criticized by some lawmakers, regulators and lobbyists representing smaller banks and other industries; few officials expect Congress to adopt the entire Administration plan. The package is viewed, however, as a starting point for intense negotiations that are expected to continue for months and could ultimately result in significant legislation.
A senior official at the Treasury Department who insisted on anonymity said the measure was intended to bolster the banking industry and prevent a taxpayer-paid bailout, while also offering consumers a wider variety of services at banks, like insurance and mutual funds.
The official said that adoption of the measure would almost inevitably cause consolidation among banks but that the department had not calculated how many banks would survive.
"What we are saying to banks is either get strong or get out," the official said.
The proposal that has received the strongest support on Capitol Hill would roll back restrictions on interstate banking. The chairmen of the House and Senate banking committees have also said they expect to make big strides in refinancing and changing the bank insurance fund, although they have stopped short of endorsing the Treasury plan to use the Federal Reserve for the refinancing.
The legislation gives the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation the authority to borrow up to $25 billion from the Fed for the dwindling fund that protects bank deposits.
It also consolidates the existing supervisory authority of four banking agencies into two, the Fed and a new agency, while still providing a signifcant role for the F.D.I.C.
The legislation would also close existing loopholes in the laws on deposit insurance so that an individual would be limited to a maximum of $200,000 in protection at any one bank. Protection is now limited to $100,000 per depositor at any one bank, but by using joint accounts with family members that amount can be substantially exceeded.

HEADLINE: Heroin Spreads Among Young in China

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KUNMING, China

 BODY:
Four decades after China eradicated narcotics use across the country in one of the great achievements of the Communist revolution, heroin is spreading rapidly among young Chinese who are bored and unhappy and looking for diversion.
China's drug problem is still tiny compared with America's or Western Europe's -- or with its levels in the China of the 1940's, when some 20 million Chinese smoked opium. But these days the number of drug abusers seems to be rising quickly in some parts of the country, particularly here in Yunnan Province in southwest China. 
 "Lots of my friends tried heroin, because young people want to find out what it's all about," said a 20-year-old woman who began using heroin two years ago while she was unemployed. She is one of 257 addicts undergoing voluntary detoxification at the Kunming Drug Abuse Research Center, and like others interviewed she asked that her name not be used.
 The narcotics are brought to Yunnan across the long and mostly unpoliced border with Myanmar, formerly known as Burma. A few years ago, drug abuse was concentrated among the peasants who live along the border, and then it spread to the provincial capital, Kunming. Now it is has reached the cities of Xian, Lanzhou and Canton, but in most of the country, including Beijing, narcotics use is still mostly unknown.
"There are several trends," said Dr. Li Jianhua, director of detoxification at the research center. "Heroin has gone from the border area to the interior, from the countryside to the cities, and to younger and younger people."
"Personally, I'm rather pessimistic about how the problem will develop," Dr. Li said.
The resurgence of narcotics has particular resonance in China, where opium is seen as a symbol and a cause of the national humiliation and decay suffered from the early 19th century until the middle of this century. Opium arrived in China in the 1720's, and when the Government tried to crack down, Britain waged the Opium War of 1839-42 to force China to end restrictions on foreign trade.
"To be a Chinese is to know the pain of the history of drugs," said Chen Cunyi, a director of the narcotics police in Yunnan Province. "Drugs brought such harm to China, and we can't allow them to proliferate once more."
No one seems to have a firm idea how many addicts there are in China. Mr. Chen estimated that there may be 10,000 in Yunnan, while one of the addicts in the drug abuse research center said there could be 50,000 in the city of Kunming alone.
 
Ruthless Measures Worked
 After the 1949 revolution, the Communists wiped out opium by mobilizing the population to shoot traffickers and insure that addicts were forced to quit abruptly. The measures were ruthless, but superbly organized. At that time, in contrast to the present, a feeling of optimism prevailed, and ordinary people wanted to take part in efforts to "build the nation" and wipe out drug use, prostitution and other problems.
These days, young people feel no such sense of purpose, and many complain that it is boredom and curiosity that drives them to narcotics and on to an array of related problems.
A Chinese newspaper reported recently that 43 people died of drug overdoses in Yunnan Province in the first 10 months of last year, and that 70 percent of crime in Yunnan was drug-related, as addicts turn to theft, robbery and prostitution to support their habits. In addition, criminal gangs flourish on the trafficking business, and drug abuse spreads the AIDS virus because of the use of shared needles.
"People know about AIDS, but they want their high," said a 21-year-old addict in the center. He said that he, along with about half of addicts, injected heroin; the rest either smoke it in cigarettes or "chase the dragon" by heating the heroin and inhaling the vapors.
 
410 Chinese With AIDS Virus
 By international standards, AIDS is a minuscule problem in China, as only 410 Chinese are known to carry the AIDS virus. But 397 of them are from Yunnan Province. While hypodermic needles are available over the counter in China, addicts say it is common to share needles at least on some occasions.
The research center was established in 1989 to try to help addicts kick the habit, using methadone, counseling and the traditional breathing exercises known as qi gong. But while the addicts have all come voluntarily, paying for the treatment themselves, one follow-up survey found that of 81 addicts who left the center, all but three resumed their drug abuse.
The Government has shown growing concern about the drug problem. Although people arrested for possession of small amounts of heroin are normally released the first time and a second offense brings a two-year sentence, a new narcotics law provides for execution of major traffickers.
"The only way to stop them is to execute them," a 34-year-old addict in the research center said as other addicts nodded approval. "They make so much in profits that even if they're sentenced to 20 years in prison, it's still worth it for them. If a pusher is arrested, his wife will continue, because the profits are so great."
A large-scale trafficker importing heroin from Myanmar can make more than $10,000 a month, the addict said. That compares with an average wage in China of about $25 a month.
 
Four Traffickers Executed
 In February the Government said four drug traffickers had been executed in Yunnan. In the southern Yunnan town of Jinghong, a photo on a public bulletin boad offers a stark warning: it shows a young drug trafficker kneeling at the execution site, about to be shot in the head.
Yunnan's newly strengthened force of 1,300 anti-drug police officers seized 3,185 pounds of heroin last year, up from 646 pounds in 1989. But Mr. Chen, the police director, said the increase reflected more effective police work rather than greater drug use.
Much of the narcotics brought to Yunnan is not intended to be consumed here, but is transported to Hong Kong or to other international ports or airports to be shipped to the West. Tighter enforcement in Southeast Asia apparently has made China an alternative shipping route from the Golden Triangle to the West.
Most of the drug users appear to be private entrepreneurs, who have the money to afford heroin at about $10 per dose, or bored young people who have not yet been assigned a job.
Marijuana grows wild in many parts of China, but it is ignored by Chinese and sought only by young foreign tourists and students. The authorities say Chinese do not know that marijuana can be smoked.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Mixed in Light Day After Gains Against Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar was mixed in light trading yesterday as traders took profits to exploit this week's sharp rise in the currency.
Currency trading was relatively quiet as the market caught its breath after a surge in the dollar. On Tuesday, the dollar flirted with nine-month highs against the German mark after remarks by Germany's monetary chief prompted wide concern about his nation's economic reunion last year. 
 "Traders have seen just fabulous volatility in the last few days, and there are an awful lot of people who don't want to get mixed up in it," said Mike Casey, an economist for Maria Ramirez Capital Consultants Inc.
Mr. Casey said several United States currency speculators bought dollars early in the session to try to increase the currency's value in the thinly traded market. But after an initial surge to 1.6630 German marks, the dollar was pushed down by traders seeking to profit from their earlier dollar purchases.
The dollar settled at 1.6425 marks, up from 1.6423 marks late on Tuesday.
Market participants said several European central banks, including Germany's Bundesbank, sold dollars to try to quell the currency's surge, but the intervention was seen as too limited to have much effect.
Traders remained cautious, however, that a concerted intervention on the scale of earlier dollar sales by central banks would hit the market.
Analysts viewed yesterday's mixed performance as an aberration in a longer upward trend. The dollar, which has risen 14 percent in the last month, is expected to climb even higher on strong postwar optimism about the economy, as well as on continued restlessness in Eastern Europe and Germany's fizzling economy.
In London, the British pound rose to $1.7770, from $1.7655 late on Tuesday. Sterling also gained against the dollar in New York, settling at $1.7855, up from late Tuesday's $1.7800.
Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar rose to a closing of 138.30 Japanese yen, from 137.98 yen at Tuesday's close. Later in London, the dollar was quoted at 138.60 yen. In New York, it settled at 138.30 yen, up from 137.55 late on Tuesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Tuesday, included: 1.4150 Swiss francs, down from 1.4175; 5.5950 French francs, up from 5.5945; 1,123.00 Italian lire, down from 1,225.00, and 1.1574 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1549.

HEADLINE: Suspect in Fatal Arson Had Called Fire a 'Nightmare'

BYLINE: By LEE A. DANIELS

 BODY:
"I heard a lot of people screaming," a 16-year-old said on March 13 at a fire in the South Bronx that killed six people. "The block was full of smoke. The fire was going like a torch. It was a nightmare on this block."
The youth was Luis Morales, who was arrested on Tuesday night and charged with setting the fire. He also wanted to have his picture taken the night of the fire, telling a photographer, "Take my picture." Afterward, he asked whether it would be in the newspaper. 
 The youth said of Donald Stephens, the owner of the building, at 1074 Fox Street, who died in the fire: "Mr. Stephens was really nice. He would let me sleep there if I had no place."
Mr. Morales was charged yesterday in State Supreme Court with 12 counts of second-degree murder, first-degree arson and reckless endangerment. The two murder counts for each death consist of counts of murder by depraved indifference to human life and murder by arson, a spokesman for Bronx District Attorney Robert T. Johnson said.
The police described Mr. Morales as an unemployed high school dropout with a long criminal record who has recently lived in the streets. The police also said he had argued with residents of the building on Fox Street, whose owner often let in the homeless.
 
Troubled and With a Bad Temper
 Intertwining her fingers, Mr. Morales's mother, Cecelia, sat in her living room a 900 East 167th Street insisting that her son was incapable of such a crime.
"My son has a bad temper," she said. "He argues with people. He argues with me. But he wouldn't harm anyone. He did not do this thing."
Mrs. Morales and another son, Roberto, and several neighborhood residents depicted Mr. Morales as a troubled youth whose slight mental retardation had long subjected him to failure in school and classmates' taunts.
Mrs. Morales said Luis left about a year ago and had been arrested in a burglary and crack sales. But she added that although he sometimes stayed away from the family apartment, he was staying with friends, and not on the streets.
 
'A Lot of Pain This Week'
 A mile away, another family struggled. Jacqueline and Jeannette Mitchell prepared to bury their mother, Alberta, who died in the fire. Mrs. Mitchell, 42, began as a part-time custodial worker about a year ago at Public School 150, across the street from the burned building. She became a permanent employee in September, her daughters and school officials said.
"We've been in a lot of pain this last week, a lot of confusion," said Jacqueline Mitchell. Referring to the suspect, she added: "He should understand what he's done to us. He's made a lot of people very unhappy."
Neither the prosecutor's office nor the police would comment on Mr. Morales's record.
Roberto Morales said that shortly after he and his brother had arrived to look at the fire, two detectives took Luis into custody and questioned him at the 41st Precinct station house, almost directly behind the burning building. Mr. Morales said his brother was released shortly after that and went home.
Neighbors remembered Mr. Stephens, a retired seaman, as a good samaritan who had helped neighborhood residents and who had opened his building to many in need of shelter.

A memorial wreath hung from the door where six people died. (Photographs by Jim Estrin for The New York Times)
