HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Securities Rise in Price

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities rose in light trading yesterday, as at least some investors apparently decided that after recent sharp declines, notes and bonds were being offered at attractive levels.
On Tuesday an alarming inflation report, the second in less than a week, helped to push bond yields close to 8.40 percent, their highest level since mid-January. 
 Traders said little real buying took place yesterday, but analysts said the rebound in prices might have been caused by a calmer reassessment of the inflation outlook.
"The inflation numbers clearly were disturbing, but the outlook is not that bad," said Michael J. Moran, chief economist at Daiwa Securities America Inc. "With the unemployment rate more than a full percentage point above its recent low, and the economy weak, we should see an abatement in inflation this year."
 
Market Participants Wary
 Still, market participants said they remained wary.
"It's very easy to say that these yields are so attractive you need to buy them," one government bond trader said. "But the Street is awash in paper, and foreign institutions are selling. Still, I don't think the economy has bottomed out yet."
Over the last month, foreign central banks and Middle Eastern investors have been heavy sellers of Treasury issues.
Traders are also wary of a rush of new issues that will begin to come to market next week.
Yesterday the Treasury announced that it would sell $11.5 billion of new two-year notes on Tuesday and $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes on Wednesday.
In when-issued trading after the announcement, the two-year notes were offered at a price to yield 7.15 percent. The five-year notes were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 7.87 percent.
In the secondary market for Treasury securities, the 7 7/8 percent 30-year bonds of 2021 were offered in late trading at a price of 94 30/32, up 21/ 32, to yield 8.33 percent, down from 8.39 percent late Tuesday.
Among note issues, the 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes were offered at 97 1/4, up 14/32, to yield 8.15 percent. And the outstanding 6 3/4 percent two-year notes were offered at 99 9/32, up 2/32, to yield 7.14 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates eased slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 5.85 percent, down two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates dipped by three basis points, to a late offered rate of 5.88 percent.
Traders said that short-term rates may have been helped by an article in U.S. News & World Report, the news weekly, which suggested that Alan Greenspan, Federal Reserve Board chairman, does not believe the trough of the recession has been reached.
 
Investment-Grade Bonds
 In the investment-grade corporate bond market, the Montreal Urban Community offered $135 million of 10-year debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch & Company.
The 9 1/8 percent securities, which mature March 15, 2001, were priced at $99.382, to yield 9.22 percent, 1.03 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the Treasury's 7 3/4 percent 10-year notes at the time of pricing.
The securities, which are noncallable for life, are rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service and A-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.
Participants in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds said that prices of most issues rose by 1/4 point to 3/8 point in sluggish trading.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that a spurt of buying late in the session helped to push prices of most widely quoted issues up by 1/4 point to 1/2 point.

HEADLINE: Trade Gap Up Slightly, To $7 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The nation's trade deficit grew moderately to $7 billion in January as imports rebounded, the Commerce Department reported today. But the import growth was substantially offset by stronger exports.
Economists generally welcomed the rise in exports, which they hope will continue and eventually help pull the economy out of recession later this year. They cautioned, however, that the trade figures for January were unusually difficult to interpret because of the weak dollar, turn-of-the-year distortions and irregular shipments because of congestion in ports as a result of the Persian Gulf war. The trade gap was $6.3 billion in December. 
 Figures on merchandise trade are also reported with a greater lag than most other economic indicators, many of which have already been published for February.
 
Consumer Goods Exports
 Still, analysts said they were encouraged by a $1.2 billion, or 3.6 percent, rise in exports to $34.5 billion, the second-highest level on record. Exports of consumer goods climbed over $4 billion for the first time.
"Exports are holding up pretty nicely" despite slowing or contracting economies of various American trading partners, said Michael L. Penzer, senior economist at the Bank of America. The record of $35 billion was posted in October.
Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher noted in a statement that exports were 9.9 percent above the January 1990 level and said it was "most gratifying to see that U.S. manufacturers are clearly aggressively seeking out markets overseas" for a broad range of products.
Meanwhile, imports for January rose $1.9 billion, or 4.8 percent, to $41.5 billion. Much of the rise reflected higher prices caused by the dollar's low international value.
 
Bill for Oil Climbs
 In addition, the nation's bill for imported oil climbed $300 million above the December level. The cost of additional volume was not entirely offset by lower prices.
January imports climbed to 170 million barrels, as the price eased to an average of $22.98 a barrel, from $25.70. At $3.9 billion, crude oil represented 55.7 percent of the total January trade deficit.
This, however, has a positive side for the future, analysts said, in that Middle Eastern producers will be using oil revenue in the aftermath of the war to buy goods and services in this country.
In contrast to the nearly 10 percent growth of exports over the last year, imports last month were virtually unchanged from the level of January 1990.
As recession gripped the economy, depressing demand, imports fell $3.6 billion in December to push the trade deficit down to $6.3 billion, a six-month low. The 11.1 percent widening of the deficit in January was a bit less than expected.
 
Reassuring Sign of Strength
 "It's reassuring that maybe there really is some economic strength out there," said Michael P. Niemira, an economist at the Mitsubishi Bank in New York, referring to the increases for both exports and imports.
The department said the export gain was paced by an $800 million rise for automotive vehicles and parts, a $500 million rise for industrial supplies and materials and a $300 million rise in consumer goods. "Other" merchandise was $600 million lower and capital goods were about unchanged.
Among imports, there were increases of $800 million for industrial supplies, $700 million for automotive goods and $300 million for consumer goods.
 
Regional Differences
 The trade report also showed that the American surplus with Western Europe fell to $1.1 billion last month, from $1.6 billion in December, while the deficit with Japan edged up to $3.5 billion, from $3.4 billion. The deficit with three of the four newly industrialized economies of the Far East -- Singapore, South Korea and Hong Kong -- narrowed substantially, but a $100 million widening with Taiwan cut the overall improvement to $200 million, at $1 billion for the month.
Unlike the other figures, those for geographical entities and energy are not adjusted for seasonal variation.
Today's report also showed the overall deficit to have been $6.9 billion for January when not seasonally adjusted. On the basis of constant 1987 dollars, the seasonally adjusted deficit jumped to $5.1 billion, from $4.1 billion.
Yet another gauge -- the deficit on a three-month moving average in current dollars -- showed a decline to $7.4 billion, from $8.7 billion in December.

HEADLINE: Hewlett's Sprightly New Mood

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., March 20

 BODY:
A series of anonymous advertisements ran in newspapers around the country last week. "57 MIPS, under $12K," said one. And at the bottom in parentheses it added, "If you guess Sun, you guess wrong."
The teaser ads, referring to new a computer able to execute 57 milllion instructions a second and costing about $12,000, were an unsual step for the Hewlett-Packard Company, known for solid engineering but an almost complete lack of marketing flair. 
 The ads also reflect the importance that Hewlett-Packard is placing on new computer work stations it will introduce on Tuesday. Industry executives said the company would start selling three new computers in the HP 9000 Series. The machines will be at least twice as fast, and in some cases several times as fast, as those offered at similar prices by other companies, including the industry leader, Sun Microsystems.
The machines could revive Hewlett's prospects in the important area of work stations, which are desktop computers more powerful than personal computers. Designed for the intense industrial computing needs of engineers and scientists, work stations are one of the fastest-growing segments of the computer business and accounted for $7.4 billion in revenues last year.
Besides the Model 720, which executes 57 million instructions per second, or MIPS, a second machine, the 730, will perform 76 MIPS at a price of about $20,000. The model 750, a more fully equipped version of the 730, will sell for about $43,000.
On a standard speed rating system known as the Specmark, the Model 720 scored over 55 and the Model 730 over 72, according to industry executives. By contrast, the $15,000 Sun Sparcstation 2 has a Specmark of 21 and a new $20,000 I.B.M. work station is rated at 32.4.
The ads for these computers are also a sign of renewed vigor and confidence throughout the proud and tradition-rich organization that has been suffering from missed opportunities and unsatisfying financial performance.
"The enthusiasm just vibrates," John A. Young, the company's president and chief executive, said in an interview at corporate headquarters here. Referring to the new computers, which the company code-named "snakes" in the hope they will be deadly to the competition, he added, "All you have to do is get close to that thing."
 
Trouble Last Fall
 Just last fall, Mr. Young was under pressure. Hewlett-Packard's computer business, which accounts for two-thirds of the company's $13 billion in revenues, had gaping problems. The company's stock price of $25 was at its lowest level in years.
In October, the company announced a reorganization that moved the chief operating officer, Dean O. Morton, into the chief executive's office with Mr. Young, seeming to cast doubt on Mr. Young's future. And David Packard, the 78-year-old co-founder and chairman of the company, began to take a more active role in the company to try to fix some problems.
Hewlett-Packard now appears to be bouncing back. The stock has recovered, closing on the New York Stock Exchange today at $45.625, buoyed by higher than expected earnings in its latest quarter and the projections by some analysts that the company's decade-long slide in operating profit margins is over. The reorganization last fall is already resulting in improved efficiencies, executives and analysts say.
Company executives also say that Mr. Young is still firmly in power. It now seems clear that the creation of the chief executive's office was more a way to prepare for the retirement of Mr. Morton and other top executives than a challenge to Mr. Young.
Indeed, Mr. Young, who is 58 years old, will reach retirement age in the next few years, as will most of the company's top officers, setting the stage for a large change in management. It would be only the second such change in the company's 53-year history, the first being in 1978 when Mr. Young took over from the founders, William Hewlett and Mr. Packard.
 
'An Inflection Point'
 All this could mean that the company is on the verge of a new era. "You're at an inflection point today," said Barry Willman, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
To be sure, a weak economy is hurting many high-technology companies, as reflected in Tuesday's announcement by the International Business Machines Corporation that its first-quarter earnings would be about half what analysts had expected. That casts a cloud over Hewlett-Packard as well. William Terry, an executive vice president, said the company was "wary" about the economy but that it was too early in the quarter to predict results.
Moreover, one new computer family does not a company make, especially a company like Hewlett, which has more than 10,000 products, from calculators and minicomputers to oscilloscopes, medical diagnostic equipment and analytical chemistry instruments for measuring pollution.
Still, succeeding in work stations is especially important to the company because those machines are taking over the jobs once performed by larger minicomputers.
 
Ranked Third in '90
 In 1990, Hewlett-Packard ranked third in market share of work stations shipped, with 16.6 percent, according to Dataquest, a San Jose, Calif., company that tracks the computer industry. That was just behind Digital's 17.5 percent, but a far cry from Sun Microsystem's 37.5 percent.
The Model 700 machines could do a lot to restore Hewlett's momentum in work stations, though it will not go all the way. For one thing, competitors could catch up by year-end with their own machines. For another, Hewlett lacks low-priced machines, selling for less than $10,000. In a few months, the company is expected to introduce a machine for less than $10,000, a segment of the market that has the highest sales volumes and in which Sun excels.
The new work stations will use technology known as reduced instruction set computing, or RISC, which operates faster than conventional microprocessors. Hewlett was one of the first to embrace RISC, but used it first only in its minicomputers. That let Sun, I.B.M. and Digital Equipment get the jump on RISC work stations.
 
Lost Market Share
 Hewlett continued to rely on more conventional microprocessors made by Motorola Inc. and lost market share last year when Motorola was late with its newest chip, the 68040. The company has also had problems merging Apollo Computer, a work station company it bought in 1989, although, Mr. Young said, "We still have a strong belief in the wisdom" of the acquisition.
The company, which was founded in a garage in 1938 by two Stanford University electrical engineering graduates, once specialized in electronic and chemical instruments that were designed by engineers for other engineers.
The computer business is much more rough-and-tumble, requiring more aggressive marketing tactics than the classy company had used in the past. Profit margins are also lower than in instruments, especially as the computer industry has shifted toward smaller machines based on industry standards.
Hewlett, which has long been considered one of the nation's best-managed companies, has fared far better than most of its competitors. Some other minicomputer companies, like Data General and Wang Laboratories, have suffered heavy losses, and even I.B.M. and Digital have gone through jarring readjustments.
Hewlett, partly because of its non-computer businesses, has remained profitable and has grown at about 10 to 20 percent a year.
Still the company's operating profit margins have shrunk steadily since 1980, said Mr. Willman, the analyst. The company also suffered from slow decision-making by committee and a centralized marketing organization could not focus well on individual product areas.
The reorganization in October tried to correct those problems. It returned marketing duties to individual product groups and split computers into two divisions. One, headed by Lewis E. Platt, handles minicomputers, work stations and other products sold directly to customers. The other division, headed by Richard A. Hackborn, handles printers, calculators and personal computers, products sold through retailers.
Mr. Hackborn is perhaps the closest thing Hewlett has to a free spirit. He is based at the printer division in Boise, Idaho, and has refused all requests to move back to Silicon Valley, which he considers too congested.
Mr. Hackborn led the company to its dominance of laser printers for computers, which now account for about $2 billion in revenues. He is also being charged with injecting new life into the company's personal computer business, where it has never broken out of the pack.
Hewlett will jump into a potentially exciting part of the market in April when it starts selling a handheld computer that will come with the Lotus Development Corporation's 1-2-3 spreadsheet software built in.

HEADLINE: Big Losses For Airlines

BYLINE: By Reuters

 BODY:
The world airline industry suffered substantial losses in January and February and will probably lose more than $2 billion for the year, the head of the International Air Transport Association said yesterday.
Gunter Eser, director general of the association, told reporters after a speech to airline industry executives that airlines had been hit by a severe drop in passenger traffic caused by the Persian Gulf war and weak economies in the United States and elsewhere.
He said the industry was also being hurt by severely rising costs for fuel and labor.
Mr. Eser said in his speech that a survey of the 202 member airlines had shown that industry revenues were down more than $1 billion in January. Incomplete figures for February so far indicate that the revenue decline last month was worse. The world industry lost $2 billion in 1990.

HEADLINE: Friend Relives Night of Police Beating

BYLINE: By SETH MYDANS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, March 20

 BODY:
As Rodney G. King was beaten by Los Angeles police officers on March 3, other officers seized one of Mr. King's passengers, Bryant Allen, who says he was manhandled and taunted in a racially motivated attempt to provoke him.
In an interview, Mr. Allen said he feared for his life as he was made to crawl along the ground, hearing at the same time his friend's screams and the sounds of police batons from the far side of the car. 
 "He was screaming, 'Stop!' " said Mr. Allen, who said he heard but did not see his friend being beaten. "Then he kind of quit, and all you could hear was like bones being broken, a crunching, like a whip sound."
In the first complete account of the incident from one who was there, Mr. Allen, 25 years old, said he believed the beating of Mr. King and the blows directed at him and a second passenger, Freddie Helms, were racially motivated. All three men in the car were black. The police officers were white. As many as 21 Los Angeles police officers were present; a sergeant and three officers have been indicted on assault charges.
 
Watching the 7 Minutes
 Mr. Allen's lawyer, John C. Burton, said he would file a Federal civil rights suit. Mr. King's lawyer said Tuesday he also would file a suit. None of the three men in the car have been charged.
Mr. Allen tapped his foot slowly as he sat with his lawyer Tuesday night, watching for the first time the full seven-minute videotape, which includes the two-minute beating that has been shown repeatedly on national television. The videotape has led to calls for the resignation of Chief Daryl F. Gates and prompted inquiries into the extent of police brutality nationwide.
Speaking quietly, Mr. Allen described Mr. King's erratic behavior behind the wheel on a night when the three men had been drinking beer and said tension was heightened when Mr. King had trouble with his seat belt as he was complying with police orders to leave his car.
He said that at one point a female officer intervened when he himself was threatened with violence. "She's the one who had her hand out saying I didn't do anything wrong," Mr. Allen recalled. She was saying, 'He's the one that had his hands up.' "
 
An Attempt to Provoke?
 Nevertheless, he said, he was kicked and manhandled and threatened by officers who said: "You want to be like your home boy? You want to be like your home boy?"
He said Mr. Helms was bloody at the end of the evening after apparently being struck on the head with a baton.
Mr. Allen said he believed that remarks like "home boy," along with his physical treatment, were part of an attempt to provoke him. "They were trying to get me to respond to that, because I'm a black kid," he said.
Asked why else he thought the incident was racial, he added, "Three blacks in a car, all white policemen, the way they look at us."
When the beating was over, the police officers left him and Mr. Helms standing by the side of the road, he said. "They said, 'Guess what?' I said, 'What?' They said, 'You're in a Crips neighborhood.' They laughed and took off." Mr. Allen said he and his friends, all unemployed, came from a neighborhood claimed by the Bloods, a rival to the Crips gang.
 
Friends Since Boyhood
 Since the incident, he said, he had spoken twice with Mr. King, who suffered multiple fractures and what his lawyer said may be permanent brain damage. Mr. King initially declined to characterize the incident as racial.
He and Mr. King have known each other at least since they were 13, Mr. Allen said. As a boy, he said, Mr. King, who is also now 25, enjoyed working on bicycles, and his father taught him to fix automobiles.
On his recent visits, he said, Mr. King was having difficulty remembering the night of the beating in a coherent way. "It sounded like he was talking in riddles, all mixed up," Mr. Allen said.
As Mr. Allen recalls it, the late-night incident began with the three men speeding down the Foothill Freeway in northern Los Angeles at what might have been as fast as 80 miles an hour. Mr. Burton said the men had each drunk a 40-ounce bottle of Old English 800 malt liquor.
Mr. Burton said, "Drugs had absolutely nothing to do with this incident." Medical tests also showed that Mr. King was free of drugs.
 
Saw Flashing Lights
 After visiting at Mr. Allen's house, the young man said, Mr. King told his friends he was taking them to a park where he had gone in the past with his father.
When he saw the flashing lights of a California Highway Patrol car behind them, Mr. Allen said: "I told him, 'Rodney, pull over, stop.' He just kept on going, kept on driving."
He said Mr. King continued driving on the freeway for about five minutes, with the patrol car behind them, during which time he continued to urge him to pull over.
"I was scared," he said, adding that he thought his friend was acting odd. "I was thinking, 'Why doesn't he pull over?' " But, Mr. Allen said, "He wasn't saying nothing, just driving."
Then, he said: "I thought he was pulling over, but he was going down the off-ramp. We stopped at the stop sign, and then we were driving again. I said, 'Rodney, pull over.' We were still driving, and the lights were flashing. I could hear a lot of cars.
"We stopped at a red light and took off again. We came to another red light. I told him, 'Rodney, stop,' and he finally went to pull over and he stopped."
 
In Glare of Light
 Their small white Hyundai was surrounded by police cars and illuminated by the glare of headlights. It was at this point, he said, that the other passenger, Mr. Helms, who had been asleep in the front seat, woke up.
"The police ordered us, 'Driver, put your hands out the window,' " Mr. Allen continued. "They said, 'Take your left hand outside the door and step out.' Rodney had the seat belt, and it kind of yanked him back. The police were getting nervous too. They told him to lie flat down, and he lay flat down."
Mr. Allen said he and Mr. Helms left the car on the opposite side, beside a large, dark park, and also lay down.
"The police put the handcuffs on me, and that's when I heard Rodney screaming," Mr. Allen went on. "He was screaming like he was getting a whupping.
"When I was little I used to get whuppings. This sounded different, like they wanted to hurt him. He's a real tough man, and he was like, 'Help!' He was screaming, 'Stop!' "
 
'They Made Me Crawl'
 After the screaming stopped, he said, he continued to hear the whipping sound of the nightsticks through the clatter of a hovering helicopter. Police officers in Los Angeles use standard-issue PR-24 aluminum nightsticks that are 24 inches long and weigh 27 ounces.
On the far side of the car, he said, he was ordered to crawl in the direction of the park, his hands still manacled behind him.
"They made me crawl a certain way, to scoot. I was flat down. I was definitely frightened. I thought I was going to get shot or something. I thought they were trying to get me to scoot somewhere real dark so they could hurt me. I had already been kicked twice."
Later, he said, "They slapped me twice against the car," threatening that he could get beaten like his friend, frisking him and covering his face so he could not see what was happening.
By that time, he said, Mr. King had stopped screaming. "I just closed my eyes," Mr. Allen said. "Whatever was happening to him, I didn't want to see."

HEADLINE: Capital-Hungry Banks Fatten Up

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
Reflecting higher confidence among investors, the banking industry has already raised more capital in stock offerings this year than it did during all of 1990.
The rush to market -- through a flurry of offerings of common and preferred stock, most of them this month -- is a sign not only of improved demand for bank stocks but also of a recognition by bankers that they must have more capital if they are to expand into new businesses or acquire other banks. 
 Led by Citicorp, which privately sold $1.28 billion of convertible preferred stock to more than three dozen investors around the world, banks have raised $2.78 billion of equity capital this year, compared with only $2.08 billion in all of 1990.
 
A Surge in Financings
 Including bond sales, which do not count toward equity capital but are an important indication of banks' financial strength, public financings this year total $4.08 billion, compared with $4.44 billion in all of last year.
The nearly $2.8 billion in equity investment raised this year is small compared with the more than $200 billion of capital in the industry. But the ability of healthy banks to raise new capital at a price they find acceptable is a sign that investors are not shunning all banks, despite heavy loan losses at some.
Federal Reserve officials, who have often urged banks to strengthen their financial base, are encouraging the financings by acting quickly when their approval is needed. The officials are also assuring potential buyers of large blocks of a bank holding company's stock that the buyers would not have to supply all the additional capital that might be needed if the company's subsidiary banks got into serious trouble -- even though such large buyers would have a controlling interest in the banking company under Federal regulations.
"The Fed is really trying to encourage various transactions which would produce more capital for the banking industry," said H. Rodgin Cohen, a banking specialist and partner at Sullivan & Cromwell, the law firm.
One example of this cooperative attitude involves Banco Santander's planned purchase of 13 percent of the stock of the First Fidelity Bancorporation, which was announced Monday. Mr. Cohen said Fed officials had indicated they would not hold the Spanish bank solely responsible for supplying additional capital if First Fidelity's subsidiary banks were to encounter serious difficulty.
The Spanish bank, which agreed to buy about 9.5 million First Fidelity shares for $220 million, will have two seats on the board of the bank, which is based in Newark. Banco Santander could eventually own 24.9 percent of First Fidelity if it exercises an option to buy 9.5 million more shares.
 
Investors Coming Back
 Analysts have warned that many banks will continue to report increases in loan losses and delinquent loans in the first half of this year. Still, "there are many investors who had made a decision to be out of bank stocks entirely, but have moved back into the group as stock prices improved," said James Schmidt, portfolio manager for the Freedom Regional Bank Fund, a Boston-based mutual fund.
Bank stock prices have increased by 50.4 percent from their lows on Oct. 31, 1990, according to an index maintained by Keefe, Bruyette & Woods, the securities firm. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index has increased 20.6 percent during the same period. During late 1989 and most of 1990, banking companies were among the worst performers in the stock market, as losses from bad loans discouraged many investors.
"Reinvestment opportunities for banks who are raising capital have never been better," said Richard Barrett, a managing director at Salomon Brothers and one of many investment bankers who have been advising banks to issue new securities.
The problems of some banks and savings institions have created "a target-rich environment" for banks with the money to make acquisitions, he said.
 
A Stronger Balance Sheet
 The Norwest Corporation, a Minneapolis banking company that bought a large bank in Wisconsin last year and has received approval to buy the largest banking company in Colorado, raised $192 million through a common stock offering in late February. The money was not needed to pay for the recent deals, said John D. Crumrine, treasurer. "But we think," he said, "that banks with the strongest balance sheet will be the most highly regarded in the marketplace and will have the most flexibility in the future."
Among the companies that have recently issued new common stock or securities convertible into stock, Norwest, Keycorp of Albany, and NBD Bancorp of Detroit are among the banking stocks recommended frequently by Wall Street analysts. The BankAmerica Corporation, another company whose stock is frequently recommended, was arranging a $125 million issue of preferred stock yesterday.
Other than the Citicorp private placement, the largest stock offering by a bank so far the year was for $689.3 million by the MBNA Corporation, a company whose only business is the credit card operation previously owned by MNC Financial of Baltimore.
Except for Citicorp, large New York City banks have not been raising new equity capital, even though their ratios of capital to assets are low by industry standards. Stock prices of the Chase Manhattan Corporation, the Chemical Banking Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation have risen, but they remain far below book value, or the value of each share if the company's assets were divided by the number of shares outstanding.
Jeffrey Peek, an investment banker at Merrill Lynch, said recently that "capital would come out of the woodwork" if some of the weakly capitalized banks were to announce merger plans that would lead to sharp cost reductions and the opportunity for bigger profits.

HEADLINE: Bush Greets Walesa With Debt Relief

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
Welcoming Lech Walesa to the White House for the first time since he was elected President of Poland, President Bush forgave an additional $800 million in Polish debt payments today.
With that decision the United States has now agreed to wipe clean 70 percent of Poland's $3.8 billion debt to Washington, 
 Administration officials said the debt reduction was intended to encourage the American business community to invest in Poland and to convince any resurgent Soviet hard-liners that Washington would continue to stand by and bolster emerging reformist Governments in Eastern Europe. Mr. Bush and Mr. Walesa followed up the debt-relief announcement by signing a joint statement declaring "a new era of cooperation and partnership."
A senior State Department official said the declaration was meant to serve as a demonstration of Washington's commitment to Poland's national security as well as its economy.
Addressing Mr. Walesa during a wind blown welcoming ceremony on the White House South Lawn, Mr Bush declared, "So, as you can see, Mr. President, we want your economic transformation to succeed, your new democracy to flourish."
He noted that by moving to eliminating 70 percent of Poland's debt, the United States was going beyond the 50 percent debt reduction set last week by the Paris Club, the consortium of Western creditor countries who among them hold $33 billion dollars of Poland's debts. "And we call on other nations to follow our example," Mr. Bush said.
Mr. Walesa, the former shipyard electrician and recipient of the Nobel Peace Prize in 1983, speaks only Polish. But he concluded his remarks with the English phrase "God bless America," at which point, Mr. Bush turned to him and responded, "Beautiful, thank you, so sweet."
Mr. Walesa responded to the debt-reduction announcement by noting that "it gives us new, great possibilities." He said Poland's economic recovery "is needed by the whole free world, for it extends its boundaries to the central region of the continent." "It extends the zone of democracy and security," he continued.
Obviously concerned that the generosity shown Poland not raise the hopes and appeals of other debtors, a State Department official said the action taken was "a very rare step" and that that scale of forgiveness would be limited to only Poland and Egypt. The Administration last year cancelled Cairo's $7.1 billion debt for sales of military hardware in gratitude for its role in the gulf crisis. Egypt has since asked its creditors for more relief.
 
Painful Economic Changes
 "These are unique circumstances," the official said, explaining that Egypt had played a critical role in the coalition that waged and won the gulf war. As for the Polish Government, he described it as "a new regime that more than any other country is undergoing a radical, comprehensive economic reform program," which he said made it "worthy of Western support."
Poland has gone farther in imposing often painful economic changes than any formerly Communist country. By ending subsidies and allowing prices to find their own level, Poland has succeeded in sharply lowering inflation and establishing a stable and convertible currency, although unemployment has risen in the process.
The American-Polish community is important politically in a number of cities.
The two leaders took a stroll through the Rose Garden, where Mr. Bush offered Mr. Walesa a flowering bud from a dogwood tree. During a one-hour meeting primarily devoted to economics, Mr. Walesa reported progress in Polish negotiations with Moscow to step up the scheduled withdrawal of 50,000 Soviet troops who are still stationed in Poland.
Mr. Bush's warmth, Administration officials said, reflects a belief that Poland's economic and political future is fundamental to the development of healthy democracies in neighboring countries struggling out of their Communist past. They said that even though Poland has been slow to privitize many state-owned industries, the Administration views Poland as the leader of Eastern European change and a hopeful example for its neighbors.
In terms of purely American politics, Mr. Bush was well aware that M. Walesa is a popular hero within the influential Polish-American communities, while Mr. Walesa was similarly well aware that these days Mr. Bush is also popular in those communities.

HEADLINE: Mayor Seeks 10% Tax Rise And Layoffs In Stamford

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., March 20

 BODY:
The Mayor of this Fairfield County corporate center is proposing to lay off 174 city workers and raise property taxes 10 percent in a budget that reflects the impact of reduced state and Federal aid as well as a slowdown in Stamford's once-booming economy.
In his $264.3 million budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning July 1, Mayor Thom Serrani on Tuesday proposed eliminating 44 vacant positions and laying off 174 of the city's 1,449 employees outside the school system. Eighty-four layoffs would come from eliminating the trash-collection division of the Department of Public Works, replacing it with private trash collectors. 
 "It is essential to live within one's budget and to occasionally accept the necessity of personal sacrifice," Mr. Serrani said in a letter to the city's Board of Finance and Board of Representatives, citing slower growth in tax revenues and a cut in state aid proposed by Gov. Lowell P. Weicker Jr. that would cost the city $7.2 million. The two boards have the power to reduce but not increase Mr. Serrani's budget.
 
Unions Unhappy
 Last summer, Stamford laid off 57 city workers, mostly clerical and public-works employees, to keep a deficit from developing in the current budget of $257.5 million.
Union leaders representing city employees expressed dismay at Mr. Serrani's decision to lay off more workers. "It just doesn't seem to be the appropriate solution for Stamford," said Peter Thor, staff representative for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and a spokesman for the Stamford Municipal Coalition, which represents nine city unions. "If this was Bridgeport, I wouldn't be saying that."
In the last two decades, this city of 108,000 became almost synonymous with suburban affluence and was the hub of Fairfield County's growth. Scores of corporations, many from New York City, relocated here. And city coffers swelled with additional property tax revenue from new homes, shopping centers, industrial parks, office towers and condominiums.
But in the last year, slower growth in the tax base and cuts in state and Federal aid have helped bring an end to that economic era, here and in other Connecticut cities.
Bridgeport, which has been flirting with bankruptcy, has been embroiled in bitter negotiations with a state fiscal oversight panel that is demanding reductions in services and layoffs of at least 58 employees to erase a $7.6 million deficit for the current fiscal year. Projections suggest that the city, which is the largest in the state, could accumulate budget shortfalls of $34 million next year and $200 million over five years.
The outlook is almost as bleak in New Haven, which is planning to lay off 236 employees to close a $6.2 million budget gap for the current year and a projected deficit of $40 million for the next fiscal year.
Though the budget proposal in Stamford entails less Draconian personnel cuts and a smaller tax increase than in Bridgeport or New Haven, officials in this prosperous city are not as accustomed to acts of austerity.
Paul A. Pacter, a professor of accounting at the University of Connecticut at Stamford and the city's Commissioner of Finance from 1984 to last October, warned that Stamford's troubles could become as dire as those in Bridgeport and New Haven.
He blamed the problems principally on the slower growth in taxable property, although other factors -- such as big pay increases awarded to city unions in arbitration proceedings -- helped make annual spending increases of 8 to 10 percent almost automatic during the 1980's. Mr. Serrani's 1991-92 spending proposal is a 3 percent increase over the current budget.
 
Some Positive Elements
 The total assessed value of taxable property in Stamford is expected to rise by $56 million, or 1.9 percent, for the next fiscal year, compared with increases of 5.1 percent last year and annual rises of about 6 to 8 percent during the previous five years.
Mr. Pacter noted, though, that Stamford, the state's fifth-largest city, has many positive fiscal attributes: no budget deficits since 1983, a moderate property-tax rate, high municipal bond ratings and a large and diversified commercial tax base.
"I really don't think Stamford is suffering from any mismanagement or overspending," he said.
Another major factor is the decrease in state and Federal aid. In the mid-1970's, 70 percent of Stamford's revenue came from property taxes, 20 percent from state and Federal funds and 10 percent from other sources. Now, 80 percent comes from property taxes, and 8 to 9 percent from the state and Federal governments.
Mr. Serrani, a Democrat who has been mayor for seven years, said the proposed tax increase would have been 6.5 percent instead of 10 percent if Governor Weicker had not proposed reducing state aid to Stamford. Stamford's property-tax rate rose by 4.5 percent last year. Tax increases during the previous six years ranged from 2 to 6 percent.
 
School Cuts Suggested
 The Mayor has proposed cuts in every city department for which he can set the budget, except the departments of health and welfare. By law, Stamford's mayor cannot reduce the budget of the Board of Education, which makes up $103.2 million of the Mayor's overall 1991-92 budget proposal. But he did urged the Board of Finance and the Board of Representatives to make reductions in the school department, which has about 1,700 employees.
All day Tuesday, workers in the city's Government Center commiserated with those who had been notified that they were to be laid off. "My greatest fear right now is if I can't make my mortgage, I might lose my condo," said one employee, Diana M. Crouse, the director of the city's Fair Rent Commission and a city employee for 17 years. "There is nothing out there. I don't even have my resume ready."
Union leaders and political opponents of Mr. Serrani have attributed Stamford's budget problems in part to mismanagement.
But even the critics concede that external factors, like the nation's recession and the slumping real estate market in the Northeast, have been a big factor. "Stamford is not growing at the dizzying pace of the 1980's," said Mr. Thor, the union leader. "But nothing is growing at that rate."

Crouse, director of the Fair Rent Commission, who will lose her job, and Sherry Perlstein, whose youth agency will no longer receive city funds. (Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times) (pg. B7)

HEADLINE: At Newsstands Soon: a Daily Slugfest

BYLINE: By ALEX S. JONES

 BODY:
A battle royal among New York City's tabloid newspapers is about to begin.
By this weekend, The Daily News should be back on most newsstands, and television commercials urging readers and advertisers to come back to the paper are scheduled to start. 
 "You can look to us to fight back for our place," said Robert Maxwell, the paper's new owner whose stewardship is to begin with tomorrow's issue. The News's founder, the Tribune Company of Chicago, sold the paper after it lost most of its circulation and advertising in a crippling strike.
 But the city's two other daily tabloid papers, New York Newsday and The New York Post, say they are going to fight just as hard to keep the significant gains in circulation and advertising they have made since the strike began on Oct. 25.
 
Campaigns Are Ready
 "We don't anticipate keeping everything that we got, but we also do not expect to shrink to anywhere near pre-strike levels," said Robert M. Johnson, the publisher of New York Newsday and the larger Newsday on Long Island. He said he had his own promotional campaign ready to run.
Peter S. Kalikow, owner of The Post, said that he had "a little" radio and television promotion planned and that he would compete with The News by "putting out the best paper we can."
Mr. Kalikow has said that his main strategy is to keep his costs down and make a modest profit, which he thinks is possible as long as The News's circulation does not swamp his own, as it did before the strike.
While regaining some advertising right away would be a vote of confidence for The News, all parties agree that the major battle will be over circulation.
Before the strike, The News had daily circulation in the New York City area of just over 1 million and Sunday sales of 1.3 million, according to the Audit Bureau of Circulations. The paper says it now has a daily and Sunday circulation of about 600,000, but the unions say it is about 400,000.
 
Circulations Went Up
 The New York Times gained little of the circulation lost by The News, and several newspaper analysts say it will not be one of the main combatants in the newspaper war.
During the strike, New York Newsday's weekday circulation rose about 120,000 and The Post, which has no Sunday paper, added about 200,000.
Even more damaging to The News, New York Newsday has sold almost 300,000 more copies on Sunday than it did before the strike. Sunday's issue is the most important of the week because it is packed with advertising.
In theory, if The News rebuilds its circulation its advertising will probably return as well.
Mr. Maxwell has already had success in luring some of the paper's largest advertisers back, at least for the moment, and some are gleeful at the prospect of a revived News.
"We're anxious to get back in the paper," said Bob Cole, advertising manager for Stern's, a department store chain with two large stores in Queens. Stern's ads have already begun appearing again in The News.
An executive of a company that places coupon ads in Sunday papers said his company could be back in The News by early April if the Sunday circulation returns. The executive, who would speak only anonymously, said The News would attract more ads in proportion to its circulation increases.
But several newspaper executives said that translating circulation gains into advertising gains would be far more difficult because the city is in an economic slump that has been devastating to overall advertising sales. In effect, The News will be battling for a larger share of a shrunken pie.
 
The Personality Factor
 The probable outcome boils down to anybody's guess.
"A lot of it has to do with Maxwell's personality and how much confidence he inspires in readers and advertisers," said W. Dean Singleton, chief executive of Media News Group Inc., a newspaper chain that includes papers in Passaic and Union City, N.J.
Mr. Singleton was one of those approached by unions in their quest for a buyer, and he characterizes Mr. Maxwell's gamble that The News can be successfully revived as "very risky."
Over the long term, Mr. Singleton said, New York Newsday would prevail as the city's leading tabloid, in large part because its owner, the Times Mirror Company of Los Angeles, is committed to remaining and has vast resources to fight indefinitely.
"If anybody gets squeezed out, it's going to be The Post," he said.
Mr. Kalikow, of The Post, disagrees. He said that The Post had long-term contracts with many of its advertisers and that he expected to cut costs further to reflect the concessions won from unions by Mr. Maxwell.
Because his costs are relatively low, Mr. Kalikow said The Post could lose some of its circulation and still survive. He said the main fight will be between The News and New York Newsday over dominance on Sunday.
Mr. Johnson, publisher of Newsday, said that New York Newsday's strong presence in Queens and Brooklyn means that the paper would be vital to the city's advertisers, barring a catastrophic decline in circulation.
Mr. Maxwell, who seems to be practicing his American slang in anticipation of a donnybrook, said of Newsday, "They ain't seen nothin' yet."

HEADLINE: Air Traffic Drops 26.8%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
International airline passenger traffic dropped by 26.8 percent last month on United States airlines amid a recession and the fear of terrorism, the Air Transport Association says.
Passenger traffic on routes inside the United States fell 5.5 percent, producing a total decrease of more than 10 percent, the steepest drop in nearly 25 years, the airline trade association said on Monday. The declines are measured against traffic in the corresponding month a year earlier. 
 Passenger miles for February fell to 5.15 million from 7.04 million internationally, to 23.2 million from 24.5 million domestically and to 28.3 million from 31.5 million over all.
"Revenues are expected to be way off," said Tim Neale, a spokesman for the association.
The losses are particularly troublesome to an industry in which two leading airlines, Continental and Pan Am, are operating under bankruptcy protection and several others are having severe financial problems.

HEADLINE: Dow Rises by 4.21; I.B.M. Drops Further

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
One day after its worst session in more than five months, the stock market brushed itself off yesterday and posted a small gain in nervous trading.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 4.21 points to close at 2872.03. Volume on the New York Stock Exchange was fairly heavy, at 196.8 million shares, and advances led declines by a small amount. 
 The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks closed up 1.33 points, to 367.92, and the Nasdaq composite index rose 3.28 points, to 466.09.
In early trading, stocks moved within a narrow range as bargain hunters sought values after Tuesday's 62-point Dow selloff.
Investors and traders kept a wary eye on I.B.M., which was a big factor in Tuesday's decline after it announced lower expected earnings. Shares of the computer maker closed down 1 yesterday, to 114 1/8, on four million shares traded.
"Basically, the market stabilized after the trauma of yesterday," said Ronald J. Hill, investment strategist for Brown Brothers Harriman Inc. Investors searched for safety, he added, "as they continue to sell high-tech issues and move money toward consumer nondurable stocks like foods, drugs and tobaccos."
Utilities showed some strength yesterday, he noted, reflecting the lower inflation fears in the bond market, and possibly the decision by the Illinois Supreme Court to allow the Commonwealth Edison Company to put into effect an already approved rate increase over the objections of consumer groups. The utility's stock was up 5/8, to 39 1/4.
Mr. Hill said yesterday's "real strength came from a reversal in bonds, indicating that inflation expectations are not getting worse, providing a base of confidence to retain stocks."
Concern over first-quarter earnings continued to worry the market, however. Some traders felt early in the session that I.B.M.'s stock price could hold and that the worst of Tuesday's decline was over. But others remained skeptical, and declining issues took an early 5-to-1 lead over stocks advancing.
 
Other Computer Stocks
 Among the personal computer stocks following I.B.M. down were Compaq Computer, down 1 3/4, to 59 1/2, and Apple Computer, down 1 3/4, to 67 3/4. Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing fell 2 1/8, to 87 1/2, also on a poor earnings outlook.
In Tokyo, the stock market was closed today for Spring Equinox Day. Yesterday, the Nikkei index slipped 557.31 points, or 2 percent, to close at 26,449.35.
Toward noon, the New York market made a small run on bargain hunting, with advances taking a slight lead over declines. But by early afternoon, the Dow had slipped into the negative side in directionless trading.
Choppy trading persisted into late afternoon, with stocks moving toward their highs as bonds posted further gains. "The market has room to rebound further," Mr. Hill said. "You had more volume on a slightly up day like today than the lighter volume on a bad day like yesterday."
Among the stocks posting gains was NCR, up 3 1/4, to 98, after A.T.& T. said it would increase its offer for the computer company to $100 a share if NCR removed its board next week. But traders and analysts noted that shares stopped short of that price, an indication that investors were unconvinced that A.T.& T. would clinch the deal. A.T.& T. shares slipped 3/8, to 34.
In the health-care sector, C.R. Bard, principally engaged in hospital and surgical specialties, rose 1 1/4, to 21 1/4, on speculation of favorable first-quarter results. The company is awaiting Food and Drug Administration approval of its Probe III angioplasty catheter
Other health-sector stocks that performed well were Pfizer, up 3 3/8, to 104; Schering-Plough, up 1 1/8, to 50 1/8; Merck, up 2 1/4, to 103 3/4, and American Cyanamid, up 1 1/2, to 53 1/4.
Warner Lambert rose 3, to 74, following a buy recommendation from a Dean Witter analyst, Jerome Brimeyer, who said the company's Cognex drug for Alzheimer's disease could be approved by the end of 1991.
Airlines were narrowly mixed, while auto stocks were down. Chrysler slipped 3/8, to 14 1/2, and General Motors fell 1 1/4, to 37 3/8.

HEADLINE: Study Finds U.S. Behind In Key Fields

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The United States, which had a commanding lead in high technology a decade ago, is now losing badly to foreign competitors in a number of fields considered crucial, a group of executives said today.
The Council on Competitiveness, a nonprofit organization of leaders in business, education and labor, reviewed America's position in technologies. Ninety-four technologies were reviewed. 
 The council found the United States was still either the leader or competitive in about two-thirds of the technologies. But in a third, the council said, United States companies were far behind and were no longer a factor in world markets or were expected to fall hopelessly behind over the next five years.
 
Disturbing Decline
 The council said this was a disturbing decline from a decade ago, when the United States would have been judged to be the leader in virtually all of the technologies surveyed.
The council's report, "Gaining New Ground: Technology Priorities for America's Future," gave each technology one of four rankings. A "strong" ranking means United States industry is in a leading world position and is in no danger of losing that position over the next five years; "competitive" means United States industry is roughly even with the world's best; "weak," means the United States is behind or likely to fall behind in the next five years, and "losing badly or lost" means the United States is no longer a factor or not likely to have a presence in the next five years.
Following are the findings:
 
STRONG
Materials and associated processing: Bioactive and biocompatible materials, bioprocessing, drug discovery techniques, emissions reduction, genetic engineering, recycling and waste processing.
Engineering and production: Computer-aided engineering and systems engineering.
Electronic components: Magnetic information storage and microprocessors.
Information: Animation and full motion computer video, applications software, artificial intelligence, computer modeling and simulation, data representation, data retrieval and update, expert systems, graphics hardware and software, handwriting and speech recognition, high-level software languages, natural language, neural networks, operating systems, optical char acter recognition, processor architecture, semantic modeling and interpretation, software engineering, transmitters and receivers.
Powertrain and propulsion: Air-breathing propulsion, low-emission engines and rocket propulsion.
 
COMPETITIVE
Materials and associated processing: Catalysts, chemical synthesis, magnetic materials, metal matrix composites, net shape forming, optical materials, photo resists, polymers, polymer matrix composites, process controls and superconductors.
Engineering and production: Advanced welding, computer integrated manufacturing, human factors engineering, joining and fastening technologies, measurement techniques and structural dynamics.
Electronic components: Logic chips, sensors and submicron technology.
Information: Broad band switching, digital infrastructure, digital signal processing, fiber optic systems, hardware integration, multiplexing and spectrum technologies.
Powertrain and propulsion: Alternative fuel engines, electrical storage technologies and electric motors and drives.
 
WEAK
Materials and associated processing: Advanced metals, membranes and precision coating.
Engineering and production: Design for manufacturing, design of manufacturing processes, flexible manufacturing, high- speed machining, integration of research and design and manufacturing, leading- edge scientific instruments, precision bearings, precision machining and forming and total quality management.
Electronic components: Actuators, electrophotography, electrostatics, laser devices and photonics.
Powertrain and propulsion: High fuel economy-power density engines.
 
LOST OR LOSING BADLY
Materials and associated processing: Display materials, electronic ceramics, electronic packaging materials, gallium arsenide, silicon and structural ceramics.
Engineering and production: Integrated circuit fabrication and test equipment and robotics and automated equipment.
Electronic components: Electrolumines displays, liquid crystal displays, memory chips, multichip packaging systems, optical information storage, plasma and vacuum fluorescent displays and printed circuit board technology.

The nation's trade deficit grew to $7 billion in January, as a rebound in imports was substantially offset by stronger exports, the Commerce Department reported. [Page D1.] The U.S. and Canada said they would speed up some tariff-cutting. [D7.]

HEADLINE: Dinkins Asks Unions to Give Back Gains to Help Shrink Government

BYLINE: By JOSH BARBANEL

 BODY:
Mayor David N. Dinkins asked municipal labor leaders yesterday to roll back health-insurance costs and other benefits as he, for the first time, proposed a long-term strategy to close a soaring city budget gap by permanently shrinking the size and cost of the government.
Mr. Dinkins provided few details, but he said the concessions he was seeking were "sizable" and could offset the need for thousands of layoffs and hundreds of millions in additional budget cuts that city agencies were directed to prepare yesterday. The actions are intended to close a $3.1 billion gap in a budget of about $29 billion for the fiscal year beginning July 1. 
 "I have every confidence we can reach an accord," Mr. Dinkins said after meeting with the labor leaders. "They can read and write and count just like I can, and they will recognize the devastating impact if we don't get some assistance from them in some of these quarters."
The sweeping request goes far beyond other concessions previously sought by the Mayor and is part of a new approach to the city's worsening fiscal situation sketched out by Mr. Dinkins in briefings at Gracie Mansion for business executives, labor and civic leaders and commissioners.
After months of criticism for what many fiscal analysts viewed as an inconsistent and piecemeal effort to close city budget gaps, Mr. Dinkins said the administration had to deal forcefully with a pattern in which the city is continuing to spend more on services than it is receiving in taxes.
With the local economy in a deep recession, he said, the city could afford no new taxes above the $1 billion increases already called for in the Mayor's financial plan. Instead he called for permanent labor concessions -- he called them "labor contributions" -- and permanent cuts in city services and the city work force.
Labor leaders, who were being asked to give back benefits won in negotiations over the last decade, including some won from Mr. Dinkins only months ago, said that they could not support the concessions Mr. Dinkins sought.
"Absolutely no givebacks," Sandra Feldman, president of the United Federation of Teachers, said after the meeting. "We are not going to open these contracts again."
At the meeting, other labor leaders said they were willing to do their fair share but were not willing to see the city "balance the budget on the backs of city workers," according to one participant.
But the labor leaders said they had agreed with the Mayor that the city's fiscal problems were serious, and they said they were impressed with Mr. Dinkins's efforts to take charge. They agreed to meet with him again this morning to continue discussions.
In addition to giving back benefits, Mr. Dinkins asked the labor leaders to consider such permanent concessions as some holidays without pay, changes in work rules and the repeal of recent state legislation increasing workmen's compensation benefits. Earlier drafts of the city's new plan called for $300 million in labor concessions, but yesterday no figures were given.
 
1970's Crisis Recalled
 The concessions sought were reminiscent of those won from municipal unions during the fiscal crisis in the 1970's, when pension and other benefits were cut back. In the early stages of that crisis, the Mayor then, Abraham D. Beame, negotiated concessions in work rules from unions to avert layoffs in one year, but sweeping layoffs were required the following year.
Behind Mr. Dinkins's efforts was a realization that the city's fiscal situation had worsened in the last few weeks with a projected reduction of $600 million in state aid and tax revenues below projections.
Mr. Dinkins, in a statement to city commissioners, called fiscal problems the "defining reality" of his administration.
Yesterday, underscoring this concern, both the city and state comptrollers issued reports showing that in the current fiscal year tax revenues were falling below the city's projections, while the number of city employees, though declining, remained above the level forecast.
 
$800 Million in Cuts Asked
 The administration said that in the next fiscal year the city faced a new budget gap of $910 million on top of the $2.2 billion gap it had reported since November. To close the new gap, Mr. Dinkins asked his commissioners to prepare more than $800 million in budget cuts, some of which would be offset by concessions he hoped to get from labor leaders.
Agencies were being asked to cut spending an average of 13 percent, in addition to severe cuts adopted within the last few months. A memo from the Mayor to agency heads said the Sanitation Department and the Department of Parks and Recreation would be hit with cuts of about 25 percent, while the Fire, Correction and Police Departments would face much lower cuts.
"We are certainly going to have some problems, and I don't want to sugarcoat that," Mr. Dinkins told reporters. "but I think it is also important to understand that part of this effort is to try to do certain things with lesser personnel, try to be more efficient."
He said he was "confident that we have the brainpower, the ingenuity and the will to get the job done."
Mr. Dinkins is also calling for a $2 billion cut in projects now included in the city's $20 billion capital budget over the next four years. But city officials said yesterday that all but $600 million of the cut projects would be replaced by other high-priority projects.
New York City spends $1 billion a year in health and welfare costs, and in its latest contracts agreed to increase city payments to union welfare funds by $100 a year for each employee. The funds typically pay for dental care, eyeglass benefits and other services.
"It is an area that virtually every employer, public and private, around the country is looking at for savings," said Robert W. Linn, a former city labor negotiator and now a labor consultant.
City health plan costs have been rising at a staggering rate. In 1984 the city agreed to cover the enrollment of each worker in what was viewed as a typical health plan, the Health Insurance Plan of New York.
But since then the cost of the H.I.P. plan has risen far above the increases in other health services; it rose by more than 30 percent in the last two years alone, said Allen J. Proctor, executive director of the state's Financial Control Board.
 
Stronger Mayoral Role Praised
 For weeks, both labor and business leaders have asked Mr. Dinkins to take a stronger role in leading the city out of its fiscal crisis and in giving them a say in the process.
Yesterday, as Mr. Dinkins called the leaders to meet with him, business executives applauded the Mayor's new proposals, and labor leaders objected to them. But both praised him for taking the lead.
Ronald K. Shelp, president of the New York City Partnership, a business group, said it was a "very dramatic change in directions."
"This is the first time I heard the Mayor say there was a structural deficit that will be addressed by recurring savings," Mr. Shelp said.
Barry Feinstein, president of Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, said: "We hollered at the Mayor to take charge, and he took charge. We were not happy with what he was saying, but he was running things and doing it well."

HEADLINE: Bizarre Priorities on Arms

 BODY:
It's a propitious moment to curb arms sales. Iraq has just demonstrated the perils of arming states to the teeth in the Middle East. And arms buyers and sellers are looking to Washington for leadership. But instead of trying to negotiate restraints, President Bush seems eager to reopen the Middle East arms bazaar. It's up to Congress to reverse his priorities.
Responding to pressures from U.S. defense contractors and their Congressional backers, Mr. Bush wants the Export-Import Bank, a Government agency, to underwrite sales of arms to states that can't afford them by guaranteeing up to $1 billion in bank loans. That would supplement the loan guarantees the Pentagon already provides. 
 And just weeks after forgiving billions in loans to Egypt, Mr. Bush intends to sell it $1.6 billion in new weapons. That deal represents just a fraction of the $18 billion in arms that the Administration is planning to sell to the Middle East in the coming year.
Oddly, in his speech to Congress on March 6, Mr. Bush put a high priority on curbing chemical, biological and nuclear arms in the region. But he said nothing about conventional arms, which suggests that he has yet to learn one of the larger lessons of the Persian Gulf war: in this unstable region, arms have a nasty way of outlasting alliances. Congress can get him to reconsider. It can hold up the Egyptian sale and vote down the Ex-Im Bank credits.
Why the rush to sell more arms? For one thing, the defense budget is on the way down, and U.S. arms makers are lobbying hard to boost sales abroad to offset declining Pentagon purchases. For another, the gulf war alarmed Turkey, Saudi Arabia and other states in the region, sharpening their appetite for weapons.
Defense Secretary Cheney even tries to justify the sales as a way to minimize U.S. presence on the ground. But he overlooks the Saudi Army's tentative performance in the war, which suggests that even new weapons won't enable the Saudis to defend themselves. And he ignores purposes other than self-defense that new weapons could serve buyers. Just look at Iraq.
Other circumstances make a rare opportunity to slow arms trafficking. Hungry buyers now want American-made weapons. Thus the usual argument that they will turn elsewhere if the U.S. doesn't satisfy their needs may not apply. Impressed by preliminary reports of U.S. technological prowess, buyers are less likely to settle for second-best.
That gives Washington extra leverage on its competitors in the arms market to cooperate in trimming sales. And other suppliers, like the Soviet Union, seem ready to cooperate.
Middle Eastern buyers will also have trouble paying for new arms. Egypt and Turkey are in poor shape economically. Israel is preoccupied with providing for the resettlement of Soviet Jews. Even oil-rich Saudi Arabia is borrowing to pay its share of the costs of the gulf war.
Seldom has the chance to restrain arms peddling been greater than it is today. If President Bush wants a really new world order, he could start by trying to negotiate constraints on arms sales.

HEADLINE: Milking Poor Families

 BODY:
What's one of the first things you'd do if you wanted to devastate poor families with young children? Raise milk prices. That's exactly what the Senate has approved, without hearings, as an amendment to an emergency appropriations bill. The provision would raise the price of whole milk by as much as 26 cents per gallon and low-fat milk by as much as 40 cents per gallon.
The sponsors, led by Senator Patrick Leahy of Vermont, contend that higher milk prices are needed to save dairy farmers victimized by a 25 percent drop in prices during the past year. The plight of dairy farmers is real, and some may go broke if milk prices don't recover. But their plight is not unique; millions of other Americans have been victimized by recession. Besides, if Congress wants to bail out dairy farmers, there are a lot of better ways than to take milk away from poor children. 
 The sponsors say their bill won't increase consumer prices very much because it affects only the price paid to dairy farmers. The basis for this claim is that because milk processors and retailers have successfully avoided passing plummeting raw milk prices on to consumers, they will now charitably choose to absorb the new price hikes. That's a novel but unconvincing assumption. The amendment would also raise the cost of food stamps and other Federal programs in ways the sponsors only partially recognize and offset.
It's no mystery why Senator Leahy wants to help Vermont dairy farmers with higher prices, whose origin few consumers will understand, rather than with higher taxes, which everyone will understand. What's odd is why 59 other senators, many from non-dairy states, went along with this outrageous affront to low-income families.

HEADLINE: Here We Go Again -- Arming the Mideast

BYLINE: By Flora Lewis; Flora Lewis is senior columnist of The New York Times.

DATELINE: PARIS

 BODY:
Momentum for a new arms race in the Middle East is already building. As Yuli Vorontsov, the Soviet Ambassador to the United Nations points out, everybody was so awed by America's high-tech weapons in the gulf war that every country in the Middle East is clamoring for something similar.
The Soviet Union is concerned about U.S. plans to deliver important new weapons to its allies -- the Arab nations as well as Israel -- and doubtless Mikhail Gorbachev brought it up with Secretary of State James Baker in their Moscow meeting. Mr. Vorontsov says Moscow favors a club of arms suppliers to prevent the kind of unrestrained buildup that made Iraq such a menace. 
 Saddam Hussein's Iraq was a Frankenstein monster, created by oil revenues, competition for the lucrative weapons market and political rivalry. It could happen again, if not in Iraq then in some neighboring, unstable regimes. Nobody can guarantee that today's friend won't become tomorrow's enemy.
There is a common interest -- between East and West, Arabs and Israelis and among regional players -- to head off a new capacity for aggression and vast new arms expenditures that undermine the development of civil societies. The international coalition against Iraq is likely to remain intact until there is assurance that Iraq's stocks of chemical, biological and nuclear weapons materials have been destroyed. Soviet officials say Iraq has a lot more Scuds than it used, maybe hundreds more, and these also must be found and destroyed.
But the longer term goal of security can be compromised by renewing the regional arms race. The tangle of national and economic interests is creating intense pressures to override the common interest.
Mr. Vorontsov claims Moscow is determined not to revive old habits. He says it has refused Syria's plea for better and more weapons and parity with Israel, though it continues to provide parts to resupply existing Syrian forces. He says he is confident his Government will resist the desires of its own military-industrial complex for larger sales.
But Middle East arms control is going to be a lot harder than arms control in Europe. Israel argues, effectively, that its survival depends on keeping well ahead of its enemies. Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Iran can show that the gulf war proved their need for truly modern defenses. The U.S. says it wants to maintain "balance," but it always seeks it at a higher level.
It isn't politically possible, and would certainly be undesirable, to establish big American bases in the gulf as the Pentagon once hoped. But the U.S. military can point to the difficulty and danger of relying on shipping equipment after a crisis starts.
The compromise tempting Washington is "prepositioning," which means to sell the Saudis and gulf emirates more arms than they can manage themselves to serve as stockpiles if American forces should have to return. The Russians say this is "old thinking," a reflex rather than a search for security based on an international agreement among leading arms suppliers.
The U.S. as yet has no initiative to propose. The Soviets are thinking of an approach that would distinguish between defensive and offensive arms, worked out initially among the five permanent members of the Security Council. Other suppliers, such as Germany, Argentina, Brazil and perhaps Switzerland and Sweden, would have to be brought in. But the Soviets argue that would be much easier if the Big Five set an example.
The simplicity of the idea should not mask the difficulty of the task. But it is urgent and specific and would be lost if utopian notions of disarmament were allowed to block concrete proposals. Moscow seems to be willing. Washington must avoid hasty commitments to allies and come up with a plan.

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: Tax Burden Drives People From New York

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Read Mario Bush's Lips" by State Senator Franz S. Leichter (Op-Ed, March 9), which advocates higher taxes for the wealthy in New York State, is a remarkable distortion and frightening coming from a legislator.
For several years I served on the New York City Industrial Development Corporation in an attempt to lure business into New York City. In contrast to Mr. Leichter's theories, the heavy rate of New York taxation was one of the leading reasons businesses were dissuaded from coming into New York City, along with poor quality of life and exceedingly difficult labor unions. 
 We live in a very mobile society where individuals and companies move freely to other locations where the business climate is considered less hostile. As it is, the citizens of New York City are taxed more heavily than any other municipality. We have lost a great many affluent people and large business organizations who could have provided jobs for many of our unemployed. To increase the tax burden further on the wealthy will continue to drive out business at an unprecedented rate.
It may interest Senator Leichter to know that every responsible study I have seen shows that the wealthy pay a very heavy proportion of the tax burden on Federal and state levels. If they remain wealthy despite this burden, it is not because they are not taxed enough, but perhaps because they are superachievers to begin with.
 
BERNARD RICHARDS
Old Westbury, L.I., March 12, 1991

HEADLINE: A Hogan Can Be as Good as a Log Cabin

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One word mars your otherwise excellent article on the Shiprock, N.M., girls' high school basketball team ("A Team Spawns Pride in a Land of Despair," sports pages, Feb. 25). Navajos do not use ceremonial "huts," but they do use "hogans," a perfectly good American word, according to Webster's New World Dictionary (third college edition).
The hogans around Shiprock are built from earth and wood, and hundreds are used as people's houses, as well as for ceremonies. The best-built ones are as finely crafted as a Maine log cabin, and more than a few are larger and in better shape than plenty of New York City apartments. 
 It might seem trivial, but calling Navajo dwellings huts disparages the homes of tens of thousands of people spread across a territory as large as West Virginia. As the rest of your article shows, Navajos are not primitives holding ceremonies in crude huts. They are simply people, struggling to maintain their culture and provide for their families in the face of difficult economic and social conditions.
 
KENNETH BOBROFF
Brooklyn, March 2, 1991

HEADLINE: The Limits of What Reparations Can Achieve;
War Guilt and Debt

 BODY:
To the Editor:
While it may be a legitimate principle that an aggressor owes reparations to compensate for war losses ("Reparations, Without Retribution," editorial, March 4), Iraq has few resources to compensate Kuwait for the damages to its economy. Iraq, with about one-third the population of Vietnam and the economic output of Kentucky, has suffered possibly $100 billion of damages to its own economy.
While you point out that Germany paid 15 billion gold marks ($3.5 billion) reparations from World War I, the total reparations assessed against it were 132 billion gold marks ($31.4 billion). The economic disaster of the 1920's (and political disaster of the 30's) resulted from the Allies' attempt to extract payments. 
 Resistance by debtor countries crystallizes as domestic opposition to the macroeconomic measures necessary to make reparations develops. This contributes to the degeneration of the country's finances, making the economy less productive and the obligation more burdensome.
German obligations did not remain constant as you imply, but evolved through a series of negotiations that rescheduled old debts and arranged new loans. The original London schedule of 1921-23 differed substantially from the Dawes plan of 1924-29 and the final Young plan of 1929-31.
The fiscal-austerity program required by the debtor country is politically unsustainable because it lowers incomes and makes the distribution less equal. We must keep in mind that war guilt does not have anything to do with the ability of a country to pay; to force Iraq to pay reparations will prove not only futile, but also harmful to future United States interests in the region.
 
DANIEL PATRICK KING
Whitefish Bay, Wis., March 6, 1991
 
The writer teaches economics at Milwaukee Area Technical College.
