HEADLINE: U.S Motor Vehicle Population Gaining

 BODY:
To the Editor:
One historically tested solution to this country's growing energy -- that is, oil -- problems, implicit in a Senate document of 1974, still merits examination and debate. In that report, made by B. D. Snell, special counsel to the Subcommittee on Antitrust and Monopoly, it was stated that:
"One bus can eliminate 35 automobiles; one streetcar or rail transport vehicle can supplant 50 passenger cars; one train can displace 1,000 cars or a fleet of 150 cargo-laden trucks." 
 In 1974, we had 129.9 million motor vehicle registrations in a population of 211.9 million. This came to a density of one motor vehicle for every 1.63 Americans. By 1988, the last year for which we have Census Bureau data, our human population had increased by 16.11 percent to 245 million. In that year, our motor vehicle registrations increased by 41.24 percent to 183.5 million cars, trucks and buses -- for a ratio of one motor vehicle for every 1.34 people.
The environmental damage caused by this incremental combustion of gasoline and diesel oil in the 15 years since this Senate document was published can only be estimated. Environmentalists will estimate the adverse effects of automotive air pollution at somehat higher levels than refiners of crude oil and manufacturers of oil-burning vehicles will.
Far less arguable are the Government data on motor vehicle accidents and deaths. In 1989, the last year for which we have final figures, there were 34.4 million motor vehicle accidents. They caused 46,900 deaths and 5.56 million injuries. In 1989 alone, according to the Insurance Information Institute, the economic losses caused by these traffic accidents came to nearly $94 billion.
During the 15 years between the Senate calculation that one street-car carries as many people as 50 passenger cars and 1989, this country suffered 775,257 deaths in motor vehicle accidents, for an average of 48,454 car crash deaths a year.
This total of traffic-accident fatalities comes to 112,791 more deaths in the 15 years since 1974 than the total of 662,565 Americans killed in all of our wars from the start of the American Revolution in 1776 to the liberation of Kuwait in 1991.
If for no other reason than the clearly estimable numbers of lives it would save daily, the national revival of the formerly common electric-powered streetcar, commuter train and even trolley-bus mass transportation systems as low-cost alternatives or supplements to the one-person, one-car system of daily transportation that sprang into being after World War II is one approach to our predictable oil shortages that is eminently worth our serious consideration.
 
ALLAN CHASE
New York, March 6, 1991

HEADLINE: For Design Mart, East River May Yet Prove Unbridgeable

BYLINE: By SUZANNE SLESIN

 BODY:
IT is quiet these days at the International Design Center, New York, in Long Island City, Queens. The corridors are virtually empty. The 10-acre $150 million complex of furniture showrooms, which seemed so promising when it opened in 1985, seems to have aged prematurely.
Gretchen Bellinger , a fabric showroom, vacated its 4,000-square-foot space in December, and the lights are off at the Artemide lighting showroom, whose designs are now shown in Manhattan. Signs at Knoll, in crisp Helvetica type, direct customers down the hall to the Westinghouse showroom. 
 And at the American Standard showroom, the faucets have been turned off at the aquatic extravaganza -- a cascade of sinks with a moat -- designed by the Chicago architect Stanley Tigerman.
These are not the best of times for makers of designer furniture, an $8 billion annual business that has been synonymous with avant-garde design for at least the past 30 years. Manufacturers, whose primary customers are architects and decorators, cite many troubles: recession, competition from manufacturers who copy and discount classic designs, the expense of flamboyant showrooms, the high cost of European imports, and a flurry of mergers and acquisitions.
Stendig Inc., a company that epitomized the buoyant market of the 60's and 70's, went out of business in October. Westinghouse Electric bought Knoll International on Oct. 1 and created a new subsidiary, the Knoll Group. And Tinicum bought International Contract Furnishings from the Chartwell Group in October.
Many of the people long associated with the smaller, innovative companies are no longer on the scene. For example, Stephen Kiviat, president of Atelier International, which made its reputation with Italian imports like the Corbusier chaise longue, resigned on March 4 after 22 years with the company.
"The 60's were not only the Doors," said Samuel Friedman, the founder of International Contract Furnishings. "There were a lot of people who also wanted to be the flower children of the furniture industry. "And when these smaller firms became profitable it became evident to the bigger firms that they needed the piquant mustard they offered."
Now these out-of-the mainstream firms are going the way of the hippie.
The International Design Center, New York (informally, I.D.C.N.Y.), was an attempt to create a new, relatively inexpensive hub away from two of Manhattan's designer furniture "districts," one around Third Avenue and 58th Street, the other around Lexington Avenue and 33d Street. The center was developed by the Lazard Development Corporation, a subsidiary of Lazard Freres ,the investment banking concern, and opened to enthusiastic responses from design-conscious New Yorkers.
Arthur Katz, executive vice president of the I.D.C.N.Y., said rent per square foot is "in the $20 range."
Showroom space in the Architects and Designers Building at Third Avenue and 58th Street in Manhattan averages $35 a square foot. Robert Beguelin, the building manager, said that of the 172,000 square feet alloted to showroom space in the building, 8 percent is currently available.
Six years after the design center opened, in spite of valiant promotional efforts, it is still difficult to get designers and their clients to cross the East River from Manhattan. Today, the center looks like an archeological site.
The two large buildings at the I.D.C.N.Y., Center One and Center Two, total about a million square feet. "Right now," Mr. Katz said, "we're about 20 percent vacant."
And much of the space in use is not filled with the spectacular furniture once envisioned. The New York City School Construction Authority now occupies 150,000 square feet. A photocopying company and a steam-fitting concern are also recent tenants.
Color Day '91, a symposium sponsored by the Color Association of the United States, Contract Design magazine and Allied Fibers , drew a crowd of about 300 people to Queens on March 12. They sat on white folding chairs in the soaring atrium of Center Two to hear the future of color in textiles discussed. But that was just one day.
"The way business is being done and who is doing it is changing," said Alexia Lalli, senior vice president, marketing and communications, at the center. "We're trying to work with our tenants and the industry to maintain the I.D.C.N.Y. as a major contract furniture showplace." Contract furniture is the industry's term for office furniture. She added, "We are also looking for other kinds of compatible tenants."
"It's a very quiet exodus," said Linda Foa, the former director of the 24-year-old organization known as Designer's Saturday. "Firms are slowly migrating back to the city." Many newer independent showrooms have settled in the Chelsea and SoHo districts of Manhattan.
George Kordaris, managing director in this country for Vitra Seating, a German furniture company, said: "Originally, everyone had great hopes of the I.D.C. being the vibrant center of design in the world. Now no one is buying furniture." Mr. Kordaris said that when employees are being laid off, new chairs are not needed. He was the host last week of a support group for out-of-work designers and furniture buyers in his company's Manhattan showroom.
"There's a whole new industry out there called 'used office furniture,' " he said. "Refurbishing and selling -- now that's a new business."
Mr. Kiviat, formerly of Atelier International, said building the center was like building a new bicycle factory just at the time that half the cyclists in the country gave up riding.
Even so there are plans for yet another design center, the New York Resource Center, which would be housed in the former B. Altman & Company store on Fifth Avenue at 34th Street. It is the idea of Judson Spencer, a marketing consultant.
"I felt the building had everything: location, freight docks, freight and passenger elevators, escalators, high ceilings, columns," he said.
Five months ago Mr. Spencer approached the building's owners, Mall Properties , a New York real-estate development company, with his plan.
"Although it's all far from being finalized, my ideas were enthusiastically received," Mr. Spencer said. "We'll see what happens. We'll know what to expect in the next 60 days."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 13, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in The Home Section on March 21 about the International Design Center in Long Island City referred incompletely to the history of International Contract Furnishings, a furniture manufacturer. It was founded jointly by Samuel I. Friedman and Hal H. Stearns.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Sterling Optical Appoints Chief and No. 2 Executive

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH M. FOWLER

 BODY:
The Sterling Optical Corporation named two top executives yesterday.
Robert K. Low, 53, was appointed chairman and chief executive. Mr. Low, a director of Sterling since 1959, replaces Richard Block, who had been chairman, president and chief executive. No reason was given for Mr. Block's replacement.
And George Casabona, the company's executive vice president, assumes the additional title of chief operating officer. Mr. Casabona, 42, will be in charge of Sterling's day-to-day operations. 
 Mr. Low was a founder and, until 1982, the president of the Savin Corporation, a maker of copying equipment. Mr. Low was unavailable for comment yesterday.
Mr. Casabona, a graduate of St. John's University and a certified public accountant, joined Sterling a year and half ago after working Silor Optical Inc., where he was an executive for 10 years.
As head of operations, Mr. Casobona said, "I'll be meeting with financial institutions and shareholders, and I'll visit stores to interface with employees."
Sterling, which lost money in the 1988 and 1990 fiscal years, has recently changed its focus to concentrate on its core business of operating and franchising its nationwide chain of 247 optical stores.
"We are the fourth-largest optical chain," Mr. Casabona said yesterday. "Half of our stores are company-owned." He noted that the Hackensack, N.J., company was installing a computerized point-of-sale to maintain better inventory control.
Turning to profits, he said, "As of Dec. 30, 1990, we continued to lose money and it looks as if we will for fiscal 1991, which ends this June 30."
Mr. Casabona said he expected the company to post a profit in the 1992 fiscal year as a result of its refocusing. "We hope to weather the economic storm in good shape and we are seeing a rebound now," he said.
To concentrate its efforts and obtain working capital, Sterling sold its Whitestone Products subsidiary, a maker of diapers, and its Uniforms by Gilson division in 1989, and its Whaledent division, a maker of dental equipment, in 1990.
Sterling's stock gained 25 cents yesterday, to $3.50, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: FUTURES/OPTIONS;
Silver Prices Drop Sharply; Gasoline Up on Supply Data

BYLINE: By Associated Press

 BODY:
Silver futures prices fell sharply yesterday, erasing Tuesday's gains, after the market failed to rise above recent highs. Other precious metals prices also fell.
Gasoline futures surged on a mixed day for the energy markets; grains and soybeans were mostly lower, and livestock and meat futures fell. 
 Silver futures settled 8.5 cents to 10.4 cents lower on the Commodity Exchange in New York, with the contract for delivery in March at $3.936 an ounce.
Gold futures ended 80 cents to $1 lower on the Commodity Exchange, with March at $363 an ounce; platinum finished $2 to $2.10 lower on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with April at $396.70 an ounce.
Yesterday's selloff was led by speculators after they failed to bid the May delivery price above the high of $4.10 an ounce posted Tuesday, when the metal had risen as much as 8.8 cents an ounce for the day, said Peter Cardillo, research director with Jesup, Josephthal & Company in New York.
William O'Neill, senior futures strategist with Merrill Lynch, said the drop in silver prices during the last week represents a fading of the euphoria that came with the end of the Persian Gulf war three weeks ago.
Prices of stocks and of industrial metals like silver and platinum rose strongly after the war, fed by hopes that the end of fighting would hasten an economic recovery in the United States.
Mr. O'Neill said those hopes were being replaced by "a more realistic view," adding, "Sure, the recession probably will be over in three to six months, but it still will probably be a relatively slow recovery, not a super boom."
Unleaded gasoline futures surged on the New York Merc, largely in reaction to the American Petroleum Institute's weekly stocks report Tuesday showing an unexpectedly large drop in gasoline stocks to 216.4 million barrels, compared with 241.2 million a year ago.
The gasoline market also continued to be supported by the shutdown of a large Mexico City refinery that produces 40,000 barrels of gasoline daily, analysts said.
"We're heading into the peak driving period and gasoline stocks are in a tenuous situation," Mr. O'Neill said.
The April contract for crude oil expired yesterday at $20.38 a barrel, down 23 cents. Other contracts for crude oil settled 10 cents to 17 cents higher, with May at $20.05 a barrel; heating oil was 0.05 cent lower to 0.29 cent higher, with April at 57.67 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was 0.85 cent to 2.02 cents higher, with April at 73.78 cents a gallon.

HEADLINE: Problems of Homeless: The Individual Stories

BYLINE: By JANET MASLIN

 BODY:
In his documentary "Home Less Home," Bill Brand does something that should not be as unusual as it is. He approaches homeless people with a camera crew and asks who they are, how they became homeless and what they do to survive. The answers, while not surprising, give individual faces to problems that are too easily reduced to generalities. "The American ideal of freedom and justice is out of sync with the facts," he concludes, after having amassed sad and persuasive evidence to corroborate that statement.
 The testimony of many homeless people would have been a sufficiently urgent basis for any documentary film on this subject. But Mr. Brand goes further, offering a disquisition on the connections between the condition of the homeless and the consequences of studying it as a series of images. Those images, he maintains, have the effect of distancing a viewer from reality. That point may be accurate, but for a film maker it is also academic and somewhat self-defeating. 
 "It's not that we can't examine what it's like," Mr. Brand says of homelessness. "It's that we need to examine the sources of our imagination." So the film includes scenes from Preston Sturges's famous "Sullivan's Travels," in which a successful film maker (Joel McCrea) and his wisecracking companion (Veronica Lake) impersonate hobos and hitch a ride on a freight train. "This screwball comedy supports the idea that we can only understand what we experience," Mr. Brand observes.
 The film looks back frequently to earlier images of homelessness, mostly from the Depression; there are still photographs by Walker Evans, Dorothea Lange, Berenice Abbott, Jacob Riis and many others. But these glimpses, says Mr. Brand, "help create a distance in me, so that even as I'm experiencing the present I'm imagining another place and time." Even the film's scenes of contemporary homeless people living near the Port Authority Bus Terminal or in City Hall Park or at shelters around New York City take on a degree of unreality in this context. "We're so accustomed to homeless people as voiceless victims that when they speak, we no longer believe they are homeless," Mr. Brand says. 
 The homeless people interviewed in the film are exceptionally calm, articulate and intelligent by any standard. Even the former psychiatric patients heard here sound unusually sane. Mr. Brand maintains that the idea that many homeless people are mentally ill is one more way of oversimplifying homelessness and keeping it at a distance. He argues for a more all-embracing way of understanding homelessness, one that takes into account the interplay between unemployment, drugs, poor health care, inflated housing costs and other contributing factors. 
 The film's outright evidence is often more effective than its academic analysis. Mr. Brand offers cogent examples of media distortion in reporting on homelessness (as in a television account of a windshield washer who claims to make $180 on a good day), and provides facts and figures to attest to the impossibility of escaping homelessness once it has set in. Still, this bleak and disturbing film concludes on a hopeful note, as two homeless young boys eagerly discuss their ambitions. Even in this disheartening atmosphere, ideas of becoming a policeman or a rock star or a world-famous boxer are not out of the question. 
 On the same program at the New Directors/New Films series is "Blackwater Summer," Christopher Dudman's prettily executed, slightly precious account of a young girl's last carefree days during a vacation that is interrupted by family tragedy. This film's romantic seashore setting is in marked contrast to anything Mr. Brand's film contains. Both can be seen tonight at 6 and Sunday at 9 P.M. at the Museum of Modern Art.

Home Less Home
Directed and produced by Bill Brand; written by Mr. Brand and Joanna Kiernan; photography by Zoe Beloff; edited by Ms. Kiernan. At the Roy and Niuta Titus Theater 1 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, as part of the New Directors/New Films series of the Film Society of Lincoln Center and the department of film of the Museum of Modern Art. Running time: 70 minutes. This film has no rating.

HEADLINE: Our Towns;
Hunting for Elk On the Terrain Of Imagination

BYLINE: By ANDREW H. MALCOLM

DATELINE: BETHEL, Conn.

 BODY:
Sadly, but not surprisingly, not one single elk responded to the magnificent elk calls of Mark Shea here the other night. That's probably because the last recorded elk in Connecticut was shot and eaten some 200 years ago.
The lack of elk response could also have been because, while capturing first place in the evening's elk-calling competition, Mr. Shea was inside a noisy motel dining room, not exactly prime elk habitat. But the place was full of elk enthusiasts enjoying an evening of socializing, eating and tax-deductible auction bidding. 
 The elk backers wore everything from tweed coats to cowboy hats, and while the state's fragile economy somewhat dimmed their enthusiasm for parting with money, everyone there was 100 percent behind elk. "It's just so important," said Bill Joyce, who organized the special elk evening again this year.
The outgoing Mr. Joyce normally sells air freight. But in recent weeks, to his wife's dismay, he was consumed with preparations for the Second Annual Big Game Banquet of the Rocky Mountain Elk Foundation, Connecticut Chapter. The seven-year-old foundation is not as well known as Ducks Unlimited or the Ruffed Grouse Society, but the goals are similar.
The eventual survival of such species is seriously threatened by increasing urbanization and recreational development of the American countryside, where the modern definition of a conservationist is someone who built his sec ond home last year.
So these private groups use a variety of techniques to raise money to buy property or conservation easements on the property of others to protect the differing natural habitats of these wild creatures. The elk foundation also makes grants to states to finance improvement of existing forage for elk or even to transplant elk into a new area, as Mr. Joyce hopes will occur in northwestern Connecticut shortly.
The foundation was the brainchild of three men in the rural northwest corner of Montana, where big game still outnumbers humans. Although the largest support springs from 13 Western states where many elk still roam, a growing number of the 80,000 members are in the East. The most successful fund raiser is a banquet like this one, where elk fanciers gather to watch slides, buy raffle tickets, swap tall tales and eat (the big game dinner turned out to be beef or chicken). Members also bid on everything from collectors' knives and rifles to color lithographs and wilderness expeditions.
Last year, Connecticut's was among 138 elk dinners held nationally, attracting more than 32,000 guests. That night, about 250 state residents donated $30,000 of the foundation's $2.3 million in banquet receipts. Elk foundation officers profess no surprise that hundreds of elk enthusiasts exist even in areas with zero elk. "Wherever you find deer hunters," said Terry Cloutier, a regional supervisor, "you'll find elk hunters or wannabes. It's the logical next step up."
Some elk foundation dinners attract 600 or more people, 95 percent of whom are hunters. "But this year," said Mr. Joyce, "we got slammed by the economy in this state and all the talk about a new income tax." Barely 200 people showed up and contributed $24,000. Some auction items even went for under cost.
While hunting remains an accepted part of everyday life in many rural areas, some hunters in metropolitan areas like New York can find themselves on the defensive against animal-rightists and nonhunters who may date their distaste for hunting to imagining what happened to Bambi's mom off screen. A few banquetgoers seemed to sense some paradox in supporting the population and improved lives of elk so that they can be stalked, felled by sure shots, gutted, eaten and have their huge heads stuffed and mounted on strong walls.
Phil Young, who hands out cards for his own sanitation service ("It May Be Sewage To You, But It's Our Bread and Butter") in New Preston, was so proud of the elk he shot last fall that he brought the head along to this year's banquet.
But for Don Stickles, hunting's main attraction is being outdoors with his dogs, trying to outwit a wily wild creature on its home turf. A carpenter and new elk foundation member, Mr. Stickles has saved for an elk-hunting expedition this fall. But he says he's unsure about slaying anything so majestic. "Frankly," he said, "I don't know if I will. I know I want to be out there, though."
Does he ever feel sad killing animals for recreation? "Every single time," he said. "When you kill an animal, you take responsibility for that creature, just like I'm sure you do when you buy part of a cow wrapped in plastic."

HEADLINE: House Backs Bailout Bill, Sending It to Bush

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Following a subdued debate of barely 25 minutes today, the House approved the $30 billion bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry that it had rejected last week, and sent the measure to the President.
Some economists have estimated that the savings and loan crisis, the worst financial debacle in American history, could ultimately cost taxpayers $500 billion. The $30 billion measure, adopted by voice vote in the Senate on Tuesday evening, a minute after it was introduced, and passed by the House by 225 to 188 today, raises to $80 billion the amount appropriated since the fall of 1989, when the effort began. 
 In addition, an estimated $69 billion is expected to be lost on insolvent savings associations seized by the Government in 1988.
House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, Democrat of Washington, who endorsed the House savings and loan measure, summed up the mood of his colleagues.
"The main problem has been that this is paying for dead horses," Mr. Foley said. "I don't think there is anyone who votes for it with great enthusiasm."
The measure was supported by 106 Democrats and 119 Republicans. During the brief debate, only one Representative, Bernard Sanders, rose to speak out against it. The first-term member from Vermont and the House's sole independent, argued that the bailout should be financed by increasing taxes on families with higher incomes and not by increasing Government borrowings.
"It's a curious bill," Representative Sanders said. "On one side, we have the President of the United States and the leadership of both parties. On the other side, I suspect we have the vast majority of the United States."
The financing is expected to last only until this fall, when the Administration will be forced to return to Congress for more money. The General Accounting Office has estimated that regulators will need $50 billion more for next year.
After the rejection of the financing measure last week, lawmakers, feeling pressure from both Democratic and Republican leaders who saw the issue of delay as a potentially greater political disaster than the actual financing, sought to move quickly to complete legislation before Congress leaves for a two-week recess beginning Monday.
"Every day we delay results in throwing away additional money," said Representative Chalmers P. Wylie, Republican of Ohio, the ranking minority member of the House Banking Committee.
Today's legislation included a measure that expands the affordable housing program of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout, by about 7,100 homes. The legislation the House rejected last week included a measure that would have required Resolution Trust to make a greater effort to employ contracting companies controlled by women and minorities. Another measure that was defeated would have required that any new money for the bailout be raised by either increasing taxes or cutting spending on other Federal programs. The current program is financed through borrowing.
Lawmakers have said they will seek changes in the bailout process the next time the Administration seeks financing.
"As we move forward, I will insist on a host of reforms," said Representative Henry B. Gonzalez, the Texas Democrat who heads the Banking Committee.
Regulators have said they intend to use the $30 billion and borrow another $47 billion for working capital to sell, transfer or close 225 savings associations, about 10 percent of the industry, with assets of $145 billion.
Peter Monroe, president of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which sets policy for the bailout, said the effort had already protected 12 million depositors holding an average of $10,000. He said the new funds would go toward protecting 8 million more.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
A Question Of Fairness In Social Security

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
In agencies and re search institutes, at the Library of Congress and in universities around town, thousands of bureaucrats and scholars here spend their days studying the most arcane elements of the Government. Just this week, for instance, the General Accounting Office, the Government's chief auditor, published studies on minority representation at the National Agriculture Statistics Service (basically satisfactory) and on postage costs at the Department of Veterans Affairs (excessive).
But a fundamental aspect of the Government's largest program has never been fully explored. No one knows for sure whether the Social Security system, on balance, is progressive or regressive -- whether, in other words, the taxes and benefits tilt in favor of the rich or the poor. 
 "No one has ever done the work to actually show how people come out under Social Security throughout their entire lives," said Robert M. Ball, a former Social Security Administrator and one of the foremost experts on social insurance programs.
The question is especially pertinent this year, because an unusual coalition of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats in Congress is pressing for a cut in the Social Security tax. One argument for such a reduction, which is opposed by the Bush Administration and many Congressional leaders, is that taken alone the tax is the most regressive faced by Americans.
A policy is said by economists to be regressive if the poor bear a greater burden than the rich. It is said to be progressive if the reverse is true. The income tax system, for example, is progressive because the tax rate increases as income goes up.
For Social Security, on the other hand, each worker and each employer pay a flat 6.2 percent on each dollar of wages up to $53,400. No tax is paid on wages above that level. And no Social Security tax is paid at all on interest, dividends and investment profit, which are much more likely to be received by the rich.
That means that a husband and a wife, say schoolteachers, who each earn $50,000 a year pay a total of $6,200 in Social Security taxes. Their employers pay another $6,200, all or part of which the teachers presumably could have been paid had it not been for the tax. But a corporate executive who earns a $500,000 salary and receives another $500,000 in dividends and capital gains pays only a couple of hundred dollars more than either teacher. The maximum Social Security tax is $3,310.80.
To liberals, that seems unfair. But what they often do not take into account is that Social Security benefits are quite progressive.
Here is how the benefits generally work. When people retire or become disabled, the wages on which they paid Social Security taxes through their working lives are adjusted for inflation into current dollars and then averaged. The benefits are 90 percent of the first $356 of average monthly income, 32 percent of the amount between $356 and $2,145, and 15 percent of the amount over $2,145.
According to the Social Security Administration, the typical retired low-wage earner last year received 57 percent of his or her average monthly wages in benefits, while people who earned exactly the maximum on which Social Security taxes were paid each year received 24 percent of their average monthly incomes.
In the case of the schoolteachers and the corporate executive, the teachers could expect retirement benefits of about $2,400 a month, assuming that $50,000 was the average annual salary of each, while the executive would get only about $1,000.
But the issue is complicated by other factors. People who are better off frequently live longer and receive benefits for more years. Moreover, affluent men are more likely to have wives who never worked and thus paid no Social Security taxes but who are entitled to benefits for spouses. Both factors add to the regressivity.
Among the factors adding to the progressivity is the greater likelihood of poor workers' becoming disabled and receiving full benefits before retirement age.
The consensus of experts is that, all things considered, the system is probably somewhat progressive, although no one knows how much so. "Somewhere in all this," said Robert J. Shapiro, director of economic studies at the Progressive Policy Institute, "is a tenure-quality Ph.D. thesis."

HEADLINE: In Face of Cuts, Fernandez Calls for Increase in Budget

BYLINE: By JOSEPH BERGER

 BODY:
Faced with the prospect of chopping $505 million out of next year's budget, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday resorted to stiff-necked bargaining tactics: He asked for $26 million more to spend.
The Chancellor initiated the annual haggling ritual as he unveiled his request for a record $7.568 billion budget, including pensions and debt service. That is $300 million more than the Board of Education will spend in the current fiscal year that ends June 30. 
 Much of that $300 million increase would be the natural result of costs necessitated by inflation, contract settlements with teachers and expenses outside his control like $66 million that is passed through the Board of Education but is destined for private and parochial schools.
But at least $26 million was Mr. Fernandez's request for brand new money for repairing crumbling buildings, for enticing parents to take a more active role in schools and for enhancing his signature program to give schools more independence in decision making.
 
Budget as 'Road Map'
 By its most recent reckoning, the Dinkins administration has told Mr. Fernandez that he must cut $505 miilion from existing programs, after taking into account those unavoidable cost increases.
But in his budget proposal -- despite the certainty of some cuts -- the Chancellor made no effort to incorporate them. In a briefing for reporters at his downtown Brooklyn office, he acknowledged that the budget document was a "road map" of the school system's priorities as the city and state begin solidifying the allocations they will give to the schools.
He maintained that he had not included any prospective cuts in his new budget document because he did not know what his final allocations from the city and the state would be.
"You don't have a budget until the budget is adopted," he said. "There will be a lot of changes before the smoke settles."
"I have to be an advocate for the school system," he said. But he also admitted, "I have to understand we are part of the city and the state."
Traditionally, chancellors have always put forward daring budget documents knowing that mayors and legislators will still find plenty to gnaw away. Last year, Mr. Fernandez sought $217 million for new or enhanced programs but ended up trimming his budget by $275 million.
Despite his oratory yesterday, Mr. Fernandez is already working to save more than $200 million of the proposed budget by asking the state's Board of Regents for relief from class-size limits for learning-disabled students, by transferring more costs of caring for handicapped students to Federal Medicaid and by seeking retirement inducements for the most senior and highest paid teachers.
 
Taking Case to Albany
 Mr. Fernandez left for Albany immediately after the briefing to make his case for relief from some state mandates to the Regents, the state's highest educational policy-making board. Until Wednesday, Mayor David N. Dinkins had been telling Mr. Fernandez that he must cut $429 million, and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had been saying Mr. Fernandez must cut $221 million.
The total of $650 million was reduced to $505 million Wednesday night when Mr. Dinkins decided to redistribute the overall state cut to other city agencies, softening the impact on the schools.
Mr. Fernandez has said that cutting $650 million would, if nothing else were done, require cuts of 15 teachers for each of the system's 1,000 schools. Without layoffs, he has warned, cuts of that magnitude could then mean the elimination of full-day kindergarten and most summer school and afterschool programs.
How Mr. Fernandez ends up cutting his budget may not be entirely within his discretion. Officials close to the seven-member Board of Education said yesterday that several members, led by Ninfa Segarra of the Bronx, were demanding to find out what was in the budget and looking for spending pockets they might prefer to pare.
Mr. Fernandez got some other bad news this week. The capital budget that finances the construction of new schools and the renovation of old ones will have to be cut again because the Dinkins administration wants to reduce its annual interest payments.
The $43 billion, four-year plan had already been slashed by $640 million and on Wednesday an additional $245 million was cut. That would eventually mean a sharp reduction in the number of new schools the badly overcrowded and decaying system had hoped to build.
Although New York City has the largest portion of the state's lagging readers, impoverished and disabled students and overcrowded classes, the document said that it spends only $5,080 a pupil compared with $5,586 for the rest of the state and $7,775 a pupil in places like Nassau County.
Mr. Fernandez argued that despite his fiscal problems he had been able to improve attendance slightly and increase mathematics scores, and should be given $26 million for new programs.
These include $16 million for repairs for a system with a backlog of 42,000 repair orders; $1.9 million for "SWAT repair teams" that would be assigned to the boroughs for more efficient service; $2 million for replacement of school desks and other furniture; $1.25 million for "family-resource centers' to encourage more parent participation, and $3 million to train staff members at the 200 schools taking part in Mr. Fernandez's self-management experiment.

HEADLINE: When Patients Pay for Charity to Patients

BYLINE: By JOSEPH F. SULLIVAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PATERSON, N.J.

 BODY:
A growing financial crisis in the care of uninsured hospital patients in New Jersey is nowhere as apparent as in urban hospitals like St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center here.
Left since January to go it alone in caring for the poor and uninsured, St. Joseph's clinics and emergency rooms provide each day the only medical care a large working-poor population has ever known. As a result, the bills of patients who have health insurance or who can otherwise pay are marked up 33 percent, the surcharge going to pay for charity care. 
 "We take care of everyone who comes to our door," said Sister Jane Frances Brady, the hospital's president.In January the Legislature let lapse a state trust that collected a surcharge on all hospital bills and distributed the proceeds among hospitals that cared for non-paying patients. The surcharge, which had reached 19 percent, was blamed for pushing up insurance costs, forcing growing numbers of employers to drop health coverage for their work forces and making individual policies too expensive.
 
Care for All, but Who Pays?
 Gov. Jim Florio's administration and the Legislature have been wrestling with proposals to make health insurance more widely available and to provide community health services as a less expensive alternative to hospital visits. But they have yet to agree on how to pay for the state's guarantee of medical care for everyone. This has forced urban hospitals, which care for the most uninsured patients, to add "markups" to their bills ranging from 30 percent to 60 percent and higher.
Suburban hospitals meanwhile, with few non-paying patients, have been able to keep their surcharges as low as 4 percent.
"It looks almost as though they're trying to force urban hospitals to cut off care for the poor," said Sister Jane Frances. "But we're not going to cut out anything; we'll keep on providing care and arguing."
When surcharges for uncompensated care and charity care for prior years are added to St. Joseph's 33 percent surcharge, a paying patient who receives care costing $2,000 gets a bill for about $3,000. The bill shows both the actual charge and the mark up. "The only reason this has not caused a revolution is that most people simply turn the bill over to their insurers," Sister Jane Frances said. "But if they must pay the bill themselves, or any part of it, they are furious.
"They can appeal the added $1,000 to the state, and everytime they appeal, they win. Soon you're losing your credibility."
People then say the hospital has "plenty of money," Sister Jane Frances said.
The disadvantage that urban hospitals find themselves in because of the loss of the trust-fund subsidy has prompted Standard & Poor's to place five hospitals on a "credit watch," which could be the first step to grading their bonds downward.
The situation also has led officials of union health and welfare plans to say they intend to steer their members away from the more expensive urban hospitals and send them to the suburbs for medical care. But this may not be as easy as it sounds.
 
Some Physicians Balk
 Michael J. Sniffen, president and chief executive officer of Overlook Hospital in Summit, where the markup for charity care is 6 percent, said that while anyone could go to any hospital in the state, the physicians might not be willing to accept the discounted fees that the union plans usually called for.
"We're operating at 90 percent of capacity," he said. "It's an individual decision for the physicians."
St. Joseph's, started in 1867 by the Sisters of Charity of St. Elizabeth in a wooden house with 12 beds, and Overlook, founded in 1906 by Dr. William H. Lawrence Jr., are among New Jersey's largest and most diverse medical institutions. St. Joseph's has 701 beds and is completing a $78 million expansion that will add 51 beds. Overlook, which started with 30 beds, now has 590.
Each has more than 600 staff physicians and admits more than 20,000 patients a year. Emergency-room visits range from 30,000 at Overlook to 40,000 at St. Joseph's and out-patient visits from 170,000 to 200,000.
The main difference is their patients. Overlook cares for indigents, but it also serves residents of some of the state's most affluent communities. This enabled the hospital to finish with a surplus last year, while St. Joseph's had its worst cash problems in memory.
 
Cost of Supplies Affected
 As a result, Overlook was able to pay its suppliers on time and qualify for discounts based on the quantity of its purchases. St. Joseph could not pay its suppliers for as long as seven months and ended up paying penalties.
"We couldn't pay early enough to avoid the extra charges or to take advantage of cash discounts we should be entitled to," Sister Jane Frances said. "In these tough economic times, the vendors needed their money."
Mr. Sniffen said the state should end the system of forcing hospitals to include a hidden tax on their patient bills to finance care for the poor. "What is needed is some kind of broad-based tax, just what kind is a political question and one for the Governor and the Legislature," he said.
Governor Florio's Commission on Health Costs called last fall for a payroll tax to finance charity care; this was among 92 recommended changes in the health-care system. Thus far a payroll tax has found little support in the Legislature, which is up for election this year.
To put the financing question off until next year, the Governor's office and some lawmakers are considering reviving the system of surcharges on all hospitals equally and distributing the proceeds to the neediest hospitals for 12 months, starting in June.
 
Some Credit Ratings Drop
 It's a solution that pleases no one, but it is designed to reverse the growing disparity in hospital charges between urban and suburban hospitals and eliminate the credit cloud that has been placed by Standard & Poor's over Beth Israel Hospital in Passaic, East Orange General Hospital, Elizabeth General Medical Center, the Helene Fuld Medical Center in Trenton and St. Elizabeth in Elizabeth.
Fred Hillmann, a spokesman for Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey, said the surcharge on hospital bills was a major cause of rising medical insurance premiums. At present, he said, 30 cents of every dollar that Blue Cross pays in claims goes to cover surcharges and not medical care.
Mr. Hillmann also said another hidden cost was rising faster than charity care, and that is the difference between what Medicare pays for those on Social Security and the actual cost of their hospital bills. Until 1988 Medicare paid the full cost of hospital bills, but costs were rising so fast in New Jersey that the Federal program set its own limits, leaving a gap that has become another surcharge in all hospital bills.
St. Joseph's, which received state permission this year to make up in its patient bills for unpaid charity care dating to 1986, adds the Medicare gap to those charges.
"If you try tell people how New Jersey's hospital reimbursement system works," Sister Jane Frances said. "You sound like you're making it up."

GRAPHIC: Photo: "It looks almost as though they're trying to force urban hospitals to cut off care for the poor," said Sister Jane Frances Brady, the president of St. Joseph's Hospital and and Medical Center in Paterson, N.J., where a 33 percent surcharge is added to the bills of patients with insurance, to pay for care for the poor. (William E. Sauro/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: British Air Giving Away 50,000 Tickets

BYLINE: By STEVEN PROKESCH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, March 21

 BODY:
Impatient to fill seats emptied by the war, British Airways announced a bold promotional campaign today aimed at coaxing people into the air again. The airline, Europe's largest, will give away about 50,000 tickets on international flights as part of a broad program of incentives and promotions.
Fear of terrorism "evaporates with a free ticket," Lord King, the chairman of British Airways P.L.C., said at a news conference announcing the program. 
 British Airways, the leading carrier between Britain and the United States, will hold a lottery in 67 countries and will give away all seats on its international flights on April 23 to and from Britain. The winners of round-trip tickets will have to return to their home country by May 31.
 
Automatic Winners
 The 20,000 people who have already booked a British Airways international flight on April 23 will be automatic winners; they will get vouchers for the value of their original one-way tickets to or from London, good toward future travel.
In addition, 30,000 round-trip tickets will be awarded to people who apply by April 1 through forms available in newspaper advertisements or at travel agencies and British Airways ticket offices. [An advertisement appears in The New York Times today on pages A12 and A13.]
British Airways said nearly 6,000 of the 50,000 available seats would be on flights from the United States to Britain, including about 1,600 seats from New York. Even seats aboard the Concorde will be free on April 23. But more than half of the seats aboard flights from the United States have already been booked, so that only about 2,800 round-trip tickets will be given away in the United States.
In addition, the carrier said 250 American winners would also win two round-trip tickets for future flights from London to anywhere in the world that British Airways serves. Similar offers are not being made in other countries.
April 23, a Tuesday, was chosen because relatively few people start international vacations on Tuesdays. The fact that the date is also Shakespeare's birthday is coincidental.
 
'It Needs a Kick Start'
 At his news conference, Lord King explained the purpose of the promotion. "The engine of consumer demand did not just idle in neutral, it sputtered to a complete stop" during the Persian Gulf war and "now it needs a kick start," he said.
Although airline travel is recovering slowly, analysts predicted that other airlines would also take strong steps. On March 13, American Airlines announced sweeping cuts in its domestic and international fares.
The airlines "are worried they will miss out on a lot of summer traffic," said Richard Hannah, a securities analyst at UBS Phillips & Drew.
Analysts said that with British Airways continuing to lose money on many underbooked flights, the promotional benefits of the giveaway would outweigh the cost. "It probably will work out to be a quite cheap means of promotion," said Colin Fell of Kleinwort Benson Securities Ltd.
Lord King said British Airways was seeing "some patchy signs of improvement" in its business. "But the road to full recovery will not be easy," he said. "It will take a full six months to build stability back and to get real business growth."
British Airways described the free tickets as "the spearhead" of a broad promotional and incentive program that it is offering through Aug. 31 with the support of others in the British tourist industry.
A record 17.7 million overseas visitors came to Britain last year, injecting about 7.5 billion, or roughly $14.5 billion, into the British economy. The British Tourist Authority said that about 6 percent of jobs in the country depended on tourism.
A spokesman for the authority said inquiries from Americans, which were 50 percent below normal during the gulf war, had returned to normal. But many of those inquiries are not translating into bookings. A spokesman for British Airways said its bookings for the summer were "significantly below" those a year ago.
The British tourism incentives include such giveaways as a lifetime of holidays at a Scottish castle and a nobility title and discounts on hotels, car rentals, restaurants and theaters.
The promotional campaign comes as British Airways faces rising competition on its all-important London-United States routes.
A March 11 agreement between the United States and Britain permits American Airlines and United Airlines, America's two strongest carriers, to fly to Heathrow, the London airport preferred by international passengers. British Airways, the leading carrier at Heathrow, was angry that the treaty allowed the transfer of most Heathrow rights from two of America's weakest airlines, Pan American World Airways and Trans World Airlines.
British Airways was also upset about the British Government's recent decision to open Heathrow to new carriers.
 
Move by Virgin Atlantic
 Virgin Atlantic Airways Ltd., the main British competitor of British Airways on the North Atlantic routes, has announced that it will try to take advantage of that decision. Virgin Atlantic now operates from Gatwick Airport in London.
British Airways also announced plans to introduce unspecified "long-term incentives, rewards and special services" aimed at attracting corporate accounts and business travelers. It declined to say whether it might include a frequent-flier program. No large European carrier offers frequent-flier programs comparable to those in the United States, although some participate in the programs of United States carriers.
British Airways participates in the programs of United, American and USAir. But its executives worry that some airlines might kick British Airways out of their programs as competition on the North Atlantic routes intensifies and it might lose business travelers. The success of British Airways in attracting higher-paying business travelers has played a big role in its transformation from a loss-plagued, state-owned airline into one of the world's most profitable investor-owned carriers.
 
30 Percent Drop in Traffic
 After the outbreak of the gulf war, British Airways' passenger traffic dropped by as much as 30 percent. In response, the carrier tried to make steep cuts in fares between the United States and Britain. But after some initial ticket sales, United States officials blocked the fare cuts.
British Airways' business has improved, but so far this month the airline's passenger traffic is still 11 percent below the level of a year ago.
The 50,000 tickets would represent an estimated 10 million, or roughly $18 million, in lost revenues if sales were strong. But, Lord King noted, "we're not actually having good days."
Judging from the flood of calls to British Airways' reservation center in New York today and the thousands of people who swamped the airline's ticket office on Regent Street in London, he is right.
 
Competitors' Comments
 Timothy Smith, an American Airlines spokesman, said American had no immediate plans to match the British Airways program.
A United spokeswoman said her carrier had no immediate comment.
Richard Branson, the chairman of Virgin Atlantic, said: "We strongly urge you to fly British Airways on April 23. As for the other 364 days of the year, you will still find the best fares and best service on Virgin Atlantic."

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
Displaced Iraqis Streaming Into Allied-Held Zone

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DHAHRAN, Saudi Arabia, March 21

 BODY:
Thousands of Iraqi civilians have streamed into small villages and isolated desert communities in Iraqi territory controlled by allied forces, United States Army officials said today.
The majority of the people are returning home after fleeing advancing allied ground forces. But many others are refugees from the civil unrest that has engulfed several towns and cities in southern Iraq, the officials said. 
 Coalition troops, mainly the United States Army, control 15 to 20 percent of Iraq, and under the Geneva Convention are responsible for the welfare of civilians in the occupied area. The head of the Army's civil affairs operations said today that American forces were trying to leave as many administrative and governmental functions as possible in the hands of Iraqi officials.
"Except for our presence, we're trying to keep this business-as-usual," the Army officer, Col. James T. Kerr Jr., said in an interview. The approach reflects Washington's oft-stated position that it has no plans to occupy any part of Iraq longer than it takes to reach a permanent cease-fire.
 
Feeding the Needy
 American officials have given needy Iraqi civilians emergency food, shelter and other relief in certain areas. But Colonel Kerr said the occupation would have to extend six to eight more weeks before American officials would begin to consider the possibility of assuming control of public services like schools, the police and sanitation.
The occupied zone embraces more than 25,000 square miles -- it is about the size of West Virginia -- and the bulk of it is desert. About 6,500 Bedouin herders live in the desert, and more than 10,000 others live in the eastern part of the area. The Euphrates River marks the zone's northern boundary, from just south of Basra and encompassing the village of Samawa. From there, the demarcation line runs southwest to the Saudi border.
Tiny rural communities dot the southern banks of the Euphrates, supporting a small but robust mercantile economy, and a few farming areas, principally onions and grasses like hay, Colonel Kerr said. Lively commerce has resumed in those areas, he said.
The civilian communities under allied control seem to have escaped much of the devastation plaguing areas of Iraq near military targets that were bombed by allied warplanes.
 
Slightly Better Conditions
 While there are some shortages of food and water certain areas, Colonel Kerr said the limited communications and sanitation systems that existed before the war were largely functional. For the most part, he said, buildings are not damaged. "Most people are picking up where they left off," he said.
In Safwan, a town of 3,000 people on the Kuwaiti border, where allied and Iraqi commanders have held cease-fire talks, farmers are returning to harvest the region's onion crop.
In the western desert, the village of Salman is showing signs of life again as an important hub for food, fuel and medical supplies for Bedouins who live within 100 miles, Colonel Kerr said.
Before the fighting started, allied planes dropped leaflets on Salman, which had a prewar population 4,500, and other communities in southern Iraq, urging residents to evacuate the combat zone. "The message was, 'Get out of Dodge,' and most people did," said Colonel Kerr, who added that only the Mayor of Salman and 11 of his friends and family stayed on.
French forces, who during the ground war protected the allies' westernmost flank, have occupied Salman. A delegation from the International Committee of the Red Cross visited the town this week, Colonel Kerr said.
He said the Army had set up checkpoints along Highway 8, the main thoroughfare between Basra and Baghdad that runs inside the northern boundary of the occupied territory, inspecting vehicles for arms and ammunition.
There has been no resistance from Iraqis in the occupied zone, and no reports of gun-smuggling from across the demarcation line with Baghdad-controlled Iraq, he said. Iraqi Army units are not permitted to cross the line. While many Iraqis are now returning home, a large but dwindling flow of refugees fleeing strife just north of the occupied territory pose a potential problem for American forces.
Along the Euphrates south of Nasiriya, a former work camp for third-country nationals had filled with about 2,000 Iraqis escaping the fighting between troops loyal to President Saddam Hussein and Shiite Muslim groups. By today, though, that number had shrunk to 200, Colonel Kerr said, suggesting that the Government was regaining control in the city.
 
Iraq Frees More Kuwaitis
 RIYADH, Saudi Arabia, March 21 (AP) -- Iraq freed 1,150 Kuwaitis today in compliance with the terms set by the allies in cease-fire talks.
The Kuwaitis were brought in buses across the Iraqi-Saudi border near the Saudi town of Arar, 550 miles northwest of Riyadh, said Roland Huguenin, spokesman for the International Committee of the Red Cross. He said he had no information on the freed Kuwaitis, and did not know how many were civilians and how many were soldiers.
Elizabeth Dole, president of the American Red Cross, said about 4,900 Kuwaitis were still held by Iraq.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thousands of Iraqi refugees fleeing from the civil unrest that has engulfed towns and cities in southern Iraq are moving into isolated desert communities in areas controlled by allied forces. Women and children gathered water and wood near a refugee camp in Safwan, Iraq. (Angel Franco/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Washington Talk;
A Question Of Fairness In Social Security

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
In agencies and re search institutes, at the Library of Congress and in universities around town, thousands of bureaucrats and scholars here spend their days studying the most arcane elements of the Government. Just this week, for instance, the General Accounting Office, the Government's chief auditor, published studies on minority representation at the National Agriculture Statistics Service (basically satisfactory) and on postage costs at the Department of Veterans Affairs (excessive).
But a fundamental aspect of the Government's largest program has never been fully explored. No one knows for sure whether the Social Security system, on balance, is progressive or regressive -- whether, in other words, the taxes and benefits tilt in favor of the rich or the poor. 
 "No one has ever done the work to actually show how people come out under Social Security throughout their entire lives," said Robert M. Ball, a former Social Security Administrator and one of the foremost experts on social insurance programs.
The question is especially pertinent this year, because an unusual coalition of conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats in Congress is pressing for a cut in the Social Security tax. One argument for such a reduction, which is opposed by the Bush Administration and many Congressional leaders, is that taken alone the tax is the most regressive faced by Americans.
A policy is said by economists to be regressive if the poor bear a greater burden than the rich. It is said to be progressive if the reverse is true. The income tax system, for example, is progressive because the tax rate increases as income goes up.
For Social Security, on the other hand, each worker and each employer pay a flat 6.2 percent on each dollar of wages up to $53,400. No tax is paid on wages above that level. And no Social Security tax is paid at all on interest, dividends and investment profit, which are much more likely to be received by the rich.
That means that a husband and a wife, say schoolteachers, who each earn $50,000 a year pay a total of $6,200 in Social Security taxes. Their employers pay another $6,200, all or part of which the teachers presumably could have been paid had it not been for the tax. But a corporate executive who earns a $500,000 salary and receives another $500,000 in dividends and capital gains pays only a couple of hundred dollars more than either teacher. The maximum Social Security tax is $3,310.80.
To liberals, that seems unfair. But what they often do not take into account is that Social Security benefits are quite progressive.
Here is how the benefits generally work. When people retire or become disabled, the wages on which they paid Social Security taxes through their working lives are adjusted for inflation into current dollars and then averaged. The benefits are 90 percent of the first $356 of average monthly income, 32 percent of the amount between $356 and $2,145, and 15 percent of the amount over $2,145.
According to the Social Security Administration, the typical retired low-wage earner last year received 57 percent of his or her average monthly wages in benefits, while people who earned exactly the maximum on which Social Security taxes were paid each year received 24 percent of their average monthly incomes.
In the case of the schoolteachers and the corporate executive, the teachers could expect retirement benefits of about $2,400 a month, assuming that $50,000 was the average annual salary of each, while the executive would get only about $1,000.
But the issue is complicated by other factors. People who are better off frequently live longer and receive benefits for more years. Moreover, affluent men are more likely to have wives who never worked and thus paid no Social Security taxes but who are entitled to benefits for spouses. Both factors add to the regressivity.
Among the factors adding to the progressivity is the greater likelihood of poor workers' becoming disabled and receiving full benefits before retirement age.
The consensus of experts is that, all things considered, the system is probably somewhat progressive, although no one knows how much so. "Somewhere in all this," said Robert J. Shapiro, director of economic studies at the Progressive Policy Institute, "is a tenure-quality Ph.D. thesis."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 23, 1991, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
The Washington Talk column yesterday about the Social Security system gave an incorrect example of benefits. The married couple who were schoolteachers and whose average annual salary was $50,000 each would together receive almost $2,044 a month, double the maximum benefit to any one individual.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
New Top Management Is Named at Bonwit

BYLINE: By Isadore Barmash

 BODY:
Pyramid Companies, the mall developer based in Syracuse, yesterday named new top management for its Bonwit Teller chain and said it would relocate the store's headquarters to Syracuse from New York City.
Frank Doroff, Bonwit's chairman and chief executive, will resign after a 60-day transition period, Pyramid said, along with two members of his team, Tom DeRogatis, chief operating officer, and Teresa Pineda, general merchandise manager. Executives close to Bonwit said the departure of the Doroff team, which had been expected in light of the headquarters move, resulted from a combination of expense pressure on Bonwit and Mr. Doroff's reluctance to move to Syracuse. 
 Named to replace them were two executives of J. W. Rhodes, an Ithaca, N.Y., department store also owned by Pyramid. Murray Daitchman, currently president and chief executive officer of J.W. Rhodes, and Roberta Benvenuti, the vice president and chief operating officer at J. W. Rhodes, will serve as a consolidated management of both Bonwit and J. W. Rhodes.
Pyramid, which operates 16 shopping centers in New York State and New England, is the largest mall developer in the Northeast. It bought Bonwit's stores in Buffalo and Boston and the use of its name at a bankruptcy auction last May. In October, a third Bonwit store was opened in a Pyramid mall, the Carousel Mall, in Syracuse.
The Bonwit corporate offices will be relocated to Syracuse "in order to benefit from a corporate synergy with Pyramid," said Robert J. Congel, Pyramid's managing partner. "This decision is based on the rapidly changing retail marketplace and the economic realities of doing business today in New York City."
Mr. Doroff, 42 years old, who was chairman and chief executive of the Federated/ Allied Merchandising Services before joining Bonwit 10 months ago, said he planned to pursue other opportunities in retailing.
Bonwit has 50 employees in its main office, but Mr. Doroff said it was not known yet how many would move to Syracuse.
A fashion retailer mostly aimed at the affluent customer, Bonwit Teller was founded in 1895 and grew to 17 stores. It experienced severe financial problems after it was bought in 1988 by the Hooker Company, an Australian developer that went into voluntary bankruptcy in the United States in 1989.
Yesterday, Mr. Congel said, "Bonwit Teller continues to thrive, and Pyramid's efforts to revitalize it are proceeding as planned." He said that three more stores would be opened in the next three years: in Albany, in 1992; Harrisburg, Pa., in 1993, and in Providence, R.I. in 1994.

HEADLINE: U.S. Seeks Much Bigger Amount To Shore Up Bank Deposit Fund

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said today that the Bush Administration's plan to shore up the ailing program that protects deposits in the nation's banks calls for an increase in his agency's borrowing authority of $70 billion, not the $25 billion the Administration proposed earlier this week.
 Mr. Seidman disclosed the higher figure during an appearance before the Senate Banking Committee as he sought to reassure the legislators that the bank insurance fund would have enough money available if needed. But instead, his discussion of the additional $45 billion in borrowing ability raised concerns among lawmakers and industry experts that the banking crisis is significantly more severe than has been portrayed by the Government and that a taxpayer bailout of the industry might be inevitable. 
It's a real surprise," said Mark Riedy, president of the National Council of Savings Institutions. "It seems to be a formal recognition that the problem is considerably larger than the Administration has been willing to talk about."
 
More for Savings Bailout
 Lawmakers have already been struggling with the highly unpopular taxpayer bailout of the nation's savings and loans. Shortly after the disclosure on the bank insurance fund, the House approved $30 billion it had rejected last week to continue the savings bailout, and sent the measure to the President. [Page D1.]
 Earlier this week the Administration said it was asking Congress to provide the F.D.I.C. with the authority to borrow $25 billion from the Federal Reserve System, which would be repaid with interest by increasing the premiums from banks to the insurance program. But also tucked into the 317-page legislative proposal sent to the lawmakers was a technical measure modifying a cap on the amount the F.D.I.C. may borrow.
 Mr. Seidman said today that the modification would permit the F.D.I.C. to treat its existing $5 billion credit line from the Treasury Department as equity. Under existing law, which allows the F.D.I.C. to borrow nine times its net worth, the agency could then use the $5 billion as collateral for borrowing an additional $45 billion.
 But Mr. Seidman predicted that the F.D.I.C. would need to borrow only $10 billion this year and that under a "pessimistic economic scenario," it would need to borrow a total of $30 billion to $35 billion over the next three years. His estimate today was consistent with earlier forecasts he had made that covered only the next two years.
 The bank insurance fund currently has $8.4 billion, or about 43 cents per $100 in deposits, and it is estimated that that will drop to 19 cents by the end of the year, But estimates by the General Accounting Office and the Congressional Budget Office predict that the fund will be insolvent within the next two years. According to Federal law, the fund should have at least $1.25 per $100 in deposits.
 James Barth, a professor at Auburn University who has served as a Government economist, said the Administration's proposal to seek so much borrowing authority for the bank fund was an ominous sign.
 "You don't ask for such large amounts of borrowing authority if you don't intend to spend it," he said. "It is an admission of serious problems, apparently far more serious than we have been led to believe."
 "This strongly suggests that we're moving closer to the admission that taxpayers will have to be involved in assisting the banks," he added. "Otherwise they would simply go to the banks to get additional capital."
 Although Mr. Seidman's comments to the committee were intended to win support for the Administration plan, it had the effect of increasing lawmakers' fears of a replay of the savings and loan debacle.
 
Concern for Taxpayers
 "We simply must not get into the position where the taxpayer in the end has to pick up the bill," said Senator Jim Sasser, Democrat of Tennessee and the chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
 Mr. Seidman sought to allay the concerns of the Senators, saying taxpayer money would be used only as a last resort. "Only if the industry is in such shape that it cannot pay premiums would the taxpayer be called upon," he said. "That is highly unlikely, but it is possible."
 He emphasized that the increased borrowing authority was a "standby plan" to be used only if the economy does not recover.
 "We will be dedicating bank premiums so that the banks will be required to pay for these loans over time," Mr. Seidman said. The F.D.I.C. is expected to raise bank premiums on June 30 to 23 cents for every $100 in deposits, from 19.5 cents, to pay the interest on the $10 billion that it plans to borrow this year. Any further borrowings, Mr. Seidman and the Administration have proposed, would be repaid through increases in the bank premiums, although the legislative proposal includes a cap on premiums at 30 cents for every $100 in deposits.
 The $45 billion in additional borrowing, which would provide working capital for the agency, would be available from the Federal Financing Bank, which was created in 1973 to coordinate the financing activities of Federal agencies whose obligations are guaranteed by the Government. The remaining $25 billion would be available from the Federal Reserve, which would lend from the pool of bank reserves it holds.
 
No Attempt to Hide
 A Treasury official who insisted on not being identified said the Administration had not been trying to hide the full amount requested for borrowing authority for working capital for the F.D.I.C. The official said the $45 billion had not been highlighted by the Administration in earlier summaries or discussions of the legislation this week because it does not significantly change the existing law since the F.D.I.C. already has the ability to borrow up to nine times its net worth.
 "If the fund is left with no equity, this will be needed to resolve problems at institutions," the official said. He added that using money from the $45 billion would be "fully collateralized" by assets from failed banks that could easily be sold.
 But critics said it was highly unusual to use a credit line as equity for the purposes of securing loans and that the whole point of pegging borrowing authority to net worth was to insure that the loans would be repaid. The move was viewed by critics as a contortion to avoid taxpayer financing of the bank insurance fund.
 "It's counterproductive for them to be leveraging their credit line," Mr. Riedy said. Professor Barth said he had never heard of the use of a credit line to serve as collateral for another loan.

HEADLINE: Envoy Denounces Soviet TV for Scapegoating U.S.

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MOSCOW, March 21

 BODY:
The United States Ambassador to Moscow today assailed the main Soviet evening television news program for reviving the old practice of blaming foreign interference and connivance for Soviet problems.
 The Ambassador, Jack F. Matlock Jr., took the program Vremya (Time) to task at a briefing for Soviet reporters, which was reported by the Interfax news agency. The sharpness and openness of the criticism was a departure from the Ambassador's usual background briefings for the press, and appeared to signal his readiness to challenge the revival of anti-American reporting on the evening news show. 
Mr. Matlock's specific target was a report on Vremya last Saturday in which the newsreader, Dmitri Biryukov, accused the A.F.L.-C.I.O. of interfering in internal Soviet affairs by declaring solidarity with striking Soviet coal miners, giving them financial assistance and inviting them to the United States.
 Mr. Matlock opened the briefing by playing a tape of the program. According the Interfax account, which was confirmed by the Embassy spokesman, the Ambassador said he was "staggered" by the presentation.
 He asked, "Is there not the slogan, 'Workers of the World, Unite' on Pravda's front page? Or does this slogan not imply help? Or perhaps Vremya commentators simply do not read Pravda?"
 Mr. Matlock said that American miners and trade unions did have contacts with their Soviet colleagues, and that representatives of independent Soviet miners' unions had been invited to the United States under the International Visitor Program, along with Soviet writers, actors, medical workers and staffers of the state television and radio company.
Mr. Biryukov also alleged that American diplomats were attending rallies of striking miners with unfriendly intentions. The Ambassador declared that there was nothing untoward in these actions: "We seek to understand what is taking place in the country and what processes are under way. We do everything openly."
 
New Television Director
 The Ambassador charged that over the past two months Vremya had resumed a xenophobic stance. He said that under Leonid P. Kravchenko, the new director of state television appointed by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev last November, Vremya had passed beyind editorial commentary to expressing the opinions of specific state structures.
 The transformation of state television under Mr. Kravchenko, and especially the undisguised use of Vremya as a vehicle for the Kremlin, have been one of the most visible aspects of Mr. Gorbachev's new politics, and a major target of the liberal opposition.
 Before Mr. Gorbachev introduced his "new thinking" in foreign policy five years ago, it was a mainstay of Soviet propaganda to imply that foreign plotters and secret services were always seeking to do harm to the Soviet Union. The insinuations served both to perpetuate a suspicion of foreigners in the population, and to create scapegoats for Moscow's own problems.
 Mr. Gorbachev's shift from liberal advisers to an alliance with conservative forces in recent months has included a revival of the practice. The President himself on a recent visit to Byelorussia insinuated that there was something suspicious in the fact that "democrats" were frequently invited to travel abroad, although he frequently travels in foreign countries himself.
 According to the report, the Ambassador also said that American economists doubted that the economic changes such as price increases now being put in practice by the Kremlin could have positive results. "We would like to maintain mutually beneficial economic relations with the Soviet Union, but we just do not know of any way to maintain them with the command and administrative system," Mr. Matlock was quoted as saying.
 But the Ambassador was also quoted as saying that American-Soviet relations were developing in the right direction, and that there could be no return to the cold war.
