HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
A Second U.S. Victory

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
Brace yourself, everybody: they are at it again.
 Some of the very experts who told Americans that Saddam Hussein would fight in the desert for months, maybe years, and would slaughter thousands of Americans, but that somehow this martial monster would crumble if we avoided war and just kept the embargo, that Muslims from Damascus to Detroit would rise up if Iraq were attacked, these same experts are again advising American readers, TV viewers and President Bush about what we ought to do, or not to do, about this same Saddam Hussein. 
This time they tell us in newspaper editorials and columns and on TV talk shows that we must rush out of Iraq right away lest we get stuck in Iraqi politics, that we should not do much more about eliminating Saddam Hussein than talk mean, but not very mean, that we must not help the rebels, that fostering democracy in Iraq is not our business, that we must not destroy the "centralizing" force in the country, which what do you know turns out to be the very same Baath Party through which Saddam Hussein slaughtered his countrymen for so long. And they tell us we must make sure that Iraq remains forever "unified."
 Would you believe it?
 All of a sudden it becomes our job to boycott the people who have risen against Saddam Hussein. It becomes our duty to make sure that Iraq, which was cobbled together after World War I by European foreign offices, remains inviolably one down the ages, something like a new Jerusalem.
 The new threat-word is "Lebanonization." We are supposed to be terrified of the idea that Iraq might split up. Remember "body bags"? Or how "the streets" -- meaning the Arab world -- were "resonating" with "resentment" against the coalition for "humiliating" Saddam Hussein?
Would any of these experts have said just before the fall of Berlin that the Nazi Party should be kept together as a centralizing force lest Germany break up? Or warned against trying to kill Hitler lest his sympathizers abroad be fearfully annoyed?
 Of course not. But then the Germans were Europeans while all we have in the Middle East is a bunch of Sunnis and Shiites and Kurds running around, who knows them, and anyway they will never understand democracy, what a thought.
 We do not have to jump into the trap of trying to manage Iraq's political life or keep troops there indefinitely.
 And with common sense we can avoid the danger of being lost in the great burning political desert of the Middle East. That is the hatred of Arab against Arab, Muslim against Muslim, created and cultivated by the same monarchies, dictatorships and religious stake-tenders who fire Arab hatred of Jews and foreigners.
 Our responsibilities are three, all within our capabilities. First is to give the Iraqi rebels a chance to get at Saddam Hussein before he massacres them with the heavy weapons he still commands -- get at him, overturn him and, praise the thought, kill him.
 Denying Saddam Hussein full use of those weapons by air attack is militarily feasible and morally inescapable. Thousands of Iraqi civilians died in the war caused by his aggression. Now we should not permit him to use his remaining armed power to exact a further price against his own people. Most of those weapons were sold to him by Western and Communist nations, the money courtesy of our present Arab allies.
 Mr. Bush has ordered Iraqi planes and helicopter gunships grounded. For this he deserves the appreciation of the world. Now Saddam Hussein should be ordered not to use his artillery and tanks to crush the rebels. Perhaps that would encourage his generals to gather close around him, revolvers finally in hand.
 The second responsibility is to tell the Iranians and Syrians not to set their Iraqi puppets in power. We and our Arab allies could use persuasion: denial of economic and military aid. It won't work completely but it might slow them down while the U.S. meets its third responsibility.
 The President should state precisely what it is he wishes for Iraq: the end of dictatorship of any kind. American representatives should seek out Iraqis, Arab or Kurd, who believe their countrymen deserve better than more tyranny and are capable of carrying out something entirely new for the Muslim Middle East: a decent election.
 By then, American troops would be gone from Iraq. But Iraq's political liberation would be their second victory in the desert, and one day it will be counted the greater.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
House Speaker Opposes Bill Withholding $55 Million From Jordan

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Thomas S. Foley, Speaker of the House, today supported President Bush's opposition to a measure passed by the Senate that would rescind $55 million in military and economic aid to Jordan, as House and Senate negotiators began debating the issue.
 "I hope the President can be given greater latitude," said Mr. Foley, a Washington Democrat. 
The Speaker said he found it "understandable that Americans felt a sense of resentment and anger" at Jordan's support of President Saddam Hussein during the Persian Gulf war.
 "But it serves no purpose that I can imagine for there to be any destabilization of the Government of Jordan, and so I hope that the President's wish will be respected," Mr. Foley said.
 Late tonight, House and Senate negotiators agreed to ease the restriction on aid to Jordan, The Associate Press reported. The legislators agreed that President Bush could restore the aid if he found that King Hussein was helping advance the Middle East peace process, The A.P. said.
 
Threat of White House Veto
 The White House has threatened to veto the bill unless the restriction is lifted. Under the Senate measure, the money would be restored if the President certified to Congress that Jordan had taken steps to advance the peace process in the Middle East. The measure would not affect humanitarian aid, nor $246 million already in the pipeline in the form of pending contracts.
 Mr. Foley also supported the President's opposition to a Senate measure that would bar money for military sales to nations that had not fulfilled financial aid pledges for the war. That restriction is contained in a $15 billion appropriations bill that the Speaker expected to clear Congress on Friday.
 The White House announced today that Japan would make a $5.7 billion contribution to the allied war effort on Friday, as an initial installment on its $9 billion pledge for 1991.
 
$42.6 Billion Gulf War
 Senators expressed special resentment over the payment delays by Arab nations.
 Saudi Arabia has paid only $6.1 billion on pledges of $16.8 billion, Kuwait has paid only $5.5 billion on pledges of $16 billion and the United Arab Emirates had paid only half of the $4 billion they had pledged.
 The Administration has put the price tag of the desert operation at $42.6 billion, and the amount is growing daily. Allies have pledged $54.5 billion, but paid only $25.6 billion.
 The House and Senate meanwhile approved a compromise agreement on a bill to authorize $15 billion for the gulf war as a last resort, if there were insufficient funds from America's allies. The bill included expanded medical, educational and health benefits for veterans and their families. The Senate approved the bill by voice vote, while the House approved the bill by a vote of 396 to 4.

HEADLINE: AFTER THE WAR;
U.N. SURVEY CALLS IRAQ'S WAR DAMAGE NEAR-APOCALYPTIC

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 21

 BODY:
A United Nations survey of civilian damage caused by the allied bombardment of Iraq calls the results "near apocalyptic." The survey, which was made public today, recommends an immediate end to the embargo on imports of food and other essential supplies to prevent "imminent catastrophe."
 The report, prepared by a United Nations team that visited the country between March 10 and March 17, says the bombing has relegated Iraq "to a pre-industrial age" and warns that the nation could face "epidemic and famine if massive life-supporting needs are not rapidly met." 
It calls for "a major mobilization and movement of resources" to provide immediate substantial supplies of food, agricultural equipment, fuel, electrical generators and machinery for water purification, garbage disposal and sewage treatment.
 
U.S. Position on Sanctions
 The report was prepared by Under Secretary General Martti Ahtisaari, who was sent by Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar. He was accompanied by representatives of Unicef, the United Nations Development Program, the High Commissioner for Refugees, the World Health Organization and the Food and Agriculture Organization. Mr. Ahtisaari, a Finn, earned praise in 1989 for his handling of Namibia's move to independence.
 A White House spokesman said the Administration would "give the report careful study," but declined to comment on its findings.
 The report seemed to be at odds with allied military officials' insistence that the damage in Iraq was largely confined to military sites and transportation links. But allied briefers acknowledged that they had destroyed power plants and oil refineries, and the United Nations report stresses that the lack of electricity and fuel is paralyzing hospitals, water purification and sewage treatment plants and irrigation projects.
 It says the monthly allocation of food staples to the population fell from 343,000 tons last September to 135,000 tons in January.
 
Most Workers Are Idle
 The report says 90 percent of Iraq's industrial workers "have been reduced to inactivity and will be deprived of income as of the end of March." Most families already "lack access to adequate rations or the purchasing power to meet normal minimal standards."
 The report says that until Iraq acquires fuel and electrical generating equipment, "food that is imported cannot be distributed; water cannot be purified; sewage cannot be pumped away and cleansed; crops cannot be irrigated; medicines cannot be conveyed where they are required; needs cannot even be effectively assessed."
 Diplomats say the report's findings are likely to bring pressure for a substantial relaxation in the trade sanctions against Iraq when the special committee monitoring compliance with the restrictions meets on Friday.
 The United States has said sanctions should be lifted only when Baghdad fulfills all the allies' conditions for a permanent cease-fire. The special committee can grant a waiver on food and shipments of humanitarian aid, but the entire embargo may be lifted only by a Security Council resolution.
 Ever since the trade embargo was imposed on Aug. 6, after the invasion of Kuwait, the United States has argued against any premature relaxation in the belief that by making life uncomfortable for the Iraqi people it will eventually encourage them to remove President Saddam Hussein from power.
 
Complex New Resolution
 An American draft of a proposed resolution on a permanent cease-fire that has been circulating here indicates that the Bush Administration wants the Security Council to lift only the ban on food shipments after adopting the complex new resolution.
 Under the American draft, even after a permanent cease-fire is set, Council permission would still be needed for imports of "materials and supplies for essential civilian needs," though the Council would examine this requirement every 60 days in the light of Baghdad's compliance and could eventually lift it.
 As expected, the American draft also requires Iraq to agree to the destruction of its ballistic missile systems as well as chemical, biological or nuclear weapons.
 
1963 Frontier Cited
 Only when Iraq formally agrees to all provisions of the draft, which is still under discussion, would a cease-fire become effective.
 The United States draft says Iraq must accept the boundary agreement it made with Kuwait in 1963 but subsequently rejected. And it empowers the Security Council to guarantee that frontier with "all necessary means," a phrase that would permit the use of military force against any violator.
In addition, it calls for deployment of a United Nations military observer force along the frontier to monitor possible cease-fire violations and establishes a special fund to pay compensation for damage caused by Iraq's annexation of Kuwait.
 The draft maintains a complete ban on sales of military equipment to Iraq as well as dangerous technologies used in making chemical, biological or nuclear weapons and sets out a four-month timetable for Iraq to comply with all these provisions.
 The original sanctions banned all trade and financial dealings with Iraq and occupied Kuwait, except for the provision of medicine. Food was allowed when the committee judged that humanitarian circumstances required it.
 This month the committee agreed to speed approval of shipments of food and humanitarian aid, but the call for lifting the restrictions appears to go further than the United States envisages at present.
 
At Odds With U.S. Position
 Assessing the effects of allied bombing and the trade embargo on Iraq's economy, the report says "the recent conflict has wrought near-apocalyptic results upon the infrastructure of what had been until January 1991 a rather highly urbanized and mechanized society."
 The report says that about 9,000 Iraqi homes were destroyed or damaged beyond repair during the war, including 2,500 in Baghdad and another 1,900 in Basra, and that about 72,000 people have been left homeless.
 It says "most means of modern life support have been destroyed or rendered tenuous" and warns that "for some time to come" the country has been "relegated to a pre-industrial age but with all the disabilities of post-industrial dependency on an intensive use of energy and technology."
 After surveying the food shortage and warning that this year's harvest may fail, the report recommends that "sanctions in respect of food supplies should be immediately removed, as should those relating to the import agricultural equipment and supplies."
 The report concludes: "It is unmistakable that the Iraqi people may soon face a further imminent catastrophe, which could include epidemic and famine, if massive life-supporting needs are not rapidly met. The long summer, with its often 45 or even 50 degree temperatures (113-122 degrees Fahrenheit) is only weeks away. Time is short."

HEADLINE: California Rains Make Hard Decisions Harder

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, March 21

 BODY:
Three weeks of torrential storms from one end of California to the other have eased the state's water crisis but could be a mixed blessing.
 Predictions of economic calamity in the nation's largest state have been scaled back and some communities are abandoning water rationing. But experts are concerned that the will to overhaul inefficent water policies will fade with the sense of emergency. 
From the point of view of water policy and planning it's a disaster," said Representative George Miller, a California Democrat who is vice chairman of a Congressional committee that deals with water issues. "It allows people to avoid the difficult questions."
 
Snow, Mud and Green Hillsides
 As he spoke, the latest in a series of fierce Alaskan weather systems brought avalanches to the Sierra Nevada, which had been bare of snow most of the winter, and flash floods and mudslides to the Central Coast near Santa Barbara, the most drought-stricken region in a state, which last received normal percipitation in 1986. Hillsides parched blond are lush and green, streams are running high and smaller reservoirs are filled to overflowing.
 In the Central Valley, where dry irrigation systems forced farmers to idle acreage, highways were closed by blowing snow and fields were ankle-deep in slush. Here in San Francisco, wind and rain pummeled cars on the bridges that span the frothy bay and pedestrians were battered with sheets of sleet and hail. There were downed power lines in Los Angeles and reports of tornadoes in San Bernardino County and funnel clouds in San Diego, where rain and severe turbulence may have contributed to a fatal crash of two Navy aircraft today.
 Last month, when the drought was most severe, political leaders seemed poised for major policy changes. Among the issues under discussion were water pricing and distribution, which are wildly uneven from district to district and farm to farm, and water marketing, in which the state can buy water from farmers at rates higher than those they pay and then sell it to strapped water districts.
 Also under discussion, as never before, were environmental issues related to the drought and strategies for conservation that do not penalize those who have already been saving water.
 The leading environmental issue is danger to Chinook salmon, which need more fresh water for spawning than is now available in the dammed Sacramento River.
 The conservation conundrum revolves around many of the rationing plans, which force household cuts of a certain percentage, regardless of how much they used in the past.
 These issues, and others, are troublesome for politicians because any redistribution takes something away from somebody, potentially costing votes. "When you allocate water, you apportion pain," said Representative Miller, vice chairman of the House Committee on Interior and Insular Affairs. "And political people prefer to put that off as long as they can."
 
A Lot of Rain Is Not Enough
 When the reservoirs were bone dry, the motivation was high for tackling these issues, but now the sense of urgency may be ebbing. "Institutions are so hidebound and attitudes so entrenched that things may have to get desperate first," said Marc Reisner, the author of "Cadillac Desert: The American West and Its Disappearing Water" (Penguin, 1986).
 The recent cavalcade of storms, one every other day or so, began on Feb. 28, when high pressure off the Pacific Coast moved aside and opened a weather pathway that had been shut for the better part of five years.
 But the rain pounding the windows and streaming from roof gutters does not tell the whole story. Statewide precipitation so far this year is 50 percent of normal, the system of 1,200 reservoirs is at half of normal and the snowpack, the primary source of spring runoff, is at 52 percent.
 "It's just not enough to make a complete difference," said Sandra Salazar of the state Drought Center in Sacramento. "We'll probably see some of the hardship lessening in specific parts of the state, but overall we're still going to have a critically dry year."
 With every new storm, Federal, state and local water officials face increased pressure to deliver more water rather than hold it in reserve.
 In each of the last four dry years, both the Federal and state water systems assumed the rains would come and maintained nearly normal deliveries, a practice that critics say led to the current crisis. But so far the huge government systems are not planning to release more water to customers, although the managers say they may reconsider on April 1, when the moisture content of the Sierra snowpack is next measured.
Farmers do not expect either system to release additional water, but they hope for relief in other ways. If the situation improves in urban and suburban areas, several growers in Fresno and Kern Counties said, extra water might be available through the "water bank," a marketing apparatus introduced last month by Governor Pete Wilson, which so far has signed contracts to buy more than 300,000 acre feet of water.
 An acre foot is 326,000 gallons, about enough to irrigate a third of an acre of farm land for a year or supply water to two typical households for a year.
 
Watering the Natural Way
 In a more immediate sense, growers say, the rain has provided some natural irrigation for the permanent crops like nut and fruit trees that were facing death. The rain in Fresno County, for instance, has been the equivalent of 24 hours of irrigation, said Ron Khachigian, vice president of an 11,000-acre orchard near Lost Hills in the San Joaquin Valley. Nut and fruit growers need about 13 such 24-hour irrigating days in a growing season, Mr. Khachigian said.
 With the rain, local water districts in urban and suburban areas have made sharply contrasting decisions.
 At one extreme is the Napa Valley town of St. Helena, which on March 12 lifted a rationing plan because its tiny reservoir, down to a 125-day supply last month, had filled to the brim. On the other hand, the Purissima Hills Water District in the Silicon Valley a day later imposed 75 percent rationing in the affluent community of Los Altos Hills.
 Elsewhere in the state, Los Angeles has postponed a stricter rationing plan. San Francisco, which canceled rationing after heavy March rains in 1989, has not budged this time.
 The confusion is nowhere more apparant than in Marin County, which this month imposed one of the state's most rigorous rationing plans: 50 gallons a day for each person, along with higher rates and harsh penalties for exceeding allotments. In the weeks since the plan was approved, more than 15 inches of rain have fallen in the county, bringing the seven reservoirs, which supply 90 percent of the district's water, to 48 percent of capacity, up from 31 percent.
 The board of directors of the Marin County Water District plans to review the situation in April. But for now tight rationing continues and long-suffering county residents, who coined the motto "save water -- shower with a friend" in the 1976-77 drought, are bragging about new ultra-low-flush toilets and conservationist tooth brushing.
The paradox was evident last month when the water district began distributing free conservation devises to its 170,000 customers. In a driving rain, residents in foul-weather gear lined up at a table in a parking lot for low-flow shower heads, toilet displacement bags and faucet restrictors.

HEADLINE: Fed Is Urged to Cut Rates

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The Joint Economic Committee of Congress urged the Federal Reserve Board today to lower interest rates as "insurance" against a long recession.
 The recommendation, carried in the committee's annual report, added the voice of the Democratic majority to that of the Bush Administration, which has urged the Fed to ease rates. 
Congressional Republicans on the committee, however, stopped short of joining the call for lower rates.
 "I frankly don't often presume to tell the chairman of the Federal Reserve what his monetary policy options should be," said Representative Richard Armey of Texas, the ranking Republican on the committee.
 But asked whether the Fed should ease credit, Mr. Armey said, "If the chairman chooses that option, I would applaud him for doing so."
 Committee chairman Senator Paul Sarbanes, a Maryland Democrat, said the nation should act to buy an "insurance policy" of measures to ward off a longer or deeper recession.

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC SCENE;
New Concerns Over U.S. Science

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
IN November 1944, with the end of World War II in sight, President Franklin D. Roosevelt wrote to Vannevar Bush, the distinguished engineer who headed the Office of Scientific Research and Development, to ask his advice on four fundamental questions:
 *What could be done, consistent with military security, to make known to the world, as soon as possible, the contributions made during the war effort to science and technology? "The diffusion of such knowledge," Roosevelt said, "should help us stimulate new enterprises, provide jobs for our returning servicemen and other workers, and make possible great strides for the improvement of the national well-being." 
What could be done to organize a program for continuing the research, spurred by the war, in medicine and related sciences?
 *What could the Government do to aid research activities by public and private organizations and deal with the interrelation between them?
 *Could an effective program be proposed for discovering and developing scientific talent in American youth, to assure the future of scientific research in this country?
 Dr. Bush's response set forth the blueprint for America's postwar investment in research and education, and led to the establishment of the National Science Foundation.
 This week, a group of leading scientists, assembled by the Carnegie Institution of Washington to honor Dr. Bush's memory, found that the four questions were still alive -- but in urgent need of fresh answers.
 Despite progress in many scientific areas, the United States has been falling behind in its industrial and economic development, with unwanted feedbacks on science itself. Some scientists at the Bush Symposium argued that a revival of manufacturing here was essential to the future of American science and technology.
 "It is not just lack of vision or pig-headedness that causes American manufacturing industries to resist introducing new materials or advanced processes," said James S. Langer of the Institute for Theoretical Physics of the University of California. "The cost of introducing new technologies in this country is enormous; capital is expensive; licensing can be risky and time-consuming, and if the product is really novel, the materials manufacturer is exposed to a variety of legal hazards."
 The problem of lagging American investment in materials, equipment and research also has macroeconomic roots: the low national savings rate and chronic Federal budget deficits curb capital formation for many individual concerns and for the nation as a whole, and permit competitors in other countries to take the lead. But can the American response be focused not primarily on manufacturing but on services ranging from medical care to education to computing and telecommunications to arts and entertainment, which are the wave of the future?
 The wide diffusion of scientific and technological knowledge that Roosevelt called for has been increasingly inhibited by the fierce competition among corporations and research groups. "Traditionally, science has been an open subject," said Sir John Kendrew, a Nobel laureate in biology at Cambridge University. "But now there is a change, even within national communities of scientists, and in particular of biologists. Nowadays they don't talk to one another so freely, because each feels that his research may be important industrially -- in other words, that there may be money in it, and specifically money in it for him or her."
The change in science toward secrecy has been gathering momentum, both in Europe and the United States, and, Sir John added, there has been a concomitant increase in the number of cases of scientific fraud and disputes about priorities that are settled only in the courts. "In my opinion," Sir John told the symposium, "this is no coincidence; rather, I believe there is a causal relationship between the two phenomena."
 "For whatever reasons," Professor Langer said, "there is a real crisis of confidence throughout all of U.S. science these days, and this crisis is particularly acute for the young men and women who should be devoting their energies" to innovative and interdisciplinary research. He called for "a less adversarial" National Science Foundation to control the competitive pressures and restore more sense of inquiry and adventure to scientific research.
 The relationship among industry, government and science -- and between research and economic growth -- is extremely complex. Big spending on research has led to rapid development of many fields -- and to big profits for some organizations. But the quest for profits and grants may hurt science itself, and thereby choke off economic growth. A new Vannevar Bush report is needed.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Lower in Hectic Day As Central Banks Stem Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Action by the world's leading central banks slowed the dollar's strength yesterday, generating a steady decline that was interrupted briefly by a rumor that Germany's embattled monetary chief might resign.
 Gold mostly slipped, with the price for current delivery unchanged from late on Wednesday on the Commodity Exchange in New York at $363. The Republic National Bank of New York later quoted a bid of $361.80 an ounce, down 40 cents. 
Currency traders said at least eight European central banks sold $500 million to $1 billion in dollars to stem the currency's advance.
 The dollar has risen by about 14 percent since the end of the Persian Gulf war on confidence in the American economy's potential to rebound. That has raised fears that the dollar's rise could ultimately have a negative effect on the economy.
 Besides the concerted intervention, the dollar was hurt by a report that unemployment claims for the week that ended on March 9, the first week after the war, rose to their highest level in eight years.
 Hillel Waxman, the vice president of foreign exchange at Bank Leumi Trust Company in New York, said the jobs report temporarily stole some of the postwar euphoria that buoyed the dollar in the last month.
 He said, however, that he did not think the report alone was enough to persuade the Federal Reserve to move to lower interest rates, a step that could stimulate the economy but also erode the dollar's value.
 The dollar was bumped briefly higher in the morning by rumors, later proved untrue, that Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the Bundesbank, Germany's central bank, might resign. He has come under fire from German officials after remarking earlier this week that the country's economic reunion was a failure.
 "It was just a rumor, but it was good enough to move the dollar up to the high levels of the day," said Lorenzo Troni, the vice president of foreign exchange at Paine Webber International Inc., also in New York
 Against the German currency, the dollar fell to 1.6315 marks, from 1.6425 marks on Wednesday.
 The financial markets were closed yesterday in Japan for a national holiday. In London, the dollar closed at 137.55 yen, lower than its close of 138.30 yen on Wednesday in Tokyo. In trading in New York, the dollar closed at 136.73 yen, down from late Wednesday's 138.30 yen.
 In London, the British pound rose to $1.7930, from $1.7770 late on Wednesday. The pound also rose in New York, fetching $1.7995 by the end of the day, more than late Wednesday's $1.7855.
 Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those of late on Wednesday, included: 1.4055 Swiss francs, down from 1.4150; 5.5555 French francs, down from 5.5950; 1,215.50 Italian lire, down from 1,223.00.
